Title: Maryland Paint Stewardship
Synopsis: Requiring producers of architectural paint or a representative organization to submit a plan for the establishment of a Paint Stewardship Program to the Department of the Environment by July 1, 2025, and in accordance with certain requirements; requiring the Department to review and approve certain plans, including a certain assessment; prohibiting the sale of certain architectural paint beginning January 1, 2026 unless an approved Paint Stewardship Program has been implemented by certain producers; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Paint Stewardship Program, requiring architectural paint producers or their representative organizations to submit a plan to the Department of the Environment by July 1, 2025. The plan must detail how postconsumer paint will be collected, transported, reused, recycled, and disposed of statewide, minimizing public sector involvement and financial responsibility. It also requires the establishment of a Paint Stewardship Assessment on architectural paint sold in the State to cover program costs. Beginning January 1, 2026, or 6 months after plan approval, producers and retailers must add this assessment to the cost of paint, and producers must participate in an approved program to sell paint in the State. The Department of the Environment's Office of Recycling is responsible for reviewing and approving these plans and annual reports. The bill also mandates a review of the program's costs and benefits by December 1, 2028.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment, Office of Recycling
stakeholders: Producers of architectural paint, retailers, distributors, consumers of architectural paint in Maryland, and the general public benefiting from improved waste management.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes an Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) model, shifting the financial and operational responsibility for managing postconsumer architectural paint from local governments and taxpayers to the paint producers themselves. This approach aims to incentivize producers to design more sustainable products and manage their products' end-of-life, which is an innovative approach to waste management and resource recovery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on environmental management through paint recycling and stewardship. While improved environmental health can indirectly benefit all communities, including those with child poverty, it does not directly address socioeconomic factors contributing to child poverty such as income, housing, food security, or education.

Title: Property Taxes - Authority of Counties to Establish a Subclass and Set a Special Rate for Vacant and Abandoned Property
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county to establish, by law, a subclass of real property consisting of vacant lots or improved property cited as vacant and unfit for habitation or other authorized use on a certain violation notice and to set a special property tax rate for certain vacant and abandoned property; requiring the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county that enacts a special tax rate to submit a certain report by December 1 each year; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county to establish a special subclass of real property for vacant and abandoned properties and to set a special property tax rate for these properties. It also requires these local jurisdictions to report annually to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the General Assembly on the special rate, the number of properties affected, revenue changes, use of revenue, and plans for adaptive reuse of these properties.
responsible_party: Local governing bodies (Baltimore City and counties) with reporting to the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Property owners of vacant and abandoned properties, local governments, residents and communities impacted by vacant properties, and the Department of Housing and Community Development.
innovative_summary: The bill provides a new regulatory tool to local governments by allowing them to create a specific property tax subclass and rate for vacant and abandoned properties. This approach is an innovative use of existing tax structures to address urban blight and encourage redevelopment, rather than implementing new technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has an indirect potential to impact child poverty by incentivizing the redevelopment of vacant and abandoned properties. This could lead to revitalized communities, improved local services (if tax revenue is used for such), and potentially safer environments, which could benefit children living in poverty within those areas. However, it does not directly provide aid or services to children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Institutions of Higher Education - Admissions Standards - Prohibition on Consideration of Legacy Preference or Donor Preference
Synopsis: Prohibiting institutions of higher education that receive State funds from considering a legacy preference or donor preference as an eligible criterion for admissions standards at the institution; and allowing an institution of higher education to ask applicants for information regarding familial relationships to alums of the institution for data collection purposes.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits institutions of higher education in Maryland that receive State funds from considering a legacy preference (familial relationship to an alum) or a donor preference (familial relationship to a financial supporter) as an eligible criterion for admissions. Institutions may still ask for this information for data collection purposes.
responsible_party: Institutions of Higher Education in Maryland receiving State funds
stakeholders: Applicants to institutions of higher education, and institutions of higher education in Maryland receiving State funds.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a regulatory change to admissions standards, prohibiting legacy and donor preferences. While it aims to foster greater equity in higher education, it is a policy adjustment to existing processes rather than an implementation of new technologies or fundamentally new government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By removing legacy and donor preferences from college admissions, this bill aims to create a more equitable admissions process. This could indirectly benefit students from lower-income backgrounds, including those from families experiencing poverty, by reducing barriers to entry that disproportionately affect those without familial or financial connections to institutions. While it doesn't provide direct financial aid or services, it enhances opportunities for qualified students who might otherwise be overlooked.

Title: Criminal Law - Indecent Exposure Within the Presence of a Minor
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from committing the common law crime of indecent exposure; prohibiting a person from, with prurient intent, committing the common law crime of indecent exposure when the person knows or reasonably should know that a minor is present and the minor is at least 2 years old and is more than 4 years younger than the person; and establishing a penalty of 5 years of imprisonment or a fine of up to $10,000 or both on conviction for a crime of indecent exposure in the presence of a minor.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's criminal law regarding indecent exposure. It explicitly prohibits the common law crime of indecent exposure and establishes a new, more severe offense for committing indecent exposure with prurient intent when the person knows or reasonably should know that a minor is present, provided the minor is at least 2 years old and more than 4 years younger than the person. Penalties are increased for this offense involving minors, from up to 3 years imprisonment and/or a $1,000 fine to up to 5 years imprisonment and/or a $10,000 fine.
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies and the Judiciary
stakeholders: Individuals who commit or are accused of indecent exposure, and minors who may be present during such acts.
innovative_summary: This bill is a standard legislative update to criminal law, clarifying and strengthening existing statutes related to indecent exposure, especially in the presence of minors. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches to public services or administration.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses criminal penalties for indecent exposure and does not directly establish programs or initiatives aimed at alleviating child poverty through economic support, education, health, or social services. Its potential impact on child poverty is indirect at best, by aiming to create a safer environment for children.

Title: Housing Innovation Pilot Program and Housing Innovation Fund - Establishment (Housing Innovation Pilot Program Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Housing Innovation Fund to provide loans for local housing authorities and county governments to develop mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing; establishing the Housing Innovation Pilot Program in the Department of Housing and Community Development to assist public housing authorities and county governments in increasing housing production and to reward counties pursuing solutions to the problem of housing scarcity; authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation of $5,000,000 to the Fund in certain fiscal years; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Housing Innovation Pilot Program and the Housing Innovation Fund within the Department of Housing and Community Development. The program provides low- or no-interest loans to local housing authorities and county governments, partnering with housing developers, to create mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing. Projects must reserve a percentage of units for households with gross annual incomes at or below 50% or 60% of the area median income, maintain affordability for at least 99 years, and may involve public ownership and prevailing wage requirements. Local housing authorities are required to provide a dollar-for-dollar match for program funds.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Local housing authorities, county governments, housing developers, and low- to moderate-income households seeking affordable housing in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program is explicitly named an "Innovation Pilot Program" and aims to reward counties pursuing "innovative solutions to the problem of housing scarcity." It promotes a mixed-income, cross-subsidized housing model and prioritizes projects that do not rely on traditional Low-Income Housing Tax Credits, suggesting an innovative financing approach. The emphasis on public ownership and a 99-year affordability restriction for units also represents a new, long-term approach to housing stability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty by increasing the supply of deeply affordable and stable housing. By mandating that 20% of units are for households at or below 50% of the Area Median Income (AMI) or 40% at or below 60% AMI, and ensuring affordability for 99 years, it directly addresses housing insecurity and cost burdens, which are major drivers of child poverty. Stable, affordable housing can free up family resources for other necessities like food, healthcare, and education, improving overall child well-being.

Title: Residential Property - Affordable Housing Land Trusts - Authority to Establish Condominium Regimes
Synopsis: Authorizing a condominium regime to be established on certain land owned by an affordable housing land trust.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's real property law to authorize affordable housing land trusts to establish condominium regimes on properties they own, specifically allowing a leasehold estate to be subjected to a condominium regime for residential purposes if an affordable housing land trust owns the reversionary fee simple estate. This change expands the entities that can create such residential condominium arrangements.
responsible_party: Maryland land records offices and affordable housing land trusts
stakeholders: Affordable housing land trusts, developers and residents of affordable housing, and individuals seeking affordable residential properties.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative update to real property law, clarifying and expanding the authority of certain entities (affordable housing land trusts) to establish condominium regimes. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to impact child poverty is indirect. By facilitating the creation and management of more affordable housing options through land trusts, it can contribute to housing stability for low-income families. Stable housing is a key factor in reducing child poverty, but this bill does not offer direct financial aid or specific poverty reduction programs.

Title: Tax Sales - Homeowner Protection Program - Funding
Synopsis: Requiring each collector of property taxes to include with each property tax bill a separate insert that describes the Homeowner Protection Program and encourages taxpayers to make a voluntary donation to the Program through a website maintained by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
bill_summary: This bill enhances funding for the existing Homeowner Protection Program. It requires local property tax collectors to include an insert with each tax bill, designed by the State Tax Sale Ombudsman, to encourage voluntary donations to the Program via a website maintained by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation. Additionally, it mandates a $15 fee for each certificate of sale issued to a purchaser at a tax sale, with this fee being credited to the Homeowner Protection Fund. The bill also reiterates the Governor's requirement to include an annual appropriation of $750,000 to the Fund for fiscal years 2023, 2024, and 2025.
responsible_party: State Tax Sale Ombudsman, State Department of Assessments and Taxation, and local collectors of property taxes. The Governor is responsible for including appropriations in the budget bill.
stakeholders: Low-income, elderly, and disabled homeowners at risk of losing their homes to tax sale foreclosure, as well as taxpayers who may make voluntary donations or pay the tax sale certificate fee.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces new approaches to funding a state program by establishing a state-maintained website for voluntary electronic donations and leveraging property tax bill inserts as a direct communication channel to solicit funds from the public. It also adds a new fee on tax sale purchasers dedicated to the fund.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The Homeowner Protection Program aims to prevent low-income homeowners from losing their homes to tax sale foreclosure. By ensuring housing stability for these families, the program directly mitigates a significant factor contributing to child poverty, such as homelessness or displacement, and provides a stable environment for children.

Title: Charter Counties - Comprehensive Plans - Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing
Synopsis: Altering requirements for the housing element of a charter county's comprehensive plan to include requirements related to affirmatively furthering fair housing; requiring the housing element of a comprehensive plan that is enacted or amended on or after January 1, 2025, to include an assessment of fair housing to ensure that the county is affirmatively furthering fair housing; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the requirements for the housing element of a charter county's comprehensive plan. It mandates that these plans, when enacted or amended on or after January 1, 2025, include an assessment to ensure the county is affirmatively furthering fair housing, which means promoting policies that overcome patterns of segregation and foster inclusive communities. It also requires charter counties to incorporate existing Assessments of Fair Housing or analyses of impediments to fair housing into their comprehensive plans when amended on or after January 1, 2024. The Department of Planning, in consultation with the Department of Housing and Community Development, will provide technical assistance to counties for developing these housing elements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Planning; Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Charter counties, residents of charter counties, particularly those in need of affordable or low-income housing, and populations impacted by fair housing issues.
innovative_summary: The bill applies existing federal fair housing concepts to state and local planning requirements, mandating that charter counties integrate 'affirmatively furthering fair housing' into their comprehensive plans. While it expands existing planning duties, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather extends an established policy framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By mandating that charter counties proactively address fair housing and the need for affordable and low-income housing in their comprehensive plans, this bill has the potential to indirectly impact child poverty. Improved access to stable, affordable, and desegregated housing can lead to better educational outcomes, health, and economic stability for families, which are key factors in reducing child poverty. However, the impact is indirect, relying on the implementation of planning policies.

Title: Natural Resources - Northern Snakehead - Common Name
Synopsis: Establishing the common name of the northern snakehead as the "Chesapeake Channa".
bill_summary: This bill renames the common name of the northern snakehead fish to "Chesapeake Channa" in Maryland. It mandates the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to adopt regulations and update all applicable published materials to reflect this new name by January 1, 2025. It also amends sections of the Natural Resources Article related to commercial northern snakehead licenses and archery fishing for the species, incorporating the new common name.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Commercial fishers holding northern snakehead licenses, recreational fishers targeting northern snakehead, and the general public who interact with DNR materials or are interested in aquatic species nomenclature in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative, as its primary purpose is to change the common name of a fish species and update corresponding administrative documents and regulations. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. Its scope is limited to a change in the common name of a fish species and subsequent administrative updates, without any provisions related to economic support, social services, or educational opportunities for children or families.

Title: Agriculture - Pollinator Habitat Plan - Requirements for State Highway Administration
Synopsis: Requiring the State Highway Administration's pollinator habitat plan to include policies and procedures regarding the use of pollinator habitat areas along State highways; requiring the Administration to track and evaluate federal programs that provide funding for pollinator habitats, native plants, and invasive species control and to apply for any funding that the Administration determines appropriate and beneficial to pollinator habitats; requiring the Administration to update the plan by October 1 each year; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates the State Highway Administration's (SHA) pollinator habitat plan. It requires the SHA to include specific policies and procedures for encouraging pollinator-friendly native plants, developing and maintaining pollinator habitats along State highways (while adhering to safety standards), and educating the public about these areas. The SHA must also track and evaluate federal programs providing funding for pollinator habitats, native plants, and invasive species control, and apply for appropriate funding. The SHA's updated plan, including current policies and a list of habitat locations and sizes, must be published on its website annually, starting by October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: State Highway Administration
stakeholders: Pollinators, the environment, drivers, bicyclists, pedestrians, and the general public in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on updating existing plans and procedures, incorporating best practices for pollinator habitats, and seeking federal funding. While beneficial for the environment, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on environmental protection and habitat preservation for pollinators. There is no direct mechanism or intent within the bill to address or impact child poverty.

Title: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange - Qualified Health Plans - Dental Coverage
Synopsis: Repealing a certain provision of law providing that a qualified health plan is not required under certain circumstances to provide essential benefits that duplicate the minimum benefits of qualified dental plans; and repealing the authority of the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to require children enrolling in a qualified health plan to have essential pediatric dental benefits required by the federal Secretary of Health and Human Services.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland law regarding qualified health plans certified by the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange. It repeals provisions that allowed qualified health plans to exclude essential benefits that duplicated minimum benefits of qualified dental plans under certain circumstances. Additionally, it removes the authority of the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to require children enrolling in a qualified health plan to have essential pediatric dental benefits separately. The effect is to ensure that essential pediatric dental benefits are included as part of qualified health plans, rather than being optional or requiring a separate dental plan purchase.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
stakeholders: Qualified individuals and employers purchasing health plans through the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange, children requiring pediatric dental benefits, and health insurance carriers offering qualified health plans in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative in terms of employing new technologies or new approaches to government. It refines existing health insurance regulations to standardize coverage requirements.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By mandating the inclusion of essential pediatric dental benefits within qualified health plans, this bill simplifies access to crucial dental care for children. This removes a potential financial and administrative barrier for low-income families who might have otherwise struggled to afford or navigate separate dental plans, thus directly improving health equity and reducing out-of-pocket burdens for families, which can indirectly impact child poverty.

Title: Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the type of financial assistance that may be provided by eligible fund managers who receive grants from the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account in the Department of Commerce to allow grants of up to $10,000 in conjunction with a loan.
bill_summary: This bill amends the types of financial assistance available through the Small, Minority, and Women–Owned Businesses Account, managed by the Maryland Department of Commerce. It expands the definition of assistance from solely "investment capital and loans" to "financial assistance," which now includes direct grants. Grants are limited to $10,000 when issued in conjunction with a loan, but larger grants (up to $50,000 per business or nonprofit, with an annual aggregate limit of $10,000,000) are permissible for businesses in federal disaster areas or areas with officially declared emergencies (including Anne Arundel County and the City of Annapolis). The bill also allows for the conversion of existing loans to grants in these emergency situations and clarifies provisions for businesses in the clean energy industry, while maintaining reporting and audit requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Small, minority, women–owned businesses; veteran–owned businesses (especially in the clean energy industry); nonprofit organizations in specific emergency areas; and eligible fund managers.
innovative_summary: The program enhances the flexibility of an existing financial assistance account by explicitly allowing grants, in addition to loans, particularly for businesses impacted by disasters or emergencies. This adaptation makes the assistance more responsive to immediate needs but doesn't introduce fundamentally new technologies or approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to support the stability and growth of small, minority, women-owned, and veteran-owned businesses, which can indirectly contribute to job creation and economic stability. While this may lead to increased household incomes and potentially reduce child poverty for families connected to these businesses, the program does not directly target families experiencing child poverty or provide services directly to children.

Title: Health Insurance – Conformity With Federal Law
Synopsis: Conforming provisions of State health insurance law with existing federal requirements, including updating effective dates for federal regulations, clarifying federal consumer protection regulations resulting from changes to the federal No Surprises Act, altering the material errors that trigger special enrollment periods, and authorizing the Maryland Health Benefits Exchange to adopt an expanded open enrollment period under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill conforms Maryland's health insurance laws with existing federal requirements. Key changes include updating effective dates for federal regulations, clarifying consumer protection regulations stemming from the federal No Surprises Act, redefining 'material errors' that trigger special enrollment periods, and authorizing the Maryland Health Benefits Exchange to adopt expanded open enrollment periods under specific circumstances.
responsible_party: The Commissioner of Insurance; The Maryland Health Benefits Exchange; The federal Department of Health and Human Services
stakeholders: Maryland residents who have health insurance, eligible employees and their dependents, health insurance carriers, and healthcare providers, particularly those providing emergency services.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily focuses on aligning state health insurance laws with existing federal regulations and updating administrative details. It clarifies federal consumer protections and allows for flexibility in open enrollment periods, but it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has an indirect potential to impact child poverty by improving clarity and access to health insurance coverage. By conforming state law with federal requirements, clarifying emergency services coverage, and potentially expanding enrollment periods, it can help families maintain or gain health insurance, thus reducing the financial burden of unexpected medical costs, which can be a driver of poverty. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance or targeted services to reduce child poverty.

Title: Property Tax - Submission of Building Permits to Supervisor of Assessments - Estimated Construction Cost
Synopsis: Requiring local permit offices to include a construction cost estimate when submitting a copy of a building permit to the supervisor of assessments of the county where the building is located.
bill_summary: This bill requires local permit offices to include an estimated construction cost when submitting a copy of a building permit to the supervisor of assessments in the county where the building is located. It amends Article – Tax – Property, Section 5–103.
responsible_party: Local permit offices and county supervisors of assessments
stakeholders: Local permit offices, county supervisors of assessments, and individuals or entities applying for building permits.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative change that requires local permit offices to include an additional data point (estimated construction cost) when submitting building permits to the supervisor of assessments. It does not introduce new technologies or significantly innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative changes related to property tax assessment information by requiring construction cost estimates with building permits. It has no direct impact on child poverty as it does not provide services, funding, or policy changes directly addressing poverty.

Title: Insurance - Protections After Loss or Damage to Property
Synopsis: Prohibiting a public adjuster, or anyone acting on behalf of a public adjuster, from soliciting or attempting to solicit a client between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m.; altering the statements that are required to be included in a public adjuster contract; altering a certain rescission period for public adjuster contracts; and requiring a public adjuster to provide notice to the Commissioner, in a form and manner the Commissioner determines, within 1 business day after the public adjuster has entered into a contract.
bill_summary: This bill enacts several changes regarding insurance protections after property loss or damage. It prohibits public adjusters from soliciting clients within 24 hours after a loss or between 8:00 P.M. and 8:00 A.M. It modifies public adjuster contracts by requiring specific statements, including extended rescission periods: 10 business days for insureds under 65 years old, and 7 business days for insureds 65 years or older. Public adjusters are now required to notify the Maryland Insurance Commissioner within one business day if they enter into a contract during, or within 72 hours after, a loss. Additionally, the bill broadens the definition of a fraudulent insurance act to include contractors offering home repair or remodeling services for *any* damages (not just weather-related) who intentionally pay or compensate an insured's deductible with intent to defraud an insurer.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Public adjusters, contractors offering home repair or remodeling services, insured individuals who have suffered property loss or damage (especially those aged 65 and older), and insurance companies.
innovative_summary: The bill updates existing consumer protection regulations and clarifies definitions related to insurance fraud and public adjuster practices. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches, focusing instead on adjusting timelines and disclosure requirements within the current regulatory framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on consumer protection and fraud prevention within the property insurance sector. While improved consumer protections in insurance claims could indirectly benefit families by ensuring fair settlements after property damage, potentially helping them retain assets that would otherwise be lost, this impact on child poverty is not direct or specifically targeted. There are no direct financial provisions or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Baltimore City - Motor Vehicle Off-Street Parking Requirements Near Mass Transit Stations
Synopsis: Prohibiting the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City from adopting or enforcing a local law that requires the creation of new motor vehicle off-street parking for a development that includes residential use and that is located within a 0.25-mile radius of a present or planned MARC, Baltimore MTA Light Rail, Red Line, or Metro station.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City from adopting or enforcing local laws that require new off-street motor vehicle parking for residential developments located within a 0.25-mile radius of a present or planned MARC, Baltimore MTA Light Rail, Red Line, or Metro station. This aims to reduce parking requirements for residential projects near mass transit.
responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City
stakeholders: Developers of residential properties in Baltimore City, residents seeking housing near mass transit, and commuters using public transit.
innovative_summary: The bill implements a modern urban planning strategy by removing minimum parking requirements near transit hubs, which is a common approach to encourage transit use, reduce car dependency, and potentially lower housing development costs. While the policy itself aligns with contemporary urban development principles, its implementation method is through standard legislative changes and does not involve new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By removing parking mandates, it may reduce construction costs for residential developments. This could, in turn, lead to more affordable housing options near transit, potentially benefiting low-income families and reducing transportation burdens. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance or services aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Residential Service Agencies - Reimbursement - Personal Assistance Services (Homecare Worker Rights Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Authorizing the Maryland Department of Health to reimburse a residential service agency for personal assistance services only if the personal assistance services are provided by an individual classified as an employee.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Homecare Worker Rights Act of 2024, mandates that the Maryland Department of Health can only reimburse a residential service agency for personal assistance services if those services are provided by an individual classified as an employee. It generally relates to reimbursements for residential service agencies.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Residential service agencies, individuals providing personal assistance services (homecare workers), and third-party payors.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a policy change requiring personal assistance service providers to be classified as employees for reimbursement purposes. This is a regulatory adjustment regarding labor classification and reimbursement conditions, rather than an innovative use of new technologies or a fundamentally new approach to government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By requiring homecare workers to be classified as employees for reimbursement, the bill could indirectly impact child poverty if these workers are parents or guardians. Employee classification might lead to improved labor protections, benefits, and potentially more stable or higher income, which could improve the financial well-being of their households. However, the bill does not directly provide services or financial aid to children or families experiencing poverty; its impact is contingent on the employment status of affected workers and the subsequent benefits.

Title: Public Health - Public Health Services and Protections - Revisions
Synopsis: Repealing the exceptions that allow the sale, distribution, or purchase of tobacco products, tobacco paraphernalia, and electronic smoking devices to or for certain individuals who are active duty members of the military; authorizing the Maryland Department of Health to reallocate from one county to another county certain projected unspent grant funding relating to cancer to address certain funding needs; altering the duties of the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect; etc.
bill_summary: This bill makes several revisions to public health services and protections in Maryland. It repeals exceptions that allowed active duty military members between 18 and 20 years old to purchase tobacco products, tobacco paraphernalia, and electronic smoking devices. It authorizes the Maryland Department of Health to reallocate unspent cancer grant funding between counties to address unmet needs. The bill alters the duties of the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect, requiring it to report on the Maryland CHAMP Initiative, and repeals the yearly expert panel on child abuse and neglect. Additionally, it transfers the responsibility for payment of emergency medical treatment charges for child abuse and neglect cases from the Maryland Department of Health to the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy. The bill also updates certain reporting references and removes duplicative reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health, Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect
stakeholders: Individuals aged 18-20 who are active duty military, tobacco retailers, counties receiving local public health cancer grants, children who are victims of abuse and neglect, and healthcare providers involved in child abuse cases.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves administrative and regulatory adjustments, such as closing legal loopholes for tobacco sales, reallocating existing cancer grant funds, clarifying reporting duties for child abuse and neglect, and transferring payment responsibilities between state agencies. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill includes provisions related to child abuse and neglect, such as transferring responsibility for emergency medical treatment payments and altering the duties of the State Council on Child Abuse and Neglect to include reporting on child abuse diagnoses and treatment. While these changes may improve support for vulnerable children by streamlining service access and oversight, they do not directly address the economic factors contributing to child poverty.

Title: Motor Vehicle Registration - Exceptions for Golf Carts - Authorization
Synopsis: Authorizing counties and municipalities to designate certain highways in their respective jurisdictions on which a person may operate a golf cart; authorizing a person with a valid driver's license to operate a golf cart only on a highway with a maximum posted speed limit of not more than 30 miles per hour or 35 miles per hour in Golden Beach Patuxent Knolls, St. Mary's County, between dawn and dusk, and if the golf cart is equipped with certain lighting devices; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes counties and municipalities to designate specific county or municipal highways under their jurisdiction where golf carts may be operated without registration. It repeals previous, more localized state authorizations for golf cart use on highways and establishes general conditions for operation, such as speed limits, lighting requirements, and driver's license possession. The goal is to provide local governments with more control over golf cart usage on their roads.
responsible_party: County and municipal governing bodies in Maryland, with the Administration (presumably the Motor Vehicle Administration) setting lighting device requirements.
stakeholders: Golf cart owners and operators, residents of counties and municipalities, and local governments throughout Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is regulatory in nature, primarily shifting the authority for designating golf cart-friendly roads from specific state provisions to local government discretion. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches, but rather a streamlined and localized regulatory framework for golf cart use.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on motor vehicle registration exceptions for golf carts and local government authority to designate roads for their use. It does not contain any provisions that would directly impact or address child poverty.

Title: Natural Resources - Sale, Barter, or Exchange of Mounted Specimens From Decedent's Estate
Synopsis: Authorizing the sale, barter, or exchange of a legally acquired mounted specimen of a game bird, excluding a migratory game bird, or game mammal, from a decedent's estate and the specimen is part of the personal property being liquidated or distributed.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's Natural Resources Article to authorize the sale, barter, or exchange of legally acquired mounted specimens of game birds (excluding migratory game birds) and game mammals. This exception applies specifically when the original owner is deceased, and the specimen is part of their personal property being liquidated or distributed from their estate.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Individuals who inherit mounted game specimens as part of a decedent's estate, those involved in estate liquidation or distribution, and individuals interested in buying or selling such specimens.
innovative_summary: This bill is a minor regulatory adjustment to existing natural resources law concerning the sale of mounted specimens from estates. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's purpose is to modify regulations regarding the sale of taxidermy from deceased estates. It does not have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Public Health - Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund and Commission
Synopsis: Altering the use of the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund to require that the Fund be used only for pediatric cancer research instead of only for pediatric cancer research, prevention, and treatment and to allow funds from the Fund to be used for administrative expenses; and establishing the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to oversee the award of competitive grants from the Fund and to develop criteria and a process for reviewing grant applications.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Pediatric Cancer Fund to focus its use exclusively on pediatric cancer research, eliminating prevention and treatment as direct uses for grants. It also allows a portion of the fund to be used for administrative expenses, including promotion of donations and staff costs. Crucially, the bill establishes the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission, a new body responsible for overseeing the award of competitive grants from the Fund to public and private entities in the State. The Commission will develop criteria, procedures, and guidelines for grant applications and conduct progress reviews of grant recipients. The bill mandates an initial appropriation of $5,000,000 to the Fund.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Pediatric Cancer Research Commission
stakeholders: Pediatric cancer patients and their families, pediatric cancer researchers, eligible physicians, hospitals, laboratories, educational institutions, other organizations and persons conducting pediatric cancer research, adult survivors of pediatric cancer, and caregivers of pediatric cancer patients.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a dedicated Pediatric Cancer Research Commission to rigorously oversee competitive grants for pediatric cancer research, ensuring a focused and evidence-based approach to funding. While creating a commission and fund is not entirely new, its specific mandate to guide scientific research funding for pediatric cancer, involving a diverse group of experts and stakeholders, represents a structured and systematized method to advance understanding and treatment of the disease.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's primary focus is on funding pediatric cancer research, which aims to improve the understanding, prevention, cure, screening, and treatment of pediatric cancer. While successful research could lead to medical advancements that indirectly reduce the burden of illness on families and potentially decrease long-term healthcare costs, the bill does not directly address child poverty through financial assistance, direct support services, or improving access to existing care for low-income families. Its impact on child poverty would be highly indirect and long-term.

Title: State Employees - Parental Bereavement Leave
Synopsis: Providing that certain State employees are entitled to use up to 10 days of parental bereavement leave with pay within 60 days after the death of the employee's child; providing that certain State employees are entitled to use up to 60 days of parental bereavement leave within 60 days after the employee experiences a stillbirth or the death of the employee's infant; and prohibiting certain State entities from requiring State employees entitled to parental bereavement leave under the Act to use any other paid leave available to the employee.
bill_summary: This bill establishes parental bereavement leave for all Maryland State employees, including temporary employees and those in higher education. Employees are entitled to up to 10 days of paid leave for the death of a child (aged 6 months to under 27 years) or a stillbirth. For stillbirths or the death of an infant (under 6 months), employees may use up to 60 days of paid leave. Appointing authorities cannot require employees to use other forms of paid leave for this purpose. The Secretary is directed to adopt regulations to govern this leave.
responsible_party: The Secretary (of the Department of Budget and Management)
stakeholders: Maryland State employees, including those in the executive, judicial, and legislative branches of State government, units with independent personnel systems, and employees of public institutions of higher education.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new category of paid leave, parental bereavement leave, for state employees, reflecting an evolving standard for workplace benefits and support for families. While this is a progressive policy update, it does not involve new technologies or fundamentally alter government operations or service delivery methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill provides paid leave to state employees experiencing the tragic loss of a child or a stillbirth. While such support can help stabilize the financial situation of affected state employee families during a difficult time, it is not a direct program or intervention specifically designed to alleviate child poverty within the broader population. Its scope is limited to state employees and their immediate families.

Title: Property Tax - Transfer to Heir or Legatee - Payment Plans
Synopsis: Exempting a grant of land transferring residential real property from the estate of a decedent to an heir or a legatee of the decedent from certain requirements for the payment of taxes on real property if the heir or legatee of the decedent enters into a payment plan to pay all the taxes due and owed on the property; exempting a grant of land that is subject to a payment plan for property taxes from certain requirements for the payment of taxes if the grantee agrees to assume the grantor's obligations under the payment plan; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies property tax laws in Maryland to provide more flexibility for homeowners. It exempts residential real property transferred from a decedent's estate to an heir or legatee from immediate tax payment requirements if they enter into a payment plan for all due taxes. Similarly, it allows properties already under a payment plan to be transferred if the new grantee assumes the plan obligations. The bill also mandates the State Tax Sale Ombudsman to contract with a vendor to operate an installment payment program for any homeowner, allowing payments for advance, current, or arrears taxes. Furthermore, it authorizes counties and municipal corporations to establish their own installment payment programs for residential property taxes in arrears.
responsible_party: State Tax Sale Ombudsman; governing body of a county or municipal corporation
stakeholders: Heirs and legatees inheriting residential real property; homeowners with delinquent property taxes; any homeowner in Maryland interested in installment payment plans for property taxes.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new approach by requiring the State Tax Sale Ombudsman to contract with a vendor to operate a statewide installment payment program for property taxes. This leverages a third-party vendor to provide flexible payment options (advance, current, arrears) to homeowners across the state. It also offers a novel exemption for inherited residential properties, allowing heirs to assume ownership with a payment plan instead of requiring upfront payment of all taxes, which is a new mechanism for property transfer in these circumstances.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a direct impact on child poverty by enhancing housing stability and preventing homelessness. By allowing heirs to take ownership of inherited residential property via payment plans and by providing installment options for homeowners with delinquent taxes, the bill reduces the risk of property loss and forced displacement. This helps families maintain stable housing, which is crucial for children's well-being, education, and overall development, thus indirectly mitigating factors contributing to child poverty.

Title: Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families to study developing and implementing a statewide strategic plan to make Maryland the best state for veterans and military families, including legislative and budgetary recommendations; requiring the Commission to consult with the Office of Military and Federal Affairs and the Maryland Military Installation Council as part of the study process; and requiring the Commission to report its findings to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Commission on Veterans and Military Families. The Commission is tasked with studying and making recommendations for developing and implementing a statewide strategic plan to make Maryland the best state for veterans and military families, including legislative and budgetary recommendations. It must also identify key performance indicators to assess the quality of life for these families relative to other states. The Commission is required to report its findings by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
stakeholders: Veterans and military families in Maryland
innovative_summary: The program establishes a commission to develop a strategic plan and identify key performance indicators to assess and improve the quality of life for veterans and military families. While focused on strategic policy development and measurement, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on improving the overall quality of life for veterans and military families, which may include aspects like workforce development and health care. While these improvements could indirectly benefit families experiencing poverty, the bill does not directly target child poverty or provide specific services or financial aid to reduce it.

Title: Rehabilitation Services - Disability - Definition
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "disability" relating to the provision of rehabilitation services in the State to align with the federal Rehabilitation Act of 1973; and defining "disability" as any physical or mental impairment that constitutes or results in a substantial impediment to employment or independent living.
bill_summary: This bill updates the definition of “disability” used in the provision of rehabilitation services in Maryland. The new definition, “PHYSICAL OR MENTAL IMPAIRMENT THAT CONSTITUTES OR RESULTS IN A SUBSTANTIAL IMPEDIMENT TO employment or independent living,” replaces the previous definition to align with federal law.
responsible_party: Maryland State rehabilitation services
stakeholders: Individuals with physical or mental impairments seeking rehabilitation services in Maryland
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it primarily updates a legal definition to align with existing federal law rather than introducing new technologies or approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is very low. While an updated definition of disability might facilitate access to rehabilitation services, potentially leading to improved employment opportunities for adults and indirectly benefiting their families, it does not directly provide resources or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Employee Rights and Protections - Personnel Actions and Harassment - Investigation of Complaints
Synopsis: Increasing, from 30 days to 60 days, the time period during which an investigation must be conducted and a written decision must be issued regarding a complaint filed by an applicant or employee alleging discrimination or harassment by an employer; and authorizing certain applicants and employees to provide written authorization to increase by an additional 30 days the time period during which an investigation of a complaint and a written decision must be completed.
bill_summary: This bill extends the time period for investigating and issuing a written decision on discrimination or harassment complaints filed by State employees or applicants from 30 days to 60 days. Additionally, it allows for an extra 30-day extension if the complainant provides written authorization.
responsible_party: Equal employment officer, fair practices officer, and the head of the principal unit within the State government
stakeholders: State employees and applicants in Maryland who file discrimination or harassment complaints.
innovative_summary: The bill does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government. It makes administrative adjustments to existing complaint investigation timelines.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses the procedural timelines for investigating discrimination and harassment complaints for State employees. While ensuring fair workplace practices can indirectly support families, it does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or resources aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Property Tax - Credit for Dwelling House of Disabled Veterans - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering eligibility for a certain property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax on the dwelling house of certain disabled veterans to include individuals who have been declared by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to have a nonpermanent service-connected disability of 100% that results from blindness or any other disabling cause; authorizing a county or municipal corporation, notwithstanding certain provisions of the Act, to enact a law limiting eligibility for the tax credit; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the eligibility criteria for a property tax credit available to disabled veterans in Maryland. It expands eligibility to include veterans declared by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to have a 100% nonpermanent service-connected disability. The bill also modifies how the amount of the credit is calculated based on disability rating. Additionally, it authorizes counties or municipal corporations to enact laws that limit eligibility for the tax credit to veterans with permanent service-connected disabilities.
responsible_party: Local county or municipal governments in Maryland, including Baltimore City
stakeholders: Disabled veterans, their surviving spouses, and local county and municipal governments in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an amendment to an existing property tax credit program, expanding eligibility and altering credit calculations. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program provides a property tax credit to disabled veterans. While it may free up household income for eligible veterans and their families, it is not directly targeted at addressing or alleviating child poverty.

Title: Property Tax Credits - Public School Employees, Health and Safety Improvements, and Property Used for Local Housing Programs
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a certain property tax credit for certain residential real property owned by a public school employee under certain circumstances; authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a certain property tax credit for certain buildings if the owner made certain health or safety improvements on or after July 1, 2024; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes local governments in Maryland (Baltimore City, counties, and municipal corporations) to offer three types of property tax credits. These credits can be granted against county or municipal property tax for: 1) residential real property owned by a public school employee in the county where the property is located; 2) apartment or condominium buildings where the owner has made health or safety improvements on or after July 1, 2024; and 3) apartment or condominium buildings used on or after July 1, 2024, for local housing programs benefiting homeless individuals or families.
responsible_party: Local governments (Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City, county governing bodies, or municipal corporations)
stakeholders: Public school employees who own residential property; owners of apartment or condominium buildings making health or safety improvements; owners of apartment or condominium buildings participating in local housing programs for homeless individuals or families; and indirectly, residents of these improved or program-affiliated buildings, including homeless individuals and families.
innovative_summary: This bill employs a standard governmental approach of authorizing property tax credits as an incentive. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services or delivery. The application of these tax credits to specific groups or for specific purposes (like supporting public school employees or encouraging housing for the homeless) is a policy choice, not an innovative mechanism.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has potential for a direct impact on child poverty primarily through the property tax credit for buildings used in local housing programs for homeless individuals or families. This could help stabilize housing for families with children experiencing homelessness, a key factor in reducing child poverty. Additionally, the tax credit for public school employees could indirectly benefit families with children if the employee is a parent, by reducing their housing costs. Health and safety improvements could also positively impact children living in affected buildings.

Title: Insurance - Penalties - Unauthorized Insurers, Insurance Producers, and Public Adjusters
Synopsis: Altering the maximum civil penalty to which an unauthorized insurer or person that violates certain provisions of State insurance law is subject for each violation; and altering the maximum civil penalty that the Maryland Insurance Commissioner may impose, in addition to suspending or revoking the license, on the holder of an insurance producer license or a public adjuster licensee for each violation of State insurance law.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum civil penalties for unauthorized insurers, insurance producers, and public adjusters who violate State insurance law. Specifically, it raises the civil penalty for unauthorized insurers or persons from a maximum of $50,000 to $125,000 per violation. It also increases the maximum civil penalty the Maryland Insurance Commissioner may impose on licensed insurance producers or public adjusters from $500 to $5,000 per violation, in addition to other disciplinary actions like license suspension or revocation.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Unauthorized insurers, licensed insurance producers, public adjusters, and indirectly, citizens who may suffer financial injury from violations of insurance law.
innovative_summary: This bill updates existing penalty amounts for violations of insurance law, which is a standard regulatory adjustment and does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on increasing civil penalties for insurance violations to deter misconduct. While ensuring a fairer insurance market can indirectly benefit consumers, it does not establish programs or allocate resources directly aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Continuing Care Retirement Communities - Transparency, Grievances, and Unit Reoccupancy
Synopsis: Requiring a provider to post the provider's most recent disclosure statement on the provider's website; increasing from yearly to quarterly the number of times a provider is required to hold a meeting open to all the provider's subscribers; requiring at the last quarterly meeting of the year an officer of the provider to give an aggregated, deidentified summary of internal grievances; requiring a provider to submit a written report to a subscriber or a beneficiary if the subscriber's unit has not been reoccupied within 9 months; etc.
bill_summary: This bill enhances transparency and accountability within Continuing Care Retirement Communities (CCRCs). It requires CCRCs to post their most recent disclosure statements on their websites, hold open meetings with subscribers quarterly (instead of annually), and for an authorized officer to provide an aggregated, deidentified summary of internal grievances at the last quarterly meeting. The bill also increases subscriber representation on CCRC governing bodies to two members, elected by the resident association of each facility, and allows these subscriber members to report nonconfidential information to their resident associations. Furthermore, the Department of Aging is mandated to collect data on internal grievances twice a year and report annually to legislative committees. Finally, for units where an entrance fee refund is conditioned on reoccupancy, if the unit has not been reoccupied within 9 months of a subscriber's death or contract termination, the provider must submit initial and then bi-annual written reports to the subscriber or beneficiary detailing the reoccupancy efforts.
responsible_party: Department of Aging
stakeholders: Subscribers (residents) of Continuing Care Retirement Communities, providers (operators) of Continuing Care Retirement Communities, and beneficiaries of subscribers.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces measures for improved transparency and accountability in Continuing Care Retirement Communities by mandating online disclosure statements, more frequent subscriber meetings, enhanced subscriber representation on governing bodies, and structured grievance reporting. While these are valuable governance and consumer protection enhancements, they do not employ new technologies or represent highly novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the regulation and oversight of Continuing Care Retirement Communities, which serve an adult and elderly population. It does not contain any provisions that would directly provide services, financial assistance, or opportunities intended to reduce child poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Teacher Development and Retention Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "institution of initial eligibility" to include community colleges as eligible institutions as part of the criteria for applicants for the Teacher Development and Retention Program; altering the evaluation requirements for the Program; requiring the Higher Education Commission to conduct an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Program and report the results to the Governor and the General Assembly by January 1, 2030; and altering the termination date from June 30, 2029 to June 30, 2030.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Teacher Development and Retention Program by expanding eligibility to include community colleges as "institutions of initial eligibility." It shifts the school years for providing initial and internship stipends, allows the program's fund to be used for administrative expenses, alters evaluation requirements from an independent consultant to a Commission-conducted evaluation, and extends the program's termination date from June 30, 2029, to June 30, 2030.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (for program administration, fund management, and evaluation) and Maryland State Department of Education (for identifying high-needs schools, grade levels, or content areas).
stakeholders: Students interested in pursuing teaching careers, enrolled in community colleges or institutions with high Pell Grant recipient rates; teachers serving in high-needs schools; and the students attending these high-needs schools.
innovative_summary: This bill refines an existing pilot program designed to incentivize teaching by expanding eligibility to community colleges and adjusting timelines. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather broadens access to an existing incentive structure.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to address teacher shortages in "high-needs schools," which are often located in communities with higher rates of child poverty. By increasing the supply of qualified teachers in these schools, the program can indirectly improve educational outcomes for children, which is a key factor in breaking cycles of poverty.

Title: Health Occupations - Pharmacists - Administration of Vaccines
Synopsis: Authorizing a pharmacist to order and administer certain vaccinations to individuals in certain age groups if certain requirements are met; altering the vaccinations that a pharmacist can administer to individuals at least 3 years old; and altering the circumstances under which a pharmacist may administer certain vaccinations.
bill_summary: This bill expands the authority of pharmacists in Maryland to order and administer a wider range of vaccinations to individuals, including children as young as 3 years old. Pharmacists can now order and administer vaccines recommended by the CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices or approved/authorized by the U.S. FDA, specifically including influenza, COVID-19, and public health emergency vaccines. To do so, pharmacists must meet specific training and certification requirements, including practical injection training, CPR certification, and continuing education. The bill also mandates informing caregivers of children about well-child visits and referrals to pediatric primary care providers when appropriate, and requires reporting administered vaccinations to the ImmuNet Program.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Pharmacy and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Maryland residents of all ages, particularly children as young as 3 years old, their caregivers, pharmacists, authorized prescribers, and primary care providers.
innovative_summary: The bill expands the scope of practice for pharmacists by allowing them to both order and administer a broader range of vaccines, including to younger age groups. This approach leverages existing healthcare infrastructure (pharmacies) to improve public access to immunizations, which is an innovative administrative strategy to enhance public health reach and efficiency, though not technologically innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By increasing access to essential vaccinations for children as young as 3 years old, the bill has the potential to improve child health outcomes. Better health can reduce the burden of illness on families, potentially lowering healthcare costs and reducing missed school or work days for parents/caregivers. While not directly providing financial aid, it addresses a crucial determinant of well-being that can indirectly alleviate some stressors associated with child poverty.

Title: Maryland Environmental Service – Governance and Requirements
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Maryland Environmental Service to delegate certain responsibilities to an employee of the Service; altering the obligations of the Service after receiving a request for services and after entering into a contract;  requiring that an audit be made of the financial books, records, and accounts of the Service by November 15 each year; and requiring the Service to report to the Governor and the General Assembly on its activities by November 15 each year.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the governance and operational requirements of the Maryland Environmental Service (MES). It alters the quorum threshold for the MES Board of Directors from five to four members, authorizes the Secretary of the Board to delegate certain responsibilities to an employee as a Deputy Secretary, and expands the definition of "municipality" to include the District of Columbia and units of the United States. The bill also clarifies that the Service is not obligated to provide projects or services before a contract is executed, revises the deadlines for financial audits and annual reports to November 15th each year, and repeals a specific audit requirement for unauthorized spending.
responsible_party: Maryland Environmental Service (Board of Directors, Secretary, Treasurer)
stakeholders: Maryland Environmental Service, its Board of Directors, employees, municipalities, and entities contracting with the Service. The general public of Maryland and the District of Columbia, as well as federal units, are indirectly impacted by the MES's operational efficiency.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily focuses on administrative adjustments, governance clarifications, and updating reporting deadlines for an existing state instrumentality. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather streamlines and formalizes existing procedures and responsibilities.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses the internal governance, audit requirements, and operational procedures of the Maryland Environmental Service. While the MES provides essential environmental services that contribute to public health and well-being, the bill itself does not directly establish or modify programs with a specific aim to address or alleviate child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be indirect and negligible.

Title: Hospitals and Urgent Care Centers - Sepsis Protocol (Lochlin's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before January 1, 2025, each hospital and urgent care center in the State to implement an evidence-based protocol for the early recognition and treatment of a patient with sepsis, severe sepsis, or septic shock that is based on generally acceptable standards of care; requiring a specialty psychiatric hospital to establish a certain process; and requiring hospitals and urgent care centers to require periodic training in the implementation of the protocol for certain staff.
bill_summary: This bill, known as Lochlin's Law, requires all hospitals and urgent care centers in Maryland to implement an evidence-based protocol for the early recognition and treatment of sepsis, severe sepsis, or septic shock by January 1, 2025. The protocol must include components specific to adults and children and be based on generally accepted standards of care, complying with CDC Sepsis Guidelines for hospitals. It also mandates periodic training for professional staff with direct patient care responsibilities, as well as indirect staff like laboratory and pharmacy personnel, and requires updated training for any substantive changes to the protocol. Hospitals must also use quality measures for internal improvement related to sepsis.
responsible_party: Hospitals and urgent care centers in Maryland, with oversight by the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Patients (adults and children) who may develop sepsis, severe sepsis, or septic shock; professional and indirect staff of hospitals and urgent care centers.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates the implementation of evidence-based medical protocols for sepsis treatment and associated staff training. While it aims to standardize and improve healthcare quality, it does so through conventional regulatory and procedural mandates rather than employing new technologies or novel governmental approaches. It institutionalizes existing best practices rather than innovating new ones.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving healthcare outcomes for patients, including children, by ensuring early recognition and treatment of sepsis. While better health outcomes can indirectly benefit families and potentially reduce medical costs that could contribute to poverty, the bill does not directly address the economic factors of child poverty through financial aid, social services, or poverty-reduction programs.

Title: Public and Nonpublic Schools - Bronchodilators - Use, Availability, Training, and Policies
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Education, in consultation with certain groups, to develop training for certain school personnel to identify symptoms of anaphylaxis, asthma, and respiratory distress in students; requiring the Maryland Department of Health, in consultation with county boards, and authorizing nonpublic schools to establish a policy to obtain, administer, and train certain school personnel to administer emergency bronchodilators to a student who is determined to be, or is perceived to be, experiencing asthma-related symptoms; etc.
bill_summary: This bill expands school health policies in Maryland to allow for the emergency administration of bronchodilators to students experiencing asthma-related symptoms or respiratory distress in public and nonpublic schools. It mandates the State Department of Education, in consultation with the Maryland Department of Health and health organizations, to develop training for school personnel on identifying symptoms of asthma, respiratory distress, and anaphylaxis, and distinguishing between them. The Maryland Department of Health, in consultation with county boards, must establish policies for public schools (and nonpublic schools are authorized to do so) for obtaining, storing, and administering bronchodilators. The bill also updates existing auto-injectable epinephrine policies to integrate with the new training requirements and provides civil immunity for school personnel and healthcare providers acting in good faith. It requires specific reporting for bronchodilator use and notification to parents/guardians. Prekindergarten students require a diagnosis and prescription for bronchodilator administration.
responsible_party: State Department of Education and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Students, school nurses, designated school personnel, public and nonpublic schools, parents/guardians, licensed health care practitioners
innovative_summary: The bill expands the types of emergency medications available in schools and updates training protocols to cover more conditions and distinguish between them. While beneficial for student health and safety, this is an incremental policy adjustment to existing health services rather than an innovative use of new technology or a novel approach to government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to improve health and safety for all students by ensuring emergency medication for asthma and respiratory distress is available in schools. While better health and consistent school attendance can contribute to long-term well-being and educational attainment, which indirectly impacts economic stability, the bill does not directly address the economic causes or symptoms of child poverty. Its impact is primarily health-related.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Immediate Vesting
Synopsis: Providing that an individual serving as the State Superintendent of Schools shall immediately vest in the State Retirement and Pension System.
bill_summary: This bill amends the State Personnel and Pensions Article to grant immediate vesting rights in the State Retirement and Pension System to the State Superintendent of Schools, adding this position to the existing list of State officials who receive immediate vesting.
responsible_party: State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: The State Superintendent of Schools and, by extension, the State Retirement and Pension System.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a technical change to the eligibility criteria for pension vesting for a specific state official. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or significantly new approaches to government operations or policy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on an employment benefit for a high-ranking state official by modifying pension vesting rules. It has no direct or indirect provisions that would impact child poverty.

Title: Insurance - Hearing Representation
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Insurance Commissioner to allow corporations, partnerships, limited liability companies, and sole proprietorships that are small employers to be represented by certain authorized individuals rather than an attorney in certain hearings held by the Commissioner.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland insurance law to allow certain business entities that qualify as small employers to be represented by authorized individuals (such as officers or designated employees) rather than an attorney in specific hearings held by the Maryland Insurance Commissioner. The purpose is to provide small businesses with more flexible and potentially less costly representation options in these administrative proceedings.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Small employers in Maryland, individuals designated to represent small employers, and the Maryland Insurance Administration.
innovative_summary: The bill allows non-attorney representation for small employers in certain insurance hearings, which is a procedural change aimed at reducing administrative burden. It streamlines existing processes rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on legal representation options for small businesses in insurance hearings and does not directly address child poverty through specific programs, financial aid, or services. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect and negligible, by potentially easing financial burdens on some small businesses.

Title: Resources and Education for All Prisons (REAP) Act
