Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to assist incarcerated individuals in accessing federal Pell Grants for higher education; requiring the Department to set goals for the number of incarcerated individuals in postsecondary education programs, establish tracking systems for their progress in postsecondary education programs, and forward certain data to the Maryland Higher Education Commission; requiring the Commission to assist the Department in establishing the tracking systems; etc.
bill_summary: The REAP (Resources and Education for All Prisons) Act requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to assist incarcerated individuals in accessing federal Pell grants for higher education. The Department is also mandated to set goals for incarcerated individuals' participation in postsecondary education programs, establish tracking systems for their progress (including college credits earned), and forward this data to the Maryland Higher Education Commission. The Maryland Higher Education Commission is required to assist the Department in creating these tracking systems. The Governor must include an annual appropriation in the budget bill for marketing postsecondary education programs to incarcerated individuals and for the tracking systems.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals in Maryland correctional institutions, institutions of higher education.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes formal tracking systems for incarcerated individuals' participation and progress in postsecondary education programs, including college credits earned, and mandates data sharing between state agencies. While not employing cutting-edge technology, this structured data collection and inter-agency collaboration represents an innovative approach to improve access to education and measure outcomes within the correctional system.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill aims to improve access to higher education for incarcerated individuals, which could indirectly lead to better employment opportunities upon release. Improved employment may, in turn, positively affect the financial stability of their families and potentially reduce child poverty. However, the bill does not directly provide services or financial aid to children or families, making its impact on child poverty indirect and long-term.

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Termination of Residential Lease - Limitation of Liability for Rent
Synopsis: Limiting a tenant's liability for rent to not more than 2 months' rent after the date on which the tenant vacates a leased premises if a physician or psychologist completes a form specifying that the tenant has a mental disorder, the management of which is substantially limited by the leased premises.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's Real Property Article to limit a residential tenant's liability for rent to a maximum of two months' rent after vacating, if a licensed physician, professional counselor, therapist, or psychologist certifies that the tenant (or an authorized occupant) has a medical condition, intellectual or developmental disability, or a mental disorder that significantly restricts their mobility, makes continued habitation unfeasible, or requires them to move for a higher level of care. This limitation does not apply if the lease has a liquidated damages or early termination clause with a 1-month or less notice and liability of 2 months' rent or less.
responsible_party: Maryland Courts
stakeholders: Residential tenants with medical conditions, intellectual disabilities, developmental disabilities, or mental disorders, and their landlords, particularly those in situations requiring a change of residence due to these conditions.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legislative amendment to existing landlord-tenant law, expanding protections for tenants with certain disabilities or disorders. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By limiting a tenant's financial liability for rent in specific circumstances related to health or disability, this bill can help prevent families from incurring significant debt or financial strain when forced to vacate a leased property. This indirect financial relief could mitigate factors contributing to child poverty for affected families, though it is not a direct poverty alleviation program.

Title: Correctional Services - Inmate Employment - Agricultural Work
Synopsis: Repealing the authority of the Division of Correction to arrange for inmates not needed or being used by the State Highway Administration to perform emergency road work to be employed in agricultural work during any part of the year at a camp in Queen Anne's County or any other county with a similar camp.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the existing law that allowed the Division of Correction to arrange for inmates in specific camps to perform agricultural work and required employers to pay prevailing wages for that work. It generally relates to the employment of inmates by removing this specific provision.
responsible_party: Division of Correction
stakeholders: Inmates in Maryland correctional facilities, particularly those who might have been employed in agricultural work, and private entities that previously employed inmates for agricultural work.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it repeals an existing law and does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill repeals a provision for inmate agricultural work. It does not directly provide services or financial support to children or families, thus it has no direct positive impact on child poverty.

Title: Health - Newborn Screening Program - Implementation of Testing
Synopsis: Repealing a certain requirement related to the inclusion of a core condition in the system for newborn screening; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to implement testing for a core condition listed in the Recommended Uniform Screening Panel within a certain time period after the core condition is added to the Panel; authorizing the Department to screen for any condition recommended by the Advisory Council and approved by the Secretary; requiring the Department to implement testing for Krabbe leukodystrophy at a certain time; etc.
bill_summary: This bill streamlines the Maryland Newborn Screening Program by removing the requirement for the Secretary of Health and the State Advisory Council to approve the inclusion of core conditions from the Recommended Uniform Screening Panel (RUSP). Instead, it mandates that the Maryland Department of Health implement testing for any new core condition added to the RUSP within 18 months. It also specifically requires the Department to implement testing for Krabbe leukodystrophy within one year of a final recommendation from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. The bill includes provisions for reporting delays in implementation to legislative committees. This measure aims to ensure timely adoption of new screening tests for hereditary and congenital disorders in newborns.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Newborn infants in Maryland, their parents and guardians, healthcare providers, laboratories, and treatment centers involved in newborn screening.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily streamlines an administrative process for integrating new conditions into an existing newborn screening program and mandates testing for a specific condition. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally change government approaches, but rather ensures the timely adoption of federally recommended health screenings.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By ensuring earlier detection and treatment of severe hereditary and congenital disorders, it can improve health outcomes for infants, which may reduce long-term healthcare burdens and associated financial strains on families, including those experiencing poverty. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance or services aimed at alleviating poverty.

Title: Baby Food - Toxic Heavy Metals - Testing and Labeling (Rudy's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning January 1, 2025, manufacturers of baby food to test a representative sample of each production aggregate of the manufacturer's final baby food product for certain toxic heavy metals; requiring, beginning January 1, 2026, manufacturers of baby food to make certain information related to the testing and a link to certain guidance available on the manufacturer's website; requiring a consumer to report to the Maryland Department of Health if the consumer believes that baby food is being sold with toxic heavy metals; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as Rudy's Law, requires baby food manufacturers to test their products for toxic heavy metals (arsenic, cadmium, lead, mercury) before packaging, starting January 1, 2025. Manufacturers must make test results publicly available on their websites and include QR codes on product labels linking to this information and FDA guidance, starting January 1, 2026. The bill also prohibits the sale of baby food exceeding FDA limits for these metals after January 1, 2025 (with a grace period for products manufactured before January 1, 2026) and establishes a consumer reporting mechanism to the Maryland Department of Health for suspected violations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Baby food manufacturers, consumers (especially parents/guardians of children under 2), and children under 2 years of age who consume baby food.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates the use of QR codes on baby food product labels to provide consumers with direct access to manufacturers' toxic heavy metal testing results and FDA guidance on health effects. This digital approach enhances transparency and consumer access to critical safety information, representing a moderately innovative use of technology in public health regulation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on ensuring the safety of baby food by requiring testing for toxic heavy metals and increasing transparency for consumers. While improving food safety is beneficial for all children, it does not directly address the economic causes or symptoms of child poverty. Its potential impact on child poverty is indirect, primarily through potential health benefits that could reduce healthcare burdens or improve long-term well-being, but it does not provide direct financial assistance or resources.

Title: Criminal Law – Sexual Solicitation of a Minor Through Child Pornography – Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting an individual from knowingly and with a certain intent soliciting a minor or law enforcement officer posing as a minor to engage in certain prohibited sexual acts with the minor by a certain means.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits individuals from knowingly and with certain intent soliciting a minor, or a law enforcement officer posing as a minor, to engage in prohibited sexual acts. It expands the definition of solicitation to include various means, such as computer, Internet, or other electronic means, especially in the context of child pornography. The bill establishes penalties for violations, including imprisonment and fines.
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies and the judicial system
stakeholders: Minors who are potential victims of sexual solicitation, individuals who commit or intend to commit sexual solicitation of minors, and law enforcement officers.
innovative_summary: The bill updates existing criminal law by explicitly including solicitation through "computer or Internet" and "any other electronic means," reflecting current technological methods used for such crimes. While it modernizes the legal framework to address digital forms of solicitation, it does not introduce new governmental technologies or groundbreaking approaches to public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses criminal acts of sexual solicitation of minors, focusing on child protection. While protecting children from exploitation is crucial for their overall well-being and can indirectly reduce factors that might lead to poverty, it does not directly provide economic assistance, support services, or poverty-reduction programs aimed at children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Motor Vehicles - Motorcycles - Passenger Restrictions
Synopsis: Requiring a rear passenger on a motorcycle to be able to firmly position the passenger's feet on the footrests of the motorcycle, subject to an exception for permanent physical disability.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland transportation law to require a rear passenger on a motorcycle to be able to firmly place their feet on the footrests while seated. An exception is made for passengers with a permanent physical disability that prevents them from doing so.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation and law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Motorcycle operators, rear motorcycle passengers, and individuals with permanent physical disabilities who ride as motorcycle passengers.
innovative_summary: The bill makes a minor regulatory adjustment to existing motorcycle passenger laws, focusing on safety through physical requirements. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill concerns motorcycle passenger safety requirements and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Dental Services - Coverage and Rate Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to study the feasibility of including removable full and partial dentures and setting adequate reimbursement rates for providers on a per-patient basis for house calls and extended care facility calls among the coverage offered by the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program; and requiring the Department to report its findings from the study to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee by December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to conduct a feasibility study on expanding coverage under the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program. The study must assess the inclusion of removable full and partial dentures and per-patient reimbursement for house and extended care facility calls. It also mandates studying reimbursement rates to ensure adequate access to care, setting them at not less than 60% of average commercial rates or American Dental Association benchmark charges. The Department must solicit input from dental organizations and advocacy groups and report its findings to legislative committees by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Low-income populations in Maryland (particularly those served by the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program), dental care providers, State chapters of national professional dental organizations, and advocacy groups for oral health.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on conducting a feasibility study to expand coverage and adjust reimbursement rates within an existing dental program. While aiming to improve access to care, the approach does not introduce new technologies or novel government methods, but rather refines existing services and payment structures.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By studying the expansion of dental services and improved reimbursement rates for the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program, this bill has the potential to directly impact the oral health of children from low-income families. Improved dental care, including access to dentures and extended care, can significantly contribute to the overall well-being, health, and development of these children, thereby indirectly addressing a barrier often associated with child poverty.

Title: Drunk Driving Offenses - Expungement and the Ignition Interlock System Program
Synopsis: Authorizing a person to file a petition for expungement of certain records relating to a probation before judgment for driving while impaired or driving while under the influence; requiring the Motor Vehicle Administration to require persons convicted of or granted probation before judgment for certain criminal offenses related to driving while impaired by alcohol, a drug, drug combination, or a combination of drugs and alcohol to participate in the Ignition Interlock System Program for certain periods of time; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland law by authorizing expungement petitions for certain probation before judgment records related to driving while impaired or under the influence. It expands mandatory participation in the Ignition Interlock System Program for individuals convicted of or granted probation for certain drunk driving offenses, clarifies that program participation begins on the day the ignition interlock system is installed, and requires the Motor Vehicle Administration to collect and report data on program participants.
responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Individuals in Maryland who are convicted of or granted probation before judgment for drunk driving offenses, as well as those seeking expungement of such records.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modifies existing legal and administrative processes related to drunk driving offenses, expungement, and the Ignition Interlock System Program. It expands the scope of mandatory participation in an existing technology-based program and introduces new data collection and reporting requirements for an established agency. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on drunk driving offenses, expungement, and the Ignition Interlock System Program. While convictions and associated costs (fines, program fees) can indirectly affect household finances and potentially impact children in poverty, the bill's provisions are not directly designed to alleviate child poverty. Any impact would be indirect through the consequences of criminal justice involvement.

Title: Baltimore County Board of Education - Nonstudent Member Compensation and Student Member Scholarships - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the annual compensation of certain nonstudent members of the Baltimore County Board of Education from $7,500 to $16,500; providing that the chair of the county board is entitled to receive $17,500 annually as compensation; and increasing the amount that a student member of the board is granted for a certain scholarship from $7,500 to $10,000.
bill_summary: This bill alters the annual compensation for nonstudent members of the Baltimore County Board of Education, increasing it to $16,500 for regular members and establishing $17,500 for the chair. It also increases the scholarship amount for student members who complete a full term from $7,500 to $10,000. These changes will take effect for terms of office beginning on or after July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of Education
stakeholders: Nonstudent members and student members of the Baltimore County Board of Education.
innovative_summary: This bill makes routine adjustments to compensation and scholarship amounts for members of a local board of education. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily adjusts compensation for adult board members and scholarship amounts for student board members. While the increased scholarship could potentially assist a student from a lower-income background, the bill's main intent and direct beneficiaries are not focused on addressing child poverty.

Title: Natural Resources - Submerged Aquatic Vegetation - Alteration or Removal Requirements
Synopsis: Authorizing certain persons to alter certain submerged aquatic vegetation in a certain manner and in accordance with certain requirements; authorizing a public utility company or telecommunications carrier to alter certain submerged aquatic vegetation in a certain manner and in accordance with certain requirements; and altering certain requirements related to the alteration or removal of certain submerged aquatic vegetation.
bill_summary: This bill modifies existing regulations concerning the alteration or removal of submerged aquatic vegetation (SAV) in Maryland's tidal waters. It expands the authorization for certain persons, public utility companies, and telecommunications carriers to trim or cut SAV in specific widths without prior Department approval, provided they notify the Department of the location and date of the activity and use best harvesting methods. It also clarifies general requirements for SAV alteration or removal under other circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Owners or renters of piers, docks, ramps, and marinas on tidal waters; public utility companies; telecommunications carriers; and individuals or entities involved in the alteration or removal of submerged aquatic vegetation in Maryland's tidal waters.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily updates and clarifies existing environmental regulations regarding the alteration of submerged aquatic vegetation, adjusting permissible activities and notification requirements. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on environmental regulations related to submerged aquatic vegetation in tidal waters and does not directly address child poverty or economic support for children and families.

Title: Persons Doing Public Business – Disclosure Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring a person to file a registration statement with the State Board of Elections within a certain time period after the award of a contract that causes the person to be doing public business; requiring persons doing public business to update information on beneficial ownership included in the registration statement in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Board; altering the time at which a person doing public business is required to file a certain initial statement with the State Board; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies disclosure requirements for persons and businesses doing public business with the State of Maryland. It requires such persons to file a registration statement, including beneficial ownership information, with the State Board of Elections within 15 business days of being awarded a contract of $200,000 or more. It also alters the timeline for filing initial statements of political contributions and requires governmental entities to ensure contractors certify these filings to the State Board of Elections or, if applicable, the Board of Public Works. The bill centralizes these reporting requirements under the State Board of Elections and repeals previous requirements for businesses with State contracts to file a list with the Secretary of State.
responsible_party: State Board of Elections; Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Persons and businesses with contracts totaling $200,000 or more with the State of Maryland or its governmental entities, and the governmental entities themselves.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency by requiring detailed disclosure of beneficial ownership for businesses contracting with the state and centralizes reporting under the State Board of Elections. While beneficial ownership disclosure is a modern governance trend, the bill primarily reforms existing administrative and legal processes rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on transparency in public contracting and political contributions. It does not directly establish services, financial aid, or programs aimed at addressing child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, through improved governance or more efficient use of public funds, which is not a direct or immediate effect.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Horse Riding - Helmet Requirement for Minors
Synopsis: Prohibiting an adult from allowing certain minors to ride a horse, donkey, mule, or pony on a highway, a public horse-riding path, or the grounds of a facility for which the primary purpose is recreational, educational, therapeutic, or competitive equestrian activities unless the minor is wearing a properly secured helmet that meets or exceeds the standards of the American Society of Testing and Materials for protective headgear used in equestrian riding.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits an adult from allowing a minor to ride a horse on a highway, public horse-riding path or trail, or at a facility primarily for equestrian activities, unless the minor is wearing a properly secured helmet that meets or exceeds specific American Society of Testing and Materials (ASTM) standards. Exemptions apply to minors crossing public highways between private land, engaged in agricultural pursuits, members of Amish or Mennonite communities, or receiving therapy services from a licensed medical provider where an alternative helmet is deemed necessary and compliant with specific guidelines. A violation involving an adult supervising multiple minors simultaneously is treated as a single violation.
responsible_party: Adults supervising minors are directly responsible for compliance; enforcement falls under Maryland law enforcement agencies.
stakeholders: Minors who ride horses, adults who supervise minors riding horses, and facilities that offer equestrian activities to the public.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a new safety regulation for horse riding by minors, which is a standard legislative action focused on public safety. It does not employ new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's purpose is to enhance safety for minors engaged in horse riding activities through helmet requirements. It does not contain any provisions that directly address or are intended to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Victims' Rights - Notification of Release From Confinement (Jaycee Webster Victims' Rights Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a certain commitment unit to include in a notification given to a victim, victim's representative, or witness regarding the release from confinement of a sentenced defendant or child respondent the telephone number of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Jaycee Webster Victims' Rights Act, requires commitment units to include the telephone number of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center in notifications given to victims, victims' representatives, or witnesses regarding the release from confinement of a sentenced defendant or child respondent.
responsible_party: Commitment units (as defined in the Criminal Procedure Article)
stakeholders: Victims, victims' representatives, witnesses, sentenced defendants, and child respondents.
innovative_summary: This bill is a minor procedural update to existing victim notification protocols, specifically by requiring the inclusion of the Maryland Crime Victims Resource Center's telephone number. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on enhancing victims' rights through improved notification about offender release. While crime and its aftermath can indirectly impact families and children, this legislation does not directly address child poverty through economic support, educational programs, or other poverty-reduction strategies.

Title: Department of Natural Resources - Maryland Geological Survey Fund - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Geological Survey Fund to finance certain direct and indirect costs, including long-term budgeting and planning for survey projects, procurements, and equipment purchases; establishing the Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund in the Department of Natural Resources; and requiring interest earnings of the Fund to be credited to the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Geological Survey Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund within the Department of Natural Resources. The purpose of the fund is to finance the direct and indirect costs of administering the Maryland Geological Survey, including long-term budgeting, project planning, procurements, equipment purchases, and operational expenses. The fund will consist of money appropriated in the State budget, interest earnings, and other accepted money, with interest earnings being credited back to the fund rather than the State's General Fund. The Department of Natural Resources is responsible for administering the fund, and expenditures must be in accordance with the State Budget.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: The general public of Maryland, researchers, and industries involved in natural resource management, land use planning, geology, and related fields indirectly benefit from the sustained operations of the Maryland Geological Survey.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a dedicated fund for an existing state agency. While it improves financial management by creating a nonlapsing fund and ensuring interest earnings remain with the Survey, it does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services or public interaction. It is a standard financial mechanism for state operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a funding mechanism for the Maryland Geological Survey, an agency focused on geological, hydrographic, and resource surveys. This activity does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or specific interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Public Health - Giving Infants a Future Without Transmission (GIFT) Act
Synopsis: Altering certain HIV and syphilis reporting and testing requirements for hospitals and health care providers for pregnant women and newborns; providing that certain documents related to certain HIV and syphilis reports are not discoverable and are not admissible in evidence in any criminal or administrative action; and altering certain penalties related to the disclosure of personal identifying health information acquired for the purpose of HIV and AIDS reporting under certain provisions of law.
bill_summary: This bill updates HIV and syphilis testing and reporting requirements for pregnant women and newborns in Maryland, aiming to prevent mother-to-child transmission. It mandates health care providers to include pregnancy status in HIV reports and to submit additional blood samples from pregnant women at specific gestational stages and at delivery for syphilis testing. Hospitals must also determine the mother's syphilis status before discharging a newborn. The bill clarifies that these health reports are confidential and not admissible in criminal, civil, or administrative actions, and increases penalties for unauthorized disclosure of personal identifying health information related to these reports.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health (via the Secretary and local health officers), health care providers, and hospitals.
stakeholders: Pregnant women, newborns, individuals diagnosed with HIV or syphilis, health care providers, hospitals, and medical laboratories.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances existing public health protocols by refining reporting requirements and increasing testing frequency for HIV and syphilis in pregnant women and newborns. While it strengthens current practices to improve disease prevention, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally change government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill aims to improve the health outcomes of newborns by preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV and syphilis. Healthier children are less likely to incur significant medical costs and developmental challenges, which can indirectly reduce financial strain on families and contribute to greater economic stability. However, the bill does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, social services, or economic programs.

Title: Economic Development - Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation - Loans
Synopsis: Altering a certain loan program to authorize the Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation to provide loans of up to $10,000 for each seasonal full-time job; expanding eligibility for the Maryland Watermen's Microloan Program within the Corporation to include, starting July 1, 2025, individuals who are residents of the State and hold a commercial fishing license to catch finfish, crabs, clams, or oysters issued by the Potomac River Fisheries Commission; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies existing loan programs managed by the Maryland Agricultural and Resource–Based Industry Development Corporation (MARBIDCO). It authorizes MARBIDCO to provide loans up to $250,000 for eligible seafood processing projects, including for seasonal full-time jobs, and requires recipients to report annually on job creation/retention. It also expands eligibility for the Maryland Watermen’s Microloan Program to include Maryland residents holding commercial fishing licenses from the Potomac River Fisheries Commission, removes specific loan amount requirements, and appropriates $500,000 annually for fiscal years 2024 through 2026 to the Program.
responsible_party: Maryland Agricultural and Resource–Based Industry Development Corporation
stakeholders: Licensed seafood dealers, beginner watermen, generational watermen, other qualified commercial fishermen, individuals holding commercial fishing licenses from the Potomac River Fisheries Commission, and seafood processing businesses in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily refines and expands existing microloan programs for the seafood industry. While the core loan mechanism is traditional, the bill includes a notable provision for loan forgiveness tied to environmental benefits, specifically the return of oyster shells to the Department of Natural Resources or planting of spat-on-shell, which acts as a creative incentive for ecological restoration within an economic development program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides microloans and economic support to commercial fishermen and seafood processing businesses. By bolstering the financial stability and income-generating capacity of individuals and businesses in this sector, it can indirectly improve the economic well-being of families involved in the industry, potentially reducing instances of child poverty among these households. However, it is not designed as a direct intervention for child poverty.

Title: Division of Parole and Probation - Criteria for Earned Compliance Credit - Exception for Supervision Fees
Synopsis: Altering a certain condition regarding the payment of certain restitution, fines, and fees that a certain supervised individual must satisfy to accrue certain earned compliance credit while under the supervision of the Division of Parole and Probation in the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
bill_summary: This bill amends the conditions under which individuals under the supervision of the Division of Parole and Probation can earn compliance credit. Specifically, it creates an exception so that the non-payment of monthly supervision fees will no longer prevent a supervised individual from accruing earned compliance credit, provided they meet all other conditions, such as being current on restitution, fines, and community supervision requirements.
responsible_party: Division of Parole and Probation in the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals under the supervision of the Division of Parole and Probation, including those on probation, parole, or mandatory release supervision.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a regulatory adjustment to the criteria for an existing earned compliance credit system. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches, but rather refines existing policy within the correctional services framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill could have an indirect positive impact on child poverty by potentially shortening the period of supervision for individuals under parole or probation who might otherwise struggle to pay supervision fees. A reduced supervision period could allow for earlier and more stable reintegration into the workforce, thereby improving the financial stability of families and potentially lifting children out of poverty or preventing them from falling into it. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance or services to children or families.

Title: Courts – Military Records – Recordation and Inspection
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions of law relating to the recordation and inspection of certain military records kept by the clerk of a circuit court to authorize the clerk to keep an electronic record instead of a book to record and index the discharge papers of a person who has served in the uniformed services of the United States; and requiring the clerk to deny inspection of the electronic record except under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill alters existing laws regarding the recordation and inspection of military discharge papers kept by clerks of circuit courts in Maryland. It permits the use of electronic records in addition to physical books, clarifies who can inspect or obtain certified copies of these records, and mandates the redaction of Social Security numbers from all such records before inspection, especially when the request is made 70 years after recording.
responsible_party: Clerk of the Circuit Court of each county
stakeholders: Individuals who have served in the Uniformed Services of the United States, their relatives, attorneys, and parties involved in civil, administrative, or criminal proceedings.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the option for circuit court clerks to maintain military discharge records in electronic format, moving beyond traditional physical books. It also implements a privacy enhancement by requiring the redaction of Social Security numbers from these records.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the administrative process of recording and inspecting military service records and does not directly address or provide resources to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Public Health - Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program to authorize pharmacists to dispense nPEP under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to adopt regulations necessary for the administration of the Program and that address the needs of certain populations, including victims of sexual assault and pediatric patients; and authorizing the Department to administer the Program, collect certain fees, and establish guidelines for training related to the Program.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Nonoccupational Postexposure Prophylaxis (nPEP) Standing Order Program in Maryland. This program authorizes pharmacists and licensed health care providers to dispense nPEP, which is medication used to reduce the chance of developing HIV after potential exposure, under a standing order without a direct prescription. The Maryland Department of Health is responsible for administering the program, collecting fees, and establishing guidelines for training and patient education. The program aims to increase access to nPEP, particularly for specific populations like victims of sexual assault and pediatric patients, following CDC guidelines.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Members of the public who may have experienced nonoccupational exposure to HIV, including victims of sexual assault and pediatric patients, as well as pharmacists and licensed health care providers who will dispense and administer nPEP.
innovative_summary: The program is innovative in its approach to public health by expanding the authority of pharmacists and licensed healthcare providers to dispense nPEP directly through a standing order. This method streamlines access to critical preventative medication for HIV, bypassing traditional prescription requirements in specific circumstances, which represents a new approach to healthcare delivery and accessibility.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly addressing financial or social support for child poverty, the program's focus on preventing HIV infection, including for pediatric patients, offers a significant long-term health benefit. By reducing the incidence of HIV, it can indirectly alleviate potential health burdens and associated economic hardships that families, including those experiencing poverty, might face due to HIV infection. The inclusion of pediatric patients means it directly serves children's health needs, which is a foundational element for well-being and future economic stability.

Title: Housing Development Permit Applications - Local Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring local jurisdictions with at least 150,000 residents to report certain information for each building or development permit application that includes a residential housing component as part of the development to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Planning on or before July 1 each year; and requiring a local jurisdiction to make a copy of the report publicly available on its website.
bill_summary: This bill requires local jurisdictions in Maryland with at least 150,000 residents to annually report specific information about building and development permit applications that include a residential housing component to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the Department of Planning. The report must include details such as the total number of applications received, approved, and rejected by type, the net number of residential units approved, and mean/median processing times. Additionally, each local jurisdiction must make a copy of this report publicly available on its website.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development and Department of Planning
stakeholders: Local jurisdictions with 150,000 or more residents, housing developers and applicants, and the general public.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates standardized data collection and public transparency regarding housing development permit applications across major local jurisdictions. While data collection isn't new, requiring comprehensive, uniform reporting and public accessibility by state law for such a critical economic sector can promote data-driven policy and accountability, representing a modern approach to local governance oversight.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on transparency and data collection regarding housing development permits. While increased housing supply and efficient processing *could* indirectly affect housing affordability, which in turn might impact families experiencing poverty, the bill does not directly establish programs, provide services, or allocate funds specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty. Its impact is highly indirect and speculative.

Title: Employment Standards, Prevailing Wage, and Living Wage - Employer Adverse Actions and Enforcement
Synopsis: Prohibiting employers from taking or threatening to take adverse action against an employee because the employee takes certain actions regarding rights and responsibilities, complaints, investigations, proceedings, or hearings; authorizing the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, within 90 days after receipt of a written complaint, to investigate a violation and attempt to resolve the issue informally through mediation; etc.
bill_summary: The bill enhances employee protections in Maryland by prohibiting employers from taking adverse actions (like discharge, demotion, or discrimination) against employees who inquire about their rights, make complaints, or assist in investigations concerning employment standards, prevailing wage, or living wage laws. It consolidates and strengthens enforcement mechanisms, authorizing the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to investigate violations, issue orders for recovery of lost wages and damages, and assess civil penalties. It also provides for employee civil actions and penalties for groundless complaints.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Employers and employees in Maryland covered by employment standards, prevailing wage, and living wage laws.
innovative_summary: The bill consolidates and streamlines existing anti-retaliation provisions across various labor laws into a single, comprehensive section, and strengthens enforcement powers. While not employing new technologies, this consolidation and enhanced enforcement approach represents an improved, more consistent governmental approach to protecting worker rights.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to protect employee rights and ensure fair wages and working conditions, which can lead to greater income stability for families. While it does not directly target child poverty, by safeguarding parental employment and income, it indirectly contributes to reducing child poverty and improving family economic well-being.

Title: Civil Actions - Civil Immunity - Educator Intervention
Synopsis: Providing that a member of the administrative, educational, or support staff of any public, private, or parochial school, acting in an official capacity, is not civilly liable for personal injury or property damage resulting from intervention in a student altercation or other student disturbance if the staff member intervened in a reasonably prudent manner and the actions taken do not constitute grossly negligent, willful, wanton, or intentionally tortious conduct.
bill_summary: This bill grants civil immunity to administrative, educational, or support staff members of public, private, or parochial schools in Maryland. This immunity protects them from civil liability for personal injury or property damage resulting from their intervention in altercations between students or other student disturbances, provided they act in a reasonably prudent manner and their actions do not constitute grossly negligent, willful, wanton, or intentionally tortious conduct. The bill amends Section 5–803 of the Article – Courts and Judicial Proceedings.
responsible_party: Maryland legal system
stakeholders: Administrative, educational, and support staff of public, private, and parochial schools, as well as students and their families who may be involved in altercations or disturbances.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it primarily modifies legal liability for school staff within the existing legal framework, rather than introducing new technologies, services, or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It focuses on civil immunity for school staff in intervention scenarios and does not provide financial assistance, services, or policy changes directly aimed at alleviating poverty.

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Notice of Utility Bills in Residential Leases - Gas and Electric Services
Synopsis: Adding gas and electric utility services to the types of services for which landlords of buildings that contain six or more residential units are required to provide a written notice to a tenant, before the initiation of a lease and each term thereafter, notifying the tenant of the total utility costs billed to the landlord in the immediately preceding year, disaggregated by utility type; and applying certain requirements relating to payment of utility services to landlords of buildings that contain five or fewer residential dwelling units.
bill_summary: This bill expands existing landlord requirements in residential leases to provide notice of utility bills to tenants, now including gas and electric services in addition to water and sewer. It clarifies different requirements for landlords based on the number of units in a building: those with six or more units must notify tenants in writing of total utility costs from the preceding year (disaggregated by utility type) or provide a copy of the bill, while those with five or fewer units must provide a copy of the utility bill. The bill's original intent to involve the Office of Home Energy Programs for financial assistance was removed.
responsible_party: Landlords
stakeholders: Landlords and tenants in residential dwelling units where landlords are responsible for collecting payments for water, sewer, gas, or electric utility services.
innovative_summary: This bill updates and clarifies existing landlord-tenant regulations regarding utility disclosures. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government services or operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill increases transparency for tenants regarding utility costs by requiring landlords to provide detailed information or copies of utility bills. While this improved transparency could potentially help families budget more effectively and avoid unexpected expenses, thereby indirectly benefiting low-income families, it does not directly provide financial aid, services, or programs specifically aimed at reducing child poverty. The direct financial assistance component was removed from the bill.

Title: Condominiums - Sales Contracts - Asbestos Disclosure
Synopsis: Establishing the unenforceability of contracts for the sale of condominium units that do not contain a statement by the vendor or unit owner as to whether the vendor or unit owner has actual knowledge of the presence of asbestos in the condominium, including a description of the location of the asbestos, whether abatement has been performed, and the date of any abatement.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland law concerning condominium sales contracts to require new disclosures regarding asbestos. For initial sales, vendors must disclose actual knowledge of asbestos on the site, including its location, abatement status, and date. For resales, unit owners must disclose their knowledge of asbestos in the unit, its location, and abatement history during their occupancy. Additionally, the council of unit owners must disclose its knowledge of asbestos on site. Contracts lacking these required disclosures will be unenforceable. The bill updates the format of the notice provided to purchasers to include these asbestos-related statements.
responsible_party: Condominium vendors and unit owners (sellers) are responsible for providing the disclosures; Maryland courts and real estate regulatory bodies are responsible for enforcement and oversight.
stakeholders: Purchasers and sellers of condominium units in Maryland, condominium developers, and condominium associations.
innovative_summary: This bill updates existing real estate disclosure laws by adding specific requirements for asbestos information in condominium sales contracts. While crucial for public health and consumer protection, it represents an amendment to established legal frameworks rather than a novel technological or governmental approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on real estate transaction disclosures for condominiums and does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or opportunities specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any potential health benefits are indirect and not targeted at this demographic.

Title: Public Employee Relations Act – Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions of the Public Employee Relations Act, including adding the definition of interested employee organization, altering the timing of exclusive representative access to new employees, clarifying the responsibilities of certain deputy directors, and clarifying the process for certain investigations of unfair labor practices.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Public Employee Relations Act to alter various provisions. Key changes include defining an "interested employee organization," adjusting the timing for exclusive representatives to access new employees, clarifying the responsibilities of deputy directors within the Public Employee Relations Board, and refining the process for investigating unfair labor practices. The changes aim to update and clarify existing labor relations procedures for public employees.
responsible_party: Public Employee Relations Board; Deputy Directors for Executive Branch, public school, and public higher education labor relations
stakeholders: Public employees, employee organizations (unions), and public employers (State, community colleges, county boards of education, Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners).
innovative_summary: This bill makes primarily administrative and procedural changes to an existing act governing public employee relations. It refines definitions, clarifies responsibilities, and updates processes (e.g., electronic notification for new employees) but does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally innovative approaches to government services or programs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on refining labor relations processes for public employees. While better labor relations could potentially lead to improved wages or working conditions for some public employees, which might indirectly benefit their families and children, the bill does not directly establish programs, allocate funds, or provide services specifically aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Health Occupations Boards – Reciprocal Licensure and Certification
Synopsis: Authorizing certain health occupations boards to adopt regulations establishing reciprocity for individuals licensed or certified in another state.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes certain Maryland health occupations boards to create regulations for reciprocal licensure or certification. This means that individuals licensed or certified in another state can become licensed in Maryland if the other state offers similar reciprocity, and if their qualifications are deemed substantially equivalent to Maryland's requirements. Applicants must be in good standing, submit an application, pay a fee, and meet any other board-established requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Occupations Boards
stakeholders: Individuals licensed or certified in health occupations in other states, current Maryland health occupations licensees, and the general public who may benefit from an increased pool of healthcare providers.
innovative_summary: This bill streamlines professional licensing across state lines for health occupations by allowing boards to establish reciprocity. While not employing new technologies, it uses a standardized regulatory approach to potentially increase the availability of healthcare professionals by reducing barriers to practice for those already certified in other states. This is an administrative improvement rather than a novel technological or policy approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill facilitates the licensure of healthcare professionals, which could indirectly improve access to healthcare services for all residents, including families with children. Improved access to healthcare could have a long-term, indirect positive impact on the well-being of families and children, potentially alleviating some stressors that contribute to poverty. However, it does not directly target child poverty through financial assistance, educational programs, or direct support.

Title: Tobacco Tax Stamp Refunds - Loss Due to Theft
Synopsis: Authorizing a claimant who buys tobacco tax stamps to receive a refund for tobacco tax stamps affixed to stolen property; requiring the claimant to provide the Comptroller with certain documentation when making a claim for a refund; and providing for a fine for making a false claim of double the amount of any tax refund in addition to any other authorized penalties.
bill_summary: This bill amends existing law to allow claimants who purchase tobacco tax stamps to receive a refund for stamps affixed to property that has been stolen. To claim a refund, the claimant must provide the Comptroller with a copy of the police report detailing the stolen property and a notarized affidavit attesting to the truthfulness of the claim. The bill also imposes a fine of double the refund amount for making a false claim. If stolen property is recovered, the claimant must notify the Comptroller and return any received refund.
responsible_party: Comptroller
stakeholders: Claimants (primarily businesses) who purchase tobacco tax stamps and experience loss due to theft, as well as the Comptroller's office.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative change to existing tax law by expanding the criteria for tobacco tax stamp refunds to include losses due to theft. It introduces new documentation requirements for these specific refund claims, but does not involve new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on tax stamp refunds for businesses or individuals who have experienced theft of tobacco products. It does not provide any direct services, financial aid, or policy changes aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Medical Records - Destruction - Notice and Retrieval
Synopsis: Extending the time period from 5 to 7 years during which a health care provider is prohibited from destroying medical records and laboratory and X-ray reports; requiring that the notice required to be provided regarding the destruction of medical records be made to the last known e-mail address of the patient or the parent or guardian of a minor; requiring a health care provider to make a medical record available for retrieval by a patient or a parent or guardian of a minor within a certain time period and at a certain location; etc.
bill_summary: This bill extends the time period health care providers must retain medical records and laboratory and X-ray reports from 5 years to 7 years. For minor patients, records must be kept until the patient reaches the age of majority plus 7 years. It requires that notices regarding the proposed destruction of medical records be sent by both first-class mail and e-mail. It also mandates that if authorization for destruction is given, health care providers must make records available for retrieval by the patient or guardian within 60 days before the proposed destruction date at a designated location.
responsible_party: Secretary of Health (for regulations), Health Care Providers (for implementation)
stakeholders: Health care providers, patients, minor patients, and parents or guardians of minor patients.
innovative_summary: The bill updates the communication method for medical record destruction notices to include email, which is a minor modernization in administrative procedures. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily focuses on the retention and destruction procedures for medical records, ensuring patients, including minors, or their guardians, have extended access to these records. While access to medical history is important, this bill does not directly provide services, financial aid, or programs specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Charles County Board of Education - Vacancy Procedures - Timing and Video Streaming and Archiving
Synopsis: Requiring the Charles County Board of Education to fill a vacancy on the county board within 90 days after the vacancy occurs; authorizing the Board to choose not to fill a vacancy that occurs in an election year for a seat that is vacant; and requiring the county board to make publicly available through its website live video streaming and complete video recordings of public meetings during which the county board conducts interviews of applicants for a vacancy on the county board.
bill_summary: This bill amends procedures for the Charles County Board of Education regarding vacancies. It requires the board to fill vacancies within 90 days, with an exception for vacancies occurring in an election year for the specific seat. The bill also mandates that the board live stream and archive video recordings of public meetings where applicants for board vacancies are interviewed, and publish applicant names and interview schedules in advance to enhance transparency.
responsible_party: Charles County Board of Education
stakeholders: Citizens of Charles County, particularly those interested in local education governance, potential applicants for board vacancies, and students within the Charles County Public Schools system.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances governmental transparency and public access by mandating live video streaming and archiving of specific public meetings on the Charles County Board of Education's website. While the technology (video streaming) itself is not new, its application to improve accountability and public engagement in local government processes represents a modern and positive approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the procedural aspects of filling vacancies on a local school board and increasing transparency in that process. It does not establish any direct programs, funding, or services aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, through potentially improved governance leading to better educational outcomes, but this is not a direct mechanism.

Title: Medical Records - Fees - Attorneys Representing Patients
Synopsis: Adding an attorney representing a patient to the list of individuals to whom a health care provider is prohibited from charging a fee for providing copies of a medical record that will be used for the purpose of filing a claim regarding or appealing a denial of Social Security disability income or Social Security benefits.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland law to prohibit health care providers from charging a fee for copies of medical records when an attorney, representing a patient, requests those records. This fee waiver applies specifically when the records are needed to file a claim for Social Security disability income or other Social Security benefits, or to appeal a denial of such benefits.
responsible_party: Health care providers
stakeholders: Patients seeking Social Security disability income or benefits, their attorneys, and health care providers.
innovative_summary: This bill expands an existing fee waiver for medical records to include attorneys representing patients for Social Security benefit claims. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or novel governmental approaches, but rather adjusts an existing regulatory framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly providing aid to children, this bill removes a financial barrier for families seeking Social Security disability income or other benefits. By making it easier and less costly to obtain necessary medical records, it facilitates access to a critical income stream for households, which can indirectly help alleviate child poverty by stabilizing family finances.

Title: Homeowners' and Homestead Property Tax Credits - Application Filing Deadline - Extension
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Department of Assessments and Taxation to accept an application for the homeowners' property tax credit submitted by a homeowner within 3 years after April 15 of the taxable year for which the credit is sought if the homeowner is enrolled in the Homeowner Protection Program; and providing for the calculation of the homestead property tax credit for certain homeowners under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill extends the application filing deadline for the homeowners' property tax credit for individuals enrolled in the Homeowner Protection Program and for certain homeowners who are at least 70 years old. It also modifies the calculation of the homestead property tax credit for certain homeowners aged 70 or older who missed filing applications in previous years, specifically for taxable years beginning after June 30, 2022, with this specific provision abrogating on June 30, 2025. The changes aim to ensure eligible homeowners receive their property tax credits.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: Maryland homeowners, particularly those enrolled in the Homeowner Protection Program and homeowners aged 70 or older.
innovative_summary: The bill makes administrative adjustments to existing property tax credit programs by extending deadlines and modifying calculation rules for specific eligible groups. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill could have an indirect, minor impact on child poverty by ensuring eligible families with children receive property tax credits they might otherwise miss, thus freeing up household income. However, it is not directly targeted at addressing child poverty with new funding or programs, but rather at improving access to existing benefits.

Title: Common Ownership Communities - Electric Vehicle Recharging Equipment (Electric Vehicle Recharging Equipment Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Altering certain requirements for procedures relating to electric vehicle recharging equipment; establishing requirements and procedures relating to an application to the governing body of a cooperative housing corporation to install or use electric vehicle recharging equipment; and requiring the Department of Housing and Community Development to publish information on its common ownership community website regarding requirements, contractor information, certain points of contact, and resources on dispute resolutions.
bill_summary: The Electric Vehicle Recharging Equipment Act of 2024 updates Maryland law to facilitate the installation and use of electric vehicle recharging equipment in common ownership communities, which include condominiums, cooperative housing corporations, and homeowners associations. It expands the definition of electric vehicle recharging equipment to cover electric bicycles, establishes specific application and approval procedures for cooperative housing corporations, and requires the Department of Housing and Community Development to publish relevant information, including regulatory summaries and contractor details, on its common ownership community website.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Residents and governing bodies of condominiums, cooperative housing corporations, and homeowners associations; owners of electric vehicles and electric bicycles; and contractors and insurers involved in electric vehicle recharging equipment installation.
innovative_summary: This bill provides regulatory updates to accommodate the growing use of electric vehicles and electric bicycles by clarifying installation processes in common ownership communities. It mandates the Department of Housing and Community Development to provide informational resources online, which is a standard governmental practice for disseminating new regulations. While it supports modern infrastructure, the approaches taken (regulatory adjustments and online information dissemination) are not highly innovative in terms of new technologies or groundbreaking governmental methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on regulatory adjustments to facilitate the installation of electric vehicle recharging equipment in residential communities. This policy change does not have a direct or immediate impact on reducing child poverty.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Driver's Licenses, Learner's Instructional Permits, and Identification Cards
Synopsis: Exempting certain applicants for identification cards who present certain documentation from the issuance fee for the identification card; extending the term of certain learner's instructional permits from 180 days to 1 year after the date of issuance; and establishing that certain driver's licenses issued to certain holders by the Motor Vehicle Administration remain in full force and effect during an absence from the State.
bill_summary: This bill makes several changes to Maryland's vehicle laws. It exempts certain applicants from paying the fee for an identification card, including individuals aged 65 or older, those with certain disabilities, individuals recently released from correctional facilities, youth under the care of the Department of Juvenile Services, youth participating in Department of Human Services programs, homeless individuals, and those under the care of the Maryland Department of Health. The bill also extends the validity of certain learner's instructional permits from 180 days to 1 year and clarifies that driver's licenses for active-duty military members and their dependents, as well as certain federal contract employees and their dependents, remain valid during absences from the State.
responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration, Department of Juvenile Services, Department of Human Services, Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Applicants for identification cards (especially seniors, disabled individuals, recently incarcerated, youth in DJS/DHS programs, homeless individuals, and those under MDH care), individuals seeking certain learner's instructional permits, members of the armed forces and their dependents, and federal contract employees and their dependents.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily updates existing regulations and modifies administrative processes for driver's licenses and identification cards. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches, focusing instead on adjusting eligibility and terms for existing services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has the potential to directly impact child poverty by removing a financial barrier (the identification card fee) for vulnerable youth, including those under the care of the Department of Juvenile Services and participants in Department of Human Services programs (ages 15-20), as well as homeless individuals. Access to a valid ID is crucial for accessing employment, housing, education, and social services, which can indirectly but significantly alleviate poverty for families and older youth.

Title: Local Government – Annual Audit Reporting Requirements – Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring 20% of certain State aid for highway user revenues and disparity grants to be discontinued if a county, municipality, or special taxing district does not submit a certain audit report within 2 calendar years after the deadline for the report, subject to a certain condition; and applying the Act beginning with the fiscal year 2024 audits that are required to be submitted under certain provisions of law.
bill_summary: This bill mandates the discontinuance of 20% of certain State aid (police aid, highway user revenues, and disparity grants) for counties, municipalities, and special taxing districts that fail to submit their required annual audit reports within two calendar years after the deadline. Previously, this action was discretionary. The bill also specifies conditions for the reinstatement of funds once the report is submitted and outlines that discontinued funds for a fiscal year in which the report was due will revert to the State's General Fund or Transportation Trust Fund.
responsible_party: Comptroller; Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services
stakeholders: Counties, municipalities, and special taxing districts in Maryland
innovative_summary: This bill primarily alters existing administrative penalties and reporting requirements for local governments. It does not introduce new technologies, novel service delivery methods, or significantly new approaches to governance, but rather strengthens enforcement of existing financial oversight by making discontinuance of funds mandatory under certain conditions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on local government audit compliance and the discontinuation of State aid as a penalty for non-compliance. It does not directly address or target child poverty. While local government funding can indirectly support services that might benefit children, this bill's impact is on financial accountability, not direct poverty alleviation programs.

Title: Department of State Police - Professional Occupations - Application Process
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of State Police to determine the manner and format for applications for certification as a private detective, security guard, security systems technician, and railroad police officer and for a license to provide security guard services; altering the application requirements related to security guard agency, private detective agency, and security systems agency licenses and commercial general liability insurance; requiring an applicant for a special police commission to submit two sets of fingerprints; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Secretary of State Police to determine the manner and format for applications and renewals for certification as a private detective, security guard, security systems technician, and railroad police officer, and for licenses to provide security guard services. It modifies application requirements for security guard, private detective, and security systems agencies, including altering commercial general liability insurance requirements for security guard agencies to apply to those employing one or more individuals (previously five). Additionally, applicants for a special police commission are now required to submit two sets of fingerprints in a specified format.
responsible_party: Secretary of State Police
stakeholders: Individuals seeking certification or licensure as private detectives, security guards, security systems technicians, and railroad police officers, as well as private detective agencies, security guard agencies, security systems agencies, and their employers in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces administrative flexibility by allowing the Secretary of State Police to designate the "manner and format" for applications and renewals, moving away from static forms. It also explicitly permits electronic transmission of notices, which suggests a modernization towards potentially digital and more streamlined administrative processes for professional licensing.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on professional licensing and administrative procedures for private security and investigative occupations. It does not include any direct provisions such as financial assistance, expanded social services, or direct programmatic interventions that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: Vehicle Towing or Removal - Insurer of Record - Electronic Notification
Synopsis: Authorizing a person who undertakes the towing or removal of a vehicle from a parking lot to notify the insurer of record electronically if that form of notice is agreed to by the tower and the insurer of record in a certain manner.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes towing companies to notify the insurer of record electronically after a vehicle has been towed from a parking lot, provided that the towing company and the insurer have mutually agreed to this form of electronic communication.
responsible_party: Private towing companies and vehicle insurers
stakeholders: Vehicle owners, towing companies, and vehicle insurers
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the option for electronic notification between towing companies and insurers, modernizing the communication process for vehicle towing incidents. This enhances efficiency by moving away from traditional certified mail for this specific notification.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative and procedural changes related to vehicle towing notifications and does not directly address or impact issues related to child poverty.

Title: Hospitals - Care of Infants After Discharge (Safe Sleep Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Requiring a hospital, as soon as practicable before discharging an infant after the birth of the infant, to provide oral and written resources to the parent or legal guardian; requiring a hospital, before discharging an infant, to ask the parent or legal guardian to describe the sleep environment that will be provided at home; requiring, by January 1, 2025, each hospital to establish a process for providing resources and information about safe sleep environments to parents and legal guardians of infants;  etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Safe Sleep Act of 2024, requires hospitals to provide oral and written educational resources to parents or legal guardians before discharging an infant after birth. These resources must cover how to provide a safe sleep environment, avoid shaken baby syndrome, and cope with crying infants. Hospitals must also inquire about a parent's ability to provide a safe sleep environment and offer a list of resources to obtain necessary items if they cannot. The Maryland Department of Health, in consultation with local health officers, is mandated to develop and update a list of county-specific resources for safe sleep items. Hospitals must establish a process for providing these resources and confirming their receipt by January 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health; Local Health Departments; Hospitals
stakeholders: Infants; Parents and legal guardians of newborns
innovative_summary: The program standardizes and mandates the provision of safe sleep education and resources to new parents by hospitals, and requires the Maryland Department of Health to compile a list of available resources. While important for public health, it does not employ new technologies or a novel governmental approach, but rather formalizes and coordinates existing best practices and resource dissemination.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a direct impact on child poverty by requiring hospitals to provide resources, including a list of where to obtain bassinets, cribs, or portable cribs, to parents or legal guardians who cannot provide a safe sleep environment. This directly addresses a potential financial barrier for low-income families in ensuring their infant has a safe sleep space, alleviating a specific cost burden and promoting infant health and safety.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Disabled Veteran Registration Plates - Issuance
Synopsis: Authorizing the Motor Vehicle Administration to issue certain special disabled veteran registration plates to disabled veterans who are between 50% and 99%, inclusive, service-connected disabled as designated or classified by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs; prohibiting the Administration from charging certain persons the fee required for replacement registration plates under certain circumstances; etc.
