bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) to issue special disabled veteran registration plates to armed forces veterans who are between 50% and 99%, inclusive, service-connected disabled, as designated by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. It specifies the types of vehicles eligible and clarifies that these plates will not display the international symbol of access. The MVA will charge standard registration fees but no additional fee for the special plates. The bill also outlines procedures for plate transfer upon vehicle ownership change and exempts certain transferees, including spouses of qualified veterans, from replacement plate fees under specific circumstances. The MVA is authorized to adopt necessary regulations.
responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
stakeholders: Armed Forces veterans who are between 50% and 99% service-connected disabled, and their spouses, in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program is not particularly innovative, as it primarily introduces a new category of special registration plates and adjusts related administrative fees and transfer rules within existing MVA processes. It does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services, but rather expands an existing type of benefit (special license plates) to a specific group of veterans.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a very low potential for direct impact on child poverty. It provides a non-monetary benefit (special license plates) and minor fee exemptions to disabled veterans, which might offer some indirect financial relief to their households, but it is not designed as a direct intervention or support program to address child poverty.

Title: Human Services - Food Supplement Program and Human Services Careers Scholarships - Alterations
Synopsis: Making technical and clarifying changes to the administration of certain food supplement benefits for children; authorizing the Department of Human Services to use certain funding to provide certain matching funds to a county to supplement certain benefits and to offset certain administrative costs; altering certain eligibility and certain requirements for the Pilot Program for Human Services Careers Scholarships; and authorizing the Maryland Higher Education Commission to prorate scholarship repayment under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill makes technical and clarifying changes to the administration of food supplement benefits for children, authorizing the Department of Human Services (DHS) to use funding to provide matching funds to counties for benefit supplements and to offset administrative costs of the federal Summer Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) program. It also alters eligibility criteria and requirements for the Pilot Program for Human Services Careers Scholarships, including revising the service obligation period and allowing the Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) to prorate scholarship repayment under certain circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services and Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Children under 19 and their households receiving food supplement benefits, counties administering food supplement programs, and students pursuing careers in human services through the scholarship program.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily focuses on administrative and technical adjustments to existing programs. While it supports the federal Summer EBT program, which utilizes modern benefit delivery methods, the bill itself does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking government approaches. Its innovation lies more in improving flexibility and efficiency within current systems.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty by making technical and clarifying changes to the Food Supplement Program, which directly provides financial assistance for food to low-income families. Authorizing funds to offset administrative costs for the federal Summer EBT program also directly supports efforts to provide food benefits to children during school breaks, thereby alleviating food insecurity and child poverty.

Title: Eastern Shore Code Counties - Maximum Hotel Rental Tax Rate - Alteration
Synopsis: Increasing, from 5% to 6%, the maximum hotel rental tax rate that counties in the Eastern Shore class of code counties may impose.
bill_summary: The bill increases the maximum hotel rental tax rate that Eastern Shore code counties in Maryland may impose from a potential 3% or 5% to 6% when unanimously approved by county commissioners. It amends Section 20-405 of the Article – Local Government.
responsible_party: Maryland General Assembly (legislative role in granting local authority)
stakeholders: Hotel operators, tourists, and local governments in Eastern Shore code counties.
innovative_summary: This bill is a conventional legislative act that modifies an existing local tax rate. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is minimal. It modifies a hotel rental tax rate, which is an indirect tax on travelers. Any potential benefits for child poverty would be indirect, highly contingent on whether counties choose to raise the tax and how they allocate any additional revenue, which is not specified or mandated by this bill.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Personal Care Aides - Wage Reports
Synopsis: Requiring residential service agencies to submit certain reports to the Maryland Department of Labor regarding wage rates for personal care aides on or before September 1 each year, beginning in 2025; and requiring the Maryland Department of Health to report to certain committees of the General Assembly by the 180th day after the release of the final federal Ensuring Access to Medicaid Services rule on an overview of the final rule and plans or steps that the Department will take to operationalize the rule.
bill_summary: This bill requires residential service agencies to annually submit reports on personal care aide wage rates to the Maryland Department of Labor, beginning in 2025. It also mandates that the Maryland Department of Health report to the General Assembly within 180 days of the final federal Ensuring Access to Medicaid Services rule, detailing an overview of the rule, the Department's operationalization plans, and how personal care aide wage data will be used to review Medicaid reimbursement rates.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor, Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Personal care aides, residential service agencies, individuals receiving home- and community-based services under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program
innovative_summary: The bill establishes standard reporting requirements for residential service agencies and mandates a report from a state department in response to federal regulations. It does not introduce new technologies or employ novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on administrative reporting of personal care aide wages and the Department of Health's response to federal Medicaid rules. While changes to aide wages or Medicaid reimbursement could indirectly affect families' incomes, the bill itself does not directly provide financial assistance or services targeted at reducing child poverty.

Title: Anne Arundel County - Speed Limits - Establishment
Synopsis: Authorizing Anne Arundel County and municipalities in Anne Arundel County to decrease the maximum speed limit to not less than 15 miles per hour on highways after performing an engineering and traffic investigation; and prohibiting Anne Arundel County and municipalities in Anne Arundel County from implementing a new speed monitoring system to enforce speed limits on highways on which the speed limit has been reduced under the Act.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Anne Arundel County and its municipalities to decrease the maximum speed limit on highways to not less than 15 miles per hour, provided an engineering and traffic investigation is conducted. It also prohibits the implementation of new speed monitoring systems (speed cameras) to enforce speed limits on highways where the limit has been reduced under this Act. Previously, this specific authority to reduce limits to 15 mph was only explicitly granted to Montgomery County.
responsible_party: Anne Arundel County and municipalities in Anne Arundel County
stakeholders: Drivers and residents in Anne Arundel County and its municipalities
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It is a regulatory change that extends existing powers regarding speed limit setting to another county, along with a restriction on speed monitoring systems in those specific instances.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not have a direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on traffic regulation and speed limits.

Title: Public Safety - Missing Persons - Purple Alert Program
Synopsis: Establishing a Purple Alert Program to disseminate information to assist in locating a certain missing person who has a cognitive impairment, mental disorder, intellectual or developmental disability, or brain injury; requiring the Department of State Police to adopt guidelines and develop procedures for issuing a Purple Alert; and authorizing the Department to consult with relevant stakeholders representing citizens with disabilities to develop procedures for the program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Purple Alert Program in Maryland, managed by the Department of State Police, to rapidly disseminate information to help locate missing persons. This program targets individuals whose whereabouts are unknown, who have a cognitive impairment, mental disorder, intellectual or developmental disability, or a brain injury (excluding certain conditions), or who are deaf, deafblind, hard of hearing, or late-deafened, and whose disappearance poses a credible threat. It specifically excludes individuals who meet the criteria for a Silver Alert. The program involves developing guidelines, training law enforcement, coordinating with the State Highway Administration for message signs, and consulting with the State Department of Education to allow high school students to assist in searches.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
stakeholders: Missing persons with cognitive impairments, mental disorders, intellectual or developmental disabilities, brain injuries, or who are deaf, deafblind, hard of hearing, or late-deafened; their caregivers; local law enforcement agencies; public and commercial television and radio broadcasters; local volunteer groups; the State Highway Administration; the State Department of Education; and high school students.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes existing alert infrastructure, such as dynamic message signs and media dissemination, which are not inherently new technologies. However, its specific focus on a distinct and broad category of vulnerable missing persons (beyond just those with Alzheimer's/dementia covered by Silver Alerts) and the unique inclusion of a structured program for high school students to assist in searches, guided by service-learning guidelines, represent a moderately innovative approach to community engagement in public safety initiatives.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on public safety by establishing a program to locate missing vulnerable individuals. While a missing person could potentially be a child from a low-income household, the program's direct purpose is not to address or alleviate child poverty through economic support, educational resources, or social services. Its impact on child poverty would be indirect at best, primarily through ensuring the safety and reunification of a missing child.

Title: Unemployment Insurance - Work Search Requirement - Exemption for Federal Civilian Employees During a Federal Government Shutdown
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of Labor to exempt a federal civilian employee who has been furloughed from the requirement to be actively seeking work for unemployment insurance benefits eligibility if, during the furlough, the employee remains able to work, available for work, and work-attached.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Secretary of Labor to exempt federal civilian employees who have been furloughed during a federal government shutdown from the requirement to actively seek work to be eligible for unemployment insurance benefits. This exemption applies if the employee remains able to work, available for work, and work-attached during the furlough period.
responsible_party: Secretary of Labor
stakeholders: Federal civilian employees in Maryland who are furloughed due to a full or partial federal government shutdown caused by a lapse in federal appropriations.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legislative adjustment to existing unemployment insurance eligibility rules to address a specific scenario (federal government shutdown). It does not introduce new technologies or particularly innovative approaches to government services; it's a practical modification to an existing system.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly targeting child poverty programs, this bill provides a crucial safety net for federal civilian employees and their families during a government shutdown. By allowing furloughed employees to receive unemployment benefits without the work search requirement, it helps stabilize household income, which can indirectly prevent families, including those with children, from experiencing financial hardship or falling into poverty during temporary unemployment.

Title: Transportation - WMATA Operating Assistance - Alteration (Maryland Metro Funding Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Repealing, for certain fiscal years, the requirement that the Secretary of Transportation withhold 35% of the State's share of annual operating grants for the Washington Suburban Transit District if the State's operating assistance provided in the approved Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority budget increases by more than 3% over the total operating assistance provided in the prior fiscal year.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Maryland Metro Funding Act of 2024, alters the conditions under which the Maryland Secretary of Transportation can withhold a portion of annual operating grants for the Washington Suburban Transit District. It repeals a previous requirement for withholding if WMATA's operating assistance increases by more than 3% (effective beginning in fiscal year 2028). Instead, it establishes new conditions for withholding 35% of funds: if the WMATA Board Chairman has served for at least two prior years or represents the same jurisdiction as the previous chairman for the two preceding years, or if the Purple Line is in service but not included on WMATA station maps.
responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of Transportation
stakeholders: The Washington Suburban Transit District, the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA), and commuters in the Maryland portion of WMATA's service area.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily adjusts administrative rules for state funding to a regional transit authority. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government. The changes are largely regulatory concerning financial management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill modifies financial withholding rules for public transit operating grants. While access to public transportation can indirectly benefit low-income families by providing access to jobs and services, these specific administrative changes to funding conditions are unlikely to have a direct, measurable impact on child poverty. The bill does not establish new programs or direct financial assistance to individuals or families.

Title: Community Schools - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain requirements for community schools and community school coordinators; requiring the Director of Community Schools to create a common needs assessment tool and an evaluation form; requiring a community school coordinator to complete a needs assessment and an evaluation in a certain manner; requiring the State Department of Education to provide feedback on the needs assessment before granting approval; and requiring the coordinator to review and modify the plan implementation periodically.
bill_summary: This bill modifies requirements for community schools and community school coordinators in Maryland. It mandates the Director of Community Schools to create a common needs assessment tool and an evaluation form, which community school coordinators must use for annual evaluations and needs assessments. The State Department of Education will provide comments on community school implementation plans, which coordinators are required to periodically review and modify. The bill also alters the percentage of existing Concentration of Poverty School Grant Program funds that local school systems with fewer than 40 eligible schools can expend on behalf of those schools, reducing it from 50% to 10% for both personnel and per-pupil grants, and requires prioritization of funding for areas of greatest need in the per-pupil grant.
responsible_party: State Department of Education (Director of Community Schools) and the Accountability and Implementation Board
stakeholders: Students, families, educators, community members, community school coordinators, local school systems, and community-based organizations/agencies involved with community schools.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances accountability and standardization within the existing community school framework by requiring a common needs assessment tool and evaluation form. It formalizes review processes for implementation plans. While these are positive steps for program efficacy, they do not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new government approaches, but rather improve the operational efficiency and data collection of an established program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has an indirect potential impact on child poverty. By improving the structure and accountability of community schools, especially through standardized needs assessments and evaluations, it aims to ensure resources are more effectively targeted to students in high-poverty schools who need wraparound services. This enhancement of support for educational and social services can help mitigate "out-of-school barriers" and promote "inclusive student achievement," which are critical factors in addressing the root causes and consequences of child poverty, even if it is not a direct financial intervention.

Title: Education – Coaches – Mental Health Training
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Education to develop guidelines for public schools and the Maryland Higher Education Commission to develop guidelines for public institutions of higher education to train coaches to recognize indicators of mental illness and behavioral distress in students who participate in athletic programs in public schools and public institutions of higher education; requiring public schools and public institutions that offer athletic programs to provide a certain training to coaches; etc.
bill_summary: This bill mandates that the State Department of Education and the Maryland Higher Education Commission, in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health and other relevant bodies, develop guidelines for training coaches in public schools and public institutions of higher education. The training will equip coaches to recognize indicators of mental illness and behavioral distress in students, including depression, trauma, violence, youth suicide, and substance abuse. Subsequently, all public schools and public institutions of higher education offering athletic programs must provide this mental health training to their coaches.
responsible_party: State Department of Education, Maryland Department of Health, Maryland Higher Education Commission, county boards of education, and the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association
stakeholders: Coaches and students participating in athletic programs at public schools and public institutions of higher education in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program is innovative in its proactive and integrated approach to student mental health. By mandating mental health training for athletic coaches across public schools and higher education, it leverages a unique and influential group within students' lives to serve as frontline observers for mental illness and behavioral distress. This systematic, statewide integration of mental health awareness into athletic programs represents a modern approach to student well-being.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program does not directly address child poverty. Its focus is on the mental health and behavioral well-being of all students involved in athletic programs. While mental health support can indirectly benefit children from low-income backgrounds by removing barriers to success, the bill does not provide financial aid, resources, or specific interventions targeted at alleviating poverty itself.

Title: Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission
Synopsis: Establishing the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission to develop recommendations relating to education and its impact on the criminal justice system; and requiring the Commission to submit an interim report of its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by June 1, 2025, and a final report by January 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission to develop recommendations regarding education and its impact on the criminal justice system, focusing on strategies to increase public safety and reduce recidivism among adult offenders.
responsible_party: Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission (with staff support from the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services)
stakeholders: Individuals involved in the criminal and juvenile justice systems, including incarcerated individuals and adult offenders, as well as the broader public through improved public safety and reduced recidivism.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a commission to undertake a comprehensive, data-driven review of prison education, aiming to develop a statewide policy framework. It emphasizes researching best practices and involves a broad advisory group with diverse expertise, representing a structured and thorough approach to policy reform rather than technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving education and employment opportunities for individuals within the criminal and juvenile justice systems, primarily adults. While successful reintegration and employment of formerly incarcerated parents could indirectly benefit their children and reduce child poverty, the bill does not directly target child poverty or provide services to children or families in poverty.

Title: Business Regulation - Contractors, Subcontractors, and Brokers - Prohibited Conduct
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from serving or acting as a contractor, a subcontractor, or a broker between a contractor and subcontractor during the 5-year period immediately following the date the person was convicted of an offense constituting criminal malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance under any federal or State law.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits any person from serving or acting as a contractor, subcontractor, or broker between a contractor and subcontractor in Maryland for a 5-year period if they have been convicted of an offense constituting criminal malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance under federal or state law.
responsible_party: Not specified, but likely relevant state business regulatory bodies responsible for enforcing business conduct laws.
stakeholders: Contractors, subcontractors, and brokers in Maryland, particularly those with past convictions for criminal malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance.
innovative_summary: This bill is a standard regulatory amendment to business law, prohibiting individuals with certain criminal convictions from working in specific roles. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on business regulation by restricting certain individuals from working as contractors, subcontractors, or brokers based on past criminal convictions. It has no direct mechanisms or provisions aimed at addressing child poverty.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Noise Abatement Monitoring Systems - Pilot Program
Synopsis: Establishing a pilot program to authorize the use of noise abatement monitoring systems in Montgomery County and Prince George's County to enforce certain motor vehicle noise requirements; requiring a county, before activating a noise abatement monitoring system, to publish notice of the locations of the systems on its website; requiring a county that authorizes a noise abatement monitoring program to report to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2025, on the implementation and costs of the program and revenues collected; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a 2-year pilot program, effective July 1, 2024, in Anne Arundel, Montgomery, and Prince George's counties, authorizing the use of noise abatement monitoring systems. These systems detect and record images and audio of motor vehicles that exceed established noise limits by at least 5 decibels. For a first offense, a warning notice is issued, and for subsequent offenses, a civil penalty not exceeding $75 is imposed. Each participating county may use up to three systems and is responsible for the program's implementation costs. The program is set to be abrogated on June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: County law enforcement agencies or designated county agencies in Anne Arundel, Montgomery, and Prince George's counties, in coordination with the District Court and the State Highway Administration. The Chief Judge of the District Court is responsible for adopting procedures.
stakeholders: Motor vehicle owners and lessees in Anne Arundel, Montgomery, and Prince George's counties whose vehicles exceed noise limits. Residents of these counties may also be impacted by reduced noise pollution.
innovative_summary: The program employs new technology for automated enforcement by using 'noise abatement monitoring systems.' These systems combine vehicle sensors, decibel readers, and recorded images and audio to automatically identify and document motor vehicles exceeding noise limits. This extends the concept of automated enforcement (like speed or red-light cameras) to environmental noise regulation, with a unique feature of requiring manual audio review by an operator before issuing a citation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is focused on enforcing vehicle noise regulations through a pilot program and does not include any provisions that directly address or alleviate child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be negligible, as it does not provide financial assistance, social services, or educational programs aimed at families experiencing poverty.

Title: Human Services - Attendant Care Program - Ongoing Additional Supports
Synopsis: Altering the purpose of the Attendant Care Program to include the provision of financial assistance for ongoing additional supports that increase an individual's independent performance of essential daily activities and is requested by an eligible individual.
bill_summary: This bill expands the purpose of the Attendant Care Program by allowing it to provide financial assistance for "ongoing additional supports" to eligible individuals with severe physical disabilities, in addition to the existing attendant care services. "Ongoing additional supports" are defined as continual support that increases an eligible individual’s independent performance of daily living activities, self-care, or mobility, as requested by the individual and approved by the Department. The bill also updates sections related to program requirements and funding availability to include these new supports.
responsible_party: Department of Disabilities
stakeholders: Individuals between 18 and 65 years old with severe chronic or permanent physical disabilities that preclude or significantly impair their independent performance of essential activities of daily living, self-care, or mobility.
innovative_summary: The bill represents an incremental expansion of an existing social service program. It broadens the types of support for which financial assistance can be provided, but it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides financial assistance to adults with disabilities (ages 18-65) for attendant care and ongoing supports. While this assistance can indirectly alleviate financial burdens on households with disabled adults, potentially freeing up resources that could benefit children in those households, it does not directly target children or programs specifically designed to reduce child poverty.

Title: Condominiums - Common Elements - Clean Energy Equipment
Synopsis: Authorizing the board of directors of a condominium to grant certain interests affecting the common elements of the condominium for the installation and use of leased clean energy equipment.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes condominium boards of directors, or councils of unit owners, to grant leases or similar interests affecting common elements for the installation and use of leased clean energy equipment, such as electric vehicle recharging equipment, solar energy equipment, and energy storage systems. It modifies the voting requirements for such grants, allowing for approval by a majority vote of the board or at least 51% of unit owners' votes, and removes the requirement for mortgagee consent in these specific cases. The bill aims to facilitate the adoption of clean energy technologies in condominiums.
responsible_party: Maryland General Assembly
stakeholders: Condominium unit owners, condominium boards of directors, councils of unit owners, clean energy equipment providers, and mortgagees.
innovative_summary: This bill is moderately innovative as it removes legislative barriers and streamlines the process for condominiums to adopt modern clean energy solutions, including solar, EV charging, and energy storage. By simplifying approval processes for leasing such equipment on common elements, it encourages green technology integration into existing residential infrastructure. This represents a progressive legislative update to facilitate environmental sustainability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on property management and the adoption of clean energy equipment within condominiums. It does not provide direct financial assistance, services, or targeted support to low-income families or children. Any potential impact on child poverty, such as through lower energy costs for some condominium residents, would be highly indirect and not a direct outcome of the bill's provisions.

Title: Correctional Services - Division of Pretrial Detention and Services - Facilities
Synopsis: Altering the composition and authority of the Division of Pretrial Detention and Services within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services; altering the authority of the Commissioner of the Division; establishing the Youth Detention Center in the Division; establishing the facility administrator and authorizing assistant facility administrators for the Youth Detention Center; and repealing authorization for the Baltimore City Detention Center.
bill_summary: This bill reorganizes the Division of Pretrial Detention and Services within the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. It alters the composition and authority of the Division, repealing the Baltimore City Detention Center and establishing a new Youth Detention Center for juvenile incarcerated individuals under the age of 18 years who have been charged with a crime as an adult in Baltimore City. It also adds the Maryland Transition Center and the Chesapeake Detention Center to the Division, and clarifies the authority of the Commissioner and facility administrators.
responsible_party: Division of Pretrial Detention and Services within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Juvenile incarcerated individuals under the age of 18 years charged with a crime as an adult in Baltimore City, as well as other inmates and staff within the Division of Pretrial Detention and Services.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves a reorganization and renaming of facilities within an existing division of correctional services. While it establishes a dedicated Youth Detention Center, this is more of a structural change within the existing framework rather than an introduction of new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a Youth Detention Center for juveniles charged as adults. While incarceration can have significant indirect impacts on families and potentially exacerbate child poverty, this bill does not directly address child poverty through financial assistance, support programs, or policy changes aimed at poverty reduction. Its focus is on the administrative structure and facility management for pretrial detention.

Title: Sustainable Growth Subcabinet and Repeal of the Office of Smart Growth
Synopsis: Repealing the Office of Smart Growth; repealing the position of Special Secretary for Smart Growth; renaming the Smart Growth Subcabinet to be the Sustainable Growth Subcabinet; altering the membership of the Subcabinet; requiring the Subcabinet to review State assistance programs, promote interagency consensus and cooperation, provide advisory and technical assistance to local jurisdictions, and gather and disseminate information to the public related to the State's sustainable growth policy; etc.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the Office of Smart Growth and the position of Special Secretary of Smart Growth. It renames the Smart Growth Subcabinet to the Sustainable Growth Subcabinet, alters its membership, and updates its duties. The Subcabinet will now focus on promoting sustainable growth policy, which includes economic growth, resource protection, planning, equity, resiliency, and neighborhood vitality, by coordinating interagency efforts, providing technical assistance, and making policy recommendations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Planning
stakeholders: Residents of Maryland, local jurisdictions, nonprofit organizations, developers, community and homeowners' associations, and county and municipal elected leaders and planning officials, who are impacted by policies related to growth, development, equity, resiliency, neighborhood vitality, and resource management.
innovative_summary: The bill renames an existing Smart Growth Subcabinet to a Sustainable Growth Subcabinet, explicitly expanding its mandate to include equity and resiliency alongside economic growth and resource protection. While it updates the policy framework and focus, the approach of using an interagency subcabinet for coordination and recommendations is not a new governmental or technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's emphasis on fostering equitable and sustainable communities, neighborhood vitality, and resource management has the potential for an indirect, long-term positive impact on conditions that could alleviate child poverty. However, it does not establish direct programs, financial aid, or specific services targeted at low-income children or families, making its direct impact on child poverty low.

Title: Natural Resources - Maryland State Parks - Funds and Plan Alterations
Synopsis: Extending the date by which the Park System Critical Maintenance Fund must be expended to before July 1, 2029; authorizing the Department of Natural Resources to expend up to $400,000 from the Park System Critical Maintenance Fund under certain circumstances; authorizing the Park System Capital Improvements and Acquisition Fund to be used for State projects on lands managed by the Department for public purposes; authorizing the Great Maryland Outdoors Fund to be used for promoting outdoor environmental education in the State; etc.
bill_summary: This bill extends the deadline for expending funds from the Park System Critical Maintenance Fund to July 1, 2029, and allows the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to expend up to $400,000 from this fund for critical maintenance projects without prior approval from the Department of General Services. It expands the allowable uses of the Park System Capital Improvements and Acquisition Fund to include State projects on any lands managed by the DNR for public purposes, not just State parks, and specifies how the first $70,000,000 received by this fund can be allocated (e.g., climate change mitigation, historic preservation, transportation improvements, water access, and land acquisition to alleviate overcrowding and expand public access, including sites of significance to diverse populations). The bill also authorizes the Great Maryland Outdoors Fund to be used for promoting outdoor environmental education. Finally, it requires the DNR to report expenditures from the Park System Capital Improvements and Acquisition Fund to the Parks and Recreation Commission at quarterly meetings and extends the deadline for the DNR to develop and publish a Comprehensive Long-Range Strategic Plan to December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources (DNR)
stakeholders: The general public, including users of Maryland State Parks and lands managed by the Department of Natural Resources, particularly those seeking outdoor recreation and environmental education opportunities. Specific consideration is given to communities affected by environmental justice concerns and historically underrepresented populations (African American, Asian, Indigenous or Native American, and Hispanic or Latino populations) for land acquisition and access.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily focuses on reallocating and clarifying the use of existing funds, extending deadlines, and improving maintenance and access for Maryland's state parks and public lands. While it includes provisions for climate change mitigation and expanding access to diverse populations, these are implemented through traditional capital improvement and land acquisition mechanisms rather than new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly address child poverty. Its focus is on improving and expanding access to state parks, outdoor recreation, and environmental education. While these initiatives can indirectly benefit children by providing access to green spaces, educational opportunities, and safe environments, there are no specific provisions or programs designed to directly alleviate child poverty through financial aid, housing, food, or targeted support for impoverished children.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Motor Vehicle Insurance Companies - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring motor vehicle insurance companies to participate in the Motor Vehicle Administration's online verification program for vehicle insurance policies for law enforcement and administrative purposes; and requiring motor vehicle insurance companies to provide certain customer information details.
bill_summary: This bill requires motor vehicle insurance companies to participate in the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration's online verification program for vehicle insurance policies. It also mandates that these companies electronically provide the Administration with details of all active insurance policies in a specified format and at determined intervals, for law enforcement and administrative purposes.
responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Motor vehicle insurance companies operating in Maryland, motor vehicle owners and drivers in Maryland, and law enforcement agencies.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances existing digital processes by mandating comprehensive electronic data provision of all active insurance policies and requiring participation in an online verification program. While leveraging modern digital infrastructure for administrative efficiency and law enforcement capabilities, it primarily extends the scope of existing technologies and mandates rather than introducing novel approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on improving motor vehicle insurance verification and data sharing. It does not directly provide economic support, services, or resources that would alleviate child poverty. Any potential impact would be indirect through general improvements in regulatory efficiency or safety, which is not a direct poverty intervention.

Title: Motor Vehicle Administration and Local Health Departments - Death Certificates - Issuance of Copies
Synopsis: Authorizing the Motor Vehicle Administration and local health departments to access electronically from the Maryland Department of Health a copy of a death certificate and, on request, provide any person authorized by regulations with a certified or abridged copy of a death certificate; and authorizing the Administration and local health departments to set and collect a fee for processing and issuing death certificates, subject to certain limitations.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) and local health departments to electronically access and issue certified or abridged copies of death certificates. It allows these entities to set and collect fees for processing and issuing death certificates, covering administrative costs and requiring a portion of the fee to be transferred to the General Fund. The bill also requires a memorandum of understanding with the Maryland Department of Health regarding fee structures. Additionally, it exempts surviving spouses and children of first responders killed in the line of duty from paying fees for death certificates if used for dependency or beneficiary claims.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health, Motor Vehicle Administration, local health departments
stakeholders: Individuals authorized to request death certificates, including surviving family members, and specifically surviving spouses and children of first responders.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a modernization of administrative processes by enabling the Motor Vehicle Administration and local health departments to electronically access death certificates from the Department of Health. This allows for a more streamlined and potentially convenient method for the public to obtain these vital records.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses administrative procedures and fees for obtaining death certificates. While easier access to these documents could indirectly help families access benefits or settle estates, it does not establish any direct programs, services, or financial assistance specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Special Registration Plates - Gold Star and Next of Kin Families
Synopsis: Authorizing the recipient of a U.S. Department of Defense Next of Kin lapel button to apply for special registration plates; and waiving the initial vehicle registration fee associated with special registration plates issued to the recipient of a Gold Star or a Next of Kin lapel button.
bill_summary: This bill expands eligibility for special Gold Star and Next of Kin vehicle registration plates to include recipients of the U.S. Department of Defense Next of Kin lapel button. It also broadens the criteria for service members' deaths to include those who lost their lives while serving on active duty or while assigned to a reserve or national guard unit in a drill status, rather than just "in combat". The bill waives the initial vehicle registration fee for these special plates and requires the deceased service member's given name and rank to be included on the plates.
responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
stakeholders: Surviving spouses, parents, and next of kin of members of the armed forces who lost their lives while serving on active duty or while assigned to a reserve or national guard unit in a drill status.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to an existing special vehicle registration plate program, expanding eligibility and modifying fee structures. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill waives an initial vehicle registration fee for a specific group (surviving military families), which provides a minor financial benefit. However, it is not directly designed to address child poverty and its impact would be negligible.

Title: Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program – Climate, Equity, and Administrative Provisions
Synopsis: Authorizing the Critical Area Commission to adopt regulations governing the transfer of development rights, fee in lieu payments, the assessment of and adaption of the critical area for climate resiliency, enhancing resilience in the critical area, and environmental justice and equity initiatives; establishing certain considerations of climate change, climate resiliency, and equity as general principles and minimum elements of local programs; etc.
bill_summary: This bill significantly updates the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program. It alters membership standards for the Critical Area Commission and expands its regulatory authority to include climate resiliency, environmental justice, and equity initiatives. Key changes involve establishing climate change and equity as core principles for local programs, requiring consideration of underserved communities in recreation planning, and integrating climate change into growth allocation decisions. The bill also modifies density standards, lot coverage limits, and the process for local program reviews and amendments. It repeals certain requirements for oil and natural gas production in the critical area and establishes a process for regular updates to statewide critical area base maps, incorporating advanced digital mapping techniques.
responsible_party: Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays, local jurisdictions, Department of Natural Resources, Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Local jurisdictions (counties and municipalities), property owners, developers, citizens of Maryland, underserved communities, overburdened communities, and natural resources within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a forward-looking approach by explicitly integrating climate change adaptation and climate resiliency into critical area planning and development regulations. This includes assessing vulnerability to climate change, developing mitigation measures for sea level rise and extreme weather, and enhancing resilience through natural and nature-based features. Furthermore, it incorporates environmental justice and equity initiatives, requiring the identification of underserved and overburdened communities and ensuring equitable distribution of environmental benefits and burdens. The use of digitally generated, georeferenced statewide base maps for critical area boundaries also reflects a modern, technology-driven approach to land management.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes explicit provisions for environmental justice and equity initiatives, requiring the identification of "underserved and overburdened communities" and measures to ensure equitable distribution of environmental benefits and burdens. "Underserved community" is defined, in part, as a census tract with at least 25% low-income residents. By mandating consideration of these communities, the bill aims to improve environmental quality and access to natural resources in areas often affected by poverty, which can indirectly lead to better health and well-being outcomes for children in those communities.

Title: Department of Natural Resources - Pay-For-Success Contracts - Procurement Exemption
Synopsis: Exempting pay-for-success contracts negotiated or entered into by the Department of Natural Resources from certain provisions of the General Procurement Law.
bill_summary: This bill exempts pay-for-success contracts negotiated or entered into by the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) from certain provisions of the General Procurement Law. It specifies that these contracts, which involve government payment only upon the achievement of measurable environmental outcomes, are a suitable procurement option for land conservation and environmental protection.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources (DNR)
stakeholders: Nonprofit entities, contractors, and investors involved in conservation service opportunities and environmental restoration efforts in Maryland. The general public and the environment benefit from improved environmental outcomes.
innovative_summary: The bill promotes pay-for-success contracting, which is an innovative approach to government procurement. This method shifts the risk of performance to the contractor by making government payment contingent on the achievement of specific, measurable environmental outcomes. This encourages performance-based solutions and leverages social and environmental impact investment.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is focused on environmental procurement methods and does not have a direct impact on child poverty. Its primary goal is to improve environmental outcomes through a specific contracting mechanism.

Title: Commercial Northern Snakehead License – Gear
Synopsis: Repealing certain buffer zones within which a commercial northern snakehead licensee may not fish using bowfishing gear; and requiring a licensee who fishes for northern snakehead to comply with Department of Natural Resources regulations governing the use of gear.
bill_summary: This bill repeals specific buffer zone restrictions that prevented commercial northern snakehead licensees from using bowfishing gear within 100 yards of certain areas (e.g., other persons, swimming areas, diver down flags, occupied blinds). It also clarifies that licensees must comply with all Department of Natural Resources regulations governing the use of fishing gear.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Commercial northern snakehead licensees, recreational users of the State's tidal waters, and individuals involved in commercial fishing activities.
innovative_summary: This bill is an amendment to existing natural resources law, specifically modifying regulations for an existing commercial fishing license. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services or programs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on regulations for commercial fishing gear for northern snakehead. It does not directly establish programs or policies aimed at reducing child poverty, nor does it provide direct economic assistance to families with children.

Title: Public Health - Clean Indoor Air Act - Revisions
Synopsis: Prohibiting vaping in certain indoor areas and places of employment and certain mass transportation; requiring that certain signs be posted in each public indoor area and each public entrance to an indoor area where smoking or vaping is prohibited; requiring the convening of a workgroup to study the issuance of alcoholic beverages licenses to tobacconists; and prohibiting the issuance of a local alcoholic beverages license to a tobacconist from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026, both inclusive.
bill_summary: This bill updates the Maryland Clean Indoor Air Act to prohibit vaping in certain indoor areas open to the public, places of employment, and mass transportation. It requires the posting of "No Smoking or Vaping" signs in these areas. Additionally, the bill mandates the Maryland Department of Health to convene a workgroup to study the issuance of alcoholic beverages licenses to tobacconists and temporarily prohibits the issuance of such licenses from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: The general public, employees, employers, businesses (especially those selling tobacco and vaping products, bars, and restaurants), and tobacconists.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily extends existing clean indoor air regulations to include vaping, which is a common legislative update. The formation of a workgroup to study a policy issue is a traditional governmental approach. No new technologies or innovative governance approaches are employed.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact is on public health by reducing exposure to secondhand vape aerosol. While improved public health can have long-term indirect benefits for all populations, including children, it does not directly address financial, educational, housing, or other socio-economic factors that directly alleviate child poverty.

Title: Housing and Community Development - Just Community Designation
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor, on the recommendation of the Secretary of Housing and Community Development, to designate certain areas as Just Communities based on certain criteria; and providing for the prioritization of State funding for Just Communities to increase racial, economic and health equity in the State.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a "Just Community Designation" in Maryland, allowing the Governor, based on the Secretary of Housing and Community Development's recommendation, to designate certain historically underserved areas as Just Communities. The designation is based on criteria reflecting a need for reinvestment due to historical negative impacts like racial segregation, residential demolition, high imprisonment rates, or environmental hazards. The purpose of this designation is to prioritize State funding for these communities to advance equity, civil rights, racial justice, and equal opportunity, and to increase racial, economic, and health equity in the state.
responsible_party: Governor and Secretary of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Residents and businesses in historically underserved communities across Maryland that have been negatively impacted by past legal racial segregation, residential demolitions, high imprisonment rates, or unequal exposure to environmental and health hazards.
innovative_summary: The program is innovative in its explicit focus on redressing historical injustices and systemic inequities through a data-driven community designation process. It uses specific historical and current metrics, such as redlining, exclusionary zoning, eminent domain, imprisonment rates, and environmental health disparities (e.g., proximity to Superfund sites, lead-based paint exposure, asthma rates), to identify "Just Communities" for prioritized state funding. This targeted approach to allocate resources based on a comprehensive understanding of historical harm is a novel and proactive way to advance equity.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly providing services or funds specifically for children, the program aims to increase racial, economic, and health equity and stimulate reinvestment in historically underserved communities. By improving community conditions, property values, business investment, and addressing environmental and health hazards, the program creates a more stable and prosperous environment for families, which can indirectly but significantly reduce child poverty through improved economic opportunities, better health outcomes, and enhanced community resources.

Title: State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board to July 1, 2027; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee by July 1, 2025, with certain information regarding the State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date of the State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2027. It also requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee by July 1, 2025, regarding the Board's activities.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor; State Amusement Ride Safety Advisory Board
stakeholders: The general public who use amusement rides, and businesses that operate amusement rides in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, focusing on extending the life of an existing advisory board and requiring a report. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is concerned with the safety of amusement rides and the continuation of an advisory board. It has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act - Civil Penalties - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain civil penalties for violations of the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act; and requiring the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to annually increase the maximum and minimum civil penalties, beginning in 2025, by the percentage increase, if any, in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers or a successor index published by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act to significantly increase civil penalties for violations. It sets new maximum and minimum penalty amounts effective before and after July 15, 2025. Crucially, it mandates the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to annually increase these civil penalties starting January 1, 2025, based on the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index to ensure compliance with federal law. The adjustments will be effective each year on July 15.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Employers in Maryland subject to the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act, and their employees, who may benefit from enhanced workplace safety due to higher penalties.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces an automatic annual adjustment mechanism for civil penalties based on the Consumer Price Index. While this ensures compliance with federal law and maintains the real value of penalties, it is a standard regulatory adjustment method rather than a novel or technologically innovative approach to government or public services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By increasing penalties for occupational safety violations, it aims to incentivize safer workplaces, potentially reducing workplace injuries or fatalities. Preventing such incidents can prevent families from experiencing financial hardship due to loss of income or medical expenses, which could indirectly mitigate child poverty. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or educational support to families experiencing poverty.

Title: Financial Institutions - Third-Party Service Providers - Examinations
Synopsis: Authorizing the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to examine a third-party service provider as to services and activities performed on behalf of an entity licensed or chartered by the Office of Financial Regulation; requiring the Commissioner to notify a certain licensed person of any examination of any third-party service provider who performs activities relating to financial services on behalf of the licensed person; authorizing the Commissioner to accept the results of an examination by certain entities; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to examine third-party service providers that perform financial activities on behalf of entities licensed or chartered by the Office of Financial Regulation. It defines what constitutes a 'regulated entity' and a 'third-party service provider,' including those offering data processing, lending support, internet-related services, and security monitoring. The Commissioner's examination power extends to the same extent as if the activity was performed by the regulated entity itself, and is not limited to the premises of the regulated entity. The Commissioner may collect fees for examinations, request information, take enforcement actions against non-compliant third-party providers, and keep information confidential. This expands the regulatory oversight of the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to better monitor risks associated with outsourced financial activities.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Financial Regulation; Office of Financial Regulation
stakeholders: Financial institutions licensed or chartered by the Office of Financial Regulation, and their third-party service providers performing activities related to financial services for the institutions' customers. This includes providers of data processing, lending support, funds transfer, fiduciary activities, trading activities, deposit taking, internet-related services (web services, electronic bill payments, mobile applications, system/software development and maintenance, security monitoring).
innovative_summary: This bill adapts existing regulatory frameworks to the evolving financial services landscape by explicitly granting the Commissioner of Financial Regulation authority to examine third-party service providers. This is a common and necessary adaptation to address risks associated with the increasing reliance of financial institutions on external vendors for critical services, including those involving modern technology like data processing, internet services, and mobile applications. While not introducing entirely new technologies, it applies established oversight mechanisms to a broader and more technologically advanced ecosystem of financial service providers.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on financial regulation and oversight of third-party service providers to financial institutions. Its impact on child poverty would be indirect, at best, by potentially contributing to a more stable and secure financial system, which could have diffuse economic benefits. However, it does not directly address or implement programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Unemployment Insurance - Covered Employment - Employees of Governmental Entities or Charitable, Educational, or Religious Organizations
Synopsis: Specifying that certain limitations on the payment of benefits to employees of governmental entities or charitable, educational, or religious organizations do not apply with respect to service in other covered employment, including covered employment for a for-profit employing unit, even if the service is provided exclusively for a governmental entity or a charitable, educational, religious, or other organization.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies that certain limitations on unemployment insurance benefits for employees of governmental entities, charitable, educational, or religious organizations do not apply if the employee also has other covered employment. Essentially, it broadens eligibility for unemployment benefits for individuals who work for these specific organizations and also have other employment, making it easier for them to receive benefits.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Employees of governmental entities, charitable, educational, or religious organizations, particularly those also engaged in other covered employment, and educational institutions.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legislative amendment that clarifies the application of existing unemployment insurance laws. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill clarifies eligibility for unemployment benefits for a specific group of workers. While unemployment benefits can provide financial support to families and indirectly prevent poverty, this bill is a technical adjustment to existing regulations and is not a direct program aimed at reducing child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be very indirect.

Title: Insurance - Holding Companies - Group Capital Calculation and Liquidity Stress Test
Synopsis: Requiring certain controlling persons of certain insurers in an insurance holding company system to file an annual group calculation as directed by the lead state commissioner of the insurance group; requiring certain controlling persons of certain insurers in an insurance holding company system to file the results of a liquidity stress test for specific data years; providing that certain information is confidential; and authorizing and requiring the Commissioner to take certain actions related to certain information.
bill_summary: This bill requires controlling persons of insurance holding companies to file an annual group capital calculation and the results of a liquidity stress test with the lead state insurance commissioner. It establishes confidentiality protections for this information and outlines how the Maryland Insurance Commissioner can use and share it to enhance regulatory oversight and solvency monitoring of insurance groups.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner; Lead State Commissioner of the insurance group (as determined by NAIC Financial Analysis Handbook)
stakeholders: Controlling persons of insurers in insurance holding company systems, insurers, policyholders, and the public.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances insurance regulation by adopting standardized, NAIC-backed frameworks for group capital calculation and liquidity stress tests. This represents a modern, coordinated approach to systemic risk monitoring within the insurance sector, moving towards more sophisticated and standardized analytical methods for financial stability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily focuses on financial regulation and solvency monitoring of insurance companies. It does not contain any provisions that directly address or aim to reduce child poverty. Any potential impact would be extremely indirect through broad economic stability.

Title: Cannabis Reform - Alterations
Synopsis: Making alterations and clarifications related to the duties of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, the Office of Social Equity, the Advisory Board on Medical and Adult-Use Cannabis, and the Maryland Cannabis Administration; altering the membership of the Commission; requiring the Advisory Board to elect a chair and removing the Director of the Administration as chair; authorizing processors to provide cannabis to cannabis licensees; providing that certain violations may be charged by a citation; etc.
bill_summary: This bill makes several alterations to Maryland's cannabis reform laws, refining the best practices for the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, changing its membership, and clarifying the duties of the Commission, the Office of Social Equity, the Advisory Board on Medical and Adult-Use Cannabis, and the Maryland Cannabis Administration. Key changes include the Advisory Board electing its chair, authorizing processors to provide cannabis to other licensees, requiring the Administration to register and regulate cannabis nurseries, and expanding the Administration's power to impose penalties and administer the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund. It also adjusts cannabis possession limits for qualifying patients, processing limits for processors, provisions for cannabis agent registration (including temporary registration), and advertising rules. Furthermore, the bill allows the Cannabis Business Assistance Fund to cover administrative costs and extends the Administration's procurement exemption until December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Cannabis Administration
stakeholders: Cannabis businesses (growers, processors, dispensaries, nurseries), cannabis registrants (transporters, security guard companies, waste disposal companies, independent testing labs), qualifying patients, adult-use cannabis consumers, social equity applicants, small, minority, and women-owned businesses, and political subdivisions.
innovative_summary: The bill refines and clarifies the regulatory framework for medical and adult-use cannabis in Maryland. While it addresses issues like social equity and adapting to potential federal changes, it primarily involves adjustments to an existing system rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally novel approaches to government services or delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly address child poverty. It focuses on the regulation, licensing, and operation of the cannabis industry, including promoting social equity and providing assistance to certain businesses. While economic growth and social equity initiatives could indirectly have a positive impact on communities, there is no direct mechanism within the bill to alleviate child poverty. The Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund is mentioned, but the bill's changes are related to reporting and information gathering for the fund, not its direct allocation or purpose for child poverty.

Title: Waterway Incident Notification System (WINS) - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Emergency Management to study issues and factors regarding the feasibility of establishing a Waterway Incident Notification System to notify members of the public of certain waterway emergencies; and requiring the Department to submit an interim report of its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024, and a final report on or before December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Emergency Management to conduct a study on the feasibility of establishing a Waterway Incident Notification System (WINS). The system would notify members of the public, including recreational boaters and commercial watermen, of active waterway emergencies, emergency marine events, or marine hazards. The study will also explore potential partnerships with federal and nearby state entities to improve these notifications. An interim report is due by December 1, 2024, and a final report by December 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Emergency Management
stakeholders: Members of the public, including recreational boaters and commercial watermen, affected by waterway emergencies, emergency marine events, or marine hazards.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a study to explore a Waterway Incident Notification System (WINS), which would use existing notification technologies adapted for waterway-specific emergencies. While the concept of public safety alerts is not new, tailoring a comprehensive system specifically for marine incidents and integrating various agencies (State, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Navy, nearby states) could represent a moderately innovative approach to enhance public safety in waterways.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on studying a waterway incident notification system for public safety, particularly for recreational and commercial water users. It does not directly address or impact child poverty or provide economic support or services to families experiencing poverty.

Title: State Personnel - Collective Bargaining - Supervisory Employees
Synopsis: Providing collective bargaining rights to certain supervisory State employees; and requiring that certain supervisory State employees have separate bargaining units.
bill_summary: This bill grants collective bargaining rights to certain supervisory State employees in Maryland and establishes separate bargaining units for these employees. It amends the State Personnel and Pensions Article to include these supervisors in collective bargaining, defining which employees are included and excluded, and outlines how bargaining units are to be formed and managed.
responsible_party: Secretary of the Department of Budget and Management (for general state employees); Presidents and Governing Boards of specific higher education institutions for their employees.
stakeholders: Supervisory State employees in various Maryland State government departments, agencies, and higher education institutions.
innovative_summary: The bill extends existing collective bargaining frameworks to a new category of state employees (supervisors) and establishes specific bargaining units for them. While significant for labor relations, it is an expansion of an established approach rather than employing new technologies or novel government methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill pertains to the collective bargaining rights of supervisory State employees. While improved wages and working conditions for these employees could indirectly benefit their families, it does not directly target child poverty through specific services, financial aid, or programs aimed at low-income children or families.

Title: Unemployment Insurance - Benefits - Election Judges
Synopsis: Prohibiting a payment to an individual as compensation received for serving as an election judge for a local board of elections in the State from being included when computing the wages required to be subtracted from an eligible claimant's weekly benefit amount; and prohibiting an individual from being denied unemployment benefits for failure to meet certain requirements due to service as an election judge in the State.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's unemployment insurance law to prevent compensation received for serving as an election judge from being subtracted from an eligible claimant's weekly unemployment benefit amount. It also ensures that individuals are not denied unemployment benefits for failing to meet certain work requirements if that failure is due to their service as an election judge.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Individuals serving as election judges for local boards of elections in Maryland who are also eligible for or receiving unemployment insurance benefits.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative adjustments to existing unemployment insurance regulations to accommodate individuals serving as election judges, rather than introducing new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a very indirect and limited potential to impact child poverty by allowing individuals who serve as election judges to retain more of their unemployment benefits, which could marginally increase household income for a specific group of beneficiaries with children.

Title: Consumer Protection - Consumer Reporting Agencies - Information in Consumer Credit Reports
Synopsis: Altering the items of information that a consumer reporting agency is prohibited from including in a consumer credit report.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland law concerning consumer reporting agencies. It modifies the circumstances under which consumer reporting agencies are prohibited from including certain adverse information in consumer credit reports. Specifically, it raises the monetary thresholds for credit transactions, life insurance policies, and employment annual salaries for which older adverse information (like bankruptcies, judgments, or collections) may still be included in a report, even if it exceeds the general 7 or 10-year exclusion period.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Consumers, consumer reporting agencies, lenders, insurance companies, and employers.
innovative_summary: This bill represents a standard regulatory adjustment to consumer protection laws, updating monetary thresholds. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services or operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The potential for this bill to directly impact child poverty is very low. While consumer credit reports can influence financial stability, this bill primarily adjusts the thresholds for reporting historical adverse information in relation to larger credit transactions, insurance policies, or higher-paying jobs. Its effects on families experiencing child poverty are indirect and likely minimal, as it does not create specific programs or direct financial aid.

Title: Insurance - Producer Licensing Requirements - Education and Experience
Synopsis: Repealing the requirements for education and experience for licensing of certain insurance producers, including producers for property and casualty insurance, life insurance, health insurance, annuities, and related products.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the education and experience requirements for individuals seeking to obtain various insurance producer licenses in Maryland, including those for property, casualty, life, health insurance, and annuities. While the examination requirement generally remains, certain exemptions are retained. The changes aim to streamline the licensing process for insurance producers.
responsible_party: The Commissioner (Maryland Insurance Commissioner)
stakeholders: Individuals seeking to become licensed insurance producers in Maryland, the insurance industry, and current licensed insurance producers.
innovative_summary: This bill focuses on simplifying regulatory requirements for insurance producer licensing by removing education and experience prerequisites, while retaining examination requirements. It is a modification of existing administrative processes rather than an introduction of new technologies or highly innovative governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is negligible. It primarily concerns changes to the administrative requirements for obtaining an insurance producer license, which does not directly address the systemic issues or provide direct support for families experiencing child poverty.

Title: Cannabis Licensing and Registration - Use of Straw Ownership - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from applying for or holding a cannabis license or registration under certain circumstances if an ownership interest in the license or registration is for the limited purpose of satisfying certain requirements of registration or licensure; and requiring the Maryland Cannabis Administration to deny a certain application or revoke a cannabis license or registration if the applicant, licensee, or registrant is determined by the Administration to be in violation of the Act or convicted of a violation of the Act.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits 'straw ownership' in Maryland cannabis licenses and registrations. It defines genuine ownership and forbids individuals from applying for or holding a cannabis license if an ownership interest is nominal, lacks genuine benefits and risks, or is solely for meeting licensing requirements. The Maryland Cannabis Administration is mandated to deny applications or revoke licenses/registrations if a violation is determined or a conviction occurs.
