However, it mandates the EMS Board and other health occupations boards to require applicants to disclose their SSN or ITIN (or provide alternative documentation) for recording in the application file. This information must then be provided to the Child Support Administration of the Department of Human Services upon request to assist in collecting child support from obligors in arrears.
responsible_party: State Emergency Medical Services Board; Child Support Administration of the Department of Human Services
stakeholders: Individuals applying for licenses or certificates from the State Emergency Medical Services Board and other health occupations boards; families and children receiving child support payments; individuals owing child support.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts administrative requirements for professional licensing and data sharing between state agencies for child support enforcement. It does not introduce new technologies, innovative service delivery models, or novel governmental approaches. The changes are procedural and aimed at streamlining existing processes related to identification and inter-agency data exchange for specific legal purposes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill enhances the ability of the Child Support Administration to collect child support payments by mandating that the State EMS Board and other health occupations boards record and provide applicant identification numbers (SSN/ITIN or alternative documentation). This improved data sharing facilitates the enforcement of child support orders, directly impacting the financial stability of families and children who rely on these payments. By helping ensure consistent receipt of child support, the bill has a positive potential to alleviate child poverty by providing a crucial source of income.

Title: State Board of Examiners in Optometry - Criminal History Records Checks
Synopsis: Requiring an applicant for a license to practice optometry and certain applicants for the renewal of a license to submit to a criminal history records check obtained from the Criminal Justice Information Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services; and providing that information obtained from the Central Repository is confidential, may not be redisseminated, and is to be used only for licensing purposes.
bill_summary: This bill requires applicants for new licenses to practice optometry and certain applicants for license renewal in Maryland to undergo State and national criminal history records checks. The process involves submitting fingerprints and paying associated fees to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository. The State Board of Examiners in Optometry will consider the criminal history information, along with other factors such as the nature of the crime and time elapsed, when deciding on license applications. For existing licensees, the criminal history check requirement applies to their first license renewal submitted on or after January 1, 2026, if their initial license was issued before the bill's effective date.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners in Optometry; Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Applicants for optometry licenses, currently licensed optometrists in Maryland, and the general public receiving optometric services.
innovative_summary: This bill implements standard criminal history records checks for a professional licensing board. It does not introduce new technologies, novel governmental approaches, or significantly innovative practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill establishes a regulatory requirement for criminal history checks for optometry licenses and has no direct impact on child poverty. Its scope is entirely focused on professional licensing standards.

Title: Criminal and Civil Trespass - Professional Land Surveyors - Exception
Synopsis: Establishing exceptions to certain criminal prohibitions against trespass on property and the civil tort of trespass for professional land surveyors, and agents and employees of professional land surveyors, who enter the property of another to practice land surveying.
bill_summary: This bill establishes exceptions to both criminal prohibitions against trespass on property and the civil tort of trespass for licensed professional land surveyors, and their agents or employees, when they enter private property to practice land surveying in Maryland. It clarifies that such individuals will not be held liable for trespass under common law or criminal law in these circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland State legal system, State Board for Professional Land Surveyors
stakeholders: Professional land surveyors, their agents and employees, and property owners in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legal clarification amending existing trespass laws. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses legal exemptions for professional land surveyors and has no direct provisions or mechanisms that would impact child poverty. Any potential effect would be extremely indirect and negligible.

Title: Cosmetology Licensure Compact
Synopsis: Entering into the Cosmetology Licensure Compact; establishing criteria for participating states; authorizing an individual practicing cosmetology to practice in a party state under certain circumstances; establishing the Cosmetology Licensure Compact Commission and its duties and powers; and providing for the amendment of and withdrawal from the Compact.
bill_summary: This bill enacts the Cosmetology Licensure Compact in Maryland. This compact aims to facilitate the interstate practice and regulation of cosmetology, improve public access and safety of services, and reduce licensing burdens. It establishes uniform requirements for multistate licensure, enhances public health and safety, supports relocating military members and their spouses, and provides increased value and mobility to licensed cosmetologists in member states. The compact creates a Cosmetology Licensure Compact Commission to oversee its administration, including maintaining a coordinated data system for licensure and disciplinary information.
responsible_party: Cosmetology Licensure Compact Commission and the Maryland State Licensing Authority (e.g., Maryland Board of Cosmetology)
stakeholders: Licensed cosmetologists, individuals seeking cosmetology services, military members and their spouses, and state cosmetology licensing authorities in member states.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes an interstate compact for cosmetology licensure, which is a modern approach to reducing professional licensure barriers and facilitating workforce mobility across states. While interstate compacts are a known mechanism, their application to professions like cosmetology, combined with a coordinated data system for sharing licensure and disciplinary information, represents an innovative governmental approach to streamline regulation, enhance efficiency, and improve public safety.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not directly address child poverty. Its focus is on professional licensure mobility and regulation within the cosmetology industry. While increased professional mobility and potential workforce stability for cosmetologists could indirectly benefit their families, this is not a direct mechanism for poverty reduction.

Title: Wage Payment and Collection - Pay Stubs and Pay Statements - Required Information
Synopsis: Requiring that a notice containing certain information provided to an employee at the time of hiring be written; requiring that the statement regarding earnings required to be provided to employees by employers be written on the physical pay stub or online pay statement and include certain information; requiring the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to create and make available to an employer at no charge a pay stub template that may be used by an employer to comply with the Act; and establishing a certain administrative penalty.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's Wage Payment and Collection law to require employers to provide more detailed written information on employee pay stubs or online pay statements. Required information includes the employer's name, address, telephone number, pay period dates, hours worked (unless exempt), rates of pay, gross and net pay, itemized deductions, and additional bases of pay. The bill also mandates that the Commissioner of Labor and Industry create and make available a free pay stub template for employers to use. Additionally, it establishes administrative penalties for non-compliance and allows employees or the Attorney General to bring civil actions against employers who fail to provide the required information.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry
stakeholders: Employees (who will receive more detailed pay information) and Employers (who must comply with new pay stub requirements and may face penalties for non-compliance).
innovative_summary: The bill updates existing regulations regarding the required content for pay stubs and online pay statements, enhancing transparency and standardization. It also tasks the Commissioner with providing a template to aid employer compliance. While beneficial for clarity, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking governmental approaches beyond standard regulatory updates and support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not directly address child poverty. It enhances wage transparency and accountability, which could indirectly benefit some families by ensuring employees receive correct wages and can identify discrepancies. However, it does not provide direct financial assistance, services, or specific interventions aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Maryland Meals for Achievement In-Classroom Breakfast Program - Alterations (Maryland Meals for Achievement Flexibility Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Clarifying that secondary schools participating in the Maryland Meals for Achievement In-Classroom Breakfast Program may serve breakfast in any broadly accessible part of the school; and authorizing elementary schools participating in the Program, subject to certain approval and allowances, to serve breakfast in any broadly accessible part of the school, including from "Grab and Go" carts.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Maryland Meals for Achievement Flexibility Act of 2024, modifies the Maryland Meals for Achievement In–Classroom Breakfast Program. It clarifies that secondary schools can serve breakfast in any broadly accessible part of the school, including from 'Grab and Go' carts. It also authorizes elementary schools, with Department and county board approval, to serve breakfast in any broadly accessible part of the school, including from 'Grab and Go' carts, provided students can consume the meal in the classroom after the start of the school day.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and county boards or sponsoring agencies for eligible nonpublic schools
stakeholders: Students in Maryland public and eligible nonpublic schools, particularly those attending schools where at least 40% of students are eligible for federal free or reduced-price meals.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces operational flexibility for an existing breakfast program by allowing schools to serve meals in any broadly accessible part of the school, including using 'Grab and Go' carts. This is a practical adaptation to increase accessibility and convenience for students, rather than a new technology or a fundamentally new approach to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program directly addresses child poverty by providing free breakfast to all students in participating schools, specifically targeting those with a high percentage of low-income students. By expanding flexibility in how breakfast is served (e.g., 'Grab and Go' and serving in various accessible locations), it aims to increase participation, reduce hunger, and improve educational outcomes for children from low-income families.

Title: Public Information Act – Surveillance Images – Illegal Dumping in Baltimore City
Synopsis: Altering a requirement that a custodian deny inspection of certain surveillance images of illegal dumping in Baltimore City to allow inspection by an employee or agent of the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development; and authorizing the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development to publicly disseminate a surveillance image as part of an investigation.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Public Information Act in Maryland concerning surveillance images of illegal dumping in Baltimore City. It alters the requirement for custodians to deny inspection of these images, allowing inspection by employees or agents of the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development for investigation or liability proceedings. Furthermore, it authorizes the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development to publicly disseminate these surveillance images as part of an investigation.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Baltimore City residents, particularly those affected by illegal dumping, individuals cited for illegal dumping, and employees/agents of the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development.
innovative_summary: The bill allows the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development to publicly disseminate surveillance images of illegal dumping as part of an investigation. While not using new technology, this represents a more proactive and public approach to enforcement, leveraging existing surveillance capabilities to identify offenders and potentially deter future illegal dumping.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By improving enforcement against illegal dumping, it may contribute to cleaner and safer neighborhoods, which can disproportionately benefit children living in poverty by enhancing their living environment and community well-being. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or resources aimed at alleviating poverty.

Title: Commission on African American History and Culture - Museum Name Change
Synopsis: Altering the name of the museum operated by the Commission on African American History and Culture in certain provisions of law from the "Banneker-Douglass Museum" to the "Banneker-Douglass-Tubman Museum".
bill_summary: This bill renames the Banneker–Douglass Museum, operated by the Commission on African American History and Culture, to the Banneker–Douglass–Tubman Museum. It also makes conforming changes in the legal provisions related to the museum's operation and funding, clarifying that the Commission initiates projects, administers funds, operates the museum, and disseminates information related to African American history and culture. The bill reaffirms the annual appropriation for the Commission.
responsible_party: Commission on African American History and Culture
stakeholders: The general public, especially those interested in African American history and culture, and visitors to the Banneker–Douglass–Tubman Museum.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It primarily involves a name change for an existing museum and updates corresponding legal language, rather than introducing new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on the renaming of a cultural and historical museum, which does not directly address economic needs or support services for children in poverty.

Title: Human Relations - Commission on Civil Rights - Appeal of Final Orders
Synopsis: Providing that a certain final order of the Commission on Civil Rights on a complaint alleging a discriminatory act is appealable in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the process for appealing certain final orders from the Maryland Commission on Civil Rights. Specifically, a denial of a request for reconsideration of a "no probable cause" finding in a discrimination complaint will now be appealable in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act, instead of directly to the circuit court.
responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Civil Rights
stakeholders: Individuals who file discrimination complaints with the Maryland Commission on Civil Rights, especially those whose requests for reconsideration of "no probable cause" findings are denied. Also, the Maryland Commission on Civil Rights and the administrative and judicial bodies involved in the appeal process.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a procedural change regarding how appeals of certain decisions by the Commission on Civil Rights are handled, shifting them to the established Administrative Procedure Act. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes a procedural change to the appeal process for discrimination complaints. While addressing discrimination can indirectly contribute to economic stability for families, this specific change to the appeal mechanism does not have a direct impact on child poverty. It clarifies a legal process rather than providing direct aid, services, or opportunities specifically aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Prince George's County - Sales and Use Tax on Energy and Fuel - Use of Revenue PG 407-24
Synopsis: Altering a certain provision of law relating to the use of certain revenue from the sales and use tax on energy and fuel in Prince George's County by allowing the revenue to be used to meet certain education funding requirements for the county; and repealing a requirement that the county appropriate a certain amount of local money to the school operating budget each fiscal year.
bill_summary: This bill alters the use of revenue from Prince George's County's sales and use tax on energy and fuel. Previously, this revenue was restricted to specific public education budget categories and required a certain amount to be appropriated to the school operating budget. The bill now allows the revenue to be used more broadly to meet the county's overall education funding requirements under State law, and it repeals the specific appropriation requirement for the county's school operating budget each fiscal year.
responsible_party: Prince George's County government
stakeholders: Residents of Prince George's County, particularly those benefiting from or involved in public education, and Prince George's County Public Schools.
innovative_summary: This bill involves fiscal and administrative adjustments to how an existing tax revenue is allocated for education within Prince George's County. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill provides Prince George's County with more flexibility in using existing sales and use tax revenue to meet general education funding requirements. While improved education funding can indirectly support children from low-income families by enhancing educational opportunities, this bill does not directly allocate new funds or establish specific programs to address child poverty.

Title: Public Utilities – Thermal Energy Network Systems – Authorization and Establishment (Working for Accessible Renewable Maryland Thermal Heat (WARMTH) Act)
Synopsis: Requiring gas companies serving at least 75,000 customers in their distribution territories and authorizing gas companies serving fewer than 75,000 customers to develop a plan for a pilot thermal energy network system or systems on or before October 1, 2024; requiring certain gas companies to submit a certain proposal or proposals to the Public Service Commission for approval on or before July 1, 2025; authorizing certain entities or a community organization to submit neighborhoods for consideration as part of a pilot system; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the WARMTH Act, requires certain gas companies to develop and propose pilot thermal energy network systems by October 2024 and July 2025, respectively. These systems utilize renewable, non-greenhouse gas emitting thermal energy for heating and cooling. The Public Service Commission will approve, modify, or reject these proposals by December 2025, with a focus on cost-effectiveness, public interest, and benefits to underserved communities. The bill establishes funding mechanisms, including federal grants and allocations from the Maryland Energy Administration, to cover costs for behind-the-meter projects (like appliance replacements and weatherization) for customers, especially those in low or moderate-income housing. It also includes community benefit agreements, prevailing wage, and local hiring requirements for project construction and maintenance.
responsible_party: Public Service Commission; Maryland Energy Administration
stakeholders: Gas utility customers, particularly those in low or moderate-income housing and underserved/overburdened communities; gas utility companies; and construction workers and local businesses involved in the projects.
innovative_summary: This program is highly innovative as it mandates and pilots the transition from traditional fossil fuel-based gas infrastructure to renewable thermal energy network systems. This represents a significant shift in utility service delivery and decarbonization strategy. The inclusion of Community Benefit Agreements to ensure equitable labor practices, local hiring, and support for disadvantaged businesses further enhances its innovative approach to clean energy infrastructure development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly impact child poverty by explicitly targeting low or moderate-income housing and underserved/overburdened communities. It aims to ensure that participating customers do not pay more for utilities, and provides funding for appliance replacements and weatherization, thereby reducing household energy costs. This frees up household income, directly benefiting children in these families. Additionally, job training and employment opportunities with prevailing wages for local residents and historically disadvantaged groups can provide economic stability for families.

Title: Prince George's County - Taxes on Telecommunications Services - Use of Revenue PG 406-24
Synopsis: Authorizing the Prince George's County Council to impose an excise tax on certain telecommunications service in Prince George's County in addition to, or instead of, a sales and use tax; altering a certain provision of law relating to the use of certain revenue from a certain tax on telecommunications services by allowing the revenue to be used to meet certain education funding requirements for the county; requiring the county to submit an annual report detailing the expenditure of revenues generated by a tax imposed by the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Prince George's County Council to impose an excise tax on telecommunications services, either in addition to or instead of an existing sales and use tax. It also modifies how the revenue from this tax can be used, specifically allowing it to meet the county's primary and secondary education funding requirements, rather than prohibiting its use to supplant State aid or other county funds. The bill further directs that a significant portion of these funds (at least 90%) be used for the Prince George's County school system's operating expenditures, with the remainder for capital projects or debt service. It also requires the Prince George's County Board of Education to consider using these funds for specific programs, including those for disruptive or low-performing students and a Spanish language immersion program.
responsible_party: Prince George's County Council; Prince George's County Board of Education; governing body of Prince George's County
stakeholders: Residents and businesses in Prince George's County who subscribe to telecommunications services, students in Prince George's County (especially disruptive/low-performing students and those in kindergarten through grade 5 for language immersion), the Prince George's County school system, and telecommunications service providers.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves adjustments to local tax authority and the permissible uses of tax revenue for education. While it mentions specific educational programs that could be funded, these are not presented as new or innovative government approaches or technologies introduced by the bill itself. The funding mechanism and its allocation are standard government functions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill allows tax revenue to be used for Prince George's County education funding, including for programs targeting disruptive/low-performing students and a Spanish language immersion program. While improved education can indirectly impact child poverty by enhancing future opportunities and addressing educational disparities often faced by children in poverty, the bill does not directly provide financial assistance or services aimed at immediate poverty reduction. Its impact is indirect through supporting and stabilizing the local education system.

Title: Public Safety - Wellness Checks - Requirements (Gabriel's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring a law enforcement agency that receives a certain request for a wellness check of an individual to conduct a wellness check or submit a request for the relevant law enforcement agency to conduct a wellness check without unreasonable delay; and requiring a fire, rescue, or emergency medical services entity to conduct the wellness check simultaneously with the law enforcement agency if the request concerns a life-threatening condition.
bill_summary: This bill, known as "Gabriel's Law," requires law enforcement agencies in Maryland to conduct wellness checks without unreasonable delay upon receiving a "qualified request" from an "interested party" concerning a life-threatening safety concern. If the individual is outside their jurisdiction, the agency must forward the request to the relevant agency. If the request specifies a life-threatening condition, fire, rescue, or emergency medical services entities must conduct the wellness check simultaneously with law enforcement. The bill defines key terms such as "interested party," "qualified request," and "wellness check."
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies; and, when a life-threatening condition is involved, fire, rescue, or emergency medical services entities.
stakeholders: Individuals for whom wellness checks are requested (particularly those in life-threatening situations), "interested parties" (healthcare practitioners or other informed persons) who initiate requests, and all Maryland law enforcement agencies and fire/rescue/EMS entities.
innovative_summary: The bill formalizes and clarifies existing public safety procedures for conducting wellness checks, especially concerning life-threatening situations and inter-agency coordination. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather refines the operational framework for an existing public safety service.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on immediate safety and wellness of individuals, not on economic support or poverty reduction. While ensuring the safety of adults can indirectly benefit children, this bill does not directly address the root causes or symptoms of child poverty.

Title: Mental Health Law - County Mental Health Advisory Committees - Membership
Synopsis: Altering the membership of a county's mental health advisory committee by including an individual with experience with mental health care for veterans or individuals serving in the military on the list of groups from which individuals may be appointed to the committee by the governing body of the county.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Mental Health Law to alter the membership of a county's mental health advisory committee. It requires the committee to include an individual with experience in mental health care for veterans or individuals serving in the military among its voting members.
responsible_party: County Mental Health Advisory Committees; governing bodies of counties
stakeholders: Individuals with mental disorders, families of individuals with mental disorders, veterans, military personnel, local mental health associations, and various county agencies and professionals involved in mental health care.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It makes a minor administrative change by expanding the required representation on existing county mental health advisory committees to include individuals with experience in veterans' or military mental health care.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is very low. While improved mental health services can indirectly support families and children, this bill only modifies the composition of an advisory committee, which is a very upstream and indirect influence on any potential outcomes related to child poverty.

Title: Maryland Technology Development Corporation - Equitech Growth Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Specifying that the Equitech Growth Fund in the Maryland Technology Development Corporation may be used only to make certain awards and to pay the costs of administering the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill alters the Maryland Technology Development Corporation's Equitech Growth Fund by specifying its uses to support the economic competitiveness and inclusive growth of emerging and advanced industries in Maryland. The Fund will provide grants, investments, loans, or other financial assistance to public, nonprofit, or private entities for workforce development and infrastructure that attracts and retains businesses. The bill mandates an annual appropriation of $5,000,000 to the Fund for fiscal years 2025 through 2033 and outlines administrative requirements, including a competitive application process, review criteria, monitoring processes, and annual reporting.
responsible_party: Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO)
stakeholders: Public, nonprofit, and private entities in Maryland, including institutions of higher education and public-private partnerships, involved in emerging and advanced industries. Ultimately, the residents of Maryland benefiting from economic growth and workforce development.
innovative_summary: The program emphasizes an "Equitech Growth Fund" approach, focusing on supporting "inclusive growth" and "diversity, equity, and inclusion in the State’s innovation economy." While the funding mechanisms (grants, loans, investments) are not new, the explicit focus on equitech and fostering an inclusive innovation ecosystem in advanced industries represents a modern and forward-thinking approach to economic development, leveraging private and federal funding.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to foster economic competitiveness, workforce development, and business attraction in emerging and advanced industries. While creating jobs and economic opportunities can indirectly alleviate child poverty by improving family incomes, the bill does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or interventions specifically targeted at children or families experiencing poverty. The impact is indirect through broader economic benefits.

Title: Maryland Department of Health - Reports on Standing Orders and Opioid Overdose Reversal Drugs
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to report to certain committees of the General Assembly on current opioid overdose reversal drugs and, for any current opioid overdose reversal drug approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration, whether the Department has added the drug to a standing order and, if not, the reasons why the drug has not been added; and requiring the report to be submitted by December 1, 2024, December 1, 2025, and December 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to submit annual reports to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee on opioid overdose reversal drugs and standing orders. The reports, due on or before December 1, 2024, 2025, and 2026, must detail currently approved opioid overdose reversal drugs and whether the Department has added each drug to a standing order, providing reasons if not.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Maryland Department of Health, Senate Finance Committee, House Health and Government Operations Committee. Indirectly, the public at large, particularly those affected by opioid use, as the reports concern the availability and policy around overdose reversal drugs.
innovative_summary: This bill focuses on standard administrative reporting requirements for existing policies regarding opioid overdose reversal drugs and standing orders. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is very low. It mandates reporting on opioid overdose reversal drugs and standing orders, which is an administrative function. While opioid addiction can have severe indirect impacts on families and child well-being, this bill does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, services, or economic support.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Administration - Clarification and Technical Correction
Synopsis: Clarifying that the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System may pay certain incentive compensation to the Chief Investment Officer for the State Retirement and Pension System if the Chief Investment Officer retires from the Investment Division of the State Retirement Agency in a certain manner; and correcting a certain incorrect reference of an age restriction applying to certain members of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System who participate in the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP).
bill_summary: This bill clarifies that the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System may pay incentive compensation to the Chief Investment Officer upon retirement under specific conditions. It also corrects an age restriction reference for members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who participate in the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP).
responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Current and retired employees of the State Retirement and Pension System, State Police Retirement System, and Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System, particularly those participating in the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP), and the Chief Investment Officer for the State Retirement and Pension System.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative clarifications and technical corrections to existing laws regarding the State Retirement and Pension System. It does not introduce any new technologies, innovative programs, or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses administrative rules and compensation for specific state employees within the retirement system. It has no direct mechanisms or stated intent to impact child poverty.

Title: Public Schools - Active Shooter Safety Drills or Trainings - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Center for School Safety to collaborate with an institution of higher education or a designated federal or national research entity to study the effectiveness and impact of active shooter safety drills or trainings by researching and analyzing data collected by local school systems; requiring the Center to identify best practices for active shooter safety drills or trainings on or before October 1, 2024; requiring local school systems to provide parents with the annual schedule of active shooter safety drills; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Center for School Safety to collaborate with research entities to study the effectiveness and psychological impact of active shooter safety drills in public schools, identifying and periodically updating best practices starting by October 1, 2024. The State Department of Education will incorporate these best practices into annual drill schedules, which must be developmentally and age-appropriate. Local school systems are mandated to collect data on drill impact, provide advanced notice and post-drill notifications to parents and students, offer mental health follow-ups, and support students and staff who may experience trauma. The drills are prohibited from including traumatic elements like simulated gunfire or role-playing active shooters. Additionally, the Center must develop model content on safe firearm storage laws for local school systems to distribute to parents annually.
responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety, State Department of Education, local school systems
stakeholders: Public school students, parents, school personnel, local school systems, local law enforcement agencies, institutions of higher education, and designated federal or national research entities
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a more research-driven and trauma-informed approach to school safety drills. By mandating collaboration with research entities to study the psychological impact and effectiveness of drills, and requiring the identification and periodic update of best practices, it moves beyond a one-size-fits-all approach. The explicit prohibition of traumatic elements in drills and the requirement for mental health follow-ups and support for vulnerable individuals represent a significant shift towards a more humane and evidence-based strategy for school safety. The data collection aspect also supports continuous improvement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on school safety through active shooter drills and firearm storage information. While creating a safer school environment benefits all students, including those in poverty, it does not directly address the root causes or symptoms of child poverty, such as providing financial assistance, food security, housing, or educational resources specifically targeted at low-income children. The impact on child poverty would be indirect, through creating a more stable and secure learning environment.

Title: Grant Applications and Reporting - Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the composition of the Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council by removing the Director of the Governor's Grants Office or the Director's designee and adding the Comptroller or the Comptroller's designee; requiring the Council to study and make recommendations to the Department of Budget and Management regarding the creation of a State Grants Ombudsperson by July 1, 2025; altering certain reporting requirements; and extending the termination date of the Council to June 30, 2029.
bill_summary: This bill alters the composition of the Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council, requiring it to study and make recommendations to the Department of Budget and Management regarding the creation of a State Grants Ombudsperson. It also modifies certain reporting requirements for the Council and extends its termination date to June 30, 2029. The changes aim to improve the efficiency and transparency of the State's grant application and management processes.
responsible_party: Maryland Efficient Grant Application Council, Department of Budget and Management
stakeholders: State grant-making agencies, non-State entities (including private nonprofit organizations, local governments), grant professionals, and the communities and individuals served by grant-funded programs.
innovative_summary: The bill promotes a more innovative approach to government by requiring the Council to study the creation of a State Grants Ombudsperson, a dedicated role to provide technical assistance, resolve delays, and disseminate information on grant opportunities. It also emphasizes the development of uniform grant application forms, financial controls, and reporting requirements to streamline and standardize the grant lifecycle across the State, enhancing efficiency and transparency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative improvements to the State's grant application and management system. While grants can fund programs that address child poverty, this legislation does not directly establish or fund such programs. Its impact on child poverty would be indirect, by potentially making it easier for organizations focused on this issue to access and manage State and federal grant funding.

Title: State and Local Parks - Play Area Accessibility - Recreation Communication Boards Pilot Program
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Natural Resources and local governing bodies to construct communication boards in certain newly constructed public play areas; defining "communication board" as a device that displays photos, symbols, or illustrations to enable individuals with limited language skills to communicate; establishing the Maryland Recreation Communication Boards Pilot Program, subject to funding, to improve play area accessibility by covering the cost of purchasing and installing communication boards at State and local parks; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Recreation Communication Boards Pilot Program, administered by the Department of Natural Resources (DNR). The program aims to improve play area accessibility by covering the costs of purchasing and installing communication boards in newly constructed or altered State and local park play areas. Local governing bodies can apply for grants from the DNR, with each grant not exceeding $3,000 per communication board. The program is funded up to $100,000 and runs from July 2024 to June 2028, with the DNR required to submit interim and a final report to the General Assembly.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Children and individuals with limited language skills who use public play areas, as well as local governing bodies responsible for park and recreation area construction and maintenance.
innovative_summary: The program introduces a statewide pilot to systematically integrate communication boards into public park play areas. While communication boards are not new technology, their implementation on a programmatic level across state and local parks to enhance accessibility for individuals with limited language skills represents a novel approach to inclusivity in public recreational spaces.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program improves accessibility to public play areas for all children, including those from low-income families, by providing communication boards. This enhances inclusive recreational opportunities, which can indirectly benefit children in poverty by making public spaces more equitable. However, it does not provide direct financial assistance or specific services targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Montgomery County - Housing Opportunities Commission - Alterations MC 3-24
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that the Housing Opportunities Commission of Montgomery County hold public hearings on assisted family housing proposals; and repealing the requirement that the Montgomery Commission publish a summary of the Montgomery Commission's annual financial report in certain newspapers.
bill_summary: This bill modifies requirements for the Housing Opportunities Commission of Montgomery County. It repeals the need for the Commission to hold public hearings on assisted family housing proposals and removes the requirement to publish a summary of its annual financial report in newspapers. Instead, the bill mandates that the full financial report and certified audit for the previous fiscal year be published on the Commission's website by December 15 each year.
responsible_party: Housing Opportunities Commission of Montgomery County
stakeholders: Residents of Montgomery County, particularly those who might benefit from or be interested in assisted family housing, and the general public seeking financial transparency from the Commission.
innovative_summary: The bill shifts the publication of financial reports from traditional newspapers to the Commission's website, reflecting a move towards digital transparency. This is a modernization of communication but not a groundbreaking innovation in governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's changes are administrative, streamlining processes for the Housing Opportunities Commission which manages assisted family housing. While the Commission's overall mission indirectly impacts families, these specific procedural changes (removing public hearing requirements for proposals and moving financial report publication online) do not directly provide new resources or services to combat child poverty. Their impact is highly indirect and minimal.

Title: Places of Public Accommodation - Motion Picture Houses - Captioning
Synopsis: Requiring all motion picture houses to offer closed movie captioning for each screening of a motion picture, with a certain exception; and requiring, if a motion picture is produced and available to motion picture houses with open movie captioning, a place of public accommodation that controls, operates, owns, or leases a motion picture house with eight or more screens in the State to provide open movie captioning for at least two screenings for each motion picture it screens each week.
bill_summary: This bill mandates that all motion picture houses in Maryland provide closed movie captioning for every screening of a film that is produced with such captioning. Additionally, motion picture houses with eight or more screens must offer open movie captioning for at least two screenings per week for each motion picture shown, with specific conditions and exceptions regarding premiere periods and less frequent screenings. The goal is to enhance accessibility in public accommodations.
responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Civil Rights
stakeholders: Motion picture houses (businesses), and the general public, particularly individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing, and their families.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates the broader implementation and standardization of existing closed and open movie captioning technologies in motion picture houses. While it significantly improves accessibility, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking governmental approaches to service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on enhancing accessibility for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing by mandating captioning services in movie theaters. It does not provide direct financial aid, resources, or specific programs designed to alleviate child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect and negligible.

Title: Community Schools - Rental Assistance for Community School Families Program and Fund - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Rental Assistance for Community School Families Program to provide rental assistance to eligible student households; requiring the Department of Housing and Community Development, in consultation with the State Department of Education, to administer the Program; establishing the Rental Assistance for Community School Families Fund; authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation of $10,000,000 in the annual budget bill for the Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Rental Assistance for Community School Families Program and Fund. The program provides direct rental and utility assistance, including arrears and relocation expenses, to eligible student households attending community schools who are at risk of homelessness or housing instability, or qualify for federal homeless assistance. The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development administers the program, in consultation with the State Department of Education, and is also responsible for administering the dedicated nonlapsing fund.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, in consultation with the State Department of Education
stakeholders: Students enrolled in community schools and their families who are at risk of homelessness or housing instability, or qualify for federal homeless assistance, and are counted under compensatory education enrollment.
innovative_summary: This program establishes a new mechanism for providing direct rental and utility assistance by leveraging the existing structure of community schools and their coordinators to identify and support families at risk of housing instability. While rental assistance programs exist, integrating this directly with the community school system for identification and aid delivery represents a novel approach to addressing student well-being through housing stability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program has a very high potential to directly impact child poverty by providing rental and utility assistance to families facing housing instability. Stable housing is a fundamental determinant of child well-being, education, and health, directly alleviating financial burdens that contribute to poverty and homelessness.

Title: Department of Veterans Affairs - Renaming and Deputy Secretary of Military Family Policy and Programs
Synopsis: Renaming the Department of Veterans Affairs to be the Department of Veterans and Military Families; renaming the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to be the Secretary of Veterans and Military Families; requiring the Secretary to appoint a Deputy Secretary of Military Family Policy and Programs; and providing that the Department of Veterans and Military Families is the successor of the Department of Veterans Affairs.
bill_summary: This bill renames the Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs to the Department of Veterans and Military Families, and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to the Secretary of Veterans and Military Families. It also mandates the appointment of a Deputy Secretary of Military Family Policy and Programs within the newly renamed department, whose role will be to direct policies and programs related to military families.
responsible_party: Department of Veterans and Military Families, Secretary of Veterans and Military Families, Deputy Secretary of Military Family Policy and Programs
stakeholders: Veterans and military families in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily involves an administrative renaming of a department and the creation of a new leadership position to focus on military families. While it broadens the scope of the department, it does not introduce new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services or delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a Deputy Secretary position to direct policies and programs for military families. While future programs under this office could potentially benefit children in military families and address factors contributing to poverty, the bill itself does not directly implement any specific programs, financial aid, or services aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Courts and Judicial Proceedings and Criminal Procedure - Technical Corrections - References to Intellectual Disability
Synopsis: Replacing references to mental retardation with references to an intellectual disability in certain provisions of law.
bill_summary: This bill makes technical corrections to Maryland law by replacing all instances of the term "mental retardation" with "intellectual disability" across various sections of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article and the Criminal Procedure Article. It also adds a definition for "intellectual disability" within these legal contexts. The changes aim to update legal terminology to align with current and more appropriate language.
responsible_party: The Maryland legal and judicial system, including courts and related state agencies such as the Department of Health and the Developmental Disabilities Administration, are responsible for applying the updated terminology in practice.
stakeholders: Individuals with intellectual disabilities, children identified as having an intellectual disability, their families, legal professionals (such as judges and attorneys), and state agencies involved in the judicial process and providing care for individuals with intellectual disabilities.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It is a technical correction focused on updating legal terminology to be more respectful and current, rather than introducing new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. Its purpose is to update legal terminology from "mental retardation" to "intellectual disability," which does not directly address economic factors or provide resources to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Persons Providing Lobbyist Compensation – Statement of Political Contributions – Exemption for Nonprofits
Synopsis: Exempting nonprofit organizations qualified under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code from the requirement for a person providing lobbyist compensation to file a statement of political contributions with the State Board of Elections.
bill_summary: This bill exempts certain nonprofit organizations, specifically those qualified under " 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, from the existing requirement to file a statement of political contributions with the State Board of Elections when providing compensation to lobbyists.
responsible_party: State Board of Elections
stakeholders:
Nonprofit organizations qualified under 
 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and entities involved in lobbying activities.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a regulatory adjustment by providing an exemption for specific nonprofit organizations from an existing reporting requirement. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government functions or services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on lobbying regulations and political contribution reporting requirements for nonprofit organizations. It has no direct provisions or mechanisms that would immediately or directly impact child poverty.

Title: Child Support - Incarcerated Obligors
Synopsis: Authorizing a court, if an obligor becomes incarcerated, to determine that a material change of circumstances warranting a modification of child support has occurred, provided that the party's ability to pay child support is sufficiently reduced due to the incarceration.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland's child support laws regarding incarcerated parents. It allows courts to consider incarceration as a material change in circumstances for modifying child support. It also prevents child support arrearages from accruing during incarceration (and for 60 days post-release) if the obligor is not on work release and lacks sufficient resources, removing previous requirements related to the length of sentence and intent to commit a crime. Additionally, it clarifies that an incarcerated parent is not considered 'voluntarily impoverished,' meaning potential income cannot be imputed to them for child support calculations based on that status. The Child Support Administration is authorized to adjust accounts to reflect these changes.
responsible_party: Maryland Child Support Administration; Maryland Courts
stakeholders: Incarcerated parents (obligors), parents receiving child support (obligees), and their children.
innovative_summary: This bill refines existing legal frameworks for child support, specifically addressing the unique financial circumstances of incarcerated parents. While it doesn't introduce new technologies or entirely new government services, it represents an updated approach to calculating and enforcing child support for a specific population, aiming for more equitable and realistic outcomes by preventing insurmountable debt for incarcerated individuals.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to directly impact child poverty is indirect. It primarily focuses on making child support calculations more equitable and realistic for incarcerated parents by preventing the accrual of unpayable debt (arrearages) and prohibiting the imputation of 'potential income.' While preventing excessive debt might improve an obligor's financial stability post-release, potentially leading to more consistent future support for their children, it does not provide direct financial assistance or services to families experiencing poverty.

Title: Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council - Membership
Synopsis: Codifying provisions relating to the Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council; altering and clarifying the composition of the Council to include certain public and private sector members; requiring the Council to submit interim reports of its work to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024, and December 1, 2025; and requiring the Council to submit a final report of its work and recommendations by June 30, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill codifies and modifies the membership of the Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council. It clarifies the composition of the Council to include representatives from various public and private sectors, such as state agencies, legislators, local government associations, higher education, electric vehicle manufacturers, charging station manufacturers, fleet operators, electrical workers, environmental groups, and public members. The Council is tasked with developing action plans, statewide standards, infrastructure plans, consumer awareness initiatives, incentive recommendations, and policies to promote the adoption and integration of zero-emission electric vehicles in Maryland. The Council will submit interim reports in 2024 and 2025, and a final report by June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Zero Emission Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Council; Department of Transportation (for staff support); Maryland Energy Administration (for staff assistance); Maryland Public Service Commission (for staff assistance)
stakeholders: Maryland residents (as consumers and environmental beneficiaries), electric vehicle manufacturers, fuel cell electric vehicle manufacturers, charging station manufacturers, electric utility companies, new vehicle dealers, fleet vehicle operators, electrical workers, environmental organizations, local governments, state agencies, higher education institutions, and automotive dismantlers and recyclers.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on the governance structure of a council dedicated to promoting zero-emission electric vehicles, which represents a forward-looking environmental and transportation initiative. However, the bill itself is primarily an administrative change, codifying and expanding the membership of an existing council. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking governmental approaches, but rather aims to improve coordination and policy development for an innovative sector.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses exclusively on the promotion and infrastructure development for zero-emission electric vehicles. While a cleaner environment and potential economic development in the EV sector could indirectly benefit all Maryland residents over time, there are no direct provisions, goals, or explicit mechanisms within this bill to specifically address or mitigate child poverty.

Title: Income Tax Credit - Venison Donation
Synopsis: Allowing an individual, subject to certain requirements and limitations, to claim a credit against the State income tax for certain qualified expenses if the individual harvests an antlerless deer and donates the deer meat to certain organizations; limiting the amount of credits an individual may claim to a maximum of $300; and requiring by January 31 each year each venison donation program that received certain donations to report certain information about each donor who intended to claim the credit to the Comptroller.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a State income tax credit for individuals who harvest an antlerless deer and donate the processed meat to a qualified venison donation program. The credit allows individuals to claim up to $75 for qualified butchering and processing expenses per deer, with an annual maximum credit of $300 (or $600 if deer were harvested under a deer management permit). The bill also extends immunity from liability for donated food to individuals claiming this credit. Venison donation programs are required to report donor information to the Comptroller annually. The tax credit is applicable for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2023, and before January 1, 2029.
responsible_party: Comptroller
stakeholders: Individuals who hunt and donate antlerless deer meat, 501(c)(3) venison donation programs, and food-insecure individuals and families who receive the donated meat.
innovative_summary: The bill utilizes a tax credit, a standard policy tool, to incentivize charitable donations of venison. While it encourages a beneficial activity, it does not introduce new technologies or a novel approach to governmental programs or services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program indirectly impacts child poverty by increasing the availability of nutritious protein (deer meat) for food assistance organizations. This can benefit families experiencing food insecurity, including those with children in poverty, by providing them with more food options. However, it does not directly target children in poverty with specific services or financial aid.

Title: Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program - Funding for Underserved and Overburdened Communities
Synopsis: Requiring at least 40% of funding provided under the comprehensive flood management grant program to be used for projects located in or directly benefiting underserved or overburdened communities; and authorizing the Governor to include in the annual State budget an appropriation of up to $20,000,000 for the comprehensive flood management grant program in fiscal year 2026 and each fiscal year thereafter.
bill_summary: The bill amends the Comprehensive Flood Management Grant Program to require that starting in fiscal year 2026, at least 40% of its funding be used for projects located in or directly benefiting underserved or overburdened communities. It also authorizes the Governor to include in the annual State budget an appropriation of up to $20,000,000 for the program in fiscal year 2026 and each fiscal year thereafter.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Residents of Maryland, especially those in underserved or overburdened communities vulnerable to flooding, and local government subdivisions.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces an innovative policy by mandating a significant percentage of existing flood management grant funding specifically for underserved and overburdened communities, thereby promoting equity in environmental resilience efforts and resource distribution.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By directing flood mitigation funds to underserved and overburdened communities, which often experience higher rates of poverty, the program helps protect homes, livelihoods, and infrastructure, thereby preventing economic hardship, displacement, and long-term instability that can exacerbate child poverty. The impact is indirect but significant in preventing a negative economic shock to vulnerable families.

Title: Tax Assistance for Low-Income Marylanders - Funding
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller, beginning in fiscal year 2025, to distribute a certain amount of abandoned property funds to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund; requiring the Governor to include $800,000 in the annual budget for the CASH Campaign of Maryland to award grants for providing certain tax assistance through on-demand and mobile tax clinics; and requiring certain tax clinics to interact with the CASH campaign to ensure sufficient access to tax preparation services for low-income Maryland residents.
bill_summary: This bill enhances funding for tax assistance for low-income Marylanders. It requires the Comptroller, beginning in fiscal year 2025, to distribute $500,000 annually from abandoned property funds to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund. The bill also mandates the Governor to include increased annual appropriations for the CASH Campaign of Maryland in the State budget: $500,000 for fiscal years 2024 and 2025, and $800,000 for fiscal year 2026 and each fiscal year thereafter. A portion of this increased funding ($150,000 annually from FY2026) is earmarked for grants to external entities operating on-demand or mobile tax clinics that serve senior, rural, or under-resourced communities. Additionally, all tax clinics supported by these funds must interact with the CASH Campaign to ensure sufficient access to tax preparation services for low-income residents.
responsible_party: Comptroller, Governor, CASH Campaign of Maryland
stakeholders: Low-income Maryland residents, including senior populations, rural communities, and under-resourced communities (including new American populations).
innovative_summary: The program promotes on-demand and mobile tax clinics, which is an innovative approach to deliver tax assistance services directly to underserved populations, improving accessibility beyond traditional brick-and-mortar sites. This flexible service delivery model helps reach individuals who might face barriers to accessing traditional tax preparation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a direct potential to impact child poverty by providing free tax preparation services. This assistance helps low-income families claim valuable tax credits, such as the federal and State earned income tax credits, and avoid predatory fees. By increasing their disposable income and preventing financial exploitation, the program directly alleviates financial hardship for families with children.

Title: Individual Tax Preparers - Code of Ethics, Notification of Actions, Enforcement, and Penalties (Stop Scam Tax Preparers Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers to publish on the Board's website a certain code of ethics and rules of professional conduct by January 1, 2026; requiring the Board to notify the Comptroller and the Field Enforcement Bureau of a violation within 5 business days after the Board determines that the violation has occurred; granting certain employees of the Bureau certain powers, duties, and responsibilities for enforcing laws pertaining to income tax preparation; etc.
bill_summary: The Stop Scam Tax Preparers Act requires the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers to publish a code of ethics and rules of professional conduct by January 1, 2026. It enhances enforcement by mandating the Board notify the Comptroller and the Field Enforcement Bureau of violations and disciplinary actions within five business days. The bill grants the Field Enforcement Bureau new powers to enforce income tax preparation laws and requires the Comptroller to notify the Board if an income tax preparer is prohibited from submitting returns electronically. It also prohibits unlicensed individuals from preparing income tax returns or claims for refund and directs any fines from such violations to the Tax Clinics for Low–Income Marylanders Fund.
responsible_party: State Board of Individual Tax Preparers, Comptroller, Field Enforcement Bureau of the Comptroller’s Office
stakeholders: Individual tax preparers, low-income Maryland residents, and the general public seeking tax preparation services.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily strengthens existing regulatory frameworks and enforcement mechanisms for individual tax preparers. It mandates the publication of a code of ethics and rules of conduct and improves inter-agency communication regarding violations. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking approaches to government services, focusing instead on tightening oversight of a regulated profession.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. It aims to protect low-income Marylanders from fraudulent tax preparers and directs fines from violations to the Tax Clinics for Low–Income Marylanders Fund. These clinics provide legal assistance with tax matters to low-income individuals, which could help families retain more income or navigate tax issues that might otherwise lead to financial hardship. However, it is not a direct intervention or benefit delivery program specifically targeting child poverty.

Title: Income Tax – Technical Corrections
Synopsis: Repealing certain obsolete provisions of law concerning the distribution of income tax revenue; and correcting a certain erroneous cross-reference.
bill_summary: This bill makes technical corrections to Maryland's income tax law. Specifically, it repeals obsolete provisions related to the distribution of income tax revenue to municipalities and corrects an erroneous cross-reference concerning an income tax credit for catalytic revitalization projects.
responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers, the General Fund of the State, and any entities previously impacted by the obsolete income tax distribution provisions.
innovative_summary: This bill makes technical corrections to existing law by repealing obsolete provisions and correcting an erroneous cross-reference. It does not introduce any innovative approaches or technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on technical corrections to income tax law, such as repealing obsolete distribution provisions and fixing a cross-reference. It does not establish new programs or allocate funds that would have a direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Disclosure of Tax Information - Tax Compliance Activity and Binding Data Use Agreements
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "tax information" for purposes of law governing the confidentiality and disclosure of tax information; authorizing, subject to certain limitations, the disclosure of certain tax information to certain tax compliance organizations and governmental entities to assist the Comptroller in tax compliance activity; requiring the Comptroller to require the party to whom the information is to be disclosed to enter into a written, binding agreement regarding the use and security of the tax information; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the definition of "tax information" to include more types of tax returns and information. It authorizes the Comptroller to disclose certain tax information to tax compliance organizations and governmental entities for the purpose of assisting the Comptroller in tax compliance activities. Such disclosure requires the recipient to enter into a binding written data use agreement with the Comptroller, which outlines the use and security of the information. The Comptroller is also required to supervise the recipients of this tax information. The bill also establishes penalties for unauthorized disclosure of this information by officers or employees of these organizations.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller
stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers, governmental entities, and tax compliance organizations that assist the Comptroller with tax compliance activities.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces formal, binding data use agreements and mandates Comptroller supervision for the sharing of tax information with external entities for compliance purposes. This approach enhances data governance, security, and inter-organizational cooperation, representing a modern best practice in managing sensitive government data, though not necessarily employing new technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on tax information disclosure and compliance. It does not directly establish programs or provide resources aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact would be highly indirect, such as increased tax revenue potentially leading to future funding for social programs, but this is not the bill's direct purpose or effect.

Title: Comptroller - Electronic Tax and Fee Return Filing Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring, for periods beginning after December 31, 2026, that returns for certain taxes and fees collected by the Comptroller be filed electronically, subject to certain exceptions; altering certain requirements for electronic filing of returns for certain taxes; prohibiting a certain tax return preparer or software company from charging a separate fee for the electronic filing of certain tax documents; and prohibiting a software company from selling different versions of the same tax software under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill mandates that returns for various taxes and fees collected by the Comptroller, including tire recycling fees, Bay restoration fees, admissions and amusement taxes, alcoholic beverage taxes, digital advertising gross revenues taxes, motor fuel taxes, income taxes (individual, corporate, and pass-through entity), income tax withholding, sales and use taxes, and tobacco taxes, must be filed electronically. Exceptions are provided for individuals with disabilities, religious beliefs prohibiting electronic filing, or other special needs as determined by the Comptroller. For individual income tax, exceptions also apply based on age and Maryland adjusted gross income thresholds. The bill also prohibits tax return preparers and software companies from charging a separate fee for electronic filing of authorized tax documents and prevents software companies from selling different versions of the same tax software based on whether a separate e-filing fee is charged. Civil penalties are established for violations of the fee prohibition.
responsible_party: Comptroller of the Treasury
stakeholders: Tax return preparers, software companies, tire dealers, local governments, water/wastewater billing authorities, individuals, corporations, pass-through entities, and anyone required to file returns for the specified taxes and fees.
innovative_summary: The bill's core mandate of electronic tax filing is a standard modernization effort, rather than truly innovative. However, the provisions prohibiting separate fees for electronic filing and preventing software companies from offering different versions of tax software based on such fees introduce a novel regulatory approach to ensure equitable access to and adoption of electronic filing, which is a moderately innovative aspect.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative changes to tax and fee filing processes and fee structures for tax preparation software. It does not introduce programs, services, or financial support directly aimed at alleviating child poverty, nor does it modify eligibility for poverty-reducing benefits. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect through general government efficiency or revenue collection, which is not considered a direct impact.

Title: Environment - Synthetic Turf - Disclosure and Study
Synopsis: Requiring a producer or seller of synthetic turf to disclose to a customer typical maintenance practices and costs for removing, replacing, and disposing of synthetic turf; and requiring the Department of the Environment, in consultation with representatives of the industry, local environmental and community stakeholders, and synthetic turf producers, retailers, and users, to conduct a study on the synthetic turf industry in the State and report its findings to certain committees of the General Assembly by July 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires producers and sellers of synthetic turf to disclose maintenance and cost information (for removal, replacement, and disposal) to customers. It also mandates the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to establish and maintain a system to track the chain of custody of synthetic turf installed on sports and playing fields in the State, from installation through reuse, recycling, or final disposal. Custodians of synthetic turf fields are required to report installation and removal information to the MDE. Additionally, the MDE must conduct a comprehensive study on synthetic turf, existing fields, and the industry in the State, with a report due by July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Producers and sellers of synthetic turf, customers of synthetic turf, custodians of synthetic turf sports and playing fields (including local governments, county school systems, higher education facilities, and professional sports organizations), and local environmental and community stakeholders.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a novel statewide chain-of-custody tracking system for synthetic turf, covering its entire lifecycle from installation to disposal or recycling. This approach aims to improve environmental oversight and waste management for a specific product, coupled with a comprehensive study to inform future policy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on environmental regulation, disclosure, and waste management of synthetic turf. It does not directly provide economic assistance, educational programs, healthcare, or other services that would immediately and directly impact child poverty. Any potential benefits would be indirect through broader environmental improvements.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Protection of Identity of Minor Victim
Synopsis: Providing that a court or a party in a criminal or juvenile delinquency case may not disclose or allow inspection of an electronic or paper court filing to a nonparty to the case unless the court or the party disclosing or allowing inspection of the filing redacts all identifying information relating to a minor victim that appears in the filing, unless the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that there is good cause to order otherwise.
bill_summary: This bill amends criminal procedure to prevent the disclosure of identifying information of minor victims in criminal and juvenile delinquency court filings to nonparties, requiring redaction unless a court finds good cause to order otherwise. It defines "identifying information" and "minor victim" for this purpose, and allows the Supreme Court of Maryland to adopt rules regarding this redaction.
responsible_party: Maryland Courts and parties in criminal and juvenile delinquency cases, with the Supreme Court of Maryland having authority to adopt rules.
stakeholders: Minor victims involved in criminal or juvenile delinquency cases.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a procedural change to protect the identity of minor victims in court filings. While important for privacy and victim protection, it does not employ new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services or operations; rather, it updates existing legal processes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on protecting the privacy of minor victims in legal proceedings by redacting their identifying information from public court filings. It does not provide direct financial assistance, services, or interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.
