Title: Health - State Advisory Council on Quality Care at the End of Life - Renaming
Synopsis: Renaming the State Advisory Council on Quality Care at the End of Life to be the State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care.
bill_summary: This bill renames the "State Advisory Council on Quality Care at the End of Life" to the "State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care." It updates all references to the council in the Annotated Code of Maryland to reflect this new name. The purpose is to broaden the council's focus from solely end-of-life care to a more comprehensive approach to serious illness care. The council's duties, membership, and operational structure largely remain the same, involving monitoring trends, studying policy impacts, providing recommendations to State agencies and the General Assembly, and promoting public and professional education concerning care at the end of life/serious illness.
responsible_party: State Advisory Council on Serious Illness Care; Department of Aging; Office of the Attorney General; Department of Health; Governor
stakeholders: Marylanders with serious or life-limiting illnesses, healthcare professionals (physicians, nurses, pharmacists), long-term care providers, health insurance industry, managed care organizations, legal community, hospice care community, advocacy groups, religious groups, hospital industry, nursing home industry, and the general public.
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, focusing on renaming an existing advisory council to broaden its scope. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government services or policymaking. The core functions and structure of the council remain unchanged.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill renames an advisory council focused on care for serious and life-limiting illnesses. While children may experience serious illnesses, the bill does not establish any direct programs, funding, or specific interventions aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty. Its focus is on advisory capacity for healthcare quality and policy, not economic support for children in poverty.

Title: Health Occupations – Practice Audiology – Definition
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "practice audiology" for the purposes of certain provisions of law governing the licensure and regulation of audiologists to include certain procedures that do not require anesthesia.
bill_summary: This bill alters the definition of "practice audiology" in Maryland law to expand the scope of services audiologists can provide. It specifically includes the evaluation, diagnosis, management, and treatment of auditory or vestibular conditions, as well as the prescription, ordering, selling, dispensing, or fitting of sound processors for osseointegrated devices and cochlear implants. The bill also clarifies that the practice of audiology includes health screenings, removal of non-impacted foreign bodies and cerumen, ordering certain cultures, bloodwork, and imaging (non-radiographic in-office and ordering radiographic), while explicitly excluding surgical procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Examiners for Audiologists (under the Department of Health)
stakeholders: Audiologists in Maryland, individuals with hearing or vestibular conditions, and patients using or considering hearing aids, osseointegrated devices, or cochlear implants.
innovative_summary: The bill updates the scope of audiology practice to include modern technologies like sound processors for osseointegrated devices and cochlear implants. It also formally includes a wider range of diagnostic and non-surgical procedures, reflecting advancements in audiological care and technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill redefines the scope of practice for audiologists. While improved access to comprehensive audiology services could indirectly benefit children by addressing hearing and vestibular issues, potentially reducing related educational or healthcare costs for families, it does not directly provide financial assistance, educational programs, or other services specifically targeting child poverty.

Title: Workplace Fraud and Prevailing Wage - Violations - Civil Penalty and Referrals
Synopsis: Increasing, from $5,000 to $10,000, the maximum civil penalty for the knowing failure of an employer to properly classify an individual as an employee; and requiring the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, on a showing by clear and convincing evidence that a violation has occurred,  to refer to the Comptroller, certain State's Attorneys, the U.S. Department of Justice, the U.S. Department of Labor, and the U.S. Department of the Treasury complaints that allege a violation of certain tax laws.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum civil penalty for employers who knowingly misclassify individuals as contractors instead of employees, from $5,000 to $10,000 per misclassified employee. It also establishes a misdemeanor penalty for knowing misclassification, punishable by a fine up to $5,000 or 60 days imprisonment, or both, per employee. The bill mandates the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to refer complaints alleging violations of certain tax laws (related to misclassification or prevailing wage) to the Comptroller, relevant State's Attorneys, the U.S. Department of Justice, the U.S. Department of Labor, and the U.S. Department of the Treasury. Additionally, it adds a misdemeanor penalty for contractors or subcontractors who knowingly violate prevailing wage laws.
responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry, Maryland Department of Labor, Department of Budget and Management, Secretary of State, Comptroller, Maryland Insurance Administration, State's Attorneys, U.S. Department of Justice, U.S. Department of Labor, U.S. Department of the Treasury
stakeholders: Employers, contractors, subcontractors, employees, and federal and state tax and labor enforcement agencies.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances existing enforcement mechanisms and strengthens inter-agency cooperation by mandating referrals of tax-related violations to multiple state and federal authorities. While not introducing entirely new technologies or approaches, it systematizes and formalizes cross-agency data sharing and enforcement actions for workplace fraud and prevailing wage violations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By increasing penalties for employee misclassification and strengthening prevailing wage enforcement, the bill aims to ensure workers receive proper wages, benefits, and tax compliance. This can indirectly reduce child poverty by improving the financial stability and income of working parents, ensuring they receive the full compensation and protections they are legally entitled to, which can uplift household income.

Title: Commission to Advance Lithium-Ion Battery Safety in Maryland
Synopsis: Establishing the Commission to Advance Lithium-Ion Battery Safety in Maryland to study and make legislative, regulatory, programmatic, or other recommendations regarding certain best practices, standards, and guidelines; requiring the Commission to submit an interim progress report to the Legislative Policy Committee by December 1, 2024; and requiring the Commission to submit a final report of its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Commission to Advance Lithium–Ion Battery Safety in Maryland. The Commission is tasked with studying and making recommendations on best practices, standards, and guidelines for preventing, detecting, and suppressing lithium-ion battery fires in consumer, transportation, and utility applications, as well as at recycling facilities. It will also examine the viability of extended producer responsibility for batteries, and develop training and education for the public and first responders on battery safety. The Commission is required to submit an interim report by December 1, 2024, and a final report with findings and recommendations by December 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Commission to Advance Lithium–Ion Battery Safety in Maryland, staffed by the Office of the State Fire Marshal
stakeholders: The public, first responders, lithium-ion battery manufacturers, vehicle propulsion battery manufacturers, utility companies, recycling facilities, vehicle dismantling sector, battery recycling trade groups, and various Maryland state agencies and associations involved in environment, energy, natural resources, public service, and fire safety.
innovative_summary: The bill addresses a modern and evolving technological safety concern – lithium-ion batteries – through the traditional governmental mechanism of establishing a study commission. While the subject matter is current, the approach of forming a commission to research and recommend policy is not innovative in itself. The commission will explore current best practices, potential extended producer responsibility, and public education regarding this technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on public safety related to lithium-ion batteries and does not contain any provisions that directly address child poverty. Its impact is on general safety and environmental practices, without a specific mechanism for poverty reduction.

Title: Election Law - Postelection Procedures
Synopsis: Altering the records and documents that a board of canvassers is required to investigate under certain circumstances; altering the responsibilities of the State Administrator, the State Board of Elections, and the Board of State Canvassers regarding the certification of election results; authorizing the members of the Board of State Canvassers to appoint certain designees to serve on the Board of State Canvassers; and altering the responsibilities of the Governor regarding election results.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland's post-election procedures. It alters the records and documents that boards of canvassers must investigate for errors, clarifies the responsibilities of the State Administrator, State Board of Elections, and Board of State Canvassers in certifying election results, and authorizes members of the Board of State Canvassers to appoint designees. Additionally, it changes the Governor's responsibilities regarding election results, including the issuance of certificates and posting proclamations on the State Board's website.
responsible_party: State Administrator, State Board of Elections, Board of State Canvassers, and the Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Maryland election officials, including local boards of canvassers, the State Administrator, the State Board of Elections, the Board of State Canvassers, the Governor, and indirectly, Maryland voters and political candidates.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily focuses on administrative and procedural adjustments to existing election law. The most notable update is the requirement for the Governor to post election proclamations on the State Board's website instead of publishing them in newspapers, which is a minor technological shift towards digital communication but not a new or innovative approach to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill deals exclusively with election law and post-election procedures. It has no direct provisions, funding, or mechanisms that would directly impact or address child poverty.

Title: Education - School Mapping Data Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the School Mapping Data Program in the Maryland Center for School Safety; providing that the purpose of the Program is to provide funds to local school systems to produce school mapping data for each public school and public charter school in the county to assist first responders in responding to emergencies at a school; authorizing the use of the Safe Schools Fund to provide funding to local school systems for the program; and requiring a certain custodian of records to deny inspection of school mapping data.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the School Mapping Data Program within the Maryland Center for School Safety. Its purpose is to provide funds to local school systems to create detailed electronic or digital school mapping data for every public school, including public charter schools. This data is designed to assist first responders during emergencies and must comply with facility mapping standards adopted by the Interagency Commission on School Construction. The School Safety Subcabinet may use the Safe Schools Fund to provide grants for this program. Additionally, the bill restricts public inspection of this sensitive school mapping data.
responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety
stakeholders: Local school systems, public schools (including public charter schools), local law enforcement agencies, first responders, students, and school personnel.
innovative_summary: The program leverages digital and electronic mapping technology to create standardized, detailed facility maps compatible with various software platforms used by public safety agencies and potentially integrated into interactive mobile platforms. This systematic approach to school safety planning, using precise digital data for emergency response, represents a modern and technologically integrated approach to public safety and preparedness.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program focuses on improving school safety through advanced mapping data for emergency responders. While a safer school environment can indirectly benefit all students, including those experiencing poverty, by fostering a more stable learning environment, it does not directly address the economic or social factors that contribute to child poverty. Therefore, its direct impact on child poverty is minimal.

Title: Education - Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program - Establishment (Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program Act)
Synopsis: Establishing the Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program within the State Department of Education to provide free, open-source phonics learning materials to be used by adults to tutor students; requiring the Department to periodically review the open-source phonics learning materials to ensure the materials are consistent with best practices in literacy education, including the science of reading; and requiring the Governor each fiscal year to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $150,000 to the Program.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Open-Source Phonics Matching Grant Program within the State Department of Education. The program provides matching funds to eligible open-source phonics organizations (nonprofit organizations, institutions of higher education, or public libraries) that produce or distribute free, open-source phonics learning materials. These materials are to be used by adults to tutor students in Maryland and must align with best practices in literacy education, including the science of reading. The Department will administer the program, review materials for consistency with best practices, and report on the program's effectiveness biennially.
responsible_party: State Department of Education
stakeholders: Open-source phonics organizations (nonprofit organizations, institutions of higher education, and public libraries), adults who tutor students, and students in the State of Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs an innovative approach by leveraging an "open-source" model for educational materials, promoting free distribution, and allowing modification of learning resources. This method, combined with state matching grants for distribution, represents a modern strategy for disseminating educational content and ensuring alignment with the "science of reading," which reflects current research-backed best practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly providing financial assistance, the program has a strong indirect potential to impact child poverty by improving literacy rates among students through effective phonics instruction and adult tutoring. Enhanced literacy is a foundational skill that significantly improves educational attainment, future employment prospects, and overall economic stability, thereby contributing to breaking cycles of poverty.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Forensic Genetic Genealogical DNA Analysis and Search - Applicability for Deceased and Missing Individuals
Synopsis: Providing that certain provisions of law regarding the use of a certain forensic genetic genealogical DNA analysis and search (FGGS) do not apply when the FGGS is conducted solely for the purpose of identifying an individual who is deceased or the subject of a certain missing person report and whose whereabouts are unknown.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies that certain legal restrictions on Forensic Genetic Genealogical DNA Analysis and Search (FGGS) do not apply when the analysis is conducted solely for the purpose of identifying an individual under the age of 18 years who is either deceased or the subject of a missing person report filed with a law enforcement agency in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Families of deceased or missing individuals under 18, law enforcement agencies, and the broader criminal justice system in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill does not introduce new technology, but it expands the permissible application of an existing innovative forensic technique (Forensic Genetic Genealogical DNA Analysis and Search or FGGS) by removing certain restrictions for the identification of deceased or missing individuals under 18. This represents an innovative approach to utilizing advanced DNA analysis for humanitarian and public safety purposes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on criminal procedure and the identification of deceased or missing children. While it addresses a critical public safety and humanitarian concern for families, it does not directly offer financial aid, services, or policies designed to alleviate the economic causes or symptoms of child poverty. Its impact on child poverty is indirect, if at all, by providing resolution to traumatic family situations, but not by addressing economic hardship.

Title: Natural Resources - Antlerless Deer Hunting Programs - Authorization
Synopsis: Authorizing a person to receive a raffle ticket for each antlerless deer hunted by the person during a certain raffle program that has as its objective the hunting of antlerless deer.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes individuals to receive a raffle ticket for each antlerless deer hunted during specific raffle programs. These programs must be held in January, aim to hunt antlerless deer, and have been previously held at least once between January 1, 2020, and January 30, 2024. This change provides an exception to the general prohibition on selling, bartering, or exchanging game mammals.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Hunters participating in antlerless deer raffle programs in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill modifies existing regulations to allow for raffle tickets in certain antlerless deer hunting programs. It does not introduce new technologies or significantly change governmental approaches; rather, it provides a legal exception for a specific type of incentive within recreational hunting.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is related to hunting regulations and does not have a direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on game management and recreational hunting incentives.

Title: Residential Property Sales - Contract Disclosures - Superfund Sites
Synopsis: Requiring the seller of residential real property located within 1 mile of a National Priorities List (NPL) Superfund site to provide the buyer with an addendum to the contract for the sale of the property that contains the identification of the Superfund site, the definition of an NPL Superfund site, web addresses for certain websites, and a notice that the buyer may void the contract of sale within 5 days after signing and dating the contract of sale.
bill_summary: This bill requires sellers of residential real property located within one mile of a National Priorities List (NPL) Superfund site to provide buyers with a specific addendum to the contract of sale. This addendum must identify the Superfund site, define it, include URLs for relevant U.S. Environmental Protection Agency websites, and notify the buyer that they may void the contract within 5 days of signing and receive a full refund.
responsible_party: Sellers of residential property; implicitly overseen by the Maryland Real Estate Commission regarding real estate practices.
stakeholders: Sellers and buyers of residential real property in Maryland located within one mile of a National Priorities List (NPL) Superfund site.
innovative_summary: This bill updates existing real estate disclosure requirements. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches, but rather clarifies and expands information disclosure for consumers regarding environmental hazards near residential properties.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on consumer protection in real estate transactions by mandating disclosures about environmental hazards. While living in a safe environment is beneficial, the bill does not directly address financial, educational, or social support mechanisms that would alleviate child poverty.

Title: Income Tax - Subtraction Modification for Donations to Diaper Banks and Other Charitable Entities - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending the termination date applicable to a subtraction under the Maryland income tax for certain donations to diaper banks and other charitable entities; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2020, but before January 1, 2027.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date of an existing Maryland income tax subtraction for donations made to diaper banks and other qualified charitable entities. The subtraction applies to donations of disposable diapers, other hygiene products for infants or children, feminine personal hygiene products, or cash specifically designated for these items. The original termination date of June 30, 2024, is extended to June 30, 2027.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office
stakeholders: Maryland taxpayers (individuals and corporations) who make donations, diaper banks, homeless shelters, domestic violence shelters, religious organizations, other charitable entities, and individuals (especially infants, children, and those in need of feminine hygiene products) who receive donated hygiene products.
innovative_summary: The bill extends an existing tax subtraction. While the original policy supported specific charitable donations, the act of extending a tax incentive is not inherently innovative in terms of employing new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill directly supports the provision of essential hygiene products, such as diapers and other items for infants and children, to individuals free of charge. This directly addresses a basic need and helps alleviate financial burdens on low-income families, thereby having a significant direct impact on child poverty by making these necessary items accessible.

Title: Education - Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission - Publishing and Meetings Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission to publish the names of the candidates for appointment to the Baltimore County Board of Education on the Commission's website before interviewing the candidates; requiring meetings of the Commission that involve action on a candidate for appointment to the county board to be public; and requiring certain meetings of the Commission to be held without the public in attendance and recorded and for the recording to be provided within 48 hours of receiving a request for the recording.
bill_summary: This bill enhances transparency for the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission by requiring it to publish the names of candidates for appointment to the Baltimore County Board of Education on its website before interviewing them. It mandates that certain meetings involving candidate interviews, deliberations, or actions be open to the public. For meetings that are closed to the public (specifically interviews and deliberations), the Commission must record them and provide a copy for public inspection within 48 hours of a request. The bill also clarifies that applications and records submitted by applicants are not confidential and are subject to disclosure.
responsible_party: Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission
stakeholders: Residents of Baltimore County, especially those interested in education and local governance; candidates for the Baltimore County Board of Education.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances government transparency by mandating the use of the Commission's website for publishing candidate names and for providing live and archived video recordings of public meetings. It also requires recording of certain closed meetings and making those recordings available digitally, leveraging technology to improve public access and oversight.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on improving transparency and public access to information regarding the selection process for the Baltimore County Board of Education. While a more transparent and accountable school board *could* indirectly lead to policies that benefit children in poverty, the bill itself does not directly establish programs, provide services, or allocate funds to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Criminal Law - Sexual Crimes - Definition of Consent and Repeal of Force
Synopsis: Requiring certain facts to be considered when determining whether a lack of consent exists for the purposes of determining certain sexual crimes; altering the elements of second-degree rape to remove the requirement of use of force or threat of force; and requiring the Maryland Judiciary to report to the General Assembly, beginning October 1, 2024, and each October 1 thereafter, certain data for the preceding calendar year, disaggregated by county and offender age, race, and sex.
bill_summary: This bill redefines "consent" for sexual crimes in Maryland to mean clear and voluntary agreement, specifying that consent can be withdrawn and is determined by the totality of circumstances, including words and conduct. It explicitly states that a prior relationship or manner of dress does not imply consent and that submission due to fear, threat, or coercion does not constitute consent. It also alters the elements of second-degree rape by removing the requirement of "force or threat of force" and replacing it with "without the consent of the other." Additionally, the bill mandates the Maryland Judiciary to annually report data on charges and convictions for certain sexual crimes, disaggregated by county, offender age, race, and sex, starting October 1, 2024, until April 30, 2029.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Individuals involved in sexual crime cases (victims and defendants), the Maryland legal system (courts, prosecutors, law enforcement), and the General Assembly.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a clearer, more explicit definition of consent in criminal law, moving towards an affirmative consent standard, and implements a structured data collection and reporting system for sexual crime statistics. While these are important legal and transparency reforms, they do not involve new technologies or groundbreaking government approaches beyond standard data collection and legislative updates.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses legal definitions and reporting requirements for sexual crimes. While contributing to a safer society could indirectly benefit all citizens, including children, it does not directly implement programs, services, or economic measures aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Hunting - Nonresident Sika Deer Stamp - Fee Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the fee for nonresident sika deer stamps from $25 to $200.
bill_summary: This bill alters the fee for a nonresident sika deer hunting stamp in Maryland, increasing it from $25.00 to $200.00.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Nonresident sika deer hunters in Maryland
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative; it simply changes an existing fee for a hunting stamp.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty, as it only increases a hunting stamp fee for nonresidents.

Title: Real Property - Access to Counsel in Evictions Program - Mandated Reports
Synopsis: Altering the information relating to the Access to Counsel in Evictions Program required to be reported by the Maryland Legal Services Corporation each year to include disaggregation by case type, the amount paid to attorneys for each case managed, the geographic distribution of cases, the disposition of cases decided, the amount of State and federal funds allocated to each designated organization, and the number of individuals provided legal representation for multiple cases.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the annual reporting requirements for the Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC) regarding the Access to Counsel in Evictions Program. It mandates more detailed information in the reports, including the number of cases disaggregated by type (nonpayment of rent, tenant holdover, breach of lease), the amount paid to attorneys per case, the geographic distribution of cases, data on case dispositions, the allocation of state and federal funds to designated organizations, and the number of covered individuals provided legal representation for multiple cases. These new reporting requirements take effect October 1, 2024, and will be abrogated on June 30, 2027.
responsible_party: Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC)
stakeholders: Low-income residential occupants (tenants) in Maryland who are eligible for legal representation under the Access to Counsel in Evictions Program.
innovative_summary: This bill focuses on altering the reporting requirements for an existing program. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government service delivery itself, but rather refines the oversight and data collection of an existing initiative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While this bill solely amends reporting requirements, the Access to Counsel in Evictions Program, which is the subject of these reports, has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty. By providing legal representation to low-income individuals facing eviction, the program directly works to prevent homelessness and maintain stable housing for families. This stability is crucial for children's well-being, access to education, and overall development, thus directly alleviating a major contributing factor to child poverty.

Title: Health Occupations - Private Dental Offices - Infection Control
Synopsis: Requiring each owner of a private dental office to designate a licensed dentist to be the supervising dentist for the private dental office; requiring a supervising dentist to complete the registration required by the State Board of Dental Examiners and be responsible for all infection control activities within the private dental office; authorizing the Board to charge a fee for the registration of a supervising dentist under the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires owners of private dental offices to designate a licensed dentist as a supervising dentist. This supervising dentist must register with the State Board of Dental Examiners and will be responsible for all infection control activities within the office, including adherence to CDC guidelines, water quality testing, and spore testing. Owners must also designate an interim supervising dentist if the primary one relinquishes duties. The State Board of Dental Examiners is authorized to charge a registration fee for supervising dentists.
responsible_party: State Board of Dental Examiners
stakeholders: Owners of private dental offices, licensed dentists, and dental patients in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill enhances existing regulatory frameworks for health and safety in dental offices by formalizing the role of a 'supervising dentist' responsible for infection control. It leverages established guidelines (CDC) and standard practices (water/spore testing). While it improves oversight, it does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, rather it refines existing practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to improve infection control in private dental offices, which contributes to general public health. While better health outcomes for children are beneficial, this bill does not directly address the economic or social factors that contribute to child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be very indirect, through improved health access and outcomes for children receiving dental care.

Title: Charter Counties - Enforcement of Local Laws
Synopsis: Increasing from $1,000 to $5,000 the maximum amount of a civil or criminal fine that may be imposed by a charter county to enforce certain local laws enacted by the county.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum civil and criminal fines that a charter county in Maryland may impose to enforce its local laws. The maximum fine is raised from $1,000 to $5,000 for most local law violations.
responsible_party: Charter counties in Maryland
stakeholders: Residents and entities within Maryland's charter counties who are subject to local laws, and the charter counties themselves in their enforcement capacity.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts the maximum monetary penalties for enforcing existing local laws. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government or law enforcement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill increases the maximum fines for violating local laws. While fines can disproportionately affect low-income families, potentially exacerbating financial hardship for those with children, the bill does not establish any direct program or intervention aimed at addressing child poverty. Its impact on child poverty is indirect and potentially negative for some families.

Title: Department of Planning - Maryland Humanities Council - Appropriation to the Marilyn Hatza Memorial Strengthening the Humanities Investment in Nonprofits for Equity (SHINE) Grantmaking Initiative
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $1,000,000 each year to the Department of Planning to be used as a grant to the Maryland Humanities Council for the Marilyn Hatza Memorial Strengthening Humanities Investment in Nonprofits for Equity (SHINE) Grantmaking Initiative; and requiring the Maryland Humanities Council to select, award, and report on grants to qualifying nonprofit organizations under the SHINE Grantmaking Initiative.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Governor to include an annual appropriation of $1,000,000 in the state budget to the Department of Planning, which will then provide these funds to the Maryland Humanities Council. These funds are for the Marilyn Hatza Memorial Strengthening the Humanities Investment in Nonprofits for Equity (SHINE) Grantmaking Initiative. The initiative aims to provide general operating grants to small and mid-size humanities, arts, cultural, and educational nonprofit organizations, considering geographic and racial diversity in the selection process. The Council is required to submit an annual report detailing grant recipients, amounts, and how funds were used to create/preserve jobs, support operations, or sustain humanities programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Humanities Council
stakeholders: Small and mid-size humanities, arts, cultural, and educational nonprofit organizations in Maryland, and the communities they serve.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a grantmaking initiative, which is a traditional government function. While the focus on geographic and racial diversity in grant selection is a positive and equitable approach, the mechanism itself does not employ new technologies or significantly innovative government approaches beyond standard grant administration.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides grants to humanities, arts, cultural, and educational nonprofits. While these organizations can offer educational and cultural enrichment that indirectly benefits children and families, the bill does not outline specific programs or funding mechanisms directly targeting child poverty reduction. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect, through the general community support provided by the funded organizations.

Title: Sexual Harassment Prevention Training - Morgan State University and St. Mary's College of Maryland - Training Format
Synopsis: Providing that a certain required sexual harassment prevention training for employees of Morgan State University and St. Mary's College of Maryland may consist of webinar, computer-based, or online training if the training includes a certain evaluative component.
bill_summary: This bill amends the requirements for sexual harassment prevention training for employees of Morgan State University and St. Mary’s College of Maryland. It allows these institutions to offer the mandatory training via webinar, computer-based, or online formats, provided the training includes an evaluative component to ensure employee engagement and comprehension of the objectives.
responsible_party: Morgan State University and St. Mary’s College of Maryland
stakeholders: Employees of Morgan State University and St. Mary’s College of Maryland, and their respective Human Resources/training departments.
innovative_summary: The bill updates the acceptable formats for sexual harassment prevention training to include webinar, computer-based, or online options, explicitly requiring an evaluative component for engagement and comprehension. While online training is a common modern practice, formalizing and mandating these specific elements for state employees in higher education modernizes the administrative approach to compliance training.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses exclusively on the administrative details of sexual harassment prevention training for adult university employees. It does not include any provisions or mechanisms that would directly affect child poverty.

Title: Allegany and Garrett Counties - Property Tax - Credit for Construction of Housing
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing bodies of Allegany County and Garrett County and municipal corporations located in Allegany County and Garrett County to grant, by law, a property tax credit on certain newly constructed dwellings; prohibiting the tax credit from exceeding $10,000; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the governing bodies of Allegany County and Garrett County, and municipal corporations within them, to grant a property tax credit for newly constructed residential real property. To qualify, the dwelling must have a building permit issued on or after June 1, 2024, be occupied by the purchaser as their principal residence, and be constructed with a sprinkler system, an on-site sewage disposal system, or fixed broadband internet access. The credit may not exceed $10,000 and can be claimed for up to 5 taxable years. The State will reimburse the counties and municipal corporations an amount equal to 50% of the foregone property tax revenue due to these credits.
responsible_party: Allegany County and Garrett County governing bodies and municipal corporations, in conjunction with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (implied) and the Comptroller's office for reimbursement.
stakeholders: Purchasers of newly constructed dwellings in Allegany and Garrett Counties, property developers, and the local governments of Allegany and Garrett Counties and their municipal corporations.
innovative_summary: The program uses a standard property tax credit mechanism to incentivize specific features in new home construction, such as sprinkler systems, advanced sewage disposal, and fixed broadband internet access. While tax credits are not new, tying them to modern infrastructure like broadband connectivity has a moderate level of innovation for local government incentives.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not directly address child poverty. It incentivizes the construction and purchase of new homes, which typically cater to market-rate housing and do not include provisions for affordability or direct financial assistance to low-income families with children. The focus is on housing features rather than affordability or access for vulnerable populations.

Title: Children - Labor Trafficking
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "abuse" to include labor trafficking of a child by any individual for purposes of provisions of law governing children in need of assistance cases and child abuse and neglect reporting; expanding provisions of law relating to the Safe Harbor Regional Navigator Grant Program to apply to child victims of labor trafficking; and requiring the Department of Human Services to include labor trafficking in its annual report on child sex trafficking to the Governor and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of "abuse" in Maryland law to include labor trafficking of a child by any individual, for the purposes of children in need of assistance cases and child abuse and neglect reporting. It also broadens the scope of the existing Safe Harbor Regional Navigator Grant Program to include child victims of labor trafficking, ensuring they receive necessary services. The bill specifies that local departments should refer suspected child victims of labor trafficking to regional navigators for services.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services, local departments of social services, and the Executive Director overseeing the Safe Harbor Regional Navigator Grant Program.
stakeholders: Child victims of labor trafficking, local departments of social services, the Department of Juvenile Services, sexual assault crisis programs, child advocacy programs, local offices of the Office of the Public Defender, and other state and local agencies involved in child protection and victim services.
innovative_summary: This bill expands existing legal definitions and an established grant program to address labor trafficking as a form of child abuse. While it provides crucial updates to address a significant issue, it primarily leverages and extends existing frameworks rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services or program delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: Child labor trafficking disproportionately affects children from impoverished backgrounds, making them vulnerable to exploitation. By expanding the definition of abuse to include labor trafficking and providing comprehensive support services (such as safety planning, emergency housing, counseling, legal services, and case management) through the Safe Harbor Regional Navigator Grant Program, this bill directly intervenes to protect children from exploitative situations. This intervention can help stabilize their lives, facilitate their recovery, and provide pathways out of the cycles of poverty that often make them targets for trafficking.

Title: Business Facade Improvement Program - Eligible Funding Recipients
Synopsis: Expanding the eligible recipients of funding provided by the Department of Housing and Community Development under the Business Facade Improvement Program to include community development organizations that serve at least one sustainable community and apply for funds.
bill_summary: This bill expands the eligibility for the existing Business Facade Improvement Program, administered by the Department of Housing and Community Development, to include certain community development organizations alongside political subdivisions. The program assists qualified businesses in sustainable communities with improving the exterior appearance of their buildings. Starting in fiscal year 2025, the Governor is mandated to appropriate $5,000,000 annually to the Program.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Community development organizations, political subdivisions, and qualified businesses located in sustainable communities seeking to improve their building facades.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative change by expanding the types of entities eligible to receive funding for an existing program. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's focus is on improving business facades, which could indirectly stimulate local economies and potentially create jobs in sustainable communities. However, it does not provide direct services, aid, or interventions specifically targeting children in poverty.

Title: Natural Resources - Fish and Fisheries - Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring certain persons licensed or regulated with respect to fish and fisheries by the Department of Natural Resources to submit reports in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's Natural Resources Article to require certain individuals and businesses licensed or regulated by the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) for fish and fisheries activities to submit reports in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department. This includes persons dealing in fish resources, those licensed to catch fish resources, individuals with angler's licenses for nontidal waters, and those with Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing licenses.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Persons licensed or regulated by the Department of Natural Resources concerning fish and fisheries, including fish packers, dealers, commercial fish harvesters, nontidal anglers, and Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishers.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on administrative updates to reporting requirements for fishing activities, which is a standard regulatory function. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill establishes new reporting requirements for fishing licenses and activities. It does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty, nor does it address factors that would immediately impact the economic well-being of families with children.

Title: Motor Vehicles - Work Zone Speed Control Systems - Revisions (Maryland Road Worker Protection Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Altering the distribution of revenue from civil fines collected through the use of work zone speed control systems; altering the highways on which a work zone speed control system may be used; clarifying that a system operator does not need to be present when a work zone speed control system is in use; altering the maximum penalty for a civil citation issued as a result of an image from a work zone speed control system; requiring the State Highway Administration to make a certain report; etc.
bill_summary: The Maryland Road Worker Protection Act of 2024 revises laws regarding work zone speed control systems. It alters the distribution of civil fine revenue, directing funds to cover costs for the Department of State Police and State Highway Administration, for State Police vehicle equipment, and for the Transportation Trust Fund for highway and work zone safety. The bill expands the types of highways where these systems can be used, clarifies that systems can be unmanned and multiple systems may be deployed in a single work zone, and removes the requirement for initial warning notices. It significantly changes civil penalties, initially increasing the maximum penalty to $80. Effective January 1, 2025, penalties will be tiered based on speed over the limit ($60 to $500), will double when workers are present, and will increase for repeat offenses (up to $1,000 for a third or subsequent offense). The bill also requires the State Highway Administration to report on pilot programs for new detection technologies and the Maryland Department of Transportation to report on how fine funds are spent.
responsible_party: Maryland State Comptroller, Department of State Police, State Highway Administration, Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Motorists/drivers, road workers, the Department of State Police, the State Highway Administration, and the Transportation Trust Fund.
innovative_summary: The bill requires the State Highway Administration to report annually on pilot programs testing new technologies for detecting and recording work zone violations, suggesting an openness to adopting new approaches for enforcement. It also clarifies the legality of unmanned work zone speed control systems, which can be seen as a modernization of operational procedures, but the systems themselves are not new technology introduced by this bill.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on enhancing road worker safety through stricter speed enforcement in work zones and revising the distribution of fine revenue. It does not contain any provisions directly aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be indirect, minor, or possibly negative if fines disproportionately affect low-income families.

Title: Workgroup to Study the Fiscal and Operational Viability of Public-Private Partnerships for Calvert County Public Schools
Synopsis: Establishing a Workgroup to Study the Fiscal and Operational Viability of Public-Private Partnerships for Calvert County Public Schools; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Board of Calvert County Commissioners, the Calvert County Board of Education, the Interagency Commission on School Construction, and the Calvert County Delegation on or before December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a Workgroup to Study the Fiscal and Operational Viability of Public-Private Partnerships for Calvert County Public Schools. The Workgroup will analyze the implementation of P3s for financing, constructing, maintaining, and operating schools, and how they might alleviate funding burdens. It will then make recommendations for new school construction, maintenance, and rehabilitation.
responsible_party: Workgroup to Study the Fiscal and Operational Viability of Public–Private Partnerships for Calvert County Public Schools, with staff provided by the Calvert County Board of Education
stakeholders: Calvert County Public Schools, students and taxpayers in Calvert County, Calvert County Board of Education, Board of Calvert County Commissioners, Interagency Commission on School Construction, and the Calvert County Delegation to the General Assembly.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to study public-private partnerships (P3s) as a potential new approach for financing, constructing, maintaining, and operating public schools. While the P3 model itself is not new, its application to public school infrastructure within Calvert County could represent an innovative strategy for the local government to manage school funding and development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to study alternative financing models for school infrastructure. While improved school facilities could indirectly benefit all students, including those experiencing poverty, the bill does not directly establish programs or services aimed at addressing child poverty. The impact, if any, would be very indirect and contingent on the recommendations and subsequent implementation of public-private partnerships.

Title: State Real Estate Commission - Complaints - Advertising Violations
Synopsis: Providing that a complaint filed with the State Real Estate Commission alleging an advertising violation may be made anonymously but must be accompanied by documentary or other evidence.
bill_summary: This bill amends the process for filing complaints with the State Real Estate Commission regarding advertising violations. It allows these specific complaints to be made anonymously and without being under oath, provided they are accompanied by documentary or other evidence. Other types of complaints still require the complainant's identity and an oath.
responsible_party: State Real Estate Commission
stakeholders: Members of the public who wish to file complaints against real estate professionals for advertising violations, and real estate professionals who are subject to these complaints.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a procedural change for filing complaints, allowing anonymity for a specific type of violation. This is a minor adjustment to an existing regulatory process and does not involve new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill concerns the regulatory process for real estate advertising complaints. It has no direct or indirect impact on child poverty.

Title: Public Schools - Student Telehealth Appointments - State Guidelines, Policies, and Access
Synopsis: Requiring, by December 31, 2024, the State Department of Education and the Maryland Department of Health jointly to adopt certain State guidelines for school health services regarding student access to telehealth appointments during the school day on the premises of public middle and high schools in the State; and requiring each county board of education to adopt and implement a certain student telehealth policy before the start of the 2025-2026 school year.
bill_summary: This bill requires the State Department of Education and the Maryland Department of Health to jointly develop State guidelines for public middle and high schools regarding student access to telehealth appointments during the school day. Each county board of education must then establish and implement a policy for student telehealth in accordance with these guidelines, ensuring designated private spaces in schools for appointments and measures for student safety and privacy.
responsible_party: State Department of Education; Maryland Department of Health; County Boards of Education
stakeholders: Public middle and high school students, parents, local school systems, middle and high school principals, school nurses, school-based health and behavioral health providers, other support personnel, health care providers of various practice areas, and the Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports.
innovative_summary: The bill promotes an innovative approach by formally integrating telehealth services into public middle and high school settings, allowing students to access healthcare during school hours. This leverages modern telecommunications technologies to improve access to care, addressing logistical barriers often faced by families.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program has a direct impact on child poverty by removing significant barriers to healthcare access for students, particularly those from low-income families. By allowing telehealth appointments during the school day, it reduces or eliminates the need for parents to take time off work, arrange transportation, or incur costs associated with off-campus appointments, thereby easing financial strain and improving health outcomes for children in poverty.

Title: Orphans' Court Judges - Restriction on Practicing Law
Synopsis: Altering a prohibition on judges of the orphans' court acting as attorneys to prohibit a judge of the orphans' court from acting as an attorney in matters related to the administration of an estate or a guardianship of a minor within the jurisdiction of the court in any county or Baltimore City, or the preparation of an estate plan or estate planning documents that might come within the jurisdiction of the court in any county or Baltimore City following the death of any individual.
bill_summary: This bill alters the prohibition on Orphans' Court judges from acting as attorneys, making the restrictions more stringent. Previously, judges were generally prohibited from practicing law in civil or criminal matters during their term, with several county-specific exceptions. The amended law now explicitly prohibits Orphans' Court judges from acting as attorneys in matters that are within the court's jurisdiction related to estate administration or guardianship of a minor, or in matters related to the preparation of estate plans that might come under the court's jurisdiction. All previous county-specific exceptions to this prohibition have been removed, making the restriction uniform across the state.
responsible_party: Maryland Orphans' Court System
stakeholders: Orphans' Court judges, attorneys practicing in estate or guardianship law, and individuals involved in estate administration or minor guardianship cases.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory change concerning the ethical conduct and permissible activities of Orphans' Court judges. It does not introduce new technologies, innovative governmental approaches, or new public services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses the professional conduct of Orphans' Court judges regarding their ability to practice law in estate and guardianship matters. While guardianships for minors can impact children's well-being, including financial stability, the bill itself does not directly establish programs or policies aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any impact would be indirect through improved judicial integrity in related cases.

Title: Correctional Services – Parole Supervision Fees and Drug and Alcohol Abuse Test Payment – Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement for the Maryland Parole Commission to assess a fee against an individual on parole and supervised by the Division of Parole and Probation under certain circumstances; and repealing  authorization for the Division of Parole and Probation to require a supervisee of the Division who is on parole to pay for certain drug or alcohol abuse testing under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement for the Maryland Parole Commission to assess a monthly fee of $50 against individuals on parole supervised by the Division of Parole and Probation. It also repeals the authorization for the Division of Parole and Probation to require these individuals to pay for drug or alcohol abuse testing.
responsible_party: Maryland Parole Commission, Division of Parole and Probation
stakeholders: Individuals on parole and supervised by the Division of Parole and Probation in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it repeals existing financial requirements for individuals on parole rather than introducing new technologies or approaches to government. It represents a policy change regarding financial conditions of parole.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By eliminating parole supervision fees and drug/alcohol testing payment requirements, this bill directly reduces financial burdens on individuals and their households. This can free up disposable income that can be used for essential needs, potentially improving the financial stability of families and indirectly alleviating child poverty by reducing household expenses.

Title: Community Development Administration - Live Near Your School Program - Extension
Synopsis: Extending the termination date for the Live Near Your School program and a related homebuyer program from September 30, 2024, to September 30, 2030.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the "Live Near Your School" program and a related homebuyer program, administered by the Community Development Administration, from September 30, 2024, to September 30, 2030. It also mandates that the Governor include an annual appropriation of $200,000 for the program in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2026 through 2030.
responsible_party: Community Development Administration
stakeholders: Current students and recent graduates of public institutions of higher education in Maryland who wish to buy homes near their schools.
innovative_summary: The program provides financial assistance in the form of grants for students and recent graduates to purchase homes near their educational institutions. This is a traditional form of incentivizing residency and promoting homeownership and does not employ new technologies or particularly novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program primarily targets current students and recent graduates to encourage homeownership near schools, not specifically low-income families with children. While homeownership can contribute to community stability, the program's direct focus is not on alleviating child poverty.

Title: Land Use – Affordable Housing – Zoning Density and Permitting (Housing Expansion and Affordability Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Historic Property Revitalization Director as a position in the Department of Housing and Community Development; prohibiting a local legislative body from prohibiting the placement of certain manufactured homes or modular dwellings in a zoning district that allows single-family residential uses under certain circumstances; requiring local jurisdictions to allow an increase in density of certain qualified projects in certain districts or zones for certain properties; etc.
bill_summary: The Housing Expansion and Affordability Act of 2024 aims to increase affordable housing options in Maryland. It establishes a Historic Property Revitalization Director within the Department of Housing and Community Development to inventory and facilitate the redevelopment of older State-owned properties. The bill prohibits local legislative bodies from banning manufactured homes or modular dwellings in zoning districts that allow single-family residential uses under certain circumstances. It requires local jurisdictions to allow increased residential density for specific "qualified projects": those on formerly State or Federal land (with historical buildings), those within three-quarters of a mile of a rail station, or those owned/controlled by nonprofit organizations, provided they include a certain percentage of affordable dwelling units (15-25% for 40 years). The bill also places limits on unreasonable project limitations (like height or parking) and restricts the number of public hearings. For qualified projects converting non-residential zones to mixed-use, a public health impact assessment must be conducted and approved by the Department of Housing and Community Development.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Developers of affordable housing, nonprofit organizations, residents seeking affordable housing (especially those earning 60% or less of the area median income), local governments and planning commissions, and communities near rail stations or former State/Federal properties being redeveloped.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a Historic Property Revitalization Director to specifically inventory and facilitate the adaptive reuse of older State-owned buildings for redevelopment, which is a targeted approach to leveraging existing state assets. It also requires public health impact assessments for certain mixed-use developments in formerly non-residential zones, representing a modern, health-conscious approach to urban planning. The density bonuses tied to specific affordable housing criteria are a significant reform to housing policy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill directly impacts child poverty by increasing the supply of affordable housing units for households earning 60% or less of the area median income. By making housing more affordable and stable, it reduces housing cost burdens for low-income families, freeing up resources for other necessities like food, healthcare, and education, thereby directly alleviating poverty's effects on children.

Title: Public Institutions of Higher Education - Student Withdrawal Policy - Reimbursement of Tuition and Fees (Cameron Carden Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Requiring each public institution of higher education to adopt a policy to authorize a student to withdraw from the institution under extenuating circumstances and to refund the student for tuition and fees paid by the student for a certain semester under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Cameron Carden Act of 2024, requires all public institutions of higher education in Maryland to adopt a policy that allows students to withdraw due to extenuating circumstances, such as illness, injury, hospitalization, or mental health issues. Under this policy, students would be eligible for a refund of tuition and fees for the semester in which they withdraw, provided these circumstances inhibit their ability to continue their education.
responsible_party: Each public institution of higher education in Maryland
stakeholders: Students enrolled in public institutions of higher education in Maryland who experience extenuating circumstances requiring withdrawal.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a standardized compassionate withdrawal and refund policy across Maryland's public higher education institutions. While a positive step for student welfare, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches, but rather institutionalizes a widely recognized student support practice.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill provides financial relief to students who must withdraw from higher education due to extenuating circumstances by mandating refunds for tuition and fees. For students who are parents or come from low-income households, this financial relief can prevent debt or reduce financial burden, thereby indirectly supporting the financial stability of families with children. However, its primary focus is on student financial protection rather than direct child poverty alleviation.

Title: Anne Arundel County - Student Loan Assistance Repayment Program for Educators - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Anne Arundel County Student Loan Assistance Repayment Program for Educators to assist in the repayment of certain student loans owed by educators who meet certain eligibility requirements; providing that the purpose of the Program is to attract, recruit, and retain a diverse cadre of qualified educators in the County's schools that is reflective of the student population; establishing requirements for applicants for assistance in the repayment of a commercial loan; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Anne Arundel County Student Loan Assistance Repayment Program for Educators. The program aims to assist educators employed by the Anne Arundel County Public School System with the repayment of their higher education loans. The county is authorized to establish the specific amount, terms, and conditions of the assistance, with the goal of attracting, recruiting, and retaining a diverse cadre of qualified educators.
responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Public School System
stakeholders: Educators employed or seeking employment in the Anne Arundel County Public School System, and indirectly, students within the Anne Arundel County school system.
innovative_summary: The program is a student loan assistance repayment program, which is a common incentive used to attract and retain professionals in specific fields. While beneficial, it does not employ new technologies or particularly innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's primary goal is to retain and attract qualified educators. While having skilled educators can improve educational outcomes for all students, including those from low-income backgrounds, thereby indirectly impacting child poverty in the long term, it does not directly provide financial assistance or services to children in poverty or their families. The eligibility criteria for educators include an income threshold, which focuses on supporting educators rather than directly alleviating child poverty.

Title: Department of Human Services - Children in Foster Care - Luggage
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Human Services to establish and maintain a decentralized supply of new luggage to be used to transport the personal belongings of a child in foster care; requiring the Department to provide new luggage to a child in foster care who is entering foster care, moving from one placement to another, or exiting foster care; prohibiting the Department from using disposable bags or trash bags to transport a child's belongings; and requiring the Department to maintain certain records.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of Human Services to establish and maintain a decentralized supply of new luggage for children in foster care. The Department must provide new luggage (suitcases, duffel bags, backpacks) to children when they enter foster care, move between placements, or exit foster care, taking into account the child's age, mobility, personal items, and preferences. The bill explicitly prohibits the use of disposable or trash bags for transporting a child's belongings and requires the Department to maintain records of any instances where such bags are used, including the reason why new luggage was not provided. The luggage provided becomes the property of the child and cannot be reclaimed. The Department must also report annually to the General Assembly on the use of disposable bags and its luggage inventory.
responsible_party: Department of Human Services
stakeholders: Children in foster care, foster parents, and Department of Human Services staff.
innovative_summary: This bill is innovative in its direct approach to addressing a long-standing issue of dignity and respect for children in foster care by mandating the provision of proper luggage instead of trash bags for their personal belongings. While not employing new technologies, it represents a new, humane standard of care and specific operational requirements for the Department.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program does not directly address the financial aspects of child poverty. Its focus is on providing dignity and practical support to children in foster care by ensuring their belongings are transported properly. While contributing to the overall well-being and reducing potential minor expenses for foster families, it does not directly alleviate child poverty.

Title: Criminal Law - Sexual Extortion, Stalking, and Revenge Porn - Statute of Limitations and In Banc Review
Synopsis: Altering the statute of limitations applicable to the crime of sexual extortion to be 5 years; altering the statute of limitations applicable to the crime of stalking to be 10 years; providing that the State may institute a prosecution for revenge porn at any time; and providing that, for purposes of the Maryland Constitution, a person who commits revenge porn shall be deemed to have committed a misdemeanor whose punishment is confinement in the penitentiary and may reserve a point or question for a certain in banc review.
bill_summary: This bill alters the statute of limitations for certain criminal offenses in Maryland. It sets a 5-year statute of limitations for sexual extortion, a 10-year statute of limitations for stalking, and establishes an unlimited statute of limitations for revenge porn. Additionally, the bill provides that cases involving sexual extortion, stalking, and revenge porn are eligible for in banc review under the Maryland Constitution, offering additional legal recourse.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and prosecuting agencies (State's Attorney, Attorney General)
stakeholders: Victims and perpetrators of sexual extortion, stalking, and revenge porn; the general public impacted by these crimes; and legal professionals within the Maryland criminal justice system.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily adjusts existing legal frameworks by altering statutes of limitations and expanding eligibility for in banc review for specific crimes. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking approaches to government services or public interventions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses criminal law by modifying statutes of limitations and judicial review processes for sexual extortion, stalking, and revenge porn. While these crimes can have severe negative impacts on individuals, including financial distress, the bill does not directly establish programs or policies aimed at alleviating child poverty through economic support or social services. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect, stemming from potentially improved justice for victims whose households might experience related financial hardship.

Title: Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program - Nancy Grasmick Public School Professional Award - Public School Nurses
Synopsis: Expanding the Nancy Grasmick Public School Professional Award within the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program to include public school nurses who are licensed as registered nurses, provide health services in public schools, and are employed by a county school system or a local health department to provide health services through an agreement with a county board.
bill_summary: This bill expands the eligibility for the Nancy Grasmick Public School Professional Award, a component of the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program, to include public school nurses. The purpose is to provide loan repayment assistance to eligible public school nurses in Maryland who have served for at least two years, thereby aiming to recruit and retain nurses in public schools across the State.
responsible_party: Office of Student Financial Assistance
stakeholders: Public school nurses in Maryland who have higher education loans and meet specific income and service criteria. Indirectly, public school students and schools will benefit from improved retention of nursing staff.
innovative_summary: The bill expands an existing loan repayment program to a new professional group (public school nurses). It does not introduce new technologies, government approaches, or novel services, but rather modifies the scope of an established program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By increasing the recruitment and retention of public school nurses, the program indirectly benefits children from low-income families by improving the availability and quality of health services in public schools. Better access to school health services can support students' overall well-being, attendance, and ability to learn, which are foundational to breaking cycles of poverty, though it does not directly provide financial assistance to children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Task Force on Responsible Use of Natural Psychedelic Substances
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force on Responsible Use of Natural Psychedelic Substances to study existing laws, scientific data, and practices related to the use of natural psychedelic substances; requiring the Task Force to make recommendations regarding any changes to State law, policies, and practices needed to create a program that enables broad, equitable, and affordable access to psychedelic substances; and requiring the Task Force to report its findings to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before July 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force on Responsible Use of Natural Psychedelic Substances to study existing laws, policies, and practices related to the use of natural psychedelic substances. The Task Force is charged with making recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly regarding the creation of a Maryland Natural Psychedelic Substance Access Program, including permitting requirements, access to treatment, and production, as well as recommendations for transitioning from criminalizing conduct involving these substances to civil penalties, expunging records, and releasing incarcerated individuals.
responsible_party: Maryland Cannabis Administration
stakeholders: Maryland residents who may benefit from natural psychedelic substances for health conditions, health care practitioners, facilitators, individuals with past convictions related to these substances, and law enforcement.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a task force to explore and recommend comprehensive policy changes regarding the responsible use, access, and decriminalization of natural psychedelic substances. This represents an innovative approach to drug policy reform and potential healthcare alternatives, reflecting a shift in governmental perspectives on these substances.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a task force to study and recommend policies on natural psychedelic substances, including decriminalization. While reduced incarceration resulting from decriminalization could indirectly benefit families and children by maintaining family stability and parental employment, the bill does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, education, or direct support programs.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Automated Enforcement Citations and Notices - Mailing Addresses
Synopsis: Requiring that citations and notices issued as a result of automated enforcement under the Maryland Vehicle Law be sent to the current mailing address on file with the Administration or if a mailing address is not available, the current residential address on file with the Administration.
bill_summary: This bill requires all citations and warning notices issued as a result of automated vehicle enforcement (such as traffic cameras, speed cameras, toll violations, etc.) to be mailed to either the current mailing address or, if unavailable, the current residential address on file with the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration.
responsible_party: Various local and state law enforcement agencies, the Maryland Transportation Authority, and local government agencies responsible for automated enforcement systems (e.g., local police departments, State police department, Baltimore City Police Department, Baltimore City Department of Transportation), using data from the Motor Vehicle Administration.
stakeholders: Registered vehicle owners in Maryland who may receive citations or warning notices from automated enforcement systems for violations such as traffic signal violations, railroad grade crossing violations, school bus camera violations, speed violations (including work zones), bus lane violations, video toll violations, and vehicle height violations.
innovative_summary: This bill clarifies administrative procedures for mailing automated enforcement citations and notices by mandating the use of addresses on file with the Motor Vehicle Administration. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government; rather, it standardizes an existing process.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses solely on the administrative process of mailing automated enforcement citations and notices. It does not provide any direct financial aid, services, or resources that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: Sales and Use Tax Exemption - Aircraft Parts and Equipment - Repeal of Reporting Requirement and Extension of Sunset
