Synopsis: Repealing a certain reporting requirement relating to an exemption from the sales and use tax for certain materials, parts, and equipment used to repair, maintain, or upgrade aircraft or certain aircraft systems; and extending the termination date of the exemption to June 30, 2030.
bill_summary: This bill repeals a reporting requirement for the Comptroller related to an existing sales and use tax exemption for materials, parts, and equipment used to repair, maintain, or upgrade aircraft. Additionally, it extends the termination date of this sales and use tax exemption from June 30, 2025, to June 30, 2030. The exemption applies to aircraft with a maximum gross takeoff weight of less than 12,500 pounds, or those weighing 12,500 pounds or more and primarily used in interstate or foreign commerce.
responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: Businesses and individuals involved in aircraft repair, maintenance, and upgrading within Maryland; aircraft owners; the broader aviation industry in the state.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily extends an existing tax exemption and repeals a reporting requirement. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services or operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on a sales and use tax exemption for the aviation industry. There is no direct mechanism or intent within the bill to address child poverty. Any impact would be extremely indirect through general economic activity, which is not a direct focus.

Title: Tree Expert Licenses - Application and Renewal Fee Alterations and Insurance Requirements
Synopsis: Specifying the maximum amounts of fees for a tree expert license established by the Department of Natural Resources by regulation; authorizing the Department to permanently revoke or temporarily suspend a tree expert license if the license holder fails to maintain liability, property, or workers' compensation insurance in a certain manner; and requiring the Department to prepare an annual report on the number of licenses issued and certain receipts and expenses and submit the report to the General Assembly by November 1 each year.
bill_summary: This bill alters the maximum application and renewal fees for tree expert licenses in Maryland, specifying new caps for examination ($45), initial license ($55), and renewal ($100) fees. It clarifies that licensed tree experts or businesses employing them must carry and show proof of workers' compensation insurance. The bill also makes the failure to maintain required liability, property, or workers' compensation insurance grounds for the suspension or permanent revocation of a tree expert license by the Department of Natural Resources.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Licensed tree experts, businesses employing licensed tree experts, and consumers of tree expert services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill updates regulatory requirements and fee structures for an existing tree expert licensing program. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the regulation, licensing, fees, and insurance requirements for tree experts. It does not contain any provisions that directly aim to address or impact child poverty.

Title: Special Chesapeake Bay and Coastal Sport Fishing License - Nonresidents - License Fee
Synopsis: Increasing the license fee for a special Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license for nonresident license applicants from $50 to $100.
bill_summary: This bill increases the annual fee for a special Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license for nonresident applicants from $50 to $100. The fee for resident applicants remains $50. This license, when affixed to a boat, authorizes anyone on board to fish for finfish in specified Maryland waters.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Nonresident applicants for a special Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license, and individuals fishing on boats holding such a license in Maryland's Chesapeake Bay, coastal bays, and Atlantic Ocean waters.
innovative_summary: This bill concerns a fee increase for an existing fishing license and does not introduce any new technologies or innovative governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill changes a fishing license fee and does not have a direct impact on child poverty. It is not designed to provide economic support or services to families or children.

Title: Correctional Services - Investigation of Suspected Homicide - Reporting
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of State Police to investigate any death of an incarcerated individual suspected to be a homicide that occurs while the individual is in the custody of the Division of Correction whether within or outside a correctional facility; and requiring the Department, by December 31 each year, to report to the Governor and the General Assembly the number of investigations completed and the number of cases referred by the Department for prosecution for the preceding calendar year.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of State Police to annually post information on its website and report to the Governor and General Assembly regarding investigations into suspected homicides of incarcerated individuals. The report must detail the number of investigations completed and the number of cases referred for prosecution during the preceding calendar year.
responsible_party: Department of State Police
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals and their families, the Governor, the General Assembly, and the public interested in correctional system transparency.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates increased transparency by requiring the Department of State Police to publish investigation data online and submit annual reports. While this improves public access to information and accountability, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, rather it formalizes and expands existing reporting practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on transparency and reporting related to investigations of deaths in correctional facilities, specifically suspected homicides. It does not contain any provisions that directly address or aim to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Maryland Online Data Privacy Act of 2024
Synopsis: Establishing generally the manner in which a controller or a processor may process a consumer's personal data; authorizing a consumer to exercise certain rights in regards to the consumer's personal data; requiring a controller of personal data to establish a method for a consumer to exercise certain rights in regards to the consumer's personal data; making a violation of the Act an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice that is subject to enforcement and penalties under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Maryland Online Data Privacy Act of 2024, establishes comprehensive data privacy regulations for companies (controllers and processors) operating in Maryland. It grants Maryland residents (consumers) various rights regarding their personal data, including the right to confirm processing, access, correct, delete, and opt out of data processing for targeted advertising, sale, or certain profiling. The bill requires controllers to provide clear privacy notices, conduct data protection assessments for high-risk processing, and prohibits the use of 'dark patterns' to obtain consent. It also restricts geofencing near mental or reproductive health facilities and the sale of sensitive data. Violations are deemed unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act.
responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Maryland residents who are consumers of online services and products, and businesses that collect, process, or sell personal data of at least 35,000 Maryland consumers, or 10,000 consumers if more than 20% of their gross revenue is from selling personal data.
innovative_summary: The bill is moderately innovative for state-level legislation. It introduces contemporary data privacy concepts such as the prohibition of 'dark patterns' in obtaining consent and mandates the recognition of 'opt-out preference signals' from web browsers or platforms, which leverage technology to empower consumer privacy choices. It also requires data protection assessments for high-risk processing activities and specifically restricts geofencing around sensitive health facilities for data collection.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on online data privacy and consumer rights, not direct economic relief or social services. While it includes protections for personal data of children (defined as under 13 under COPPA) and minors (13-18), by prohibiting targeted advertising and data sales without consent for these age groups, these measures are protective rather than direct interventions to alleviate child poverty. There is no direct impact on financial well-being or access to resources for families in poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Credit Eligibility and Transfer of Credits - English as a Second Language Courses (Credit for All Language Learning (CALL) Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a public community college to consider a course or program for English as a second language or English language learner as eligible for world language or humanities credit toward an associate's degree if the course is not classified as remedial; requiring the transferability of world language credits earned by students who transfer from community colleges to institutions of higher education; and requiring institutions of higher education to review and consider the transfer of certain credits for language or humanities courses.
bill_summary: The "Credit for All Language Learning (CALL) Act" requires public community colleges to consider English as a Second Language (ESL) or English Language Learner (ELL) courses as eligible for world language or humanities elective credit towards an associate's degree, provided they are not classified as remedial. The bill also mandates that credits earned for such courses at community colleges be transferable to any public institution of higher education in the State, and requires private nonprofit institutions of higher education to review and consider the transfer of these credits.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC), public community colleges, and public and private nonprofit institutions of higher education in Maryland.
stakeholders: Students, particularly English as a Second Language (ESL) or English Language Learner (ELL) students, public community colleges, public institutions of higher education, and private nonprofit institutions of higher education in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new policy approach by explicitly valuing and mandating the transferability of English as a Second Language (ESL) and other language/humanities courses from community colleges to higher education institutions. This addresses a specific barrier for a diverse student population, streamlines academic pathways, and represents an innovative step in credit recognition and transfer policy within the state's higher education system, focusing on equitable access and efficiency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill can have a direct impact on child poverty by making higher education more accessible and efficient for students, especially those from immigrant or lower-income backgrounds who may be English language learners. By ensuring ESL courses count for credit and are transferable, it reduces the time and cost required to earn a degree, thereby lowering financial barriers and accelerating students' entry into better-paying jobs. This improved access to economic mobility directly benefits their families and children by increasing earning potential and reducing the financial burden of education.

Title: Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program - Modifications
Synopsis: Modifying provisions of law governing application, administration, and enforcement of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program, including provisions related to the payment of contributions, the calculation of the average weekly wage, the submission of claims for benefits, the application of the Program to self-employed individuals, the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Fund, the satisfaction of Program requirements through private employer plans or insurance, and the use of contributions or other funding.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the existing Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program in Maryland. It adjusts rules for covered employees, defines wages for self-employed individuals, clarifies information disclosure, and modifies claim procedures. Key changes include moving the start date for contributions to July 1, 2025, and benefit claims to July 1, 2026. It also changes the calculation of the average weekly wage, allows for electronic filing, and permits the Secretary of Labor to use funds for grants to community partnerships for public education and outreach. Additionally, it revises provisions for private employer plans to satisfy program requirements, including application fees and limits on employee deductions, and clarifies appeal processes and enforcement.
responsible_party: Secretary of Labor
stakeholders: Maryland employees, employers, self-employed individuals, and their families, particularly those taking leave for childbirth, adoption, foster care, kinship care, serious health conditions, or military exigencies.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces administrative updates such as explicit provisions for electronic filing of reports and forms by employers and the use of information-sharing and integration technology for program administration. It also allows the Secretary of Labor to award grants to facilitate community partnerships for public education, which could be a novel approach to outreach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides paid leave benefits to covered individuals for caring for or bonding with a newborn child, or a child placed through foster care, kinship care, or adoption. This financial support helps maintain income stability for families during crucial periods, directly mitigating the risk of financial hardship and potential child poverty associated with taking unpaid leave.

Title: Citizens Committee for the Enhancement of Communities Surrounding Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport - Membership
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Citizens Committee for the Enhancement of Communities Surrounding Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport by increasing the total number of members from 11 to 12 and requiring the Committee to include one member each from legislative districts 12A and 12B instead of one member from legislative district 12.
bill_summary: This bill amends the membership of the Citizens Committee for the Enhancement of Communities Surrounding Baltimore–Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport. It increases the total number of committee members from 11 to 12 and specifies that the new member will be recommended by the delegate representing District 12B, splitting the previous District 12 representation into 12A and 12B.
responsible_party: The Secretary (of Transportation)
stakeholders: The Citizens Committee members, legislative delegates from districts 12A, 12B, 13, and 32, and community associations that are either wholly or partially situated in the certified noise zone or a 2-mile border outside of the certified noise zone of Baltimore–Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport.
innovative_summary: This bill only makes administrative changes to the composition of an existing committee and does not introduce any new technologies, methods, or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill modifies the membership of a committee focused on communities around an airport, primarily concerning noise zones. It has no direct connection or mechanism to address child poverty.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Victim Compensation - Alterations (Victim Compensation Reform Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Altering the composition of the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board; altering certain duties, powers, and procedures for the Board to make awards to victims of crime; altering the powers and duties of certain employees; altering the amount and types of awards the Board is authorized to make to certain victims of crime; authorizing reconsideration and judicial review of decisions of the Board; authorizing the Governor to include certain funding in the annual budget bill for the Criminal Injuries Compensation Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Victim Compensation Reform Act of 2024, significantly reforms Maryland's Criminal Injuries Compensation Board and Fund. It alters the Board's composition to be more diverse and victim-centric, expands the definition of 'victim,' broadens eligibility for awards to include domestic partners and dependent minors/adults under guardianship, and increases maximum compensation amounts for various expenses like funeral costs, medical care, mental health counseling, and property damage. It also introduces new eligible expenses such as one-time relocation, child care related to seeking care, and assistive technology for disabilities. Crucially, the bill removes provisions that allowed victim conduct to reduce or reject an award and expands the types of evidence the Board must accept, making it easier for victims to receive compensation. It streamlines the claims process by allowing delegation of initial determinations, reducing processing times, and establishing an online application portal for emergency awards, which are now presumptive for certain critical needs like funeral expenses and emergency relocation. The bill also authorizes the Governor to ensure adequate funding for the Criminal Injuries Compensation Fund in the annual budget.
responsible_party: Criminal Injuries Compensation Board (within the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services)
stakeholders: Victims of crime, their dependents, family members, domestic partners, dependent minors, adults under legal guardianship impacted by crime, and those who incur expenses for victims (e.g., funeral costs).
innovative_summary: The program introduces several modern and innovative approaches to victim compensation. It streamlines the application process by establishing an online portal for emergency awards and mandates faster processing times (30 days for initial claims). It significantly broadens accepted evidence to include sworn statements from qualified third parties and protective/peace orders, reducing the burden on victims. The expansion of eligible expenses to include relocation costs, child care for seeking medical/psychological care, and assistive technology for disabilities demonstrates a more holistic and responsive approach to victim needs, leveraging modern understandings of trauma and recovery. The removal of victim-blaming clauses in award determination is also a progressive approach to victim support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly impact child poverty by providing crucial financial support to families affected by crime. By expanding eligibility to include dependent minors and adults under legal guardianship, increasing maximum award amounts for various expenses (medical, mental health, funeral), and specifically covering costs for child care incurred while seeking treatment, the bill directly addresses financial burdens that can lead to or exacerbate child poverty. The inclusion of emergency relocation funds and compensation for lost wages further stabilizes family finances, helping to maintain housing stability and income essential for preventing children from falling into poverty or alleviating its effects after a traumatic event.

Title: Mental Health - Assisted Outpatient Treatment Programs
Synopsis: Authorizing each county to establish an assisted outpatient treatment program by July 1, 2026; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to establish an assisted outpatient treatment program in a county that does not opt to establish the program by July 1, 2026; requiring the Office of the Public Defender to provide representation in assisted outpatient treatment proceedings; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes assisted outpatient treatment programs across Maryland. These programs allow a civil court to order individuals, aged 18 or older, with serious and persistent mental illness and a history of treatment non-adherence, to adhere to a specific outpatient treatment plan. The aim is to reduce homelessness, hospitalizations, arrests, and incarcerations among this population. Counties are required to establish their own programs by July 1, 2026, or the Maryland Department of Health will establish one for them. The Office of the Public Defender will provide legal representation for indigent individuals in these proceedings.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and County Local Behavioral Health Authorities or Core Service Agencies
stakeholders: Individuals at least 18 years old with serious and persistent mental illness, their families, emergency facilities, hospitals, correctional facilities, and mental health programs. More broadly, the public benefits from reduced homelessness, arrests, and incarcerations related to untreated mental illness.
innovative_summary: This program introduces a new civil court-ordered assisted outpatient treatment for individuals with serious and persistent mental illness in Maryland. While this approach is a "federally recognized best practice" implemented in most other states, it represents a significant innovation for Maryland, which was previously one of only three states without such statutory authority. It employs a structured, recovery-oriented, and multidisciplinary care coordination team approach to manage severe mental illness within the state.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's objective to reduce homelessness, hospitalizations, arrests, and incarcerations among adults with serious mental illness has the potential to indirectly impact child poverty. By providing stability and treatment to parents suffering from severe mental illness, it could improve family stability, reduce parental incarceration, and enable parents to better meet their families' basic needs. However, as the program directly targets individuals aged 18 and older, its impact on child poverty is indirect.

Title: Housing and Community Development - Study on the Establishment of a Homeless Shelter Licensing Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Study on the Establishment of a Homeless Shelter Licensing Program in the Department of Housing and Community Development; requiring the Study to review current habitability and admissions standards of homeless shelters in the State; and requiring the Study to report to a certain Assistant Secretary in the Department and certain committees in the General Assembly by July 1, 2025, its recommendations on habitability and admission standards and a plan to establish a program in the Department to license homeless shelters.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a study within the Department of Housing and Community Development to review current habitability and admissions standards of homeless shelters in Maryland. The study will recommend basic standards for homeless shelters and a plan for establishing a statewide licensing program for these shelters. The Department is required to hire one full-time employee to conduct this study in consultation with political subdivisions. A report of findings and recommendations is due by July 1, 2025, to the Assistant Secretary of the Homeless Solutions Division and legislative committees.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Homeless individuals, homeless shelter operators and owners, and political subdivisions in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on conducting a study to develop licensing standards for homeless shelters, which is a standard regulatory and policy development process for government. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking approaches to public services, but rather seeks to improve existing frameworks for a vulnerable population.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill initiates a study on homeless shelter licensing. While improved and standardized homeless shelters could indirectly benefit children experiencing homelessness by providing safer and more stable temporary housing, the study itself does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, direct services, or other poverty reduction interventions. Its impact is a very indirect and upstream policy analysis.

Title: Time to Serve Act of 2024
Synopsis: Increasing, from 15 to 30, the maximum number of days of disaster service leave for employees in the Executive Branch of State government; and increasing, from 15 to 30, the maximum number of days of paid leave the Secretary of Budget and Management may provide for uniformed services training or active uniformed services duty in a reserve unit of the armed forces or organized militia.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the "Time to Serve Act of 2024," increases the maximum number of days for disaster service leave for employees in the Executive Branch of State government from 15 to 30 days in any 12-month period. It also increases the maximum number of paid leave days the Secretary of Budget and Management may provide for uniformed services training or active duty in a reserve unit of the armed forces or organized militia from 15 to 30 days. The bill generally relates to disaster service leave and paid leave for State employees.
responsible_party: Secretary of Budget and Management; Appointing Authority (for approval of leave)
stakeholders: Employees in the Executive, Judicial, and Legislative branches of State government, including temporary employees and those in units with independent personnel systems; specifically, Executive Branch employees for disaster service leave, and all State employees for uniformed services leave.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts existing administrative leave policies for State employees by increasing the number of allowable days for disaster service and uniformed services leave. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services but rather modifies current personnel regulations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill increases paid leave days for State employees. While this could indirectly support the financial stability of State employee families, including those with children, it is not a direct intervention or program specifically designed to address child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be incidental and not a primary objective.

Title: State Government - Permits, Licenses, and Certificates - Processing (Transparent Government Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Requiring each principal department and independent unit to create a  catalog of information relating to permits, licenses, and certificates issued by the department or independent unit and to submit the catalog to the Governor on or before October 1, 2024; requiring each department and independent unit to post certain completed information relating to permits, licenses, and certificates on the website of each department or independent unit by October 1, 2025; and establishing the Government Efficiency Commission.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Transparent Government Act of 2024, requires each principal department and independent unit of the State government to create and submit a catalog of all permits, licenses, and certificates they issue to the Governor by October 1, 2024. This catalog must include descriptions, validity terms, statutory authority, application methods, estimated processing times, fees, and impacts of criminal history. Departments and independent units must also post application process updates and processing times on their websites annually, starting December 1, 2024. The bill establishes a Government Efficiency Commission to monitor permit/license processing efficiency, compile reports, review statutory provisions, and make recommendations to improve efficiency and remove barriers for individuals and businesses. The Commission is required to submit annual reports to the Governor and General Assembly starting December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland State departments and independent units, the Government Efficiency Commission, and the Office of the Governor
stakeholders: Individuals and businesses seeking permits, licenses, or certificates from the State of Maryland; all principal State departments and independent units; and the general public seeking transparent government information.
innovative_summary: The program promotes government innovation through enhanced transparency and efficiency. It mandates a systematic cataloging and public posting of detailed information about all State permits, licenses, and certificates, including processing times and IT systems used. The establishment of a dedicated Government Efficiency Commission, composed of legislative, executive, and business community members, provides a structured, data-driven approach to continuously monitor and recommend improvements to government processes. This fosters a more accountable and responsive government environment.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not directly address child poverty. Its focus is on improving the efficiency and transparency of government permitting and licensing processes. While a more efficient government could indirectly foster economic growth and job creation, which might eventually benefit families and reduce child poverty, the program does not include any specific, targeted interventions or direct support mechanisms for children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Economic Development - Entrepreneurial Innovation Programs - Establishment (Pava LaPere Legacy of Innovation Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Pava LaPere Innovation Acceleration Grant Program in the Maryland Technology Development Corporation to provide grants to technology-based start-up companies founded by students from institutions located in the Baltimore-Columbia-Towson Metropolitan Statistical Area; establishing the Baltimore Innovation Initiative Pilot Program within the Maryland Innovation Initiative of the Corporation; requiring certain appropriations for the programs to be included in the annual budget bill in certain fiscal years; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Pava LaPere Legacy of Innovation Act of 2024, establishes two new programs within the Maryland Technology Development Corporation: the Pava LaPere Innovation Acceleration Grant Program and the Baltimore Innovation Initiative Pilot Program. Both programs aim to foster the growth of entrepreneurial innovation and technology-based start-up companies, specifically those founded by students or faculty from postsecondary institutions in the Baltimore-Columbia-Towson Metropolitan Statistical Area. The Pava LaPere program provides $50,000 grants to qualifying startups, while the Baltimore Innovation Initiative, a pilot program with a sunset date of June 30, 2027, provides funding to eligible universities for projects that support new technology businesses, advance commercialization (with a preference for AI/ML in health care and biotechnology), foster equitable development, and create economic impact.
responsible_party: Maryland Technology Development Corporation
stakeholders: Technology-based start-up companies, students, faculty, postsecondary institutions, and industry partners within the Baltimore-Columbia-Towson Metropolitan Statistical Area.
innovative_summary: The programs promote technological innovation by supporting startups founded by university students and faculty, especially those focused on integrating artificial intelligence or machine learning in health care and biotechnology. This approach encourages commercialization, university-industry collaboration, and targets high-growth tech sectors within a specific metropolitan area.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to stimulate economic growth and create jobs through the development of technology-based startups. While a stronger economy and more employment opportunities can indirectly alleviate poverty, the programs do not directly provide services or financial assistance to individuals or families experiencing child poverty.

Title: Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention in the Maryland Department of Health to reduce firearm violence, harm from firearm violence, and misuse of firearms in the State by partnering with federal, State, and local agencies and affected communities to implement a public health approach to firearm violence reduction; requiring the Center to submit to the Governor and the General Assembly by May 1, 2025, a preliminary State Plan for a Public Health Approach to Reducing Firearm Violence; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention within the Maryland Department of Health. The Center's purpose is to reduce firearm violence, harm from firearm violence, and misuse of firearms across the State by implementing a public health approach. It will achieve this by partnering with federal, state, and local agencies, consulting with affected communities and experts, developing strategic plans, offering training and technical assistance, issuing best practice guidance, facilitating data sharing, conducting public awareness campaigns, and promoting evidence-based prevention initiatives.
responsible_party: Center for Firearm Violence Prevention and Intervention in the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Communities disproportionately impacted by firearm violence, public health experts, individuals and organizations with expertise in firearm safety and training, state and local agencies, health care professionals, community and faith-based organizations, higher education and research institutions, and the general public of Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program adopts a public health approach to firearm violence reduction, emphasizing collaboration across government agencies, community engagement, evidence-based strategies, and data sharing. While a public health approach to violence is recognized, its systematic implementation at a state level with a dedicated center, focused on inter-agency cooperation and strategic planning, represents a structured and moderately innovative government initiative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly providing economic relief or services to children in poverty, this program aims to reduce firearm violence, which disproportionately affects communities with higher poverty rates. By creating safer environments and reducing trauma associated with violence, it can indirectly improve the well-being and stability for children living in poverty, potentially fostering better health, educational outcomes, and overall community resilience.

Title: Workers' Compensation - Occupational Disease Presumptions - First Responders (Caring for Public Employees in the Safety Professions - CAPES Act)
Synopsis: Providing that certain firefighters, fire fighting instructors, rescue squad members, advanced life support unit members, and members of the Office of the State Fire Marshal who have thyroid, colon, or ovarian cancer are presumed, under certain circumstances, to have an occupational disease that was suffered in the line of duty and is compensable under workers' compensation law.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the CAPES Act, expands the list of cancers presumed to be occupational diseases for certain first responders under workers' compensation law. Specifically, it includes thyroid, colon, and ovarian cancer for paid and volunteer firefighters, fire fighting instructors, rescue squad members, and advanced life support unit members, making these conditions compensable if suffered in the line of duty under specified circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Workers' Compensation Commission (as the body overseeing workers' compensation law)
stakeholders: Paid and volunteer firefighters, fire fighting instructors, rescue squad members, advanced life support unit members, sworn members of the Office of the State Fire Marshal, and their dependents.
innovative_summary: This bill modifies existing workers' compensation law by expanding the list of presumed occupational diseases for first responders. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather adjusts eligibility criteria within an established legal framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a potential indirect impact on child poverty by enhancing the financial security of first responders and their families. By making it easier for first responders to receive workers' compensation for certain cancers, it provides a crucial safety net for families, preventing potential financial hardship and income loss that could lead to child poverty if a parent becomes disabled or dies due to these work-related illnesses.

Title: Protecting Election Officials Act of 2024
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from knowingly and willfully making a threat to harm an election official or an immediate family member of an election official because of the election official's role in administering the election process; and establishing that a person who violates the Act is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $2,500 or both.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Protecting Election Officials Act of 2024, prohibits individuals from knowingly and willfully making threats to harm an election official or their immediate family members due to the official's role in administering the election process. A violation is a misdemeanor, punishable by up to 3 years imprisonment, a fine of up to $2,500, or both. The bill defines "election official" to include State and local election board members, employees, counsel, directors, and election judges, as well as individuals who assist in administering an election and pages. It also defines "harm" and "threat" and went into effect as an emergency measure on April 9, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland law enforcement agencies and the Maryland judiciary (for enforcement); State Board of Elections and local boards (as the beneficiaries of protection)
stakeholders: Election officials, including State and local election board members, employees, counsel, directors, election judges, and their immediate family members.
innovative_summary: The bill addresses a growing concern regarding threats against election officials by creating a specific legal prohibition and penalty. While it's a critical update to legal protections, it doesn't introduce new technologies or fundamentally alter governmental approaches; rather, it strengthens existing legal frameworks for election integrity and safety.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on protecting election officials from threats and does not have any direct provisions or mechanisms that would address child poverty. Its impact is on the safety of individuals involved in the democratic process.

Title: Frederick County - Alcoholic Beverages - Weinberg Center/New Spires Arts Stages Beer, Wine, and Liquor License
Synopsis: Altering the Class C (Weinberg Center) beer, wine, and liquor license in Frederick County to be the Class C (Weinberg Center/New Spires Arts Stages) beer, wine, and liquor license; expanding the licensed premises to include the New Spires Arts Stages; altering the officials who may sign a certain license application; authorizing the license holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor at an event held by an outside group that has rented the Weinberg Arts Center or the New Spires Arts Stages; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the Class C alcoholic beverages license in Frederick County, renaming it the Class C (Weinberg Center/New Spires Arts Stages) beer, wine, and liquor license. It expands the licensed premises to include the New Spires Arts Stages, modifies the officials authorized to sign the license application, and permits the license holder to sell alcoholic beverages during events hosted by outside groups renting either facility.
responsible_party: Frederick County Alcoholic Beverages Board
stakeholders: Non-profit Weinberg Center for the Arts, New Spires Arts Stages, their patrons, customers, and outside groups renting these facilities in Frederick County.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative change to an existing alcoholic beverage license and does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is solely focused on alcoholic beverage licensing for arts venues and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Frederick County - Alcoholic Beverages - Manufacturer's Limited Beer, Wine, and Liquor Permit
Synopsis: Establishing a manufacturer's limited beer, wine, and liquor permit in Frederick County; authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County to issue a permit to holders of certain manufacturer's licenses; establishing that the permit authorizes the holder to allow a licensed caterer or other contracted party to provide sealed beer, wine, and liquor products not manufactured by the holder during private events for on-premises consumption; and requiring the Board to adopt certain regulations.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a new manufacturer's limited beer, wine, and liquor permit in Frederick County. This permit allows holders of certain manufacturer's licenses (Class 1 distillery and Class 5 brewery) with a local on-site consumption permit to authorize a licensed caterer or other contracted party to provide sealed beer, wine, and liquor products (even if not manufactured by the holder) for on-premises consumption during private events. The Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County is responsible for issuing these permits, approving events, and adopting regulations, including setting an annual permit fee. The manufacturer cannot have a direct or indirect pecuniary interest in the contracted party, and public patrons must not enter the private event area during such events.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage manufacturers (specifically Class 1 distilleries and Class 5 breweries) in Frederick County, licensed caterers or contracted parties working with these manufacturers, and individuals attending private events at these establishments.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a new permit type that grants alcoholic beverage manufacturers in Frederick County more flexibility in hosting private events by allowing a third-party caterer to serve a wider range of alcoholic products, including those not produced by the manufacturer. While it offers a new operational approach for businesses, it is a regulatory adjustment within an existing framework rather than a novel government service or technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on alcoholic beverage permits and regulations for manufacturers and private events. It does not contain any provisions directly aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty.

Title: Frederick County - Alcoholic Beverages - Municipal Golf Course License
Synopsis: Authorizing the Frederick County Board of License Commissioners to issue a municipal golf course license to an official of the City of Frederick designated by the Mayor of the City of Frederick; and authorizing the Board to transfer the license to a different city official designated by the Mayor under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill amends alcoholic beverage laws in Frederick County to allow a municipal golf course license (Class M–G beer, wine, and liquor) to be issued to an official of the City of Frederick designated by the Mayor, in addition to a golf course manager. It also authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County to transfer this license to a different designated city official upon request from the City of Frederick, and sets the annual license fee at $600.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County
stakeholders: Officials of the City of Frederick, municipal golf course managers, and patrons of municipal golf courses in Frederick County.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a minor administrative change to existing alcoholic beverage licensing rules in Frederick County, specifying who can hold a municipal golf course license. It does not involve any new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill pertains to the administrative details of alcoholic beverage licensing at a municipal golf course. It has no direct or intended impact on child poverty or related interventions.

Title: Dorchester County - County Applicants - Polygraph Examination
Synopsis: Exempting applicants for employment as a paramedic or an emergency medical technician with Dorchester County or as a 9-1-1 specialist at the Dorchester County 9-1-1 Center from the prohibition on employers requiring or demanding that an individual submit to or take a polygraph examination as a condition of prospective employment.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's Labor and Employment law to exempt certain applicants for employment with the Dorchester County Department of Emergency Services and the Dorchester County Department of Corrections from the general prohibition on employers requiring polygraph examinations. Specifically, it allows polygraph examinations as a condition of prospective employment for paramedics and emergency medical technicians within the Emergency Medical Services Division, 9-1-1 Center Dispatcher Specialists at the Dorchester County 9-1-1 Center, and correctional officers at the Dorchester County Detention Center.
responsible_party: Dorchester County Department of Emergency Services, Dorchester County Department of Corrections
stakeholders: Applicants for paramedic, emergency medical technician, 9-1-1 dispatcher specialist, and correctional officer positions within Dorchester County; Dorchester County Department of Emergency Services; Dorchester County Department of Corrections.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it involves an amendment to existing employment law regarding polygraph examinations, not the introduction of new technologies or novel government approaches. It adjusts an exemption for specific local government hiring practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It relates to employment screening requirements for specific county jobs and does not establish programs or policies aimed at alleviating poverty or supporting families with children.

Title: Prince George's County - Judgeships - Circuit Courts
Synopsis: Altering the number of resident judges of the circuit courts by adding one additional judgeship in Prince George's County.
bill_summary: This bill increases the number of resident judges in the Circuit Court for Prince George's County by one, raising the total from 24 to 25. This change amends the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article of the Maryland Code.
responsible_party: Circuit Court for Prince George's County
stakeholders: Residents of Prince George's County, the judiciary, and legal professionals operating within Prince George's County.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it involves a standard administrative adjustment to the number of judgeships within a county's circuit court to manage caseloads, rather than employing new technologies or novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill's potential to have a direct impact on child poverty is very low. Increasing the number of judges primarily addresses judicial caseloads and court efficiency, which does not directly provide services, financial support, or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Legal Advertisement or Legal Notice in Dorchester County - Publication in Newspaper or Newspaper in General Circulation - Digital Newspapers
Synopsis: Establishing for the publication of certain notices in Dorchester County that any required advertisement or notice be published and distributed through print and digital format; providing that if there is no print and digital publication meeting all the qualifications under the Act, the advertisement or notice may be placed in any digital publication that can be accessed in Dorchester County and that regularly contains local news and information for Dorchester County; etc.
bill_summary: This bill redefines what constitutes a "newspaper" or "newspaper in general circulation" for the purpose of publishing legal advertisements and notices in Maryland to include publications offered in a digital format. It establishes specific requirements for Dorchester County, mandating that legal advertisements and notices be published and distributed through both print and digital formats. If no publication meets all standard qualifications in both formats, a digital-only publication that regularly contains local news and information for Dorchester County may be used.
responsible_party: Dorchester County government and other entities required to publish legal notices in Maryland.
stakeholders: Government entities, courts, and individuals or organizations required to publish legal advertisements or notices, as well as the general public who accesses these notices, especially in Dorchester County.
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes the definition of "newspaper" to explicitly include digital formats for legal publications, acknowledging the shift in media consumption. It also mandates a dual print and digital approach for legal notices in Dorchester County, ensuring broader accessibility in an increasingly digital world.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses the technical and legal requirements for publishing public notices and advertisements. It does not directly provide services, financial aid, or programs aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Growing Apprenticeships and the Public Safety Workforce (GAPS) Act
Synopsis: Altering the Law Enforcement Cadet Apprenticeship Program in the Maryland Department of Labor to be the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program; expanding the purpose and scope of the Program to promote careers with certain public safety agencies; altering the eligibility criteria and the types of grants to be awarded under the Program; requiring the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop certain mental health wellness policies to be implemented in certain law enforcement agencies and correctional facilities; etc.
bill_summary: The Growing Apprenticeships and the Public Safety Workforce (GAPS) Act alters the Law Enforcement Cadet Apprenticeship Program into the Public Safety Apprenticeship Program, expanding its scope to include various public safety agencies. It establishes new start-up grants (up to $200,000) and stabilization grants ($5,000 per apprentice) for public safety agencies to develop registered apprenticeship programs. The bill also mandates the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop mental health wellness policies for law enforcement agencies and correctional facilities, and creates a temporary workgroup to study and recommend strategies for increasing employment in the law enforcement and corrections workforce.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission
stakeholders: Young individuals, the public, law enforcement agencies, correctional facilities, public safety agencies, and individuals seeking careers in the law enforcement and corrections workforce.
innovative_summary: This bill expands a proven workforce development model (apprenticeships) to a critical public sector (public safety), introducing specific grant types to incentivize agency participation. It also mandates the development of mental health wellness policies for public safety personnel, which is a modern and important approach to supporting a demanding workforce. While it does not employ cutting-edge technology, it represents a structured and proactive approach to addressing recruitment, retention, and well-being challenges in public safety.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill creates and expands career pathways into stable public safety jobs through apprenticeship programs, which can improve economic stability for participating families. While it does not directly target or provide specific benefits to families experiencing child poverty, offering stable employment and career advancement opportunities to young individuals can indirectly contribute to reducing child poverty by improving household income and economic mobility. The removal of a previous criterion that focused on apprentices from high-poverty zip codes reduces its direct targeting potential.

Title: Discrimination - Military Status - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting discrimination based on military status with regard to housing and employment.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits discrimination based on military status across various sectors, including housing, employment, financial transactions, education, health care, insurance, public utility services, and State personnel actions. It amends numerous sections of the Maryland Code to include "military status" as a protected characteristic.
responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Civil Rights
stakeholders: Individuals with military status (members of uniformed services, reserve components, veterans, and their dependents) in Maryland, as well as businesses, educational institutions, healthcare providers, financial institutions, and state agencies interacting with these individuals.
innovative_summary: The bill extends existing civil rights protections to a new protected class, which is a standard legislative process for addressing discrimination, not a novel technological or governmental approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill prohibits discrimination based on military status across various sectors including housing, employment, education, and health care. While removing barriers to fair treatment in these essential areas can indirectly contribute to the economic stability of military families and thus potentially impact child poverty, it does not involve direct financial aid or specific programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Community Investment Corporation - Establishment (Housing and Community Development Financing Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Community Investment Corporation as an independent unit to make investments and financial assistance available in certain low-income communities in the State; expanding the eligible uses of the Strategic Demolition and Smart Growth Impact Fund to include grants and loans for credit enhancement for certain projects; requiring that members of the investment committee to be geographically representative of the locations of low-income communities in the State; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Community Investment Corporation as an independent state instrumentality to make investments in low-income communities. The Corporation's purposes include qualifying as a Community Development Entity, applying for federal New Markets Tax Credits, facilitating qualified equity investments, and fostering inclusive entrepreneurship. The bill also expands the eligible uses of the Strategic Demolition and Smart Growth Impact Fund to include credit enhancement for certain projects.
responsible_party: Maryland Community Investment Corporation
stakeholders: Residents and businesses in low-income communities in Maryland, nonprofit entities, entrepreneurs, and qualified businesses and projects within the state.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a new state corporation to act as a Qualified Community Development Entity to apply for and allocate federal New Markets Tax Credits. This approach uses an existing federal financial incentive program, administered by a new state entity, to channel private investment into economically distressed areas. While a strategic financial mechanism, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government beyond establishing a new leveraging entity.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By facilitating investments, job creation, and economic development in low-income communities, the program could improve economic opportunities and resources for families, potentially lifting some children out of poverty. However, it does not directly target families with children in poverty through specific benefits or services, relying instead on broader community economic improvement.

Title: Street Racing and Exhibition Driving – Prohibited Acts, Enforcement, and Penalties
Synopsis: Altering certain penalties and points assessments for certain motor vehicle violations related to participation in a race or speed contest; prohibiting a person from engaging in exhibition driving on any highway or private property that is used for driving by the public; establishing certain affirmative defenses to a certain charge of exhibition driving; etc.
bill_summary: This bill significantly increases penalties and points assessed for motor vehicle violations related to street racing and speed contests. It also prohibits 'exhibition driving' on any highway or private property used by the public, defining it as operating a vehicle in a manner that intentionally results in excessive acceleration/deceleration, tire skidding/squealing, swerving, loud engine noise, loss of wheel contact, or transporting passengers in unsafe areas. The bill establishes new penalties, including imprisonment and fines, especially when serious bodily injury occurs, and provides affirmative defenses for certain exhibition driving charges. It also clarifies and expands regulations for 'special event zones' beyond Worcester County.
responsible_party: Maryland State law enforcement agencies and the Judiciary
stakeholders: Motor vehicle drivers in Maryland, particularly those involved in street racing or exhibition driving, victims of such activities, and the general public benefiting from enhanced road safety.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily strengthens existing traffic laws and introduces new definitions and prohibitions for dangerous driving behaviors like 'exhibition driving.' While it expands the scope of enforcement and modifies penalties, it does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches; rather, it refines and enhances the current regulatory framework for public safety.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on road safety and deterring dangerous driving behaviors. It does not contain any provisions that directly provide financial assistance, services, or opportunities aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, such as a reduction in traffic-related injuries or fatalities that might indirectly prevent family financial hardship.

Title: Employment Discrimination – Sexual Orientation
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions of law prohibiting employment discrimination on the basis of sex and gender identity to also prohibit employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's employment discrimination laws to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation. It expands existing protections related to sex and gender identity to include sexual orientation concerning wages, employment opportunities, career tracks, promotions, and other terms of employment.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and relevant state enforcement agencies for employment discrimination laws
stakeholders: Employees and job applicants in Maryland, particularly those who identify as LGBTQ+, and employers in Maryland who must comply with anti-discrimination laws.
innovative_summary: This bill expands existing civil rights protections to include sexual orientation, aligning with a broader trend in anti-discrimination law. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather updates an existing legal framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to prevent employment discrimination, which can indirectly contribute to economic stability for individuals and families by ensuring fair employment practices. However, it does not directly establish programs, funding, or services specifically aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Consumer Protection - Online Products and Services - Data of Children (Maryland Kids Code)
Synopsis: Requiring a certain entity that offers an online product reasonably likely to be accessed by children to complete a certain data protection impact assessment by April 1, 2026, under certain circumstances; requiring certain privacy protections for certain online products; prohibiting certain data collection and sharing practices; authorizing certain monitoring practices to allow a child's parent or guardian to monitor the child's online activity or location without providing an obvious signal to the child; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Maryland Kids Code, requires covered entities offering online products reasonably likely to be accessed by children to complete data protection impact assessments. It mandates certain privacy protections for these online products, prohibits specific data collection and sharing practices, and authorizes certain monitoring practices, all aimed at enhancing the online privacy and well-being of children.
responsible_party: The Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Children under 18 years old who access online products, and covered entities (sole proprietorships, LLCs, corporations, associations) that operate online products and meet certain revenue or data processing thresholds.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a new regulatory framework, the Maryland Age-Appropriate Design Code Act, inspired by similar efforts in the United Kingdom and California. It requires covered entities to proactively design online products with the 'best interests of children' in mind, including conducting data protection impact assessments, configuring default privacy settings to a high level, and prohibiting certain data collection, profiling, and dark pattern usage for children. This represents a modern, proactive approach to online child safety through design principles.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on protecting the online privacy, safety, and well-being of children by regulating data practices of online products. While ensuring a safer digital environment can indirectly contribute to overall child well-being, it does not directly address economic factors or provide resources to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Motor Vehicles - Recreational Vehicle Dealer Agreements
Synopsis: Requiring recreational vehicle dealers to hold a dealer agreement with a recreational vehicle manufacturer to sell the manufacturer's recreational vehicles in the State; establishing licensing requirements for a recreational vehicle manufacturer, distributor, or factory branch; altering the required terms and conditions of a recreational dealer agreement; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes new regulations for agreements between recreational vehicle (RV) manufacturers, distributors, and dealers in Maryland. It requires RV manufacturers, distributors, and factory branches to obtain licenses from the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA). The bill specifies detailed terms and conditions for dealer agreements, covering aspects like termination and nonrenewal, transfer of dealer ownership, warranty obligations, vehicle inspection and rejection, and prohibited unfair practices. It also outlines procedures for dispute resolution, including mandatory mediation, and grants the MVA authority to impose penalties, such as license suspension, revocation, and fines, for violations.
responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
stakeholders: Recreational vehicle manufacturers, distributors, factory branches, and recreational vehicle dealers operating in Maryland. Indirectly, consumers of recreational vehicles may be impacted by improved dealer protections and warranty clarity.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a comprehensive regulatory framework for the recreational vehicle industry in Maryland, formalizing licensing, dealer agreements, and warranty processes. While it modernizes and clarifies existing business relationships and provides mechanisms for dispute resolution within this specific sector, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking approaches to government services or operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses exclusively on regulating the commercial relationships within the recreational vehicle industry, including licensing, dealer agreements, and warranty practices. It does not contain any provisions, programs, or funding mechanisms that directly address or aim to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Community Colleges - Maryland Community College Promise Scholarship - Requirements
Synopsis: Establishing that applicants for a Maryland Community College Promise Scholarship are not subject to certain requirements of the scholarship application process if the applicant enrolls in a noncredit vocational certificate program, enrolls in a sequence of noncredit courses leading to licensure or certification, or participates in a registered apprenticeship program.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Maryland Community College Promise Scholarship to make it more accessible. Specifically, it exempts applicants who enroll in noncredit vocational certificate programs, sequences of noncredit courses leading to licensure or certification, or registered apprenticeship programs from certain requirements, such as grade point average (GPA) criteria and the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) submission, unless a Pell Grant can be used for the noncredit program. These applicants are still eligible if they are a resident of the state or graduated from a high school in the state.
responsible_party: Maryland community colleges
stakeholders: Applicants for the Maryland Community College Promise Scholarship, particularly those pursuing noncredit vocational certificates, noncredit licensure/certification courses, or registered apprenticeships.
innovative_summary: The bill adjusts eligibility criteria for an existing scholarship program, removing barriers for specific types of vocational and apprenticeship students. While beneficial, it does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By expanding eligibility for the Maryland Community College Promise Scholarship to include students in vocational and apprenticeship programs, and by easing GPA and FAFSA requirements for these pathways, the bill directly reduces financial barriers to education and job training. This can lead to increased access to higher-paying jobs for low-income individuals and families, thereby directly impacting child poverty by improving household economic stability.

Title: Education - Public Libraries - Collective Bargaining (Library Workers Empowerment Act)
Synopsis: Authorizing employees of public libraries to form, join, and participate in an employee organization and engage in certain other activities related to collective bargaining; requiring employers and certified exclusive representatives to engage in good faith bargaining; establishing a collective bargaining process for employees of public libraries; prohibiting employers and employee organizations from engaging in certain actions regarding the exercise of an employee's rights under the Act; applying the Act prospectively; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Library Workers Empowerment Act, authorizes employees of certain public library systems in Maryland to form, join, and participate in employee organizations for collective bargaining. It establishes a detailed process for collective bargaining, including certification of exclusive representatives, good faith bargaining requirements, and procedures for resolving impasses through mediation. The bill also outlines prohibited actions for both employers and employee organizations, such as strikes and lockouts, and repeals previous specific collective bargaining provisions for Howard County Library System, replacing them with a broader framework for other county public library systems, including the Enoch Pratt Free Library, but excluding Baltimore, Montgomery, and Prince George's Counties.
responsible_party: Maryland public library systems and their boards of trustees, in collaboration with employee organizations and county governing/funding bodies for budgetary approval.
stakeholders: Full-time and part-time employees of county public library systems in Maryland (excluding Baltimore County, Montgomery County, and Prince George's County, but including the Enoch Pratt Free Library), as well as the public library systems themselves and their governing/funding bodies.
innovative_summary: This bill extends collective bargaining rights to a new sector of public employees (certain public library workers) in Maryland. While the concept of collective bargaining is not new, its application to this specific group of public sector employees modernizes labor relations within these library systems, establishing a formal framework for negotiations and dispute resolution where one may not have existed previously for these specific entities. The mechanisms (e.g., neutral decision-makers, mediation) are standard practices in labor relations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By establishing collective bargaining rights, it aims to improve the wages, hours, and terms of employment for public library employees. If collective bargaining leads to higher wages and better benefits for these employees, it could improve the economic well-being of their families, potentially alleviating financial hardship for those with children and indirectly reducing child poverty. However, it does not directly target child poverty or provide specific programs or services for children in poverty.

Title: Electronic Transactions Protection Act - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing the Electronic Transactions Protection Act.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the Electronic Transactions Protection Act, including Sections 6–201 through 6–203 and the related subtitle of the State Government Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland. The repeal takes effect on October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: The general public and entities involved in electronic transactions in Maryland, as the act being repealed pertained to their protection.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it repeals an existing act and does not establish new programs, technologies, or approaches to government. It is a legislative cleanup.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill repeals an act concerning electronic transactions and has no direct impact on child poverty. Its scope is entirely unrelated to poverty alleviation.

Title: Natural Resources - Recreational Catching of Oysters or Clams - Requirements
Synopsis: Altering certain authorizations to recreationally catch clams in the State; establishing a recreational oyster license; requiring an applicant for a recreational oyster license to be at least 16 years of age; requiring the Department of Natural Resources to use a part  of the application fees collected to replenish public fishery oysters bars; requiring the Department to issue complimentary or discounted recreational oyster licenses; authorizing certain individuals to catch oysters without a license under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a new recreational oyster license in Maryland, requiring individuals aged 16 and older to obtain it to harvest oysters in tidal waters. It outlines the application process, which includes a $10 fee, a portion of which will be used by the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to replenish public fishery oyster bars. The DNR is authorized to issue complimentary licenses to specific groups, including former prisoners of war, unemployable American veterans, 100% service-connected disabled American veterans, and blind residents, and discounted licenses to Purple Heart recipients. Property owners or lessees bordering tidal waters and their immediate family residing on the property are exempt from the license requirement but must register with the DNR. The bill also clarifies regulations for recreational clam catching.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Recreational oyster and clam harvesters in Maryland, including residents, non-residents, former prisoners of war, American veterans, blind residents, Purple Heart recipients, and individuals who own or lease property bordering tidal waters of the State.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a standard licensing program for recreational oyster harvesting. While it includes provisions for complimentary and discounted licenses for specific veteran groups and disabled individuals, and an exemption for riparian property owners, these are administrative provisions rather than innovative uses of technology or fundamentally new approaches to government services. The use of a portion of the fee for oyster bar replenishment is a standard conservation funding model.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily concerns the regulation and licensing of recreational oyster and clam harvesting. There is no direct connection or stated intention to impact child poverty. The provisions do not offer financial aid, educational support, healthcare, or housing assistance that would directly alleviate child poverty.

Title: Harford County - Alcoholic Beverages - Stadium License Annual Fee
Synopsis: Reducing the annual fee for a stadium beer, wine, and liquor license in Harford County from $10,000 to $7,000.
bill_summary: This bill reduces the annual fee for a stadium beer, wine, and liquor license in Harford County from $10,000 to $7,000. It also outlines regulations for sales, service, and consumption of alcoholic beverages at professional baseball stadiums in the county, including specific restrictions during games and requirements for servers.
responsible_party: Harford County Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Owners, lessees, or concession managers of professional baseball stadiums in Harford County that hold a stadium beer, wine, and liquor license, as well as individuals serving alcohol at these venues and patrons.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It primarily adjusts an existing fee structure and reiterates regulations for alcoholic beverage sales at stadiums, without introducing new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill changes the annual fee for an alcoholic beverage license for a stadium. There is no direct mechanism or intent within the bill to address or impact child poverty.

Title: Consumer Reporting Agencies - Records of Criminal Proceedings - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting consumer reporting agencies from including in a consumer report certain records relating to a criminal proceeding involving a consumer; and prohibiting consumer reporting agencies from relying on  information in certain criminal proceedings concerning the consumer to make a determination of the creditworthiness of a consumer.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits consumer reporting agencies from including specific records of criminal proceedings in consumer reports, such as those where the consumer was falsely accused, acquitted, had charges dropped (nolle prosequi), or did not receive a guilty verdict. It also prohibits the inclusion of expunged criminal records and bars these agencies from using such information to determine a consumer's creditworthiness.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Maryland consumers, particularly those with past criminal proceedings that did not result in a guilty verdict or whose records have been expunged, and consumer reporting agencies.
innovative_summary: The bill represents a regulatory adjustment to existing consumer protection laws by placing new restrictions on the type of information consumer reporting agencies can use. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather refines the scope of information considered in credit reporting.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By removing certain criminal records as barriers to credit access, the bill has the potential to indirectly improve the economic stability and opportunities for adults. Increased access to credit can lead to better housing, employment, and overall financial well-being, which could benefit families and children living in poverty by reducing financial stress and opening pathways to economic advancement for their parents or guardians.

Title: Next Generation Scholars of Maryland Program - Program Administrator - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the administrator of the Next Generation Scholars of Maryland Program to be the Maryland Higher Education Commission rather than the State Department of Education; and requiring the Department to assist the Commission with the review of applications and the selection of nonprofit organizations to administer the Program in local school systems.
bill_summary: This bill alters the administrator of the Next Generation Scholars of Maryland Program from the State Department of Education to the Maryland Higher Education Commission. The Department of Education will now collaborate with and assist the Commission in certain program duties, such as reviewing applications for nonprofit organizations that administer the program.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (with assistance from the State Department of Education)
stakeholders: High school students who qualify for a Guaranteed Access Grant or free or reduced-price lunch, and these students when they matriculate at an institution of higher education. Specifically, students in local school systems where at least 50% of students are eligible for free lunch.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily involves an administrative change in who oversees an existing program. The Next Generation Scholars Program itself provides standard educational support services such as mentorship, college visits, financial aid literacy, and career assessments. There are no new technologies or innovative government approaches introduced by this legislation.
