While supporting adults with disabilities in maintaining employment and accessing healthcare can indirectly benefit families and children by increasing household income and stability, it is not a direct intervention specifically designed to alleviate child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be secondary through the improved economic well-being of the adults in the household.

Title: Fire Protection and Prevention - Residential Rental Property - Requirements (Melanie Nicholle Diaz Fire Safety Act)
Synopsis: Establishing certain requirements relating to the installation of certain fire safety equipment in residential rental high-rise buildings and certain other property; authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a certain property tax credit; establishing the Workgroup to Develop Fire Safety Best Practices for Pre-1974 High-Rise Apartment Buildings; requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations by December 31, 2024; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Melanie Nicholle Diaz Fire Safety Act, establishes new fire safety requirements for residential rental high-rise buildings in Maryland. Key provisions include mandating smoke detection equipment in public corridors, emergency escape lighting, and requiring landlords to post notices and include lease disclosures for buildings without complete automatic sprinkler systems. Landlords must also provide fire safety and evacuation information to tenants, and supply special notification appliances for deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing tenants without charge or documentation. The Department of Housing and Community Development, in coordination with the State Fire Marshal, is tasked with identifying and publishing information on funding sources for sprinkler system upgrades. Additionally, local jurisdictions are authorized to grant property tax credits for fire safety improvements. A temporary Workgroup is established to study fire safety risks and develop best practices for pre-1974 high-rise apartment buildings.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development; State Fire Marshal; Maryland Department of Emergency Management; Department of State Police; local jurisdictions
stakeholders: Owners and landlords of residential rental high-rise buildings, condominium associations, cooperative housing corporations, tenants (including deaf, deafblind, hard of hearing, and mobility-impaired residents), local governments, fire service professionals, and the general public in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill implements standard fire safety measures through updated regulations, mandates, and the authorization of local property tax credits as an incentive. While the creation of a workgroup to develop best practices for older buildings is a structured approach to policy development, and the identification of funding sources is helpful, these methods are not particularly innovative in terms of new technologies or novel governmental approaches. The focus is on implementing existing, proven safety technologies and practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to improve fire safety and living conditions in residential rental high-rise buildings, which can indirectly benefit families and children by reducing risks of injury, death, and displacement due to fires. A safer home environment contributes to overall family well-being. However, the bill does not directly address the economic factors of child poverty such as income, food security, or access to poverty alleviation services.

Title: Libraries - Regional Resource Centers - Governing Board Membership
Synopsis: Increasing, from one member to two members, the number of public members from each area served by the participating library systems on the governing board for each regional resource center.
bill_summary: This bill increases the number of public members on the governing board for each regional resource center from up to one member to up to two members from each area served by participating library systems. It also clarifies that the board of trustees of the Washington County Free Library acts as the governing board for the Western Maryland Regional Resource Center.
responsible_party: Governing Boards for Regional Resource Centers, including the Board of Trustees of the Washington County Free Library
stakeholders: The public in areas served by participating library systems, and the governing boards of regional resource centers.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a minor administrative change by increasing the number of public members on library governing boards. It does not involve new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill's direct impact on child poverty is very low. It is an administrative change to the composition of library governing boards and does not directly provide services or resources aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Maryland Insurance Administration – Professional Employer Organizations – Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Insurance Administration to study professional employer organizations in the State to review certain regulations, histories, health plans, requirements, and regulatory structures in other states and to address any potential impacts of proposed statutory changes in the State relating to the offering of health coverage by professional employer organizations on the small group market in the State; and requiring the Administration to report to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Insurance Administration to conduct a study on professional employer organizations (PEOs) in the State. The study will examine PEO regulations, their history, health plan designs, participation requirements for businesses (especially small employers), and the regulatory structures in other states that allow co-employed individuals to participate in PEO large group plans. It will also address the potential impacts of proposed statutory changes related to PEO health coverage on the small group market in Maryland. The Administration must report its findings to the House Health and Government Operations Committee and the Senate Finance Committee by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
stakeholders: Professional employer organizations (PEOs), businesses participating in PEO arrangements (especially small employers), individuals co-employed through PEOs, health insurance providers, and the small group health insurance market in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates a study, which is a standard legislative and regulatory activity. It does not introduce new technologies, programs, or particularly novel approaches to government or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on studying professional employer organizations and their impact on health coverage and the small group insurance market. While access to health coverage can indirectly support families and potentially alleviate financial burdens, this bill is a study of a regulatory and market aspect, not a direct intervention or program specifically targeting child poverty reduction.

Title: General Provisions - Damages or Losses - Definition
Synopsis: Defining "damages" or "losses" in statutory causes of action to protect civil rights or consumer rights and providing that "damages" or "losses" includes reasonable nominal damages.
bill_summary: This bill defines "damages" or "losses" in statutory causes of action related to civil rights and consumer rights to include reasonable nominal damages. This clarification aims to ensure that individuals have access to legal remedies, even when substantial monetary loss cannot be proven, in response to recent judicial trends perceived as limiting civil and consumer protections.
responsible_party: Maryland Courts
stakeholders: Individuals and protected classes of persons seeking to enforce civil rights or consumer rights under Maryland law.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It clarifies legal definitions in response to judicial interpretations, rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to directly impact child poverty is low. While it aims to protect civil and consumer rights, which can indirectly benefit vulnerable populations by enabling legal recourse against exploitative practices, it does not establish direct programs, financial aid, or services specifically targeting child poverty.

Title: Parents in Substance Use Disorder Treatment - Children in Need of Assistance and Treatment Facilities
Synopsis: Establishing a presumption that placement with a child's parent is in the best interest of the child, the child is receiving proper care and attention, and there is not a certain emergency situation if the child's parent is receiving certain substance use disorder treatment and the child is in the presence of the child's parent for the duration of the child's parent's treatment; authorizing the Behavioral Health Administration to require a facility providing certain treatment to provide beds and services to the patient's children; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a legal presumption that it is in a child's best interest to be placed with a parent undergoing residential substance use disorder treatment, provided the child can be present during the treatment. It also authorizes the Behavioral Health Administration to require substance use disorder treatment facilities to offer beds and services for patients' children, allowing them to remain with their parents during treatment. Additionally, local departments of social services are mandated to file a report with the court if a child is not placed with a parent in such a treatment program.
responsible_party: Behavioral Health Administration
stakeholders: Parents undergoing residential substance use disorder treatment, their children, substance use disorder treatment facilities, local departments of social services, and the courts.
innovative_summary: This bill represents a progressive approach by recognizing the importance of keeping families together during a parent's substance use disorder treatment. By authorizing the Behavioral Health Administration to require treatment facilities to provide services for children and allow them to reside with their parents, it moves towards a more family-centered treatment model, which is less common in traditional substance use disorder treatment. It addresses a systemic barrier to treatment completion and family reunification.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential for a direct positive impact on child poverty by supporting family reunification and a parent's successful completion of substance use disorder treatment. Keeping children with their parents during treatment can reduce the trauma and disruption of separation, potentially leading to more stable family environments post-treatment. This stability can indirectly improve the family's economic well-being by allowing the parent to focus on recovery and eventual employment, rather than dealing with the complexities and costs associated with child removal and separate care.

Title: Calvert County - Ethics - Conflict of Interest and Commissioner Expulsion
Synopsis: Requiring that the conflict of interest provisions enacted by Calvert County include certain provisions relating to judicial relief for certain violations of the county's conflict of interest provisions; requiring the ethics provisions enacted by Calvert County to include a provision requiring the Calvert County Ethics Commission to make public any recommendation it makes to expel a Commissioner; and requiring Calvert County to enact a law or regulation that authorizes the removal of a county elected official for certain violations.
bill_summary: This bill requires Calvert County to strengthen its ethics provisions. Specifically, it mandates that the county's conflict of interest laws include provisions for judicial relief for violations, requires the Calvert County Ethics Commission to make public any recommendation to expel a Commissioner, and compels the county to enact a law authorizing the removal of elected officials from office for conflict of interest violations.
responsible_party: Calvert County; Calvert County Ethics Commission; governing body of Calvert County
stakeholders: Local officials, county officers, employees, and elected officials in Calvert County, as well as the general public who benefit from increased government transparency and accountability.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances existing ethics regulations and enforcement within Calvert County by mandating stricter conflict of interest provisions, public disclosure of expulsion recommendations, and explicit authority for removing elected officials. While these are improvements to governance, they do not involve new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather strengthen established practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on government ethics, conflict of interest, and official accountability within Calvert County. It does not contain any provisions, programs, or funding directly aimed at addressing child poverty.

Title: Calvert County - Procurement - Local Preference
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Calvert County to enact an ordinance that establishes a local percentage preference for certain procurement contracts; and requiring the County Commissioners to comply with certain provisions of law under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Calvert County to enact an ordinance that establishes a local percentage preference for procurement contracts. This means that a qualifying resident business in Calvert County may be awarded a contract even if its bid is slightly higher than a nonresident business's lowest responsive bid, provided it does not exceed a specified percentage. The County Commissioners must comply with certain provisions of law when enacting such an ordinance.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Calvert County
stakeholders: Businesses, both resident and nonresident, that bid on procurement contracts with Calvert County. Indirectly, the residents of Calvert County through the county's economic development and contracting practices.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a local preference for procurement contracts, which is a common policy tool used by local governments to support local businesses. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on procurement preferences for businesses, aiming to support local economic activity. While local economic growth could indirectly benefit families and potentially reduce poverty, it does not provide direct services, financial aid, or programs specifically targeted at children or families experiencing poverty. The impact on child poverty is therefore very indirect and not a primary focus.

Title: Prince George's County Family Child Care Home Expansion Grant Program - Establishment PG 505-24
Synopsis: Establishing the Prince George's County Family Child Care Home Expansion Grant Program in the Prince George's County public school system; providing that the purpose of the Program is to increase the number of registered family child care providers, registered family child care homes, and registered large family child care homes in low-income communities in the county; requiring a local school system to develop a certain application process; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Prince George’s County Family Child Care Home Expansion Grant Program within the Prince George’s County public school system. The program's goal is to increase the number of registered family child care providers and homes in low-income communities within the county. It achieves this by awarding grants to nonprofit organizations that will provide training, technical assistance, and financial support to individuals who want to become family child care providers. These individuals must live in low-income communities, have a household income not exceeding 50% of the statewide median, and own or rent the dwelling to be used as a child care home. The Governor is required to appropriate $500,000 annually to the program starting in fiscal year 2026.
responsible_party: Prince George’s County Public School System
stakeholders: Individuals in low-income communities in Prince George’s County interested in becoming family child care providers, existing registered family child care providers, nonprofit organizations providing child care support services, and families in low-income communities needing child care.
innovative_summary: The program addresses a critical need for child care by expanding capacity in specific communities through grants to local nonprofits. While it doesn't employ novel technologies, its targeted approach to support individuals with low incomes to establish child care services in their own communities represents a practical and community-focused solution to a persistent social issue.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty by increasing access to child care in low-income communities and for families whose income is below 50% of the statewide median. By supporting the establishment of more affordable and accessible child care options, it can enable parents to work or pursue education, thereby improving household income. Additionally, it creates opportunities for low-income individuals to become child care providers, offering a pathway to increased personal income.

Title: Carroll County - Contracts and Purchasing
Synopsis: Increasing from $25,000 to $50,000 the cost of a public work or improvement or the purchase price of supplies or equipment for which the County Commissioners of Carroll County may enter into a contract; and requiring that when the cost of a public work or improvement or the purchase price of supplies or equipment in Carroll County exceeds $50,000 under certain conditions, the Procurement Officer for the County Commissioner shall advertise for bids for at least 1 week in a media accessible to the general public.
bill_summary: This bill increases the threshold for Carroll County Commissioners to enter into contracts for public works, improvements, supplies, or equipment without formal bidding from $25,000 to $50,000. For contracts exceeding $50,000, the bill requires the Procurement Officer to advertise for bids for at least one week in public media, including an internet website. It also clarifies that the Procurement Officer (formerly Chief of the Bureau of Purchasing) can participate in cooperative or piggyback purchasing with other governmental agencies.
responsible_party: Carroll County Commissioners; Procurement Officer for the County Commissioner
stakeholders: Carroll County government departments, businesses seeking county contracts in Carroll County, and the general public of Carroll County.
innovative_summary: The bill formalizes the use of an internet website for advertising bids, which is a standard practice rather than an innovative approach. It also permits cooperative purchasing, which is an efficient procurement method but not new.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily concerns local government procurement rules and thresholds. While efficient government operations can indirectly benefit the community, there are no direct provisions or specific programs within this bill aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Annual Vehicle Shows - Motor and Trailer Homes
Synopsis: Altering the number of annual vehicle shows in which motor and trailer home dealers, and salesmen employed by dealers, may participate.
bill_summary: This bill alters the number of annual vehicle shows in which certain dealers can participate. It changes the allowance for new vehicle dealers franchised to sell Class M motor homes or Class G trailers from participating in more than 3 annual vehicle shows to participating in more than 2 annual vehicle shows. It also combines this provision with motorcycle dealers, allowing all three types of dealers (motorcycles, Class M motor homes, or Class G trailers) to participate in more than 2 annual vehicle shows.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation (Motor Vehicle Administration)
stakeholders: New vehicle dealers franchised to sell motorcycles, Class M motor homes, or Class G trailers, and their licensed salesmen.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory change to vehicle laws and does not introduce any new technologies or innovative governmental approaches. It adjusts the permissible number of annual vehicle shows for certain dealers.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill makes a minor regulatory adjustment to the number of vehicle shows certain dealers can attend. This change has no direct impact on child poverty or programs designed to alleviate it.

Title: Income Tax - Individual Income Tax Credit Eligibility Awareness Campaign
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller to implement and administer a certain individual income tax credit eligibility awareness campaign to identify and encourage individuals to apply for certain individual income tax credits; authorizing the Comptroller to enter into a certain data sharing agreement with other State agencies to carry out the awareness campaign; and requiring, in each of fiscal years 2026 through 2030, the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $300,000 for the awareness campaign.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Comptroller to implement and administer an individual income tax credit eligibility awareness campaign. The campaign aims to identify underserved individuals who are eligible for state income tax credits but have not claimed them, and then encourage them to apply. It authorizes the Comptroller to enter into data sharing agreements with other State agencies to assist in identifying these individuals and mandates an annual appropriation of $300,000 for the campaign from fiscal year 2026 through fiscal year 2030.
responsible_party: The Comptroller
stakeholders: Underserved individuals who are eligible for state individual income tax credits but have not claimed them.
innovative_summary: The program is innovative in its use of data sharing agreements between the Comptroller and other State agencies to proactively identify underserved individuals who may be eligible for tax credits but have not claimed them. This targeted outreach approach, leveraging inter-agency data, represents a new approach to ensuring eligible citizens receive their rightful benefits.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty. By identifying and encouraging underserved individuals to claim eligible individual income tax credits, many of which (such as the Earned Income Tax Credit or child tax credits) directly provide financial relief to low-income families with children, it can put money directly into the hands of these families, thereby alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Investment Portfolio and Local Government Investment Guidelines - Investment Standards
Synopsis: Requiring the Treasurer to consult with governmental entities prior to proposing certain regulations; repealing the limitations on investment in certain assets in which the Treasurer may invest or reinvest certain unexpended or surplus funds; authorizing the Treasurer to retain investments made prior to the effective date of the Act until the investments have reached their respective maturity dates; authorizing the Treasurer and governmental entities to invest or reinvest in certain surplus funds under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill updates the State's investment portfolio and local government investment guidelines. It repeals previous limitations on the types of assets the State Treasurer may invest in, requiring the Treasurer to adopt new regulations specifying authorized asset classes. The Treasurer must consult with governmental entities before proposing regulations that alter investment types and must notify local governmental entities about updates to investment standards. It also allows the Treasurer and governmental entities to retain existing investments until maturity and to continue using prior investment authorizations until new regulations are adopted.
responsible_party: State Treasurer
stakeholders: Maryland State government, local governmental entities (including county boards of education and library trustees), and minority business enterprises providing brokerage and investment management services.
innovative_summary: The bill updates existing financial regulations by removing previous limitations on investment types and requiring the State Treasurer to adopt new, potentially broader, investment policies and asset classes. While it modernizes investment standards, it primarily involves regulatory adjustments rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the investment policies for state and local government funds. While sound financial management can indirectly benefit public services, there is no direct mechanism or specific program within this bill designed to address or impact child poverty.

Title: State Procurement - Small Business Preference Procurement
Synopsis: Requiring each procurement unit to establish a price preference for small businesses; and designating the Board of Public Works as the regulatory authority for the Small Business Preference Program.
bill_summary: This bill requires each procurement unit within the Executive Branch of Maryland State Government to establish a price preference for small businesses. It designates the Board of Public Works as the central regulatory authority for the Small Business Preference Program, consolidating oversight that was previously spread across multiple departments. The bill also clarifies how units can meet their small business procurement objectives, allowing them to apply contracts awarded through both the Small Business Preference Program and the Small Business Reserve Program, or any contract awarded to a small business, toward these objectives. The price preference includes additional percentages for veteran-owned and disabled veteran-owned small businesses.
responsible_party: Board of Public Works and all units and agencies of the Executive Branch of State Government
stakeholders: Small businesses, especially veteran-owned and disabled veteran-owned small businesses, seeking government contracts; and all units and agencies of the Executive Branch of State Government involved in procurement.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily centralizes regulatory authority and streamlines processes for an existing small business procurement program. While it improves efficiency and clarity, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services or procurement methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By enhancing opportunities for small businesses to secure government contracts, it may foster economic growth, job creation, and potentially higher wages, which could in turn indirectly benefit families and children. However, it does not provide direct financial assistance or specific services aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Shellfish Aquaculture - Harvest Hours
Synopsis: Repealing a restriction which prohibited the harvesting of shellfish between the hours of sunset and sunrise from certain areas leased for aquaculture; and requiring the Department of Natural Resources to establish by regulation the hours for harvesting shellfish within leased areas.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the previous restriction on shellfish aquaculture leaseholders from harvesting between sunset and sunrise. Instead, it requires the Department of Natural Resources (DNR), in consultation with the Aquaculture Coordinating Council, to establish by regulation the specific hours for harvesting shellfish within leased areas.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR)
stakeholders: Shellfish aquaculture leaseholders and anyone involved in the shellfish harvesting industry in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory adjustment, shifting the authority for setting shellfish harvesting hours from a statutory fixed rule to departmental regulation. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes a regulatory change regarding shellfish harvesting hours for aquaculture. While it could potentially affect the operational flexibility and income of shellfish leaseholders, any direct impact on child poverty is highly indirect and minimal, as it does not provide direct aid, services, or economic opportunities specifically targeted at families experiencing poverty.

Title: Housing and Community Development - Community Action Boards
Synopsis: Requiring certain community action boards to meet certain federal requirements for tripartite boards; and repealing certain requirements relating to the composition of community action boards.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland law regarding Community Action Boards, eliminating state-specific requirements for their composition. Instead, it mandates that these boards must comply with the federal requirements for a tripartite board as outlined in 42 U.S.C. § 9910, which typically ensures representation from elected officials, the private sector, and low-income community members. The purpose is to align state law with federal standards for community action agencies.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Community action agencies, their board members (including elected public officials, representatives of low-income persons, and other community groups), and the low-income individuals and families served by these agencies.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative; it is a regulatory update designed to align state law with existing federal requirements for the composition of community action boards. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The potential for direct impact on child poverty is low. While community action agencies often serve low-income populations that include children, this bill primarily focuses on the administrative governance of these agencies by updating board composition requirements. It does not establish new programs, allocate funding, or create specific interventions directly targeting child poverty.

Title: Energy Efficiency and Conservation Plans
Synopsis: Requiring each electric company, each gas company, and the Department of Housing and Community Development to develop a plan for achieving certain energy efficiency, conservation, and greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets through certain programs and services and superseding certain existing energy efficiency and conservation goals; requiring the Public Service Commission to establish a working group to study and make recommendations on extending certain program assistance to certain moderate-income households; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires electric companies, gas companies, and the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) to develop and implement plans for achieving specific energy efficiency, conservation, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction targets. It supersedes existing goals and requires the Public Service Commission (PSC) to establish and oversee these targets, ensuring full cost recovery and financial incentives/penalties for utilities. The DHCD is specifically tasked with providing energy efficiency and conservation programs for low-income households, coordinating and leveraging various funding sources for comprehensive home upgrades, and developing a plan to provide energy efficiency retrofits to all low-income households by 2032. The bill also includes job requirements for contractors involved in DHCD programs, such as minimum wage, paid leave, and health benefits. Additionally, it mandates studies on energy efficiency services for minority and women-owned businesses and a working group to study assistance for moderate-income households.
responsible_party: Public Service Commission; electric companies; gas companies; Department of Housing and Community Development; Department of the Environment; Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs; certification agency designated by the Board of Public Works.
stakeholders: Electric and gas utility customers (residential, commercial, industrial), low-income households, moderate-income households, tenants, building owners and managers, electric companies, gas companies, municipal electric or gas utilities, small rural electric cooperatives, midsize electric cooperatives, contractors in the energy efficiency and conservation services industry, and minority and women-owned businesses.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a comprehensive, statewide, and target-driven approach to energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions reduction. It is innovative in its explicit coordination and leveraging of multiple funding sources (federal, state, and ratepayer contributions) for a 'whole home approach' to upgrades for low-income housing. It also includes specific job quality requirements for contractors in DHCD programs (e.g., minimum wage, paid leave, health benefits, collective bargaining rights), which is a novel approach to ensuring social equity alongside environmental goals.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly impact child poverty by significantly focusing on low-income households. It explicitly aims to reduce utility expenses for low-income residents through energy efficiency, conservation, and beneficial electrification measures. The bill mandates the DHCD to coordinate extensive funding to support 'whole home' upgrades for low-income housing, including health and safety improvements, weatherization, and general maintenance. It also includes provisions to ensure that the benefits of weatherization accrue primarily to low-income tenants, preventing rent increases or evictions. These measures directly address housing stability and affordability, key factors in combating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program and Health Insurance - Coverage for Prostheses (So Every Body Can Move Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and certain insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations to provide certain coverage related to prostheses; establishing that certain insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations must comply with certain provider network requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the "So Every Body Can Move Act," requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and private health insurers (insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations) to provide comprehensive coverage for orthoses and prostheses. This includes coverage for the devices, components, repairs, and replacements, under specific conditions related to a patient's physiological changes or irreparable damage to the device. The bill sets regulations for coverage, including prohibiting separate financial requirements, higher copayments/coinsurance than for primary care, and annual or lifetime dollar maximums. It also establishes that medical necessity requirements cannot be more restrictive than Medicare's, and must consider the devices necessary for activities of daily living, essential job-related activities, and physical activities (like running, biking, swimming) to maximize whole-body health and limb function. Furthermore, it mandates non-discriminatory utilization review determinations and requires insurers to ensure access to at least two distinct in-network providers for these services and provide out-of-network reimbursement if in-network options are unavailable.
responsible_party: Maryland Medical Assistance Program (administered by the Secretary of Health), Maryland Insurance Administration, Maryland Department of Health, Maryland Health Care Commission, private insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations.
stakeholders: Individuals in Maryland who require orthoses or prostheses, including those with neuromuscular or musculoskeletal disorders, or limb loss/absence, who are covered by the Maryland Medical Assistance Program or private health insurance policies.
innovative_summary: The bill's approach to innovation lies in its expansive definition of "medical necessity" for orthoses and prostheses, specifically including their use for physical activities such as running, biking, and swimming, to maximize whole-body health and function. This broadens the scope of covered activities beyond basic mobility, aiming for a more holistic view of patient well-being. However, the mechanism of expanding insurance mandates is a traditional governmental approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a high potential for indirect impact on child poverty by mandating comprehensive coverage for orthoses and prostheses for children under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and private insurance. By significantly reducing or eliminating the out-of-pocket costs for these essential medical devices, the bill alleviates a substantial financial burden on families, particularly low-income families. This financial relief can prevent families from incurring medical debt, free up household income for other necessities, and enable children with disabilities to access critical devices that improve their health, mobility, participation in education, and overall quality of life, which can lead to better long-term outcomes and break cycles of poverty.

Title: Business Regulation - Detached Catalytic Converters - Record-Keeping Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring records of junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and automotive dismantlers and recyclers to include certain information about the vehicle from which a detached catalytic converter, or part of a detached catalytic converter, was obtained from a person.
bill_summary: This bill requires junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and automotive dismantlers and recyclers to maintain more detailed records when acquiring detached catalytic converters. Specifically, they must include the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) of the vehicle from which the converter was obtained. This aims to combat catalytic converter theft by making it more difficult to sell stolen parts.
responsible_party: Junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and automotive dismantlers and recyclers are responsible for implementing the record-keeping requirements. Oversight for automotive dismantlers and recyclers falls under the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA).
stakeholders: Junk dealers, scrap metal processors, and automotive dismantlers and recyclers, as they must comply with the new record-keeping requirements. Indirectly, vehicle owners and the general public may benefit from a reduction in catalytic converter theft.
innovative_summary: This bill strengthens existing record-keeping requirements to address the issue of catalytic converter theft. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government, but rather enhances an established regulatory framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to deter catalytic converter theft, which can be a financial burden for vehicle owners, including those with lower incomes. While reducing crime can indirectly benefit communities and alleviate financial stress, this bill does not directly provide services or resources to address child poverty.

Title: Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program – Alterations
Synopsis: Expanding eligibility for financial assistance under the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program to include individuals who purchase certain qualified property after a qualified project is completed, at an affordable sales price as determined by certain regulations, and as an owner-occupant.
bill_summary: This bill expands eligibility for the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program. Previously, financial assistance was available to affordable housing developers. Now, it also includes individuals who purchase a qualified property as an owner-occupant, provided the property is purchased at an affordable sales price after a qualified project is completed.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Affordable housing developers, individuals purchasing newly constructed or substantially rehabilitated residential real property as owner-occupants in low-income census tracts and sustainable communities that were historically redlined.
innovative_summary: This bill itself primarily expands eligibility for an existing program, rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches. The underlying program addresses appraisal gaps in historically redlined neighborhoods, which is an innovative approach to rectify historical housing injustices, but this specific bill focuses on broadening access.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to make homeownership more accessible and affordable in historically disadvantaged areas by closing appraisal gaps. By enabling more families to purchase stable, affordable homes, it can directly contribute to housing stability and wealth building for families, which are key factors in reducing child poverty.

Title: State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators - Requirements for Assisted Living Managers
Synopsis: Extending, from October 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026, the date by which an individual must be licensed by the State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators before practicing as an assisted living manager in the State; altering the requirements for the manager training course that certain assisted living managers are required to complete; altering the requirements for serving as an interim assisted living manager; and requiring the Board to submit certain reports on assisted living managers to certain committees of the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the requirements and deadlines for assisted living managers to be licensed by the State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators. It extends the date by which managers must be licensed to July 1, 2026, alters the manager training course requirements to allow for virtual training methods, and revises the rules for serving as an interim assisted living manager. The bill also changes the staggered terms for assisted living manager members on the Board and establishes reporting requirements for the Board regarding the implementation of these licensure requirements.
responsible_party: State Board of Long–Term Care Administrators
stakeholders: Assisted living managers, assisted living programs, individuals seeking to become assisted living managers, and the State Board of Long–Term Care Administrators.
innovative_summary: The bill incorporates virtual training methods into the approved manager training courses, modernizing how assisted living managers can meet their educational requirements. This provides increased flexibility and accessibility for participants.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill regulates the licensing and training of assisted living managers. While it aims to improve the quality of care in assisted living facilities, which can indirectly benefit families, it does not directly address or implement programs to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Board of Public Works - Transparency Data Dashboard
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller to develop and maintain on the Board of Public Works' website a procurement transparency data dashboard; establishing a governance committee composed of the liaisons to the Board from the offices of the Governor, the Comptroller, and the State Treasurer to review the contents of the dashboard for accuracy and completeness; and requiring the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2025, to include in the annual budget bill such sums as are necessary for one full-time position and data dashboard development software.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Comptroller to develop and maintain a public, interactive, and searchable procurement transparency data dashboard on the Board of Public Works' website. The dashboard will include information on Board of Public Works meetings, agendas, contract spending, and details on State procurement preference programs (Minority Business Enterprise and Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise goals). It will also be compatible with the Comptroller's online payment processing portal to integrate vendor payment data. A governance committee, composed of liaisons from the Governor's, Comptroller's, and State Treasurer's offices, will review the dashboard's content. Starting in Fiscal Year 2025, the Governor will include appropriations in the annual budget for at least one full-time position in the Comptroller's office and necessary software to develop and maintain the dashboard.
responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: The general public, state agencies, businesses (especially minority and veteran-owned businesses) involved in state procurement, and vendors who do business with the State of Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a new public-facing, interactive, and searchable online dashboard for state procurement data. It integrates diverse information such as Board of Public Works agendas, contract spending, details on procurement preference programs, and vendor payment data, enhancing government transparency through modern web-based tools.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on government procurement transparency and does not establish any direct programs or provide resources specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be highly indirect and not a primary objective of the program.

Title: Business Regulation - Sale of Motor Fuel - Pricing Signage (Gas Price Clarity Act)
Synopsis: Establishing that certain provisions governing signage at retail service stations supersede inconsistent local law; altering a signage requirement for retail service stations relating to the price of regular gasoline so that the signage prominently displays clearly and visibly the credit and debit price, if higher than the cash price, or the credit and debit price and the cash price; repealing an exemption from a certain signage requirement for retail service station dealers with not more than 3 dispensing units; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Gas Price Clarity Act, updates state regulations for motor fuel pricing signs at retail service stations. It mandates clearer and more prominent display of credit, debit, and cash prices for regular gasoline, and allows for similar display for diesel and other fuels. It also establishes state law preeminence over local signage laws, removes an exemption for smaller stations, and requires gasoline suppliers to cover the cost of new signs needed for compliance.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller
stakeholders: Retail service station dealers, gasoline suppliers, and consumers (motorists).
innovative_summary: This bill primarily updates existing regulations on signage to ensure clearer pricing information for consumers. It does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking government approaches, and is a standard regulatory update.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to provide clearer pricing information for motor fuel, which might enable consumers to make more informed purchasing decisions and potentially save a very small amount of money. However, this is an indirect and negligible impact on household finances and does not directly address the root causes or symptoms of child poverty.

Title: Maryland Department of Health - Health Commissions and Maryland Insurance Administration - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to contract with an independent consultant to conduct a certain study of the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the Maryland Health Care Commission, the Maryland Insurance Administration, and the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission; and requiring the Department to submit a report on the results of the study to the Governor, the Senate Finance Committee, and the House Health and Government Operations Committee on or before January 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to contract with an independent consultant to conduct a study of several key state health entities: the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the Maryland Health Care Commission, the Maryland Insurance Administration, and the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission. The study will examine overlaps in duties, identify opportunities for streamlining and efficiency, suggest better alignment with modern healthcare models (like the Maryland Total Cost of Care and AHEAD models), and recommend administrative structural changes. A report on the study's findings is due to the Governor and legislative committees by January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: The Health Services Cost Review Commission, the Maryland Health Care Commission, the Maryland Insurance Administration, the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, and indirectly, the overall healthcare system and residents of Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates a study to analyze and potentially streamline existing state health commissions and the Maryland Insurance Administration. While it seeks to improve efficiency and alignment with current healthcare models, it primarily involves an internal organizational review and doesn't introduce new technologies or novel approaches to public services. Its innovation lies in seeking to optimize established structures rather than creating new ones.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the administrative efficiency and structure of state health commissions and the Maryland Insurance Administration. It does not establish any direct programs, services, or funding mechanisms specifically aimed at addressing child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be highly indirect, possibly through more efficient healthcare systems that could benefit low-income families generally, but this is not the bill's primary or direct intent.

Title: Corporations and Associations - Ratification of Defective Corporate Acts - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the process by which a defective corporate act may be ratified; and altering rules for certain legal actions by persons claiming to be adversely affected by a ratification.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the process by which defective corporate acts in Maryland can be ratified. It alters definitions related to defective corporate acts, putative stock, and failures of authorization. The bill outlines new procedures for boards of directors and stockholders to ratify these acts, specifies the quorum and voting requirements, and details the conditions under which notice must be given to stockholders and putative stock holders. It also clarifies the requirements for filing "articles of validation" with the Department when a defective corporate act would have required a charter document filing. Additionally, it revises the rules and timeline for legal challenges by persons adversely affected by such a ratification.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation (for filings); Maryland courts (for disputes)
stakeholders: Maryland corporations and associations, their boards of directors, stockholders, and putative stockholders, as well as any individuals or entities claiming to be adversely affected by corporate actions.
innovative_summary: This bill makes technical legal changes to corporate governance procedures. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government services, operations, or policy implementation. It is an amendment to existing corporate law.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses exclusively on technical aspects of corporate law, specifically the ratification of defective corporate acts. It has no direct mechanisms, provisions, or intent to impact child poverty, nor are there any foreseeable direct effects on families or children's economic well-being.

Title: Maryland Tort Claims Act - Sheriffs and Deputy Sheriffs - County Responsibility
Synopsis: Clarifying that a county assumes the responsibilities of a certain tort claim against a sheriff or deputy sheriff under the Maryland Tort Claims Act; clarifying that, for certain tort claims against a sheriff or deputy sheriff, the State is the proper defendant; and specifying that it is the intent of the General Assembly that the Office of the Attorney General and the State Treasurer work with certain entities when disputes arise regarding the allocation of responsibility for tort claims under the Act.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies the financial responsibility for tort claims filed against sheriffs and deputy sheriffs under the Maryland Tort Claims Act. It specifies that counties are responsible for certain tort claims related to law enforcement functions and detention center functions, while the State is identified as the proper defendant in such claims. The bill also states the General Assembly's intent for the Office of the Attorney General and the State Treasurer to collaborate with counties and their insurers to resolve disputes regarding claim responsibility.
responsible_party: Counties, Office of the Attorney General, and the State Treasurer
stakeholders: Sheriffs, deputy sheriffs, county governments (including Baltimore City), the State of Maryland, and individuals who may file tort claims against sheriffs or deputy sheriffs.
innovative_summary: This bill clarifies legal responsibilities and financial allocations within an existing legal framework (Maryland Tort Claims Act). It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations or services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses governmental liability and legal processes for tort claims involving law enforcement personnel. It does not establish programs or policies with a direct impact on child poverty or provide economic support to families.

Title: Higher Education - Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship to make the scholarship applicable to all programs at institutions of higher education in the State; altering the maximum award available, when a scholarship should be credited, and to whom initial awards should be provided under the scholarship; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the existing Charles W. Riley Firefighter and Ambulance and Rescue Squad Member Scholarship. It expands the scholarship's applicability to all courses at institutions of higher education in Maryland, removes the limitation to specific fire or EMS-related degrees, and now includes graduate study. It also modifies the maximum award amounts, specifies that other student financial aid (excluding loans) must be credited before the scholarship, mandates that initial awards be granted on a first-come, first-served basis, and prioritizes students in fire or EMS-related majors for the first $400,000 in scholarships distributed each fiscal year.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) - Office
stakeholders: Maryland residents actively engaged as career or volunteer firefighters, ambulance, or rescue squad members who are pursuing higher education in the State.
innovative_summary: The bill makes administrative and eligibility adjustments to an existing scholarship program. It does not introduce new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services or program delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides scholarships for higher education to firefighters and EMS personnel, which could indirectly lead to improved economic stability for these individuals and their families. However, it is not directly targeted at or designed to address child poverty, nor does it offer direct financial assistance or services to children or families living in poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Part-Time Senatorial and Delegate Scholarships - Alterations
Synopsis: Allowing an applicant of a part-time senatorial or delegate scholarship with a documented disability to request from the Maryland Higher Education Commission a waiver from the requirement to carry at least 6 semester hours of courses each semester.
bill_summary: This bill allows applicants for part-time senatorial or delegate scholarships who have a documented disability to request a waiver from the Maryland Higher Education Commission regarding the requirement to carry a certain number of semester hours each semester. This alteration provides greater flexibility for students with disabilities to maintain their scholarships.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Part-time college students with documented disabilities who are applicants for or recipients of senatorial or delegate scholarships in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces an administrative waiver process to accommodate part-time scholarship recipients with disabilities, making existing scholarship programs more flexible and accessible. While this is a positive step towards equity, it represents an adjustment to existing rules rather than a fundamentally new technology or approach to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on providing administrative flexibility for adult college students with disabilities regarding their scholarship requirements. While enhancing access to higher education can indirectly improve future earning potential and thus reduce the likelihood of future poverty for these individuals and their families, it does not directly impact child poverty through specific programs or financial aid aimed at children or families with children currently experiencing poverty.

Title: Prekindergarten - Ulysses Currie Head Start Program - Eligibility for State Funds
Synopsis: Authorizing a provider in the Ulysses Currie Head Start Program to receive certain State funds under certain circumstances; and exempting providers in the Program from certain State requirements for eligible prekindergarten providers.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the eligibility criteria for providers in the Ulysses Currie Head Start Program to receive full State funds, allowing them to do so even if they receive federal funds. It also exempts these providers from certain State prekindergarten quality requirements if those requirements conflict with federal Head Start Program requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Prekindergarten providers in the Ulysses Currie Head Start Program, children enrolled in these programs, and their families, particularly those from low-income backgrounds.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts administrative and funding eligibility rules for an existing program. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill enhances the ability of Ulysses Currie Head Start Program providers to receive state funding and reduces potential conflicts with federal requirements, thereby strengthening a program specifically designed to support low-income children and families with comprehensive early childhood services. This has a high indirect impact on child poverty by improving access to quality early education and support services.

Title: Education - Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program and Fund - Established
Synopsis: Requiring certain information to be provided to the parents of a child with a disability under certain circumstances; establishing the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program; establishing the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Fund; requiring interest earnings of the Fund to be credited to the Fund; requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $1,000,000 to the Fund beginning in fiscal year 2026; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Access to Attorneys, Advocates, and Consultants for Special Education Program and Fund in Maryland. Its purpose is to provide legal, advocacy, and consultation services to eligible students with disabilities from low-income households. The bill requires public agencies to provide information about this program to parents of children with disabilities under certain circumstances, and to collect and report data related to individualized education programs, mediation, and due process proceedings. The program aims to help eligible families navigate the special education system and resolve disagreements with public agencies regarding their child's educational services.
responsible_party: Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service and the Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Parents of children with disabilities, particularly those from low-income households (not exceeding 150% of Maryland Legal Services Corporation income guidelines); students with disabilities; attorneys, advocates, and consultants providing special education services.
innovative_summary: This program offers an innovative approach to ensuring educational equity and access to justice for low-income families of students with disabilities. By establishing a state-funded program and fund to cover the costs of legal, advocacy, and consultancy services, it directly addresses financial barriers that often prevent families from challenging inadequate special education services. The partnership with the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service for program administration and referral, coupled with explicit income criteria, represents a structured governmental approach to leverage external expertise for public benefit in a critical area.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a direct and high potential to impact child poverty by specifically targeting 'eligible students' whose parents have household incomes not exceeding 150% of the Maryland Legal Services Corporation income guidelines. By funding legal, advocacy, and consultation services, it removes a significant financial barrier for low-income families seeking appropriate special education for their children with disabilities. Better educational outcomes for children with disabilities can improve their long-term economic prospects, reduce financial strain on families due to unmet needs, and allow parents to focus on employment rather than navigating complex legal systems without support, thereby directly mitigating factors contributing to child poverty.

Title: Garrett County – Sheriff’s Salary – Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the salary of the Sheriff of Garrett County; and repealing the requirement for the Garrett County Salary Study Commission to study and issue a report that contains recommendations relating to the salary of the Sheriff.
bill_summary: This bill alters the annual salary of the Sheriff of Garrett County, setting it at 80% of the salary of the State's Attorney of Garrett County. It also repeals the requirement for the Garrett County Salary Study Commission to study and issue recommendations regarding the Sheriff's salary. The changes to the Sheriff's salary will take effect at the beginning of the next term of office after October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Garrett County Commissioners, Sheriff of Garrett County
stakeholders: The Sheriff of Garrett County, the Garrett County Salary Study Commission, and indirectly the State's Attorney of Garrett County.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It makes administrative changes to the method of calculating a public official's salary and modifies the responsibilities of a local government commission, without introducing new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It focuses solely on the salary of the Garrett County Sheriff and the administrative duties of a local salary study commission.

Title: Garrett County - Procurement - Bids and Contracts
Synopsis: Increasing the minimum dollar amount of contracts for which the County Commissioners, or any employee of Garrett County, are required to advertise for bids from $25,000 to $50,000; exempting certain contracts for professional services from a requirement to advertise for bids; and authorizing contracts for professional services required to be licensed by the State to be solicited by written bids.
bill_summary: This bill increases the minimum dollar amount for contracts in Garrett County that require advertising for bids from $25,000 to $50,000. It also exempts certain contracts for professional services from the requirement to advertise for bids and allows them to be solicited by written bids. The purpose is to generally relate to procurement in Garrett County.
responsible_party: Garrett County Commissioners, or any employee of Garrett County
stakeholders: Businesses seeking contracts with Garrett County, and residents of Garrett County through changes in public procurement processes.
innovative_summary: This bill makes standard amendments to local procurement thresholds and procedures. It does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on changes to procurement thresholds and procedures for Garrett County contracts. It does not directly provide services, financial aid, or programs aimed at addressing child poverty.

Title: Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program - Modifications
Synopsis: Altering procedures for the claiming and awarding of grants under the Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program to allow an individual or corporation who paid or incurred qualified capital expenses during the immediately preceding calendar year to submit a grant application.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Winery and Vineyard Economic Development Grant Program in Maryland. Specifically, it alters the procedures for individuals and corporations to apply for grants, changing the application submission timeframe to specify that applications are for qualified capital expenses incurred during the immediately preceding calendar year. It also removes the specific September 15 application deadline and December 15 award deadline, instead stating that the Department shall award grants to eligible applicants and clarifying the process for pro-rata grant distribution if applications exceed available funding.
responsible_party: the Department (likely the Maryland Department of Economic Development)
stakeholders: Individuals and corporations involved in the winery and vineyard industry in Maryland who incur qualified capital expenses.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative; it makes procedural changes to an existing grant program for wineries and vineyards, without introducing new technologies or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill modifies a grant program for wineries and vineyards, which is aimed at economic development within that industry. It does not directly target or address child poverty, and any potential impact would be very indirect through general economic activity and job creation.

Title: State Treasurer and Comptroller - Membership Responsibilities
Synopsis: Removing the State Treasurer from the Board of Trustees for the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation and repealing related authority and duties; removing the State Treasurer or the State Treasurer's designee from the Maryland Commission on Climate Change and the Coast Smart Council; and adding the Comptroller or the Comptroller's designee as a member of the Maryland Commission on Climate Change and the Coast Smart Council.
bill_summary: This bill revises the membership responsibilities of the State Treasurer and the Comptroller. It removes the State Treasurer from the Board of Trustees for the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation, the Maryland Commission on Climate Change, and the Coast Smart Council. It adds the Comptroller or their designee as a member of the Maryland Commission on Climate Change and the Coast Smart Council. The bill also repeals certain related authority and duties of the State Treasurer.
responsible_party: State Treasurer, Comptroller, Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation, Maryland Commission on Climate Change, Coast Smart Council
stakeholders: The State Treasurer, the Comptroller, and the various state boards and councils affected by the membership changes (Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Foundation, Maryland Commission on Climate Change, Coast Smart Council), and indirectly, the public served by these entities.
innovative_summary: This bill solely focuses on administrative restructuring of membership on existing state boards and councils. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government operations or public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's purpose is to modify the membership of several state boards and councils, shifting responsibilities between the State Treasurer and the Comptroller. These are administrative governance changes that do not establish direct programs, funding, or interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Washington County - Alcoholic Beverages - Multi-Use Sports and Events Facility Beer, Wine, and Liquor License
Synopsis: Altering the stadium beer and wine license in Washington County to be a multi-use sports and events facility beer, wine, and liquor license; authorizing the license holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption in the multi-use sports and events facility; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the alcoholic beverages license in Washington County, changing the 'stadium beer and wine license' to a 'multi-use sports and events facility beer, wine, and liquor license'. It expands the types of alcohol that can be sold to include liquor, defines the licensed premises as the entire facility, and increases the annual license fee from $2,000 to $2,500. It also removes the separate Sunday permit fee and mandates that all employees of the license holder complete alcohol awareness training and obtain a crowd control training certificate.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Owners of professional baseball team franchises operating multi-use sports and events facilities in Washington County, their employees, and patrons of such facilities.
innovative_summary: The bill makes administrative changes to an existing alcoholic beverage license, expanding its scope and adding standard training requirements for employees. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a negligible direct impact on child poverty. It focuses on changes to alcoholic beverage licensing for a sports facility, which does not provide direct support, services, or economic opportunities specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Building Performance Standards – Local Requests for Guidance – Religious Considerations
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Labor, on request of a local jurisdiction and in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General, to provide guidance for the implementation and enforcement of the Maryland Building Performance Standards in relation to any religious observance, practice, or belief.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor, upon request from a local jurisdiction and in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General, to provide guidance for the implementation and enforcement of the Maryland Building Performance Standards, specifically in relation to any religious observance, practice, or belief.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor (in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General)
stakeholders: Local jurisdictions, local building officials, and religious communities in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill clarifies how existing building standards should consider religious observances, practices, or beliefs, which is an adjustment to regulatory interpretation rather than an innovative new program or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill provides guidance on the application of building performance standards concerning religious considerations; it does not directly address or impact child poverty.

Title: Washington County - Procurement - Vehicles
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Washington County to enter into a certain contract for the purchase of one or more vehicles without advertising for bids if the amount involved in the contract does not exceed $100,000.
bill_summary: This bill amends Washington County's local laws to allow the County Commissioners or an employee of the county to purchase one or more vehicles without advertising for bids, provided the contract amount does not exceed $100,000. Previously, the general threshold for requiring bids was $50,000 for most contracts.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Washington County
stakeholders: Washington County government employees involved in procurement, vehicle suppliers, and indirectly, Washington County residents.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it merely adjusts a financial threshold within existing procurement procedures and does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty as it pertains to administrative procurement processes for vehicle purchases within Washington County, which does not directly address the causes or effects of child poverty.

Title: Agriculture – Nuisance Insects
Synopsis: Requiring, instead of authorizing, the Secretary of Agriculture to implement, under certain circumstances, a program to use Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis to control or eliminate nuisance insects in the State; and requiring, instead of authorizing, the Secretary to carry out a certain project to control or eliminate nuisance insects if the county or municipality in which the nuisance insects are located agrees to pay 50% of the costs associated with the project.
bill_summary: This bill mandates that the Secretary of Agriculture implement a program using Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis to control or eliminate nuisance insects in the State, subject to available funding. Previously, the Secretary was only authorized to do so. The bill also requires the Secretary to carry out nuisance insect control projects if the affected county or municipality agrees to pay 50% of the project costs, remitting these payments to the Nuisance Insects Fund. The program's implementation will occur on State-owned, local government, and private properties with consent, and includes measures like aerial/backpack spraying, field studies, optimal scheduling, and public notification.
responsible_party: Secretary of Agriculture
stakeholders: The general public, especially those living, working, or recreating in areas affected by nuisance insects like black flies; local governments (counties and municipalities); property owners; local press outlets; emergency responders; and local riverkeepers.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily changes the mandate of an existing program for nuisance insect control from optional to required, rather than introducing new technologies or novel approaches to government. The method of control (Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis) and notification procedures are already established.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill addresses nuisance insects that can impact recreation, employment, and tourism. While controlling nuisance insects could indirectly improve quality of life and potentially support local economies, its direct impact on alleviating child poverty is minimal and highly indirect. It does not provide direct financial assistance, services, or resources specifically targeted at low-income children or families.

Title: Health Insurance - Utilization Review - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering and establishing requirements and prohibitions related to health insurance utilization review; altering requirements related to internal grievance procedures and adverse decision procedures; altering certain reporting requirements on health insurance carriers relating to adverse decisions; and establishing requirements on health insurance carriers and health care providers relating to the provision of patient benefit information.
bill_summary: This bill revises health insurance utilization review processes in Maryland. It mandates health insurance carriers to establish online systems for electronic prior authorization requests and to provide real-time patient out-of-pocket cost information and medication alternatives, linked directly to e-prescribing and electronic health record systems. The bill also modifies requirements for internal grievance procedures, adverse decision reporting, and the criteria used for utilization review, aiming to improve transparency, efficiency, and timely access to health care services for insured individuals.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission and Maryland Insurance Administration (for oversight and monitoring); Health insurance carriers and private review agents (for implementation)
stakeholders: Insured individuals, patients, enrollees, health care providers (physicians, dentists, hospitals), health insurance carriers, private review agents, and pharmacy benefits managers in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates health insurance carriers to implement online, real-time electronic prior authorization and patient out-of-pocket cost information systems that integrate with e-prescribing and electronic health record systems. This represents a significant modernization of healthcare administrative processes, leveraging digital technology to enhance transparency and efficiency in obtaining necessary medical services and understanding costs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not a direct anti-poverty program, the bill's provisions for improving access to timely healthcare services, streamlining prior authorization processes, and providing real-time cost transparency can indirectly benefit families experiencing child poverty. By reducing administrative hurdles and unexpected healthcare costs, it can help prevent medical debt, ensure consistent access to necessary treatments, and alleviate financial burdens that disproportionately affect low-income households.
