Title: Behavioral Health Crisis Response Services - 9-8-8 Trust Fund Fees
Synopsis: Establishing a 9-8-8 fee to be paid by each subscriber to switched local exchange access service, commercial mobile radio service, or other 9-8-8-accessible service; establishing a prepaid wireless 9-8-8 fee to be paid on certain retail transactions; requiring the Comptroller to deposit the 9-8-8 fees and the prepaid wireless 9-8-8 fees in the 9-8-8 Trust Fund; and requiring the Comptroller to adopt procedures for auditing fee collection and remittance by telephone companies and commercial mobile radio service providers.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a 25-cent monthly fee on subscribers to certain telecommunications services (switched local exchange access, commercial mobile radio service, or other 9-8-8-accessible services) and a 25-cent fee on prepaid wireless retail transactions. These fees will be deposited into the 9-8-8 Trust Fund, which is dedicated to supporting the 9-8-8 national suicide prevention and mental health crisis hotline and developing statewide behavioral health crisis response services, including crisis call centers, mobile crisis teams, and stabilization centers. The Comptroller is responsible for adopting fee collection procedures and auditing, and subscribers enrolled in the Lifeline program are exempt from these new fees.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Comptroller
stakeholders: Subscribers to switched local exchange access service, commercial mobile radio service, or other 9-8-8-accessible service, and consumers of prepaid wireless telecommunications service (excluding Lifeline program enrollees). Ultimately, the bill impacts individuals experiencing behavioral health crises who utilize the 9-8-8 hotline and related crisis response services.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a dedicated and sustainable funding stream, through a system of telecommunications fees, for the 9-8-8 national suicide prevention and mental health crisis hotline and associated statewide behavioral health crisis response services. While the fee collection mechanism is a standard approach, ensuring stable financial support for a comprehensive, modern behavioral health emergency response system represents an innovative step in public health and emergency services delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program funds critical behavioral health crisis response services. By providing accessible mental health support, it can indirectly help stabilize families facing crises, potentially mitigating factors that contribute to or worsen child poverty. The bill explicitly exempts subscribers enrolled in the federal Lifeline program from these fees, which directly protects low-income households from an additional financial burden, thereby reducing a potential negative impact on child poverty.

Title: State Board of Physicians - Performance of X-Ray Duties Without a License
Synopsis: Altering the circumstances under which individuals without a license to practice medicine may perform X-ray duties; authorizing the State Board of Physicians to impose a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each violation on the physician's office and $1,000 for each individual violation of the Act; and requiring the Board, by October 1, 2029, to report to certain committees of the General Assembly on the number of individuals registered to perform limited X-ray duties and the continuation or replacement of the registration process.
bill_summary: This bill formalizes and expands the requirements for individuals without a full medical license to perform specific limited X-ray duties in Maryland. It establishes detailed educational, clinical training, examination (including an American Registry of Radiologic Technologists limited scope exam), and registration requirements with the State Board of Physicians. It also defines the scope of X-ray procedures these individuals can perform, sets supervision mandates for physicians' offices, and introduces civil penalties for non-compliance. The State Board of Physicians is tasked with reporting on the effectiveness of this registration process and recommending whether it should transition into a formal limited licensure category.
responsible_party: State Board of Physicians
stakeholders: Individuals performing limited X-ray duties, physicians, physician's offices, licensed radiologic technologists, and patients receiving X-ray services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a standardized and formalized training, examination, and registration process for individuals performing limited X-ray duties, enhancing regulatory oversight and competency standards. While it modernizes regulatory practices, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily focuses on regulating the qualifications and duties of individuals performing X-ray procedures. While ensuring competent healthcare services can generally benefit all populations, including children, there is no direct mechanism or intent within this bill to specifically address or reduce child poverty.

Title: State–Owned Nursing Homes – Deficiencies, Citations, and Fines – Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the department charged with oversight of a State-owned nursing home operated by a contractor, instead of the contractor, to provide notice of certain deficiencies and enforcement actions to the Governor and certain members of the General Assembly; requiring the department charged with oversight, rather than the contractor, to provide certain information to certain persons within 30 days after the contractor's final acceptance of a plan of correction or completion of an informal dispute resolution; etc.
bill_summary: This bill shifts the responsibility for reporting deficiencies, citations, and fines at State-owned nursing homes from the contractor operating the home to the State department charged with its oversight. It requires this department to provide notice of deficiencies and enforcement actions to the Governor, specific legislative committees, and local governing bodies within 15 days of a final survey finding. It also mandates that the department provide a statement of deficiencies, a plan of correction, or results of informal dispute resolution within 30 days after the contractor's final acceptance or completion of dispute resolution. Additionally, it expands the definition of 'monitoring agency' and requires the Department to submit annual reports on survey activities and enforcement actions to the Governor and General Assembly starting in 2024.
responsible_party: Department charged with oversight of State-owned nursing homes
stakeholders: State-owned nursing homes, contractors operating State-owned nursing homes, the Governor, the Senate Finance Committee, the House Health and Government Operations Committee, members of the General Assembly representing districts with nursing homes, and local governing bodies of counties where nursing homes are located.
innovative_summary: This bill is not particularly innovative, as it primarily involves administrative changes to reporting responsibilities and expanding the list of entities considered 'monitoring agencies.' It refines existing oversight mechanisms rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services or programs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It focuses on transparency and oversight of State-owned nursing homes, which primarily serve an adult and elderly population. While improved oversight could indirectly lead to better care, it does not provide direct services, resources, or policies aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Education - Initial Teacher Certification - Requirements
Synopsis: Repealing a provision of law that requires a teacher preparation program to require a student to pass a certain assessment as a graduation requirement; altering the requirements for initial teacher certification; authorizing a local school system to establish a comprehensive induction program to aid in meeting a certain requirement for initial teacher certification; altering the qualification requirements for a teacher who holds a professional license or certificate from another state; etc.
bill_summary: This bill reforms initial teacher certification requirements in Maryland. It removes the mandate for teacher preparation programs to require a nationally recognized, portfolio-based assessment for graduation. For initial certification, it provides new pathways, including passing subject-specific examinations and either a portfolio-based assessment or completion of a rigorous local school system teacher induction program. It also removes the requirement for a specific reading instruction mastery test. The bill clarifies that candidates can meet literacy requirements through an approved assessment, a certain GPA, or documentation of effective evaluations from a local induction program. Additionally, it streamlines certification for out-of-state teachers and mandates the State Superintendent to pursue reciprocal educator credentialing agreements with other states.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education; State Superintendent of Schools
stakeholders: Individuals seeking initial teacher certification in Maryland, current teachers from other states seeking certification in Maryland, teacher preparation programs, and local school systems.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the option for local school systems to develop and implement rigorous, comprehensive teacher induction programs with a locally developed portfolio component as an alternative pathway to initial teacher certification. This provides flexibility and decentralization in how teachers demonstrate competency, moving beyond a sole reliance on standardized state or national assessments.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to streamline and update teacher certification requirements, potentially increasing the pool of qualified teachers and ensuring teacher competence. While a stronger, more stable teaching workforce can positively impact all students, including those from low-income backgrounds, this bill does not directly address the financial needs or socio-economic challenges faced by children in poverty. Any impact would be indirect through improved educational quality.

Title: Civil Actions - Public Nuisances - Firearm Industry Members (Gun Industry Accountability Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Prohibiting firearm industry members from knowingly creating, maintaining, or contributing to a public nuisance through the sale, manufacture, distribution, importation, or marketing of a firearm-related product under certain circumstances; requiring a firearm industry member to establish and implement certain reasonable controls regarding the sale, manufacture, distribution, importation, marketing, possession, and use of certain firearm-related products; authorizing certain civil actions for violations of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Gun Industry Accountability Act of 2024, prohibits firearm industry members from knowingly creating, maintaining, or contributing to public harm through the sale, manufacture, importation, or marketing of firearm-related products under certain circumstances. It requires these members to establish and implement reasonable controls to prevent unlawful sales, loss, or theft of products. Violations are deemed a public nuisance, allowing the Attorney General, county attorneys, or the Baltimore City Solicitor to bring civil actions seeking injunctive relief, restitution, and damages. The bill also requires the Attorney General to study the legality and feasibility of mandating licensed firearm dealers to provide records of firearm trace requests to the Attorney General.
responsible_party: Attorney General, county attorneys, Baltimore City Solicitor, in consultation with the Department of State Police for the study.
stakeholders: Firearm industry members (manufacturers, distributors, importers, marketers, and sellers of firearms and related products), the general public, victims of gun violence, and state and local government legal offices.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces an innovative legal approach by explicitly defining the actions of firearm industry members that contribute to public harm as a "public nuisance" and establishing a specific cause of action against them. It mandates "reasonable controls" for the industry, which is a novel regulatory and liability framework designed to reduce gun violence by holding the industry accountable through civil litigation, rather than solely relying on criminal enforcement or individual tort claims.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to reduce gun violence, which disproportionately affects communities and families experiencing poverty. While it does not directly provide financial assistance or specific services to children in poverty, a reduction in gun violence could indirectly lead to safer communities, fewer traumas, and improved stability for families, potentially alleviating some of the systemic challenges faced by children in poverty by fostering more secure living and learning environments.

Title: Maryland Transit Administration - Locally Operated Transit Systems - Mandatory Funding
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning in fiscal year 2026, the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation from the Transportation Trust Fund of $80,533,314 for the Locally Operated Transit System Grant Program.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor, starting in Fiscal Year 2026, to include an annual appropriation of at least $80,533,314 from the Transportation Trust Fund to the Locally Operated Transit System Grant Program for statewide program operations.
responsible_party: Maryland Transit Administration; Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Users of locally operated transit systems, local communities, and the general public relying on public transportation in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill mandates a specific funding level for an existing grant program, rather than establishing a new service or employing new technologies or approaches to government. Its innovation lies in changing a discretionary funding mechanism to a mandatory one.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program can indirectly impact child poverty by ensuring stable funding for transit systems, which provides reliable and affordable transportation for families to access employment, education, healthcare, and essential services, thereby reducing household transportation costs and increasing opportunities for economic stability. However, it does not directly distribute funds or services specifically targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange - State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program - Amount of Annual Subsidies
Synopsis: Altering the amount of funds the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is authorized to designate for annual subsidies under the State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program for certain fiscal years to include unspent funds designated for subsidies for young adults in a previous calendar year.
bill_summary: This bill alters the State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program by allowing the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to designate annual subsidies exceeding $20,000,000 for calendar years 2024 and 2025 if there are unspent funds from previous calendar years. Previously, the annual subsidy amount was capped at $20,000,000. The pilot program provides health insurance subsidies to young adults aged 18 to 40 with incomes between 133% and 400% of the federal poverty level.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
stakeholders: Young adults in Maryland aged 18 to 40, whose incomes are between 133% and 400% of the federal poverty level.
innovative_summary: The bill itself is not innovative as it primarily modifies funding rules for an existing program. The program itself, offering health insurance subsidies, is a standard approach to making healthcare more affordable.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program targets young adults up to age 40. While some young adults in this age range may be parents, the subsidies are for individual health insurance and do not directly address child poverty. It could have an indirect positive impact if it improves a parent's financial stability and access to healthcare, thus freeing up resources for their children, but it's not a direct intervention for child poverty.

Title: Health Occupations - Certified Dialysis Technicians - Continuing Education Requirement
Synopsis: Altering the continuing education requirement for certified dialysis technicians to complete 3 hours of continuing education approved by the Board.
bill_summary: This bill alters the wording of the continuing education requirement for certified dialysis technicians in Maryland. It clarifies that technicians must complete 3 hours of continuing education approved by the Board for certificate renewal, in addition to 16 hours of practice or an approved dialysis technician training program. The substantive requirement of 3 hours of continuing education remains unchanged.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Nursing (referred to as "the Board")
stakeholders: Certified dialysis technicians in Maryland and, indirectly, their patients.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a minor administrative adjustment to existing continuing education requirements for a specific health occupation. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes a minor regulatory change regarding continuing education for dialysis technicians. It has no direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on professional certification standards, not economic support or poverty reduction for children.

Title: City of Frederick - Assignment of Offenders to Road Work - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing a provision of law requring a District Court judge to assign, if practicable, an offender to work the public roads of Frederick County or the City of Frederick as a penalty for a violation of a municipal law or ordinance of the City of Frederick.
bill_summary: This bill repeals existing provisions in Maryland law that allowed a District Court judge to assign individuals found guilty of violating municipal laws or ordinances in the City of Frederick to perform road work on public roads in Frederick County or the City of Frederick.
responsible_party: District Court in the City of Frederick, Frederick County Sheriff's Office, and City of Frederick public works departments, as their procedures relating to offender assignment are altered.
stakeholders: Individuals found guilty of violating municipal laws or ordinances in the City of Frederick, as well as the District Court judges, the Frederick County Sheriff's Office, and public works personnel who previously managed or guarded these offenders.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative; it repeals an outdated legal provision concerning offender penalties, rather than introducing new technologies or approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to directly impact child poverty is low. By repealing road work as a penalty option, offenders may face alternative penalties such as fines or incarceration. Fines could indirectly increase financial strain on families, and incarceration can disrupt family structures, both of which might have an indirect negative effect on child poverty. However, the bill does not establish any direct programs or policies to address child poverty.

Title: State Procurement - Small Business Reserve Program - Goals and Outreach Program
Synopsis: Increasing a participation goal from a minimum of 15% to 20% for certain small businesses for certain procurement contracts; requiring the certification agency, in consultation with Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to develop an outreach program to increase the participation of small businesses that are owned by economically disadvantaged individuals; requiring, by each December 1, the certification agency to submit a report on the outreach program and the dollar amount of certain awards; etc.
bill_summary: This bill renames the "Small Business Reserve Program" to the "Small and Minority Business Reserve Program." It increases the participation goal for small businesses in State procurement contracts from 15% to 20% of the total dollar value. It also establishes a new 10% participation goal for certified minority business enterprises. Furthermore, the bill requires the Certification Agency, in consultation with the Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs, to develop an outreach program to increase the participation of small businesses owned by economically disadvantaged individuals in the program. Finally, it alters the reporting requirements for State units regarding their procurement awards.
responsible_party: Certification Agency, Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs, and Maryland State government units
stakeholders: Small businesses, certified minority business enterprises, veteran-owned small business enterprises, economically disadvantaged individuals who own businesses, and Maryland State government units involved in procurement.
innovative_summary: The bill updates an existing procurement program by adjusting participation goals and adding a targeted outreach program. While the outreach component is a new initiative, the overall approach of setting procurement targets and supporting specific business categories is a standard government practice, not employing new technologies or fundamentally novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to increase economic opportunities for small and minority businesses, including those owned by economically disadvantaged individuals, through state procurement contracts. While this could indirectly lead to job creation and improved economic stability for business owners and employees, potentially benefiting families with children, it is not a direct intervention for child poverty. The impact is indirect and contingent on broader economic effects.

Title: Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System - Reemployment as Sheriff
Synopsis: Requiring the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System to suspend the retirement benefit of a retiree of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System who is elected as a sheriff within 1 year after retirement; providing for the reinstatement of a benefit; providing that a suspension of a benefit does not affect survivor benefits; and applying the Act prospectively.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System to require the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System to temporarily suspend the retirement allowance of a retiree who is elected as a sheriff less than one year after their retirement date. It specifies provisions for the reinstatement of the allowance once the individual ceases serving as sheriff, including accumulated cost-of-living adjustments, and clarifies that survivor benefits are not affected by the temporary suspension.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System; State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Retirees of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System who are elected as sheriffs less than one year after retirement, and their surviving spouses, children, or designated beneficiaries.
innovative_summary: This bill adjusts existing rules regarding the reemployment and retirement benefits of law enforcement officers who become sheriffs. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, focusing instead on administrative policy within an established pension system.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill's primary focus is on the pension benefits of reemployed law enforcement retirees. It does not contain any provisions or mechanisms directly aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Town of Keedysville - Parking of Vehicles - Restrictions
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from parking certain vehicles in the Town of Keedysville, Washington County.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland's transportation law to prohibit the parking of certain large vehicles, including trucks, tractors, trailers, school buses, and passenger buses, on streets and highways in the Town of Keedysville, Washington County. This restriction applies unless the parking is essential to the immediate use of the vehicle. Violations are subject to fines, with each vehicle and each day constituting a separate offense.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Residents and visitors of the Town of Keedysville, Washington County, particularly those operating or owning Class E (trucks), Class F (tractors), Class G (trailers), Class H (school buses), and Class P (passenger buses) vehicles.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory change to local parking rules and does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses parking regulations for certain types of vehicles and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Death Certificates - Cause or Manner of Death Determinations - Requirements After Change or Correction (Katherine Morris Death Reclassification Act)
Synopsis: Requiring, if a victim's initial determination of death recorded on the victim's death certificate was amended or corrected to be undetermined or homicide, an assistant State's Attorney with knowledge of the case to meet with a person in interest on the request of the person in interest for a certain purpose; requiring a law enforcement agency to reopen or reinvestigate an investigation involving the death of a victim whose cause or manner of death was amended or corrected to be undetermined or homicide; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Katherine Morris Death Reclassification Act, establishes new requirements when a death certificate's cause or manner of death is amended or corrected to be "undetermined" or "homicide." It mandates that an assistant State's Attorney with knowledge of the case meet with a "person in interest" upon request to explain investigation decisions. It also requires the medical examiner to notify the State's Attorney and local law enforcement of such changes and request an amended death certificate be sent to the person in interest. Furthermore, law enforcement agencies are required to reopen or reinvestigate cases where a death certificate has been reclassified to undetermined or homicide, and these reopened cases cannot be closed for at least 20 years after notification.
responsible_party: Assistant State's Attorney, Medical Examiner, Secretary of Health, and local law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Families and legal representatives (persons in interest) of deceased individuals whose cause or manner of death has been reclassified to undetermined or homicide, as well as State's Attorneys and local law enforcement agencies.
innovative_summary: This bill refines existing legal and investigative procedures rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally innovative government approaches. It primarily mandates specific actions, communication, and extended investigation periods for reclassified death cases, aiming for greater transparency and justice for affected families. The 20-year non-closure period for reopened cases is a notable procedural change, but not a technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on legal and investigative processes related to the reclassification of causes of death. While it aims to ensure justice and provide closure for families, it does not include any provisions for direct financial aid, social services, or economic opportunities that would directly address or alleviate child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect at best, through broader societal justice outcomes.

Title: Washington County - Interscholastic Athletics - Student Eligibility Waiver and School Classification
Synopsis: Authorizing the Washington County Board of Education to waive a certain eligibility requirement for participation in interscholastic athletics at a certain Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association member school for students who attend certain public high schools; requiring the Washington County Superintendent of Schools to report to the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association the school enrollment of member schools in grades 9, 10, and 11 as of September 30 of each even-numbered year; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Washington County Board of Education to waive the enrollment and attendance eligibility requirement for participation in interscholastic athletics at a student's zoned high school for students who attend a public school in the county that does not have its own interscholastic athletics program. It also requires the Washington County Superintendent of Schools to include these students, who receive a waiver, in the official school enrollment numbers reported to the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association for the purpose of classifying member schools for athletic contests.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of Education and Washington County Superintendent of Schools
stakeholders: Students in Washington County who attend public schools without interscholastic athletics programs, public high schools in Washington County, and the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a specific waiver and reporting mechanism for student athletic eligibility and school classification in Washington County. It is a modification of existing administrative rules rather than an innovative program employing new technologies or novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill allows more students to participate in interscholastic athletics, which could provide benefits like improved physical health, teamwork skills, and potential for scholarships. While these benefits can indirectly contribute to long-term well-being, the bill does not directly address immediate financial needs, access to resources, or other direct drivers of child poverty.

Title: Public Safety - Law Enforcement Agencies - Positive Community Feedback
Synopsis: Adding positive community feedback that was not solicited by the police officer who is the subject of the feedback to the list of records that are not considered personnel records; requiring the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop a process for citizens to submit positive community feedback; requiring each law enforcement agency to adopt the uniform citizen positive community feedback process; and requiring a law enforcement agency to maintain a certain record that is subject to public inspection.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission to develop a uniform process for citizens to submit positive community feedback about law enforcement officers. All law enforcement agencies in the state must adopt this process, post it on their websites, and maintain records of positive feedback. These records will be subject to public inspection under the Maryland Public Information Act, distinguishing them from traditional personnel records.
responsible_party: Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission and individual law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Citizens of Maryland, law enforcement officers, and law enforcement agencies
innovative_summary: The program is innovative by establishing a formal, uniform, and publicly accessible statewide process specifically for positive community feedback regarding law enforcement officers. This shifts the focus beyond just complaints to acknowledge positive interactions and promotes transparency by making these records publicly inspectable, representing a new approach to public engagement and accountability in policing.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on enhancing community relations and transparency with law enforcement through a positive feedback mechanism. It does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or policies aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Somerset County – Fire, Rescue, and Emergency Medical Services
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Somerset County to enact local laws and adopt other measures to manage, direct, and regulate fire, rescue, and emergency medical services in the County; authorizing the County Commissioners to authorize or create an entity or a body to administer the County's affairs in the County relating to fire, rescue, and emergency medical services; and requiring the County Commissioners to establish an Emergency Services Advisory Council to make certain recommendations under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Somerset County to enact local laws and measures to manage, direct, and regulate fire, rescue, and emergency medical services in the County. It also allows the Commissioners to create an entity to administer these services and requires them to establish an Emergency Services Advisory Council to provide recommendations on operations.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Somerset County
stakeholders: Residents of Somerset County, volunteer emergency services personnel, and anyone relying on fire, rescue, and emergency medical services in the county.
innovative_summary: The bill grants new administrative authority to the Somerset County Commissioners for managing emergency services and mandates the creation of an advisory council. This is primarily a governance and organizational change, not introducing new technologies or novel approaches to service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the organizational structure and management of emergency services. While effective emergency services are beneficial for community safety and well-being, it does not directly address child poverty through specific programs, financial aid, or economic opportunities.

Title: Somerset County - Fire Companies - Appropriations
Synopsis: Requiring the County Commissioners of Somerset County to appropriate to certain organized volunteer fire companies in the county certain amounts for fiscal years 2025 through 2030; and requiring that the appropriations required for fiscal year 2030 remain in effect for subsequent fiscal years unless altered by a future enactment.
bill_summary: This bill requires the County Commissioners of Somerset County to provide specific annual appropriations to eight organized volunteer fire companies within the county. The appropriations are detailed for fiscal years 2025 through 2030, with the amount designated for fiscal year 2030 continuing for all subsequent fiscal years unless a new law is enacted to change it.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Somerset County
stakeholders: Organized volunteer fire companies in Somerset County and the residents they serve.
innovative_summary: This bill provides routine financial appropriations to volunteer fire companies, which is a standard governmental function. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill provides funding for essential emergency services, which indirectly benefits all residents, including families with children in poverty, by ensuring public safety. However, it does not directly offer specific programs, financial aid, or interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Somerset County – Sale of Property – Revells Neck Road
Synopsis: Authorizing the County Commissioners of Somerset County to sell the property at Map 32, Parcel 149 on Revells Neck Road under terms considered appropriate by the county commissioners.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Somerset County to sell a specific property located on Revells Neck Road (County Tax Map 32, Parcel 149) under terms they deem appropriate. It amends existing law regarding the sale of county surplus property, including previous authorizations for sales to Shore Up Inc. and the City of Crisfield.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Somerset County
stakeholders: The County Commissioners of Somerset County, potential buyers of the Revells Neck Road property, and indirectly, the residents of Somerset County.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it deals with a standard governmental function of authorizing the sale of county property. It provides specific authorization for a property sale and makes minor adjustments to existing property sale procedures.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It concerns the authorization for the sale of a specific county property and does not establish any programs or initiatives aimed at addressing child poverty.

Title: Agriculture - Invasive Plant Species - Regulation (Biodiversity and Agriculture Protection Act)
Synopsis: Altering the regulatory approach for controlling invasive plant species in the State, including repealing certain provisions of law relating to a two-tiered regulatory approach and requiring the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a list of prohibited invasive plants by regulation in a certain manner on or before October 1, 2024; establishing certain protocols for assessing certain nonnative plants and determining whether those plants are invasive or whether the plants may be placed on a certain watch list; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Biodiversity and Agriculture Protection Act, revises Maryland's approach to regulating invasive plant species. It repeals a two-tiered classification system, requiring the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a single 'prohibited invasive plant' list by October 1, 2024, based on professionally recognized assessment protocols. The bill outlines procedures for assessing nonnative plants, determining invasiveness ranks (high, medium, low, insignificant), and creating a 'watch list' for plants needing future reassessment. It establishes roles for expert assessors, the Invasive Plants Advisory Committee, and requires the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Natural Resources to post these lists online, with the University of Maryland Extension linking to them. The Department of Agriculture will also distribute these lists annually to plant-related businesses. Additionally, the State Highway Administration is authorized to control and dispose of prohibited invasive plants along state highways without prior approval, provided it follows Department regulations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture (Secretary of Agriculture and Invasive Plants Advisory Committee), Department of Natural Resources, University of Maryland Extension, State Highway Administration
stakeholders: Nurseries, plant dealers, plant brokers, landscapers, plant wholesalers, plant retailers, State Highway Administration, and the general public and natural environments of Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program updates the state's regulatory approach to invasive plants by replacing a two-tiered system with a single 'prohibited invasive plant' list, driven by professionally recognized, science-based assessment protocols (like NatureServe's 2004 protocol). It introduces a 'watch list' for non-prohibited plants, allowing for future reassessment. The inclusion of 'Early Detection Rapid Response (EDRR) Plant Species' and defined roles for 'Expert Assessors' and 'Qualified Independent Assessors' represents a more structured, proactive, and scientifically rigorous approach to managing invasive species, moving beyond simple classification to active monitoring and adaptive regulation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily focuses on environmental regulation concerning invasive plant species. While a healthy environment can indirectly benefit all citizens, including children, there are no direct provisions within the bill that specifically address or aim to alleviate child poverty. Its impact on child poverty is therefore negligible.

Title: Public Health - Opioid Restitution Advisory Council and Fund - Revisions
Synopsis: Requiring the Secretary of Health to present decisions for the allocations of money from the Opioid Restitution Fund to the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to post on the Department's website certain information regarding allocations of money from the Fund; and requiring the Department to report to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 1, 2024, on the best process for making the expenditures of all opioid settlement agreements accessible to the public.
bill_summary: This bill revises the Public Health – Opioid Restitution Advisory Council and Fund. It requires the Secretary of Health to present decisions for allocating money from the Opioid Restitution Fund to the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council and mandates the Maryland Department of Health to post this allocation information on its website. The bill also changes the 'Opioid Operational Command Center' to 'Maryland’s Office of Overdose Response' and its 'Executive Director' to 'Special Secretary of Overdose Response'. A key provision is the requirement that, in each fiscal year, at least 25% of the money in the Fund must be used to support community-based nonprofit recovery organizations. Additionally, it establishes new reporting requirements for political subdivisions on how they expend received funds and requires the Department to submit these reports to the General Assembly. Finally, by December 1, 2024, the Maryland Department of Health must report on the best process for making all opioid settlement expenditures publicly accessible.
responsible_party: Secretary of Health, Maryland Department of Health, Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council, Maryland's Office of Overdose Response
stakeholders: Individuals with substance use disorders, community-based nonprofit recovery organizations, hospitals, correctional facilities, schools, political subdivisions, and the general public in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces enhanced transparency and accountability measures for the Opioid Restitution Fund by requiring public posting of allocation decisions and detailed expenditure reports from political subdivisions. While these are positive steps for good governance and public access to information, they primarily leverage existing digital platforms for reporting and data sharing rather than employing new or groundbreaking technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has an indirect but significant potential to impact child poverty by strengthening substance use disorder prevention, treatment, and recovery services. By allocating funds to evidence-based programs and community-based recovery organizations, it can support parents and guardians struggling with addiction, potentially leading to more stable family environments, improved parental employment, and better overall well-being. Services like expanding crisis beds and residential treatment for minors and educational campaigns in schools also directly benefit children affected by the opioid crisis, which is often a contributing factor to family instability and poverty.

Title: Principal Departments - Individuals With Limited English Proficiency - Access to Public Services
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before July 1, 2025, the principal departments of the Executive Branch to fully implement certain provisions of law requiring equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency.
bill_summary: This bill expands and updates an existing law (Article – State Government Section 10–1103) requiring equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency. It mandates that all principal departments of the Executive Branch must fully implement these provisions, which include providing oral language services and translating vital documents, by July 1, 2025. Additionally, any new principal department created after October 1, 2024, must comply within one year of its creation.
responsible_party: Principal departments of the Executive Branch
stakeholders: Individuals with limited English proficiency
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative in terms of new technology or approaches. It extends existing requirements for providing language access services to more government departments, reinforcing compliance with established policies rather than introducing novel methods or technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to improve access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency. By ensuring better access to various state services (e.g., human services, labor, health, education), it could indirectly benefit families and children by helping them navigate systems and access resources that could alleviate poverty. However, it does not directly provide financial aid, housing, or specific child-focused poverty reduction programs.

Title: State Personnel - Maryland Department of Health - Pay Rates
Synopsis: Increasing the number of certain bargaining units for the purpose of specifying certain pay rates for certain employees of the Maryland Department of Health; and requiring that the pay rates of certain Department employees who are in certain bargaining units and who work at certain facilities be equal to certain pay rates of the employees who work at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland State Personnel and Pensions law to increase the number of bargaining units for certain Maryland Department of Health (MDH) employees. It mandates that pay rates for specific MDH employees, including those in the Behavioral Health Administration, Developmental Disabilities Administration facilities with high forensic admission rates, and the Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents – Baltimore and Rockville, be set equal to, or calculated at the equivalent of, two grades higher than the pay rate effective July 1, 2020, for similarly qualified employees at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital. Additionally, it specifies that pay rates for Clifton T. Perkins Hospital employees not receiving a forensic pay premium shall be at least two grades higher than their pay rate effective June 30, 2020.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Employees of the Maryland Department of Health who have direct contact with patients and are in Bargaining Units D, E, F, G, or H, specifically those at Clifton T. Perkins Hospital, facilities within the Behavioral Health Administration or Developmental Disabilities Administration with high forensic admission rates, and the Regional Institutes for Children and Adolescents – Baltimore and Rockville.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts pay rates for certain state employees within the Maryland Department of Health. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services; rather, it modifies existing compensation structures based on established benchmarks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill increases the pay rates for certain Maryland Department of Health employees. While an increase in income for these employees could indirectly improve the economic well-being of their families, including any children, the bill does not directly establish programs or services specifically targeting child poverty. The impact would be a secondary effect of higher wages.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Coverage for the Treatment of Obesity - Required Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to study the impact of requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide comprehensive coverage for the treatment of obesity, including coverage for intensive behavioral therapy, bariatric surgery, and FDA-approved antiobesity medication; and requiring the Department to report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to conduct a study on the impact of mandating comprehensive coverage for the treatment of obesity under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program. The study will include identifying and comparing obesity treatment coverage in other states' medical assistance programs and estimating potential cost savings. The Department must report its findings by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients, especially those with obesity, and the general public and State budget due to potential fiscal impacts of future coverage decisions.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates a standard comparative and cost-benefit analysis study, which is a conventional approach to policy evaluation and does not employ new technologies or innovative governmental methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill establishes a study on potential health care coverage. While future coverage for obesity treatment could indirectly benefit children from low-income families by improving health outcomes and reducing health-related costs, this bill itself does not directly implement any programs or allocate funds that directly address child poverty.

Title: Montgomery County – Subdivision Plats – Conditions PG/MC 111–24
Synopsis: Providing that the Montgomery County Planning Board may tentatively approve a subdivision plat subject to specified conditions; and providing for the approval and submission of a certain subdivision plat to the county land records.
bill_summary: This bill allows the Montgomery County Planning Board to grant tentative approval to subdivision plats, contingent upon the fulfillment of specified conditions. Once these conditions are met, a post-completion hearing is not required before final approval and submission to land records, thereby streamlining the plat approval process in Montgomery County. Tentative approvals may not be entered on the plat or allow it to be filed or recorded until all conditions are satisfied.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Planning Board
stakeholders: Land developers, property owners, and residents in Montgomery County whose properties are subject to or affected by subdivision plats.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a procedural change to the subdivision plat approval process, allowing for conditional tentative approvals and potentially streamlining the final approval. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches, but rather adjusts existing regulatory steps.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily deals with land use regulations and the procedural approval of subdivision plats. It has no direct mechanisms or provisions to address or alleviate child poverty. Any impact would be extremely indirect, such as potential minor influences on housing development and affordability over a long term, which is too tenuous to be considered direct.

Title: Environment - Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reductions - Manufacturers
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "manufacturing" for purposes of certain greenhouse gas emissions reduction requirements to exclude the production of cement; altering the application of certain provisions of law regarding the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing sector to apply only to persons that engaged in manufacturing in 2023; requiring the Department of the Environment to make certain considerations and consult with certain stakeholders related to the regulation of the production of cement; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters Maryland's greenhouse gas emissions reduction requirements for manufacturers. It specifically excludes cement production from the general definition of manufacturing for these requirements and mandates that the Department of the Environment consider factors like energy intensity, early action investments, alternative fuel sources, and abatement technologies when regulating cement production, consulting with stakeholders. For other manufacturers, the bill limits greenhouse gas emission reduction requirements to their 2023 levels and exempts manufacturers producing renewable energy components or greenhouse gas reduction technology from these specific new limitations.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Maryland manufacturers, especially cement producers, and the public concerned with environmental regulations and greenhouse gas emissions.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces regulatory adjustments and specific considerations for an existing environmental framework. While it refines the approach to emissions reduction for certain industries by considering factors like early action investments, alternative fuel sources, and financial incentives for abatement technologies, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches to emissions reduction.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses entirely on environmental regulations regarding greenhouse gas emissions from manufacturers. It does not establish any direct programs, services, or financial support mechanisms designed to alleviate child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect, through potential economic effects on the manufacturing sector, which is not a direct intervention.

Title: Agriculture - Food Processing Residuals Utilization Permit - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing a food processing residuals utilization permit; prohibiting a person from utilizing food processing residuals in the State unless the person obtains a permit; requiring the Department of Agriculture to provide a certain notice and information to certain persons in a county where food processing residuals will be stored; establishing the Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund; authorizing a representative of the Department to enter and inspect any site where food processing residuals are utilized; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a food processing residuals utilization permit program, shifting oversight from the Department of the Environment to the Department of Agriculture. It requires individuals or entities utilizing food processing residuals (organic material generated by processing agricultural commodities) in the State to obtain a permit. The bill outlines application requirements, public notice procedures for permit applications involving storage, permit terms (1 year maximum), and conditions for maintaining and renewing permits. It also establishes the Food Processing Residuals Administration Fund, a special, nonlapsing fund supported by fees, to cover administrative costs. The Department of Agriculture is authorized to conduct inspections, impose administrative penalties for violations, and may administer a Commercial Hauler Certification Program for individuals transporting food processing residuals.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture (Secretary or Secretary's designee)
stakeholders: Agricultural operations, commercial brokers, commercial haulers, food processing plants, landowners where residuals are applied, local governments, and the general public concerned with environmental and public health impacts.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily restructures and clarifies regulatory oversight for food processing residuals, shifting responsibility from the Department of the Environment to the Department of Agriculture. While it establishes a new permit program, a dedicated fund, and a voluntary certification program for haulers, these are standard governmental approaches to regulation and management rather than employing new technologies or highly innovative governance methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on environmental regulation and agricultural practices related to the utilization of food processing residuals. There are no provisions within the bill that directly aim to reduce child poverty or provide services, aid, or economic opportunities specifically targeted at families with children experiencing poverty.

Title: Environment - Delegated Authorities - Well and Septic Program Permits
Synopsis: Requiring a local health department or county government to which the Department of the Environment has delegated authority to administer a septic and well program to submit, by December 1, 2024, a schedule of review times for certain well and septic program permits for approval; and requiring a local health department or county government to submit well and septic program permit data to the Department for review beginning 3 months after the original schedule submission approved by the Department and every 3 months thereafter.
bill_summary: This bill requires local health departments or county governments with delegated authority for well and septic programs to submit a schedule of permit review times to the Department of the Environment for approval by December 1, 2024. Additionally, it mandates that these delegated authorities submit well and septic program permit data to the Department for review every three months, starting three months after the schedule is approved. This aims to standardize oversight of well and septic permitting processes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Local health departments, county governments with delegated well and septic program authority, and indirectly, property owners requiring well and septic permits.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes new reporting and approval requirements for delegated well and septic programs, focusing on standardizing review times and data submission. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government beyond enhanced administrative oversight.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses administrative oversight and reporting requirements for well and septic system permits. It does not directly provide financial assistance, educational opportunities, healthcare services, or other resources that would immediately impact child poverty. Any potential impact would be very indirect, relating to housing stability or environmental health, but not a direct intervention against poverty.

Title: Washington County Board of Education - Members - Residency Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring that a member of the Washington County Board of Education be a resident of Washington County for at least 6 months and the State for at least 12 months immediately preceding the date the member takes office; and requiring members of the county board to maintain a primary residence in Washington County during their term.
bill_summary: This bill requires members of the Washington County Board of Education to have resided in Washington County for at least 6 months and in the State of Maryland for at least 12 months immediately preceding their date of taking office. Additionally, members must maintain a primary residence in Washington County throughout their term, or they will be ineligible to continue serving on the board.
responsible_party: Washington County Board of Education; Washington County Commissioners
stakeholders: Members and potential members of the Washington County Board of Education; residents of Washington County
innovative_summary: This bill does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to government. It modifies the residency requirements for members of an existing county board of education.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative requirements for public office holders, specifically residency rules for the Washington County Board of Education members. It has no direct mechanisms or provisions to address or alleviate child poverty.

Title: Consumer Protection - Consumer Council - Name Change
Synopsis: Changing the name of the Consumer Council in the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General to the Consumer Protection Commission.
bill_summary: This bill renames the Consumer Council, which is part of the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General, to the Consumer Protection Commission. It also allows members of the newly named Commission to receive per diem compensation in accordance with the State budget, whereas previously they served without compensation.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General, Division of Consumer Protection
stakeholders: Consumers, businesses, and the general public in Maryland who are affected by consumer protection policies and regulations.
innovative_summary: This bill involves a name change for an existing advisory body and adjusts compensation for its members. It does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill's changes to the name and compensation of a consumer protection advisory body have no direct impact on child poverty. Its effects on consumer protection policy are indirect at best.

Title: Maryland Department of Labor – Unemployment Insurance – Study on Actively Seeking Work Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Labor, on or before December 1, 2024, to conduct a study on the actively seeking work requirement of the unemployment insurance system in the State and other states to evaluate the effects of ghosting on actively seeking work requirements and report on the study to the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to conduct a study on the actively seeking work requirements for unemployment insurance benefits in Maryland and other states. The study will evaluate the effects of 'ghosting' (job applicants failing to attend interviews or maintain contact) on these requirements. It will also examine other states' requirements, determine the Department's ability to verify reported information using existing resources, evaluate why the online BEACON system doesn't allow employers to report claimant contact or ghosting incidents, and assess the feasibility of removing certain employer input requirements for reporting ghosting. The Department must report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Unemployment insurance claimants, employers, and the Maryland Department of Labor's unemployment insurance system.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates a study of existing unemployment insurance systems and practices, specifically focusing on the BEACON online system and the phenomenon of 'ghosting' in the job market. While the study itself is not an innovative program, its goal is to assess and potentially improve the efficiency and accuracy of existing technological systems and processes, and to adapt them to current labor market behaviors. It explores how technology can be better utilized for verification and reporting within the unemployment insurance framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By studying and potentially improving the efficiency and integrity of the unemployment insurance system, it could help ensure that eligible families receive benefits more effectively, which in turn could provide financial stability during periods of unemployment. However, it does not directly allocate resources or establish services aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network to identify and analyze options for establishing and maintaining an open access science, technology, and innovation network or hub of citizen scientists and experts in science, technology, and industry for certain purposes; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network. The Workgroup is tasked with identifying and analyzing options for creating an open-access science, technology, and innovation network, including a digital referral network of experts. It will evaluate methods for registering participants and making expertise available to the public. The Workgroup must report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network (supported by the University of Maryland, Baltimore County)
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland Senate and House of Delegates, the Executive Director of the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, representatives with expertise in fostering community-based applications of science/technology, institutions of higher education, private sector experts, and nonprofit sector advocates. The general public may benefit from improved science and technology insights and solutions.
innovative_summary: The bill aims to establish a framework for an open-access science, technology, and innovation network, potentially leveraging digital platforms for expert referrals and noninstitutional collaboration. While the concept of a workgroup is not innovative, the network it proposes, focused on open exchange of ideas and evidence-based data, could introduce new approaches to government-supported innovation and public access to scientific expertise.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill establishes a workgroup to explore creating a science and technology innovation network. Its focus is on facilitating collaboration, information exchange, and sound decision-making in science and technology. There is no direct mechanism or stated intent within the bill to address child poverty directly; any impact would be highly indirect through general societal or economic improvements.

Title: Office of the Attorney General - Investigative Authority - Health Care Fraud
Synopsis: Authorizing the Office of the Attorney General, a Deputy Attorney General, or an Assistant Attorney General to issue a subpoena to a person to produce certain materials, answer written interrogatories, and give certain testimony in furtherance of an ongoing health care fraud investigation under the Maryland False Health Claims Act or other civil authority; authorizing the Attorney General to report a failure to obey a certain subpoena to the circuit court with jurisdiction over the matter; etc.
bill_summary: This bill expands the investigative authority of the Office of the Attorney General, a Deputy Attorney General, or an Assistant Attorney General to issue subpoenas for health care fraud investigations under the Maryland False Health Claims Act or other civil authority. These subpoenas can require individuals to produce documentary material, answer written interrogatories under oath, and give sworn oral testimony. The bill also establishes a process for the Attorney General to report a failure to obey such a subpoena to the circuit court for enforcement.
responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Individuals and entities involved in or suspected of health care fraud in Maryland, who may be subject to investigation and subpoenas by the Attorney General's office.
innovative_summary: The bill strengthens the investigative capabilities of the Attorney General's office by formalizing and expanding subpoena powers for health care fraud investigations. While it enhances enforcement tools, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally alter government approaches, but rather refines existing legal processes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on enhancing the investigation and prosecution of health care fraud. While reducing fraud can indirectly safeguard public funds that might be used for social services, it does not directly create programs, allocate resources, or implement interventions specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be very indirect and speculative.

Title: Montgomery County - Clerk of the Circuit Court - Plat Recordation PG/MC 110-24
Synopsis: Authorizing a plat in Montgomery County to be drawn, recorded, and maintained in electronic form in a manner approved by the State Archivist.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Clerk of the Circuit Court in Montgomery County to draw, record, and maintain plats (maps of land subdivisions) in electronic form. This electronic process must be approved by the State Archivist, offering an alternative or supplement to traditional physical record-keeping methods.
responsible_party: Clerk of the Circuit Court for Montgomery County and the State Archivist
stakeholders: Property owners, land developers, land surveyors, and the Clerk of the Circuit Court's office in Montgomery County.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the option for electronic recordation and maintenance of plats in Montgomery County, modernizing a traditional government record-keeping process by allowing for digital formats alongside or in place of physical ones. While electronic records are not a novel concept, their application to this specific legal and administrative process represents a step towards digital transformation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the administrative process of plat recordation and maintenance within Montgomery County's legal framework. It does not provide any direct services, financial aid, or systemic changes that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Average Final Compensation - Compensation Adjustments
Synopsis: Establishing that certain adjustments to compensation may not be considered an extraordinary salary increase when determining the average final compensation of a member in the State Retirement and Pension System; and requiring a member to submit certain information to the State Retirement Agency in a certain manner at the time of retirement.
bill_summary: This bill amends the State Retirement and Pension System to clarify what types of salary increases are not considered 'extraordinary salary increases' when calculating a member's average final compensation. Specifically, salary increases due to promotion, adjustments to address compensation inequities among employees in the same position classification, or increases to match market compensation will now be included in the calculation. Members receiving such increases must submit a certified form from their employer to the State Retirement Agency at the time of retirement to confirm the nature of the salary increase.
responsible_party: State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Members of the State Retirement and Pension System, including the State Police Retirement System, and their employers (Maryland State agencies/departments).
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative and legal adjustments to how retirement benefits are calculated, particularly regarding what constitutes an 'extraordinary salary increase.' It introduces a new requirement for members to submit a specific form to the State Retirement Agency when retiring under certain conditions. This is a procedural modification, not an innovative program or a new approach to government services or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary purpose is to refine the calculation of retirement benefits for state employees. While it could lead to slightly higher retirement incomes for some retirees, thereby potentially benefiting their households, it is not a direct intervention or program specifically designed to address child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be highly indirect, dependent on the individual circumstances of state employee retirees and their families.

Title: Correctional Officers' Retirement System - Membership
Synopsis: Altering membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System to include certain employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Maryland Department of Health; requiring the State Retirement and Pension System to transfer the creditable service of employees transferred into the Correctional Officers' Retirement System under the Act unless the employee elects not to transfer service on or before June 1, 2025; authorizing certain employees to elect not to transfer service; etc.
bill_summary: This bill expands membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System (CORS) to include certain employees of the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) working in specific facilities and positions, such as CAMH Associate, Licensed Practical Nurse – CI, and Security Attendant roles, effective July 1, 2024. It outlines procedures for transferring creditable service and calculating retirement benefits, including unused sick leave, for employees moving from the State Employees’ Retirement System or State Employees’ Pension System to CORS. Employees affected by this change on July 1, 2024, who had creditable service before July 1, 2008, are generally transferred into CORS, but they have the option to elect not to transfer their service by June 1, 2025.
responsible_party: State Retirement and Pension System; Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Employees of the Maryland Department of Health in specific facilities (Eastern Shore Hospital Center, Thomas B. Finan Center, The Potomac Center/The Secure Evaluation and Therapeutic Treatment Program, Spring Grove Hospital, Springfield Hospital Center, The Regional Institute for Children and Adolescents Baltimore, John L. Gildner Regional Institute for Children and Adolescents) and specific positions (CAMH Associate – CI, Developmental Disability Associate – CI, Direct Care Assistant – CI, Licensed Practical Nurse – CI, Resident Associate SETT – CI, Security Attendant I, II, or III, Security Attendant Manager I or II, Security Attendant Supervisor). Also, members of the Correctional Officers' Retirement System, State Employees' Retirement System, and State Employees' Pension System.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves administrative changes to retirement system eligibility and service transfer rules for certain state employees. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill modifies retirement benefits and system membership for certain state employees. While stable employment and retirement benefits indirectly support families, these changes do not directly or primarily target the reduction of child poverty through specific interventions, direct financial aid, or social programs.

Title: Public Health – Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program – Recovery of Funding
Synopsis: Altering the number of years after completion of a project funded in part by a grant of the Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program after which the State may recover funding under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill alters the timeframe during which the State of Maryland can recover grant funding from Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs). Specifically, it reduces the recovery period from 30 years to 15 years for projects where the property was leased by the FQHC, while maintaining the 30-year recovery period for projects where the property was owned by the FQHC. This change applies if the property is sold, transferred to an ineligible entity, or ceases to operate as an FQHC.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs), counties, municipal corporations, and nonprofit organizations that receive grants for FQHC projects, and ultimately, the communities and patients served by these centers.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative adjustment to the financial recovery terms of an existing grant program. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government operations. Its focus is on refining legal and financial accountability mechanisms within an established framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily modifies the recovery period for state grants provided to Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs). By clarifying and potentially easing financial recovery terms for certain FQHC projects (those involving leased properties), it may indirectly support the establishment and continued operation of FQHCs. FQHCs provide essential healthcare services to underserved communities, which can indirectly benefit children in poverty by improving health outcomes and reducing healthcare barriers. However, this is an administrative adjustment to grant terms and not a direct program aimed at poverty reduction or providing direct aid to families or children.

Title: State Officers and Employees – Required Surety Bonds – Insurance Policies Authorized
Synopsis: Altering the requirements that certain officers and employees of the State be covered by certain surety bonds to allow the officers and employees to be covered by certain insurance policies; transferring certain duties and responsibilities of the Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee to the State Treasurer; and repealing certain provisions of law related to the approval, form, and record of certain surety bonds required for certain officers and employees of the State.
bill_summary: This bill alters the requirements for certain State officers and employees to be covered by surety bonds, allowing them instead to be covered by insurance policies. It transfers the duties and responsibilities related to determining the type and amount of coverage from the Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee to the State Treasurer, and repeals the committee itself. The State Treasurer will now be responsible for setting the coverage requirements for most state officers and employees who handle public funds or property.
responsible_party: State Treasurer; Governor (in consultation for some roles); Comptroller (record keeping)
stakeholders: Maryland State officers and employees who are required to be bonded or insured, and the State agencies that employ them.
innovative_summary: The bill allows for the use of insurance policies as an alternative to traditional surety bonds for State officers and employees, providing flexibility in how financial safeguards are met. It also centralizes the responsibility for determining coverage types and amounts with the State Treasurer, replacing a committee-based approach, which could streamline administrative processes. This is a procedural innovation in risk management and administrative efficiency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the financial oversight and accountability of State officers and employees through bonding or insurance. It has no direct or indirect provisions that would impact child poverty.

Title: State Employees - Paid Sick Leave - Certificate of Illness or Disability Signed by a Licensed Clinical Professional Counselor
