Synopsis: Authorizing a licensed clinical professional counselor to sign a certificate of illness or disability when a State employee uses sick leave for 5 or more consecutive workdays.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland law to authorize a licensed clinical professional counselor to sign a certificate of illness or disability for State employees who use sick leave for five or more consecutive workdays. This expands the list of accepted healthcare providers whose documentation is valid for State employee sick leave purposes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management
stakeholders: State employees in the State Personnel Management System who use sick leave for extended periods, and licensed clinical professional counselors who can now provide official documentation for such leave.
innovative_summary: This bill is not particularly innovative. It makes an administrative update to the list of recognized healthcare professionals whose documentation is accepted for State employee sick leave, reflecting an adjustment to existing policy rather than a new approach or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a very low direct impact on child poverty. It is an administrative change to State employee sick leave policy, expanding who can sign a medical certificate. While secure employment and benefits for State employees can indirectly support families, this specific change does not directly address child poverty through new programs, funding, or direct assistance.

Title: Frederick County - School Construction Master Plan Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup; and requiring the Workgroup to comprehensively evaluate all school facility needs in Frederick County and report its findings and recommendations to certain Frederick County officials, the Interagency Commission on School Construction and the Frederick County House and Senate Delegations by December 31, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup to comprehensively evaluate school facility needs, explore solutions for balancing fiscal demands with educational priorities, and consider cost-saving or cost-sharing opportunities for new projects, maintenance, and renovations in Frederick County Public Schools. The Workgroup is required to report its findings and recommendations by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Frederick County School Construction Master Plan Workgroup (with staff support from the Frederick County Board of Education)
stakeholders: Students, parents, educators, taxpayers, and residents of Frederick County impacted by school facilities and construction planning.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a traditional legislative workgroup to study school construction needs. It does not employ new technologies or significantly alter governmental approaches, relying instead on a standard collaborative study model.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on school construction planning and facility needs, which can indirectly benefit all students by improving learning environments. However, it does not directly address or implement programs aimed at alleviating child poverty through financial assistance, specific social services, or targeted educational interventions for children in poverty.

Title: Boundary of the Frederick County Soil Conservation District - Alteration
Synopsis: Establishing the Frederick County Soil Conservation District to include the Catoctin Soil Conservation District and the Frederick Soil Conservation District.
bill_summary: This bill consolidates the Catoctin Soil Conservation District and the Frederick Soil Conservation District into a single Frederick County Soil Conservation District. This administrative change reduces the total number of soil conservation districts in Maryland from 24 to 23.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture (State Soil Conservation Committee)
stakeholders: Landowners, farmers, and residents within Frederick County, as well as personnel of the former Catoctin and Frederick Soil Conservation Districts.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative consolidation of existing districts and does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on soil conservation district consolidation has no direct impact on child poverty. Its effects are primarily administrative and environmental.

Title: Washington County - Public Facilities Bonds
Synopsis: Authorizing and empowering the County Commissioners of Washington County to borrow not more than $50,000,000 in order to finance the construction, improvement, or development of certain public facilities in Washington County and to effect such borrowing by the issuance and sale at public or private sale of its general obligation bonds; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Washington County to borrow up to $50,000,000 by issuing general obligation bonds. The funds will be used to finance the construction, improvement, or development of various public facilities, including roads, bridges, storm drains, public school buildings, community college facilities, public safety buildings, libraries, water and sewer infrastructure, and parks and recreation facilities. Additionally, funds can be used to provide loans to volunteer fire departments for equipment and facilities, and to acquire easements for agricultural land and woodland preservation.
responsible_party: County Commissioners of Washington County
stakeholders: Residents of Washington County, volunteer fire departments in Washington County, and landowners participating in agricultural and woodland preservation easement programs.
innovative_summary: The bill utilizes standard local government financing mechanisms, such as general obligation bonds and installment purchase obligations, to fund public facilities and services. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government administration or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill finances general public infrastructure and services, such as schools, water and sewer projects, and emergency services, which can indirectly benefit all residents, including children in poverty, by improving community resources and safety. However, it does not establish direct programs or provisions specifically designed to reduce child poverty or provide targeted support to impoverished families.

Title: Prince George's County and Montgomery County - The Washington Suburban Transit Commission Reform Act PG/MC 103-24
Synopsis: Authorizing the Secretary of Transportation's designee to attend meetings of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors on behalf of the Secretary when the Secretary is not available; authorizing the Washington Suburban Transit Commission to reappoint a certain appointee to be a principal member of the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Washington Suburban Transit Commission Reform Act, makes several changes primarily affecting the Washington Suburban Transit Commission (WSTC) and its representation on the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA) Board of Directors. It authorizes the Secretary of Transportation's designee to attend WMATA Board meetings and grants the designee full powers when doing so. It also allows for the reappointment of certain WSTC appointees to the WMATA Board. Crucially, the bill removes a previous limitation, granting the WSTC full autonomy to enter into contracts and agreements without requiring review and approval from the governing bodies of Prince George's and Montgomery Counties.
responsible_party: Washington Suburban Transit Commission; Secretary of Transportation
stakeholders: Residents of Prince George's County and Montgomery County who rely on public transportation, as well as the administrative staff and members of the Washington Suburban Transit Commission and the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Board of Directors.
innovative_summary: This bill focuses on administrative and governance reforms, streamlining existing processes rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government. The changes mainly involve clarifying roles, granting more autonomy to the Washington Suburban Transit Commission for contracts, and adjusting appointment rules.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on the administrative and governance structure of transit commissions and authorities. While efficient public transit can indirectly benefit low-income families by improving access to jobs and services, this bill does not establish any direct programs, funding, or interventions specifically aimed at reducing child poverty. The impact on child poverty is therefore extremely indirect and negligible.

Title: Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission - Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program - Expansion PG/MC 101-24
Synopsis: Expanding the Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program to include certain sewer pipes and diagnostic actions; altering the maximum amount of a loan that may be made under the Program from $5,000 to $10,000; altering the total amount of loans that the Program may provide or have outstanding from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000; and increasing to $200,000 the amount of funding through fiscal year 2034  which the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission must include for the Program in the Commission's budget.
bill_summary: This bill expands the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission's (WSSC) Connection Pipe Emergency Replacement Loan Program. It broadens the program to include sewer pipes and diagnostic actions, increases the maximum individual loan amount from $5,000 to $10,000, raises the total outstanding loan limit from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000, and extends the required annual budget funding from $100,000 to $200,000 for fiscal years 2020 through 2034.
responsible_party: Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission
stakeholders: Residential customers of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission who require emergency replacement or diagnosis of malfunctioning water or sewer service pipes on their property.
innovative_summary: This bill expands an existing loan program to cover additional types of pipes and diagnostic services. It does not introduce new technologies or employ novel approaches to government services, maintaining a traditional loan structure for infrastructure repair.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides loans for emergency home infrastructure repairs (water and sewer pipes). While addressing a critical housing need, it is a loan program requiring repayment, rather than direct financial aid or a grant. Its impact on child poverty is indirect, as it helps homeowners manage unexpected repair costs, which could prevent housing instability, but it is not specifically targeted at low-income families or designed to reduce child poverty directly.

Title: Armed Forces - Support of Military Families and Addition of Space Force
Synopsis: Adding the Space Force to certain provisions of law related to the armed forces; authorizing military spouses and residents of the State who are members of the National Guard of another state or a reserve component of the armed forces to terminate certain contracts at any time after the date the service member receives certain military orders to relocate; altering the definition of a "military-connected student" for purposes of the Purple Star Schools Program; and authorizing the Governor to make certain posthumous awards.
bill_summary: This bill updates various Maryland laws to include the Space Force within definitions related to the armed forces. It expands consumer protections by allowing military spouses and Maryland residents serving in other states' National Guard or a reserve component to terminate certain service contracts (telecommunication, internet, TV, gym, satellite radio) if they receive military relocation orders. The bill also broadens the definition of a "military-connected student" for the Purple Star Schools Program to include dependents of Space Force members and National Guard members from any state. Additionally, it authorizes the Governor to award posthumous commissions, appointments, or promotions.
responsible_party: Maryland State government agencies, including the Governor's Office, the Adjutant General, and the Department of Education (for the Purple Star Schools Program).
stakeholders: Members of the U.S. armed forces (including Space Force, National Guard, and Reserve components), military spouses, military-connected students, and service providers (telecommunication, internet, TV, athletic clubs, satellite radio).
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modernizes existing laws by incorporating the Space Force into various legal definitions and expanding existing protections to a broader group of military personnel and their families. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services; instead, it updates current legislative frameworks to reflect contemporary military structures and provide more inclusive support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has an indirect potential to impact child poverty by enhancing financial stability and providing educational support for military families. Extending contract termination rights can alleviate financial burdens associated with military relocations, and including more students in the 'military-connected student' definition for the Purple Star Schools Program can ensure these children receive appropriate educational support. However, it does not directly provide income, housing, or food assistance that would directly address child poverty.

Title: Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup to study certain standards related to EV charging stations; and requiring the Workgroup to report its framework and recommendations to the Senate Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee and the House Economic Matters Committee on or before November 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup to develop a framework for reliability and reporting standards for electric vehicle (EV) charging stations, study which government entities are responsible for ensuring accountability, and make recommendations for adopting and implementing regulations related to EV charging. These recommendations include standards for payment options, subscription requirements, transparent information, employee training, power output, registration, reporting, labeling, uptime, customer support, monitoring, and charging system compatibility. The Workgroup is required to report its framework and recommendations by November 1, 2024. The Act will be abrogated on June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment Workgroup, supported by the Public Service Commission
stakeholders: Electric vehicle owners and users in Maryland, electric vehicle service providers, government agencies involved in transportation and energy regulation, and members of the EV industry.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a workgroup to develop standards and recommendations for electric vehicle charging infrastructure. While the mechanism of a workgroup is not innovative, its focus on standardizing and improving the reliability and accessibility of a relatively new and evolving technology like EV charging stations, addressing issues like uptime and diverse payment options, is a forward-looking approach to public infrastructure regulation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to develop recommendations for electric vehicle charging infrastructure. This initiative does not have a direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on improving EV charging services, which is generally unrelated to direct poverty reduction efforts.

Title: Highways – Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program to create a system of supplemental guide signs to direct motorists to eligible individual attractions by directing the motorists first to groups of attractions; requiring the State Highway Administration and the Department of Commerce to develop standards and procedures for determining the eligibility of an attraction for a sign; requiring the Administration to notify certain committees of the General Assembly at least 30 days before amending the Program; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Tourist Area and Corridor Signage Program in Maryland. The program aims to create a system of supplemental guide signs on state highways to direct motorists to eligible individual tourist attractions. The State Highway Administration, in collaboration with the Department of Commerce, will administer the program, develop eligibility standards for attractions, and review signage plans. Tourist attractions will be responsible for the costs of designing, fabricating, installing, and maintaining their signs, and will pay application and annual administrative fees. The Administration may amend the program if it could result in a sanction by the Federal Highway Administration and must notify specific legislative committees of any such amendments. The bill also outlines general eligibility criteria for attractions to participate.
responsible_party: State Highway Administration, in collaboration with the Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Maryland tourist attractions, the tourism industry, motorists, and the general public seeking recreational, historical, cultural, or leisure activities in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a formal system for tourist area and corridor signage, which is a fairly traditional approach to guiding visitors. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on tourism infrastructure through highway signage, which aims to boost local economies by increasing visitation to attractions. While a stronger economy could indirectly benefit some families, there is no direct mechanism within the program to address or alleviate child poverty.

Title: Baltimore City Sheriff - Staffing
Synopsis: Increasing from one to three the number of assistant sheriffs required to be appointed by the Baltimore City Sheriff; authorizing the Baltimore City Sheriff to appoint social workers and any additional sworn or civilian personnel if the funding for the personnel is provided in the ordinance of estimates or any other source; and applying the Act to all full-time sworn law enforcement officers who are deputy sheriffs at the rank of lieutenant or below and court security officers.
bill_summary: This bill significantly modifies the staffing structure and labor relations for the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office. It increases the required number of assistant sheriffs from one to three and explicitly authorizes the Sheriff to appoint social workers and any additional sworn or civilian personnel, provided funding is available through the Sheriff's operating budget or other sources. Additionally, the bill establishes comprehensive procedures for collective bargaining for full-time sworn law enforcement officers (lieutenant rank and below) and court security officers within the Sheriff's Office, detailing processes for recognition, negotiation, mediation, and binding arbitration on certain matters.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Sheriff's Office
stakeholders: The Baltimore City Sheriff, assistant sheriffs, deputy sheriffs, court security officers, social workers, other sworn and civilian personnel within the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office, and potentially the residents of Baltimore City who are served by the Sheriff's Office.
innovative_summary: The bill's provision for the Baltimore City Sheriff to appoint social workers represents a modern, multidisciplinary approach to public safety and law enforcement, aiming to address community needs beyond traditional policing roles. The detailed framework for collective bargaining, including mediation and arbitration, also formalizes and modernizes labor relations within the Sheriff's Office.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on the administrative and staffing structure of the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office. While the authorization to appoint social workers could potentially lead to services that indirectly support vulnerable families and children, there is no direct mechanism or specific program within the bill designed to address child poverty. Any impact would be indirect and contingent on how these social workers are deployed and the scope of their services.

Title: Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services to identify reentry services in the State, develop a plan to establish a new division within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, and develop a plan to expand certain services for individuals after release from incarceration; and requiring the Task Force to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services. The Task Force is charged with identifying existing reentry services in Maryland, pinpointing gaps, assessing markers of successful reentry, and developing a comprehensive plan to create a dedicated Division of Returning Citizens within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. This division would aim to coordinate reentry programs, remove barriers, and empower individuals to reduce recidivism. The Task Force must also develop a plan to expand a wide array of post-release services, including housing, employment, socialization, health, legal assistance, and education. The Task Force is required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly by December 31, 2025.
responsible_party: The Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services, staffed by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
stakeholders: Individuals formerly incarcerated (returning citizens), currently incarcerated individuals and their family members, State agencies involved in public safety, housing, health, human services, labor, and legal aid, and various non-profit organizations focused on reentry and justice reform. The broader community will also be impacted by improved reentry services and reduced recidivism.
innovative_summary: The bill proposes a structured and comprehensive approach to improving reentry services by establishing a Task Force to plan for a dedicated 'Division of Returning Citizens' within a state department. This new division would centralize and coordinate a wide range of services, from housing and employment to health and legal aid, aiming for a more holistic and systemic approach to reintegration. The inclusion of individuals with lived experience (formerly incarcerated individuals and family members of incarcerated individuals) directly on the Task Force also represents a modern and inclusive approach to policy development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a strong potential for an indirect impact on child poverty. By focusing on expanding and coordinating comprehensive reentry services such as stable housing, employment, financial literacy, and health services for formerly incarcerated individuals, the bill addresses key determinants of family economic stability. Many incarcerated individuals are parents, and providing effective support for their successful reintegration can lead to more stable family environments and improved financial security for their children, thereby reducing child poverty.

Title: State Agency Workforce Policy for the 21st Century Act
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that an appointing authority send a copy of the selection plan and job announcement to the Secretary of Budget and Management at least 1 week before posting a job announcement; and repealing the requirement that the appointing authority wait until after the close of a position announcement to review qualified applicants.
bill_summary: The State Agency Workforce Policy for the 21st Century Act streamlines State government employment processes by repealing certain requirements for appointing authorities regarding job announcement submissions and applicant review timelines. It mandates the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) to actively recruit for vacant positions, which includes developing school-to-work and apprenticeship programs, promoting benefits, and collaborating with career counselors and local workforce development boards to expand the pool of qualified applicants.
responsible_party: Department of Budget and Management (DBM)
stakeholders: State government job applicants, existing State employees seeking advancement, and State government agencies.
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes State government hiring practices by removing procedural hurdles and mandating proactive, targeted recruitment strategies. It emphasizes expanding access to State employment and actively engaging with educational and workforce development entities through school-to-work and apprenticeship programs, representing a forward-thinking approach to public sector staffing.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to make State employment more accessible through active recruitment and the development of apprenticeship programs. This could lead to increased employment opportunities and stable incomes for individuals, which may indirectly benefit families and reduce child poverty by providing parents with better job prospects and financial stability. However, it is not a direct intervention specifically targeting children in poverty.

Title: Consumer Protection – Self–Administered Sexual Assault Evidence Collection Kits
Synopsis: Providing that a party in a criminal trial involving an allegation of sexually assaultive behavior may not introduce information that physical evidence of sexually assaultive behavior was obtained using certain materials; providing that selling, offering for sale, or distributing a certain self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kit is an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice; establishing the Forensic Nurse Examiner Training Grant Program and the Forensic Nurse Examiner Training Grant Program Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the sale, offer for sale, or distribution of self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kits, making such actions an unfair, deceptive, or abusive trade practice. It also stipulates that information derived from physical evidence collected using such kits is inadmissible in criminal trials involving sexually assaultive behavior. The bill establishes the Forensic Nurse Examiner Training Grant Program and a special, nonlapsing fund to support it. This program aims to assist nonprofit entities and higher education institutions in funding training for nurses to conduct forensic examinations of sexual assault victims. Additionally, the bill voids any agreements or policies that limit or waive rights or warranties on products used to collect sexual assault evidence.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Victims of sexual assault, nurses, nonprofit entities and higher education institutions that provide victim resources, the Attorney General's Office, and consumers in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a grant program to fund training for forensic nurses, which improves the standard of care for sexual assault victims. It also regulates and bans the sale of self-administered sexual assault evidence collection kits, a consumer protection measure. While beneficial, these are standard governmental approaches (grants, regulation) rather than employing new technologies or highly innovative governmental methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving the response to sexual assault through consumer protection and enhanced forensic nursing training. While sexual assault can have profound and lasting impacts on individuals and families, potentially contributing to economic hardship, this bill does not directly address the root causes or immediate symptoms of child poverty, such as income support, housing, or educational opportunities for low-income children.

Title: Behavioral Health Advisory Council and Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the membership and terms of members of the Behavioral Health Advisory Council; altering the membership of the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access; and requiring the Commission, in coordination with the Council, to make recommendations regarding the continuation of the State's behavioral health carve-out and the financing structure and quality oversight necessary to integrate somatic and behavioral health services and ensure compliance with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership and duties of the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access. It requires the two bodies to meet jointly and coordinate on various tasks, including an annual report and a specific report by July 1, 2025, on the continuation of the State's behavioral health carve-out, financing for integrated somatic and behavioral health services, and compliance with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act within the Maryland Medical Assistance Program. It also encourages the Maryland Department of Health to evaluate and consider participating in the federal Innovation in Behavioral Health Model.
responsible_party: Behavioral Health Advisory Council, Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access, Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals with behavioral health disorders and their family members, medical professionals, academic and research professionals, state and local government agencies involved in health, human services, juvenile services, public safety, disabilities, aging, housing, education, and labor, as well as various behavioral health advocacy groups, providers, health insurance carriers, managed care organizations, and participants in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program. Specific populations include geriatric, youth, individuals with developmental disabilities, and the criminal justice-involved population.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily makes structural and procedural changes to existing advisory bodies. However, it explicitly directs the Maryland Department of Health to evaluate and consider applying to the federal "Innovation in Behavioral Health Model," indicating an intent to explore and potentially adopt innovative approaches to behavioral health care at the state level.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not a direct anti-poverty program, the bill's focus on improving access to and quality of behavioral health services, integrating somatic and behavioral health, and ensuring compliance with mental health parity laws within the Maryland Medical Assistance Program has a significant indirect impact on child poverty. Improved access to essential healthcare, particularly for youth and low-income families served by Medicaid, can stabilize family health, reduce financial burdens associated with untreated conditions, and improve long-term well-being and opportunities for children.

Title: Maternal Health – Assessments, Referrals, and Reporting (Maryland Maternal Health Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing requirements on local health departments and certain health care providers and facilities regarding maternal health, including requirements regarding prenatal risk assessment forms and postpartum infant and maternal referral forms; requiring hospitals and freestanding birthing centers to participate in the Severe Maternal Morbidity Surveillance Program to identify risk factors and causes of Severe Maternal Morbidity; requiring the Program to report its findings and recommendations by December 1, 2025;  etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Maryland Maternal Health Act of 2024, establishes new requirements for local health departments, health care providers, and facilities regarding maternal health. It mandates the use of standardized prenatal risk assessment forms and postpartum infant and maternal referral forms, which must be submitted to local health departments. Hospitals and freestanding birthing centers are required to provide specific resources and follow-up calls to birthing parents after high-risk pregnancies. The bill also requires the Secretary of Health, in collaboration with the Maryland Health Care Commission, to develop an annual 'Maryland Report Card for Birthing Facility Maternity Care' to evaluate facilities based on various metrics, including delivery rates, complication rates, and patient input, disaggregated by race and age. Additionally, hospitals and freestanding birthing centers must participate in the Severe Maternal Morbidity Surveillance and Review Program to identify risk factors and causes of severe maternal morbidity and make recommendations for reduction.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health; Secretary of Health; Maryland Health Care Commission; local health departments; Severe Maternal Morbidity Surveillance and Review Program
stakeholders: Pregnant patients, birthing parents, newborns, licensed health care providers, hospitals, freestanding birthing centers, local health departments, and the general public.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces several modern approaches to maternal health monitoring and improvement. It mandates electronic submission of prenatal risk assessment forms, a step towards digital health records and efficient data collection. The creation of a public 'Maryland Report Card for Birthing Facility Maternity Care' with data disaggregated by race and age is innovative as it aims to increase transparency, accountability, and address health disparities directly through public reporting. Enhancing the Severe Maternal Morbidity Surveillance and Review Program to identify contextual drivers and causes of SMM, and requiring facility participation, represents a data-driven approach to quality improvement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving maternal and infant health outcomes through standardized assessments, referrals, and public reporting. While better maternal health can contribute to family stability and reduce healthcare costs, which indirectly supports families and may mitigate factors contributing to child poverty, it does not directly provide financial assistance, childcare, or other poverty-alleviating resources. Its impact on child poverty is therefore indirect, through improved health and potentially reduced long-term health burdens.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - 46th Alcoholic Beverages District - Revisions
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a total of 10 new Class B-D-7 licenses and a total of 2 new Class A-7 licenses within a certain bounded area; providing that, in the 46th alcoholic beverages district in Baltimore City, a certain license may be issued and an existing license may be moved to a building that is within 300 feet of a place of worship or school under certain circumstances; prohibiting the Board from authorizing a license to a recipient of a certain State grant; etc.
bill_summary: This bill revises alcoholic beverage licensing rules in Baltimore City's 46th alcoholic beverages district. It authorizes the Board of License Commissioners to issue a limited number of new Class A–7 and B–D–7 licenses within a specific industrial waterfront area. The bill also modifies conditions for issuing or transferring licenses near schools and places of worship in newly designated neighborhoods, requiring community association Memoranda of Understanding or letters of support. Additionally, it provides temporary extensions and conversion allowances for specific existing licenses and permits the Board to waive certain dining room adjacency requirements for after-hours restaurant operation.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders and applicants in Baltimore City, particularly within the 46th alcoholic beverages district; community associations and residents in the specific bounded areas affected by licensing changes; businesses interested in operating licensed establishments in these areas.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves adjustments to administrative rules and boundaries for alcoholic beverage licensing. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations. The use of Memoranda of Understanding with community associations is a well-established practice for community engagement, not a new innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses exclusively on alcoholic beverage licensing and zoning regulations in Baltimore City. It does not contain any provisions, mechanisms, or explicit goals directly aimed at addressing or impacting child poverty.

Title: State Board of Nursing - Executive Director Qualifications
Synopsis: Altering the qualifications for the executive director of the State Board of Nursing.
bill_summary: This bill removes specific educational and professional experience requirements for the executive director of the State Board of Nursing. Previously, the executive director was required to be a registered nurse with a master's degree in nursing or its equivalent. The bill gives the Board more flexibility in defining the qualifications for this position.
responsible_party: State Board of Nursing
stakeholders: Individuals interested in the Executive Director position for the State Board of Nursing, the State Board of Nursing, the nursing profession, and the public of Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative change to the qualifications for an existing position within state government. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government functions, but rather provides more flexibility to the State Board of Nursing in selecting its executive director.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill alters the qualifications for an administrative position within the State Board of Nursing and has no direct or indirect impact on child poverty.

Title: State Board of Pharmacy - Prohibition on Discrimination Against 340B Drug Distribution
Synopsis: Prohibiting a 340B manufacturer from taking certain direct or indirect  actions to limit or restrict the acquisition or delivery of a 340B drug; making a violation of the Act an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice within the meaning of the Consumer Protection Act; and requiring the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board to conduct a study of the 340B Program and report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly by July 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits 340B manufacturers from taking actions to limit or restrict the acquisition or delivery of 340B drugs by pharmacies under contract with covered entities. Violations are deemed unfair trade practices, subject to investigation by the State Board of Pharmacy or the Consumer Protection Division of the Office of the Attorney General, and may incur civil fines. The bill also requires the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board, in consultation with the Maryland Department of Health, to conduct a study on the 340B Program's implementation, impact, and finances in the State, with a report due by July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Pharmacy, Consumer Protection Division of the Office of the Attorney General, Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board, Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: 340B manufacturers, wholesale drug distributors, third-party logistics providers, covered entities (hospitals, clinics, etc.), pharmacies contracting with covered entities, and patients who receive care from covered entities that utilize the 340B program.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes new regulatory prohibitions and mandates a study on an existing federal drug pricing program. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches, but rather strengthens existing oversight and information gathering.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While the 340B program itself is intended to provide discounted drugs to healthcare organizations that serve vulnerable populations, allowing these entities to reinvest savings into patient care, this bill focuses on regulatory enforcement and a study. Its impact on child poverty is indirect, by potentially improving the financial stability of healthcare providers serving low-income families and ensuring access to affordable medication.

Title: Carroll County – Sheriff – Salary
Synopsis: Increasing the annual salary of the Sheriff of Carroll County to $191,078.10 beginning in 2026 and $212,309 beginning in 2027.
bill_summary: This bill alters the annual salary of the Sheriff of Carroll County. It sets the salary at $140,000 beginning December 5, 2023, then explicitly at $191,078.10 beginning in 2026. For 2030 and every four years thereafter, the salary will be the lesser of the highest step salary for a Department of State Police Lieutenant Colonel or 110% of the Sheriff's previous term's salary. Any changes to the State Police pay plan during a Sheriff's term will not apply to the incumbent but will take effect in the next term of office.
responsible_party: Carroll County government
stakeholders: The Sheriff of Carroll County
innovative_summary: This bill adjusts the salary of a public official using a formula that references the Maryland Department of State Police pay plan. It does not introduce any new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill exclusively addresses the salary of the Sheriff of Carroll County and does not contain any provisions that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: Criminal Organizations - Underlying Crime
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "underlying crime" that is applicable to certain prohibitions against participation in criminal organizations.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of "underlying crime" within the Criminal Organizations law. The expanded definition now includes the common law misdemeanor of misconduct in office, felony fraud and related crimes, specific child pornography violations (§ 11–207 or § 11–208 of the Criminal Law Article), and violations of the Maryland Consumer Protection Act. It also clarifies that using a firearm in the commission of a crime and certain contraband offenses are included as underlying crimes, thereby broadening the scope of activities that can be prosecuted under criminal organization statutes.
responsible_party: Attorney General and State's Attorneys
stakeholders: Individuals involved in criminal organizations, victims of crimes (especially those related to child pornography, fraud, consumer protection, misconduct in office, and firearm use), law enforcement, and the judiciary.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it solely expands legal definitions within existing criminal statutes and does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill expands the definition of "underlying crime" for criminal organizations to include offenses like felony fraud, consumer protection violations, and child pornography. While increased prosecution of these crimes may indirectly protect vulnerable families from exploitation and harm, potentially mitigating some factors contributing to poverty, the bill itself does not offer direct interventions or programs to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Income Tax Subtraction Modification – Death Benefits – Law Enforcement Officers and Fire Fighters
Synopsis: Allowing a subtraction under the Maryland income tax for the payment of a death benefit under a collective bargaining agreement to a spouse or beneficiary of a law enforcement officer or fire fighter whose death arises out of the course of employment; and applying the Act retroactively to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2021.
bill_summary: This bill amends Maryland income tax law to allow a subtraction for certain death benefits paid to a surviving spouse or other beneficiary of a deceased law enforcement officer or fire fighter. Specifically, it expands the existing subtraction to include death benefit payments received under a collective bargaining agreement from a county or municipality in the state. The act is retroactive, applying to all taxable years beginning after December 31, 2021, and took effect as an emergency measure on May 9, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller of the Treasury
stakeholders: Surviving spouses and other beneficiaries of deceased law enforcement officers and firefighters in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill modifies existing income tax law to expand the scope of eligible death benefits for a tax subtraction. This is a standard legislative adjustment to tax policy and does not employ new technologies or approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill provides a tax subtraction for death benefits to specific beneficiaries. While this could potentially increase disposable income for households that include children of deceased law enforcement officers or firefighters, it is a targeted benefit and not directly aimed at broad child poverty reduction efforts.

Title: Public Safety - Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program to assist community organizations, nonprofit entities, and local governments in funding security operations during times of high pedestrian traffic in certain entertainment districts; establishing the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program Fund; authorizing the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2026 and each fiscal year thereafter, to include up to $1,000,000 in the annual budget bill for the Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Entertainment District Security Grant Program and its associated special, nonlapsing fund. The program provides grants to community organizations, nonprofit entities, and local governments to fund security operations during times of high pedestrian traffic in designated entertainment districts that experience a higher than average number of calls for police assistance related to reported crimes.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Community organizations, nonprofit entities, and local governments in Maryland with eligible entertainment districts, as well as residents and patrons of these districts.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a grant funding mechanism to enhance security in specific entertainment districts, which is a conventional method for addressing public safety concerns. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving public safety and security in entertainment districts. While creating safer communities can indirectly benefit residents, including families, the program does not directly provide services, financial aid, or resources specifically targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Income Tax - Opportunity for Filers to Register to Make Anatomical Gift
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller to implement procedures to offer certain income tax return filers the opportunity to register to make an anatomical gift in accordance with the Maryland Revised Uniform Anatomical Gift Act through a hyperlink to the anatomical gift donor registry.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Comptroller to implement new procedures that offer individual income tax return filers the opportunity to register as organ donors. This includes adding an 'Organ Donation' checkoff option on the income tax return form and providing a hyperlink for electronic filers to the anatomical gift donor registry. The Comptroller will then transmit the consenting individual's registration information (driver's license/ID number, name, and date of birth) to the State's contracted organ procurement organization.
responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: Maryland individual income tax filers, individuals awaiting organ transplants, and organ procurement organizations.
innovative_summary: The program leverages existing state infrastructure by integrating organ donor registration into the individual income tax filing process, both through a physical checkoff on forms and a hyperlink for electronic filers. This approach is a novel way to reach a broad segment of the population and potentially increase organ donor registration rates by meeting people where they are already completing essential civic duties.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill facilitates organ donor registration and does not have a direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on public health and civic engagement rather than economic relief or social welfare programs aimed at reducing poverty.

Title: Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing to study and make recommendations regarding certain services, programs, advocacy, outreach efforts, and other items to improve the quality of life of individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by June 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a temporary Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing to study and make recommendations regarding services, programs, advocacy, and outreach efforts aimed at improving the quality of life for individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing. The Workgroup is required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by June 1, 2025. The Act itself will take effect on July 1, 2024, and will be abrogated on June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: Workgroup for the Deaf, Deafblind, and Hard of Hearing, supported by the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
stakeholders: Individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing in Maryland, and State or local nonprofit organizations serving these communities.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a temporary workgroup to study existing issues and make recommendations, which is a standard governmental approach to policy review and development. It does not introduce new technologies or particularly innovative methodologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program establishes a workgroup to study and recommend improvements to educational, employment, health, and social opportunities for individuals who are deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing. While enhanced opportunities could indirectly lead to greater economic stability for these individuals and their families, potentially reducing child poverty, the bill does not directly target child poverty or provide specific anti-poverty interventions. Its impact would be indirect through improved life chances.

Title: Health Insurance - Mental Health and Substance Use Disorder Benefits - Sunset Repeal and Modification of Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Altering certain reporting requirements on health insurance carriers relating to compliance with the federal Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act; altering requirements for certain analyses of nonquantitative treatment limitations required of health insurance carriers; establishing certain remedies the Commissioner may use to enforce compliance with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act and related reporting requirements; repealing the requirement that a certain form be used for the reporting requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies reporting requirements for health insurance carriers regarding compliance with the federal Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act. It alters requirements for analyzing nonquantitative treatment limitations, establishes new enforcement remedies for the Maryland Insurance Commissioner, and shifts the burden of persuasion to health insurance carriers to demonstrate compliance. The bill repeals the requirement for the Commissioner to use a specific federal form for reporting and eliminates the termination date for these reporting requirements, making them permanent. The effective date is April 25, 2024, as an emergency measure.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, individuals with health benefit plans, and members seeking mental health and substance use disorder benefits.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances regulatory oversight and enforcement of existing federal mental health parity laws. While it introduces more stringent reporting, comparative analysis requirements, and stronger enforcement tools for the Commissioner, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather strengthens an existing regulatory framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill does not directly target child poverty. Its focus is on ensuring equitable access to mental health and substance use disorder benefits through health insurance parity. While improved access to these health services could indirectly support the well-being and stability of families, including those experiencing poverty, it does not provide direct financial or programmatic assistance to reduce child poverty.

Title: Education - Blind and Visually Impaired Students - Textbook Equity
Synopsis: Establishing requirements for each county board of education regarding provision of the instructional materials that will be used in the upcoming school year for students with individualized education programs; requiring the county board to coordinate with the Instructional Resources Center to provide the materials in a specialized format to blind or visually impaired students; requiring, beginning January 1, 2025, certain textbook publishers to provide an electronic file of pupil edition textbooks; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes new requirements for county boards of education and the State Department of Education to ensure that blind and visually impaired students receive instructional materials in specialized formats (braille, large print, audio, or digital text) by the first day of the school year. It mandates that textbook publishers provide electronic files of textbooks in the National Instructional Materials Accessibility Standard (NIMAS) format to the National Instructional Materials Access Center (NIMAC) when textbooks are provided to county boards. The bill also requires annual reporting from the Instructional Resources Center to the Department, and from the Department to the Governor and General Assembly, on the accessibility and delivery of these materials.
responsible_party: Each county board of education, the Instructional Resources Center within the State Department of Education, and the State Department of Education.
stakeholders: Blind and visually impaired students in Maryland, their families, and textbook publishers.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances existing educational equity processes by establishing clearer deadlines for county boards to determine instructional materials, mandating timely provision of specialized formats to students, and formalizing annual reporting on accessibility. While it leverages established digital accessibility standards (NIMAS), the innovation lies primarily in the stricter regulatory framework and improved coordination rather than new technologies or governance models.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on ensuring educational equity and access for blind and visually impaired students by providing instructional materials in specialized formats. While improved educational access can lead to better long-term academic and career outcomes, thereby indirectly impacting future economic stability, it does not directly address immediate child poverty through financial assistance, direct aid, or other social welfare programs.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Remote Ultrasound Procedures and Remote Fetal Nonstress Tests
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide remote ultrasound procedures and remote fetal nonstress tests if the patient is in a residence or a location other than the office of the patient's provider and the provider follows the same standard of care that the provider would follow when providing the services on-site.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) to cover remote ultrasound procedures and remote fetal nonstress tests for eligible pregnant women. These services must utilize secure, digital technology compliant with HIPAA and approved by the Federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The program will reimburse for these remote services in the same manner as on-site services, provided the provider follows the same standard of care.
responsible_party: The Secretary of Health (administering the Maryland Medical Assistance Program)
stakeholders: Eligible pregnant women whose family income is at or below 250 percent of the poverty level, and healthcare providers participating in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program.
innovative_summary: The program incorporates the use of digital technology for remote health data collection and secure electronic transmission, requiring FDA-approved solutions and HIPAA compliance for providing medical procedures remotely. This represents a modern approach to healthcare delivery within a state assistance program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By expanding access to prenatal care services, including remote ultrasounds and fetal nonstress tests, for low-income pregnant women, the program can contribute to improved maternal and infant health outcomes. While not a direct financial intervention, ensuring access to quality healthcare for expectant mothers is a critical indirect factor in supporting child well-being and reducing the long-term impacts of poverty.

Title: Public Safety - Automatic License Plate Readers - Captured Plate Data Storage and Upload
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "historical data" to include automatic license plate reader data stored by cloud computing; establishing that certain captured automatic license plate reader data is the property of a certain law enforcement agency and may not be sold for any purpose; establishing that certain captured automatic license plate reader data may be uploaded to the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center; and extending certain penalties for a violation of the Act to a vendor contracted by a law enforcement agency.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland law concerning Automatic License Plate Readers (ALPRs). It expands the definition of "historical data" to include data stored via cloud computing, clarifies that captured plate data is the property of the law enforcement agency and cannot be sold (including subscriptions or licenses), permits data upload to the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center (MCAC), and extends penalties for data misuse to contracted vendors. Additionally, it mandates that law enforcement agencies and the Department of State Police establish procedures for data protection, auditing, personnel screening, and reporting data breaches, especially by vendors, to ensure proper use and security of ALPR data.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police; Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center; local and state law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Law enforcement agencies in Maryland, vendors contracted by these agencies for ALPR services, and the general public whose vehicle license plate data is collected and stored by ALPR systems.
innovative_summary: The bill addresses contemporary issues in data management and privacy by explicitly including cloud computing in data definitions, establishing clear data ownership, restricting data sales by agencies and vendors, and mandating procedures for data breach reporting, especially from third-party vendors. While ALPR technology itself is not new, the focus on modern data governance, cybersecurity, and vendor accountability reflects an innovative approach to regulating existing technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses entirely on the regulation, storage, and access of automatic license plate reader data by law enforcement agencies and their vendors. It does not contain any provisions related to economic support, education, healthcare, or other direct interventions that would impact child poverty.

Title: Blueprint for Maryland's Future Implementation - Funding for Implementation Coordinators
Synopsis: Requiring for each fiscal year each county board of education to provide $150,000 for the salary and benefits of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future implementation coordinator in the county; and requiring the implementation coordinator's salary and benefits to be paid for by the State and the county in a certain proportion.
bill_summary: This bill requires each county board of education to provide $150,000 for the salary and benefits of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future implementation coordinator for fiscal years 2026 and 2027. This funding will be shared by the State and the county in proportion to the foundation program. The bill also amends certain reporting dates related to the independent evaluation of the Blueprint, primarily removing or altering provisions concerning an independent evaluation entity and associated reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland State Government, County Governments, and County Boards of Education
stakeholders: County Boards of Education, local school systems, Blueprint for Maryland's Future implementation coordinators, and public school students and communities in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily makes administrative and funding adjustments to an existing education reform initiative (the Blueprint for Maryland's Future). It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the administrative funding for an implementation coordinator role within a broader education reform. While the overall Blueprint for Maryland's Future aims to improve education, which could indirectly impact child poverty, this specific bill's direct impact on child poverty is negligible as it addresses an administrative function rather than direct poverty alleviation.

Title: Alcoholic Beverages - Class 4 Limited Winery License - Requirements and Authorizations
Synopsis: Altering certain cultivation or production requirements applicable to a holder of a Class 4 limited winery license by basing them on certain agricultural products instead of grapes and other fruit; and altering the standards for the purchase of certain wine by a license holder.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the requirements for Class 4 limited winery licenses in Maryland. It changes cultivation and production requirements to be based on "Maryland-grown agricultural products" instead of solely grapes and other fruit. License holders must either own or contract 20 acres of Maryland-grown agricultural products or ensure at least 51% of their annual wine ingredients are Maryland-grown, with potential exemptions from the Secretary of Agriculture. The bill also alters the standards for purchasing wine by a license holder, specifying it must be finished wine made entirely of Maryland-grown agricultural products, and removes the previous authorization for license holders to blend purchased wine with their own. Additionally, it expands the list of food items that limited wineries can prepare, sell, or serve.
responsible_party: Secretary of Agriculture, Executive Director (Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis), and the Comptroller
stakeholders: Class 4 limited winery license holders, Maryland farmers who produce agricultural products, and consumers of Maryland wines and pomace brandy.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative and regulatory changes to existing alcoholic beverage licensing rules, primarily by redefining ingredient sourcing and sales authorizations for wineries. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on regulating alcoholic beverage licenses and agricultural product sourcing for wineries. There is no direct or intended mechanism within the bill to address child poverty.

Title: Compensation for Individuals Erroneously Convicted - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain benefits that a certain individual who has been erroneously convicted of a crime is entitled to receive; requiring the State to notify a certain individual of certain information in writing under certain circumstances when the State intends to reduce or prevent an award of compensation to the individual; and repealing obsolete provisions of law relating to the filing of a certain petition for compensation.
bill_summary: This bill alters the compensation and benefits available to individuals in Maryland who have been erroneously convicted and confined. It modifies the types and durations of benefits, such as extending housing accommodations to 5 years and access to higher education to 8 years. It clarifies eligibility criteria, including individuals convicted of conspiracy to commit a felony, and revises how prior civil awards or settlements impact compensation. The bill also establishes a notification requirement for the State when intending to reduce or prevent a compensation award and repeals obsolete provisions regarding petition filing deadlines.
responsible_party: Board of Public Works, Office of Administrative Hearings, Attorney General, and relevant State agencies
stakeholders: Individuals erroneously convicted, sentenced, and confined under State law for crimes they did not commit, and their estates.
innovative_summary: The bill does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches. It refines and expands an existing compensation and benefits scheme for wrongfully convicted individuals, focusing on improving fairness, clarity, and the scope of support provided. The changes are largely procedural and augmentative rather than innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on providing compensation and re-entry support (housing, education, healthcare, job training) to erroneously convicted adults. While these benefits can stabilize households and indirectly benefit any dependent children, potentially alleviating child poverty within those specific families, the program is not directly targeted at children or families experiencing poverty. The impact on child poverty would be secondary and indirect.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Class B Beer, Wine, and Liquor Licenses
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a Class B beer, wine, and liquor license in a certain area; and establishing the requirements for a holder of the license.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue Class B beer, wine, and liquor licenses to restaurants located in Ward 4, Precincts 1 and 2 of the Downtown Management District. To qualify, restaurants must have at least 51% of daily receipts from food sales, be classified as a high or moderate priority food service facility by the Baltimore City Health Department, and have a Memorandum of Understanding with the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore. The licenses cannot be transferred and new licenses will not be issued after June 30, 2028, though existing ones may be renewed.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
stakeholders: Restaurants located in Ward 4, Precincts 1 and 2 of the Baltimore City Downtown Management District, the Baltimore City Health Department, and the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore.
innovative_summary: This bill modifies existing alcoholic beverage licensing regulations for a specific geographic area and type of establishment within Baltimore City. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services, but rather fine-tunes a regulatory framework.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill concerns the issuance of alcoholic beverage licenses to restaurants and has no direct provisions or mechanisms to address or alleviate child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, through general economic activity or employment, not a direct focus of the bill.

Title: 9-1-1 Trust Fund - Purposes - Training in Telecommunications Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation
Synopsis: Altering the purposes of the 9-1-1 Trust Fund to including funding the costs of telecommunications cardiopulmonary resuscitation training.
bill_summary:
This bill alters the purposes of the Maryland 9
1
1 Trust Fund to include funding the costs of telecommunications cardiopulmonary resuscitation (T-CPR) training for public safety answering point personnel. The T-CPR training must adhere to the most current nationally recognized emergency cardiovascular care guidelines, include recognition protocols for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, and provide continuing instruction on compression-only cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
responsible_party:
Maryland 9
1
1 Board
stakeholders: Public safety answering point personnel and individuals who experience out-of-hospital cardiac arrest and call 9-1-1.
innovative_summary: This bill enhances existing emergency response protocols by ensuring funding for specialized telecommunications CPR training for 9-1-1 dispatchers. While it improves service delivery, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides specialized training for 9-1-1 personnel to improve emergency response for cardiac arrest. While improved emergency services can benefit all members of the public, including children, it does not directly address the systemic causes or immediate needs related to child poverty such as financial aid, food security, housing, or specific educational support for low-income families.

Title: Anne Arundel County - Human Relations Commission - Subpoena Enforcement
Synopsis: Authorizing the Human Relations Commission of Anne Arundel County to apply to a circuit court in any county to seek relief if a party fails to comply with a subpoena.
bill_summary: This bill grants the Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission enhanced authority to enforce its subpoenas. If a person fails to obey a subpoena, the Commission may apply to a Circuit Court for an order compelling attendance and testimony of witnesses or the production of documents. The court may then issue such an order, and failure to obey the court's order may be punished as contempt of court. This act takes effect on October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission
stakeholders: The Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission and individuals or entities subpoenaed by the Commission in Anne Arundel County.
innovative_summary: This bill makes procedural changes to the subpoena enforcement powers of a county human relations commission. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government functions, but rather strengthens existing legal mechanisms for compliance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses the procedural enforcement powers of the Anne Arundel County Human Relations Commission's subpoenas. While the Commission's work may broadly relate to human rights, this specific bill's changes to subpoena enforcement are administrative and legal, and do not directly establish programs or provide resources that would impact child poverty.

Title: State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners - Veterinary Technicians and Veterinary Assistants
Synopsis: Authorizing a veterinary assistant to perform certain tasks under the immediate or direct supervision of a veterinary practitioner or a veterinary technician under the direct supervision of a veterinary practitioner; and authorizing a veterinary technician to perform certain procedures, including certain emergency procedures and euthanasia, if the veterinary practitioner determines the veterinary technician is qualified to perform the procedures.
bill_summary: This bill updates the regulations for veterinary assistants and veterinary technicians in Maryland. It defines different levels of supervision (direct, immediate, indirect) and specifies tasks and procedures that veterinary assistants can perform under supervision. It also expands the scope of practice for veterinary technicians to include certain procedures like inducing anesthesia, simple dental extractions, basic suturing, emergency life support, and euthanasia under specific conditions. Additionally, it clarifies the qualifications for veterinary technicians, recognizing an alternative pathway for existing veterinary assistants to become technicians until October 1, 2027, in accordance with Board regulations.
responsible_party: State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners
stakeholders: Veterinary practitioners (veterinarians), veterinary technicians, veterinary assistants, animal emergency hospitals, animal shelters, and animal owners.
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes the scope of practice for veterinary support staff and clarifies supervision requirements, aligning roles with current industry practices and educational standards. While it updates definitions and expands task allowances, it does not introduce fundamentally new technologies or approaches to government, but rather refines existing regulations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the regulation of veterinary professionals and their scope of practice. There is no direct link or explicit mechanism within the bill to address or impact child poverty. Any potential impact would be indirect and negligible, such as very slight shifts in veterinary care costs, which are too far removed to be considered direct.

Title: Standing - Environmental and Natural Resources Protection Proceedings (Clean Water Justice Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Providing certain persons standing in environmental and natural resources protection proceedings; authorizing persons that meet standing requirements to bring certain civil actions under certain circumstances; requiring a plaintiff, under certain circumstances, to give certain notice and provide certain documentation to the Department of the Environment and the Attorney General and to file a certain affidavit; authorizing a court to grant certain relief, award certain costs, and impose certain civil penalties; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Clean Water Justice Act of 2024, expands the standing rights for individuals and associations in environmental and natural resources protection proceedings in Maryland. It defines 'injury in fact' to include negative impacts to health or the use and enjoyment of natural resources. The bill allows persons and associations meeting federal standing requirements to bring civil actions against alleged violators of environmental standards, provided they give 60 days' notice to the appropriate Secretary, the Attorney General, local jurisdictions, and the alleged violator. It outlines conditions under which an action cannot be brought (e.g., if the Secretary is diligently prosecuting) and allows for intervention in civil actions brought by the Secretary. Courts may grant equitable relief, impose conditions to protect natural resources, award litigation costs to prevailing parties, and impose civil penalties or approve supplemental environmental projects.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment (Secretary), Attorney General, Maryland Circuit Courts, and local governments.
stakeholders: Individuals, associations, corporations, and other nongovernmental entities affected by environmental and natural resource issues; alleged violators of environmental standards (persons or political subdivisions); the State (Department of the Environment, Attorney General); and local governments.
innovative_summary: This bill is innovative in its approach to environmental governance by expanding legal standing for private citizens and associations. It empowers the public to initiate civil actions against environmental standard violators and intervene in state-led cases, thereby democratizing access to environmental justice and augmenting enforcement capabilities beyond traditional government agencies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on environmental protection and legal standing, without any direct provisions for addressing child poverty. While improved environmental quality can have indirect benefits on public health and community well-being, potentially easing burdens on low-income families, it does not establish programs, services, or financial support mechanisms explicitly designed to reduce child poverty.

Title: Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program in the Maryland Department of Aging; establishing that the purpose and the goals of the Pilot Program are to support the "village" concept of local, volunteer-led organizations that aim to provide certain services to community members who choose to age in place and to expand those services to more residents in the geographic region; and requiring the Montgomery County Village Consortium to establish a certain plan and submit certain reports.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Miriam Kelty Aging and Senior Social Connection Hub and Spoke Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Aging. The program aims to learn, test, and develop best practices for administering 'Villages' (local, volunteer-led organizations supporting seniors aging in place) using a hub and spoke model. Its purpose is to centralize administrative tasks, coordinate resources, help develop new villages, and build social connections to combat loneliness among seniors. The Montgomery County Village Consortium is selected to implement the 3-year pilot program, receive an annual appropriation, and submit reports on its progress and best practices.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
stakeholders: Seniors aging in place, local volunteer-led organizations (Villages) that support seniors, and the Montgomery County Village Consortium.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes a 'hub and spoke' model to centralize administration and support for existing and emerging volunteer-led organizations (Villages) that assist seniors aging in place.
