This approach aims to improve efficiency, coordinate resources, and expand services by leveraging a central hub, which is an innovative way to scale and professionalize community-based, volunteer-driven senior support networks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program focuses entirely on supporting seniors aging in place and fostering social connections among them. There is no direct mechanism or stated goal within the bill that would impact child poverty. Any potential impact would be highly indirect, such as alleviating financial or caregiving burdens on younger family members who might otherwise support these seniors, but this is not a direct effect on child poverty.

Title: Advanced Practice Registered Nurses - Certification Requirement and Exceptions
Synopsis: Requiring an individual, subject to certain exceptions, to be certified as an advanced practice registered nurse before practicing advanced practice registered nursing in the State.
bill_summary: This bill requires individuals to be certified as Advanced Practice Registered Nurses (APRNs) before practicing in Maryland. It amends the Health Occupations Article to include APRNs in the existing regulatory framework for registered and licensed practical nurses, outlining specific exceptions to this certification requirement for groups such as students in accredited graduate-level APRN programs, federal employees, and individuals authorized by the Board under specific circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Nursing
stakeholders: Advanced Practice Registered Nurses (APRNs) in Maryland, students pursuing APRN degrees, and the patients they serve.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory update that mandates certification for Advanced Practice Registered Nurses. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather formalizes existing practice into law by updating licensure requirements for a specific medical profession. Therefore, it is not innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's direct impact on child poverty is very low. It focuses on the certification requirements for Advanced Practice Registered Nurses, which is a regulatory change in the healthcare sector. While qualified healthcare professionals contribute to community well-being, this bill does not include provisions for direct financial aid, specific programs targeting children in poverty, or economic support for families.

Title: Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact - City of Frederick
Synopsis: Authorizing the City of Frederick to participate in the Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the City of Frederick to become a participating jurisdiction in the Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact. This allows the City of Frederick to request and provide mutual assistance for emergency management with other counties and cities already part of the compact.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Emergency Management; City of Frederick; other participating jurisdictions
stakeholders: The City of Frederick, its residents, and all other jurisdictions participating in the Maryland Intrastate Emergency Management Assistance Compact.
innovative_summary: This bill expands participation in an existing emergency management compact. It does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government, but rather broadens the scope of a well-established inter-jurisdictional mutual aid system.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill enhances emergency preparedness and response capabilities for the City of Frederick by allowing it to participate in a mutual aid compact. While improved emergency response can indirectly benefit all residents, including families with children in poverty by ensuring safety and quicker recovery from disasters, it does not directly address the root causes of child poverty or provide specific programs for children in poverty.

Title: County Boards of Education – Budgets – Notice (Transparency in Education Spending Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Education to adopt a process for the uniform and timely reporting of certain county board of education budget information to a county governing body; requiring a county board to post certain budget information on the county board's public-facing website, in an easily identifiable location; requiring a certain audit to be sent to the county council or the county commissioners; etc.
bill_summary: The "Transparency in Education Spending Act" requires the State Board of Education to establish a uniform process for county boards of education to report budget information to their respective county governing bodies. It mandates that county boards post their budget submissions, approved budgets, audit results, and certain operational reports on their public-facing websites to increase transparency in education spending.
responsible_party: State Board of Education; County Boards of Education
stakeholders: County Boards of Education, county governing bodies (county commissioners, county councils, county executives), the State Board of Education, the State Superintendent, various legislative committees, and the general public interested in education spending.
innovative_summary: The program enhances transparency in education spending by requiring a uniform reporting process for county board budgets and mandating that detailed budget information, approved budgets, and operational reports be publicly posted on county board websites. This approach leverages digital platforms for greater public access and accountability in educational finance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on increasing financial transparency and accountability in education budgets. It does not directly establish programs or allocate funds specifically aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be indirect, through improved resource allocation within schools serving disadvantaged populations, but this is not a primary or direct mechanism of the bill.

Title: Business Regulation - Restaurants and Traders - Licensing Requirements
Synopsis: Altering an exception for licensed restaurants to the requirement that a person who does business as a trader or an exhibitor have a trader's license to apply only to restaurants that generate 10% or less of their annual sales from nonfood items.
bill_summary: This bill alters the licensing requirements for restaurants in Maryland. Previously, licensed restaurants were generally exempt from needing a trader's license. This bill changes that exemption so it *only* applies to restaurants that generate 10% or less of their annual sales from nonfood items. Restaurants exceeding this threshold will now require a trader's license.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor (or relevant state licensing authority)
stakeholders: Restaurants operating in Maryland, especially those currently licensed under Subtitle 16 of the Business Regulation Article that derive more than 10% of their annual sales from nonfood items.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative change to existing business licensing requirements, clarifying and narrowing an exemption for restaurants regarding trader's licenses. It does not involve new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses solely on business licensing regulations for restaurants. It has no direct provisions, services, or interventions aimed at addressing or impacting child poverty.

Title: Landlord and Tenant - Failure to Repair Serious and Dangerous Defects - Tenant Remedies (Tenant Safety Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing that a landlord that offers a residential dwelling unit for rent is deemed to warrant the dwelling fit for human habitation; authorizing multiple tenants to join as plaintiffs in a civil action against a landlord and authorizing a court to issue an order for separate trials or other orders necessary to prevent delay or avoid prejudice; providing that a court may order certain relief in civil actions relating to the breach of warranty of habitability, including actual damages, abatement of rent, and lease termination; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Tenant Safety Act of 2024, establishes that landlords warrant dwelling units are fit for human habitation. It enhances tenant remedies for serious and dangerous defects by allowing multiple tenants to join lawsuits, creating rebuttable presumptions for rent abatement and limiting rent escrow payments to 50% of rent due *after* a court order, and authorizing the award of attorney's fees and litigation expenses to prevailing tenants. It also outlines landlord defenses and allows courts to order actual damages, rent abatement, lease termination, return of security deposits, and relocation expenses for tenants. Additionally, it specifies conditions under which a landlord may recover attorney's fees if a tenant's complaint is found to be in bad faith.
responsible_party: Maryland Court System
stakeholders: Residential tenants throughout Maryland, especially those living in dwellings with serious and dangerous defects, and landlords of residential dwelling units in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily strengthens existing legal protections for tenants and clarifies legal processes. While enhancing access to justice is valuable, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new government approaches beyond refining existing legal frameworks. The introduction of specific rebuttable presumptions and explicit allowance for multi-tenant actions streamlines legal processes but is not highly innovative in a technological or novel governmental design sense.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill could have an indirect positive impact on child poverty by improving housing conditions for low-income families and potentially reducing housing-related financial burdens. By allowing for rent abatement, termination of leases, and recovery of relocation expenses and attorney's fees, it can help families avoid living in unsafe conditions and potentially recover funds or reduce housing costs, thereby mitigating financial strain. However, it does not directly provide income support or specific services targeting child poverty.

Title: Harford County – Alcoholic Beverages – Performing Arts Theater License
Synopsis: Altering eligibility for a performing arts theater license in Harford County by altering the definition of "performing arts theater" and authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Harford County to issue the license to a certain for-profit theater, rather than a nonprofit theater; authorizing the holder of the license to sell liquor for on-premises consumption in addition to beer and wine; and altering the license fee from $500 to $1,500.
bill_summary: This bill alters the eligibility for a performing arts theater alcoholic beverage license in Harford County, allowing for-profit theaters to obtain the license instead of only nonprofit theaters. It expands the types of alcoholic beverages that can be sold to include liquor, in addition to beer and wine, for on-premises consumption. The bill also increases the annual license fee from $500 to $1,500 and refines the definition of 'performing arts theater'.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Harford County
stakeholders: For-profit performing arts theaters in Harford County, patrons of these theaters who consume alcoholic beverages, and authorized and licensed alcoholic beverage wholesalers.
innovative_summary: This bill updates existing regulations for an alcoholic beverage license, expanding eligibility and sale options. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches to public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is focused on alcoholic beverage licensing for performing arts theaters and has no direct provisions or mechanisms that would impact child poverty.

Title: Maryland Health Care Commission – Nursing Homes – Acquisitions
Synopsis: Requiring a person, at least 60 days before the closing date of the acquisition of a nursing home, to submit a request for acquisition to the Maryland Health Care Commission and provide certain notice to residents, resident representatives, and employees of the nursing home; establishing requirements regarding the approval or denial of a request for acquisition of a nursing home; providing for judicial review of a final decision of the Commission regarding a request for acquisition of a nursing home; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires anyone planning to acquire a nursing home in Maryland to submit a request for acquisition to the Maryland Health Care Commission (MHCC) and notify residents, resident representatives, and staff at least 60 days before the closing date. The MHCC will review the request, considering its consistency with the State Health Plan, its potential for more efficient and effective health care services, and the public interest. The public interest evaluation includes soliciting comments from residents, their families, and staff, and consulting with the Attorney General. The MHCC will also evaluate the past quality performance of nursing homes owned or operated by the acquirer. Additionally, the bill mandates that acquired nursing homes reduce the number of resident rooms with more than two beds, or obtain a waiver. Persons acquiring nursing homes must submit annual reports to the Commission for three years post-acquisition. The bill also establishes judicial review for the MHCC's final decisions.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission
stakeholders: Nursing home owners, operators, and potential acquirers; nursing home residents, their family members and representatives; and nursing home staff employees.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances regulatory oversight by requiring pre-acquisition review, public input from residents and staff, and consideration of the acquiring entity's past quality performance. It also introduces a mandate for reducing multi-bed rooms in nursing homes. While these measures strengthen existing regulatory processes and improve resident welfare, they do not introduce fundamentally new technologies or government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the regulation of nursing home acquisitions and the quality of care provided to residents, who are primarily elderly or adult. There is no direct provision or intent within the bill to address child poverty. Any potential impact would be extremely indirect, such as if improved nursing home stability indirectly affects the employment of parents working in the facility, which is outside the bill's direct scope.

Title: Certified Nursing Assistants - Licensing Requirements and Administrative Updates
Synopsis: Exempting an individual who practices as a certain nursing assistant for less than 4 months under federal regulations from the State's certification requirement; altering the designation of, and licensure requirements for, certified nursing assistants and geriatric nursing assistants; requiring an applicant for certification as a certified nursing assistant to complete a nursing assistant competency evaluation; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates the licensing requirements and administrative processes for certified nursing assistants (CNAs) in Maryland. It replaces the 'geriatric nursing assistant' designation with new categories: 'Certified Nursing Assistant–I' (authorized to practice in any setting) and 'Certified Nursing Assistant–II' (restricted from nursing facilities unless approved as CNA–I). The bill outlines new requirements for certification, including a nursing assistant competency evaluation, and allows certain acute care nursing assistant training programs to request waivers for federal instructor experience requirements. It also exempts individuals practicing as CNA-Is for less than four months under federal regulations from state certification and mandates the State Board of Nursing to update regulations and notify certified individuals.
responsible_party: State Board of Nursing
stakeholders: Certified nursing assistants, geriatric nursing assistants, aspiring nursing assistants, nursing homes, individuals receiving care in nursing facilities, dialysis technicians, medication technicians, and nursing assistant training programs.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modernizes administrative and licensing categories for nursing assistants. It mentions standards for the online provision of didactic instruction, which represents a minor update in educational delivery methods, but does not introduce significant new technologies or approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential for direct impact on child poverty is very low. It focuses on the professional licensing of healthcare support staff. While improved regulation and a streamlined certification process could indirectly contribute to a more stable workforce and better healthcare services, it does not provide direct financial assistance, housing support, or specific programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Sexual Assault Forensic Examinations Conducted Through Telehealth - Reimbursement and Study
Synopsis: Authorizing the reimbursement of a sexual assault forensic exam conducted through peer-to-peer telehealth under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee to conduct a study on the feasibility of a telehealth program that includes a pilot program for conducting sexual assault forensic examinations through telehealth; and requiring the Committee to report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the reimbursement of sexual assault forensic examinations conducted through peer-to-peer telehealth. It also requires the Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee to conduct a study on the feasibility of establishing a telehealth program, including a pilot program (TeleSAFE Pilot Program), for conducting these examinations. The committee must report its findings and recommendations by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Sexual Assault Evidence Kit Policy and Funding Committee
stakeholders: Victims of alleged rape, sexual offense, or child sexual abuse; forensic nurse examiners; qualified health care providers; hospitals; and the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces and promotes the use of "peer-to-peer telehealth" for sexual assault forensic examinations. This is an innovative application of telehealth technology, aiming to enhance access to specialized forensic expertise and services, potentially in remote or underserved areas, by allowing a forensic nurse examiner to assist in an examination from a different location.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving access to and reimbursement for sexual assault forensic examinations, including for child victims of sexual abuse. While sexual assault can have profound and long-lasting impacts that may indirectly affect a child's well-being and a family's economic stability, the bill does not provide direct interventions for alleviating child poverty, such as financial aid, educational support, or housing assistance.

Title: Labor and Employment – Workforce Development – Talent Innovation Program and Fund
Synopsis: Establishing the Talent Innovation Program in the Maryland Department of Labor to increase access to high-quality job training by using innovative and sustainable talent financing mechanisms to help meet skill needs in the State's prominent and emerging industry sectors; and requiring the Department, beginning on January 1, 2025, and each January 1 thereafter, to report to the Governor, the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House on Program activities and use of the Talent Innovation Fund.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Talent Innovation Program and Fund within the Maryland Department of Labor. The program aims to increase access to high-quality job training using innovative and sustainable talent financing mechanisms like "pay-it-forward" and pay-for-performance models. It targets skill needs in prominent and emerging industry sectors such as cybersecurity, health care, biotechnology, manufacturing, and artificial intelligence, and includes an initial pilot focusing on cybersecurity training through regional cyber ranges.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor, specifically the Division of Workforce Development and Adult Learning, the Governor's Workforce Development Board, and the Secretary of the Department.
stakeholders: Maryland residents seeking high-quality job training; employers, institutions of higher education, tax-exempt organizations, public agencies, local workforce development boards, and registered apprenticeship sponsors in sectors such as cybersecurity, health care, biotechnology, manufacturing, and artificial intelligence.
innovative_summary: The program is explicitly designed to use "innovative and sustainable talent financing mechanisms" including a "pay-it-forward" revolving-door funding model and pay-for-performance programs. It also allows for conducting pilots and research to develop new financing approaches, with an initial pilot focused on expanding regional cyber ranges for cybersecurity talent development, indicating a modern and forward-thinking approach to workforce development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's focus on increasing access to high-quality job training for adults has the potential to indirectly impact child poverty by improving adult employment opportunities and wages. This can lead to greater economic stability for families with children. However, it does not provide direct financial assistance or services specifically targeted at children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Hospitals and Related Institutions – Residential Treatment Centers – Accreditation
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "accredited residential treatment center" for certain provisions of law governing hospitals and related institutions to include residential treatment centers accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities or the Council on Accreditation.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of an "accredited residential treatment center" in Maryland law to include centers accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) or the Council on Accreditation (COA), in addition to the previously recognized Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations. This change affects how these centers are regulated and inspected by the Department of Health.
responsible_party: The Department (referring to the Maryland Department of Health)
stakeholders: Residential treatment centers, patients receiving care in these centers, and accreditation organizations.
innovative_summary: The bill is not innovative. It is an administrative update that expands the list of recognized accreditation bodies for residential treatment centers, standardizing regulatory oversight by acknowledging more widely used accreditation standards. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to have a direct impact on child poverty is extremely low. It focuses on administrative changes to the definition of "accredited residential treatment center." While these centers may serve children, and quality care is important, the bill does not provide direct financial aid, services, or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Growing Family Child Care Opportunities Pilot Program – Permanent Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Growing Family Child Care Opportunities Pilot Program as a permanent program; and extending the appropriation that the Governor is required to make in the annual budget bill to the Program to fiscal year 2026.
bill_summary: This bill permanently establishes the Growing Family Child Care Opportunities Program, which provides annual grants to local jurisdictions and child care licensing regions in Maryland. The program aims to increase the supply and ensure the sustainability of family child care providers, particularly in areas with high poverty, high unemployment, or a shortage of available child care. Grants are used to recruit new providers through multilingual outreach, offer technical assistance, provide financial incentives, and give start-up assistance for materials, curriculum, and renovations. The program also helps providers achieve quality benchmarks and business sustainability.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education in partnership with the Maryland Child Care Resource Network
stakeholders: Family child care providers (current and prospective), children under 13 (or developmentally disabled individuals under 21), parents, local jurisdictions, and child care resource centers, with a specific focus on areas experiencing above-average rates of poverty and unemployment or a lack of available child care providers.
innovative_summary: The program primarily utilizes traditional grant funding and technical assistance models to address child care shortages. It focuses on outreach, support, and financial incentives for providers but does not incorporate new technologies or significantly innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty by explicitly targeting areas with above-average rates of poverty and unemployment. By increasing the availability and sustainability of family child care, it helps remove a significant barrier to employment for parents, allowing them to work or pursue education, thereby directly contributing to household income stability and poverty reduction. Access to quality child care also supports early childhood development.

Title: Emergency Medical Services - Maryland Emergency Department Wait Time Reduction Commission - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Emergency Department Wait Time Reduction Commission to address factors throughout the health care system that contribute to increased emergency department wait times; authorizing the Commission to request data from certain entities; and requiring the Commission, beginning November 1, 2025, to report annually to the Governor and General Assembly on its activities and findings including updates on the development, impact and, implementation of the recommended programs on emergency department wait times.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Emergency Department Wait Time Reduction Commission to address factors throughout the health care system that contribute to increased emergency department wait times. The Commission will develop strategies and initiatives, including those focused on ensuring patients are seen in appropriate settings, improving hospital efficiency and inpatient throughput, and enhancing post-discharge resources. It will identify and recommend improvements for data collection, facilitate the sharing of best practices, and submit annual reports on its activities, findings, and recommendations.
responsible_party: Maryland Emergency Department Wait Time Reduction Commission, co-chaired by the Secretary of Health and the Executive Director of the Health Services Cost Review Commission
stakeholders: Patients, hospitals, emergency department staff, emergency medical professionals, local emergency medical services, managed care plans, advanced primary care practices, the Maryland Hospital Association, patient advocacy organizations, behavioral health providers, and various State and local health agencies.
innovative_summary: The program employs a collaborative, data-driven approach to tackle a complex systemic issue (emergency department wait times) by bringing together various healthcare stakeholders and state agencies. While not introducing new technology, its multi-faceted strategy of data collection, recommendation development, and best practice sharing across the health system represents a structured and coordinated governance innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to improve the efficiency and access to emergency medical services for all Maryland residents. While improved healthcare access and efficiency can indirectly benefit all populations, including children in poverty, the bill does not contain specific provisions or direct interventions targeted at reducing child poverty.

Title: Environment - Playground Surfacing Materials - Prohibitions
Synopsis: Prohibiting, on or after October 1, 2024, a person from installing, supplying, selling, soliciting, or offering for sale playground surfacing materials that contain a certain concentration of lead or a component product, material, or substance to which PFAS chemicals were previously intentionally added for certain purposes; prohibiting a county, municipality, or unit of local government from adopting any ordinance, rule, or regulation related to playground surfacing materials that is less stringent than of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the installation, supply, sale, or offering for sale of playground surfacing materials in Maryland that contain more than 90 parts per million of lead, intentionally added PFAS chemicals, or more than 20 milligrams per kilogram of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH). These prohibitions take effect on or after October 1, 2024. The bill also prevents local governments from adopting less stringent regulations regarding these materials and requires manufacturers to establish and provide a certificate of compliance to the Department of the Environment upon request.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Children using public playgrounds, manufacturers, suppliers, and sellers of playground surfacing materials, and local governments in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes new regulations to prohibit specific harmful chemicals like lead, PFAS, and PAH in playground surfacing materials. While the focus on these specific chemicals in the context of playgrounds is a positive step for public health, the approach of prohibition and compliance certification is a standard regulatory method and does not employ new technologies or particularly innovative governance approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to improve public health and safety for all children using playgrounds by eliminating hazardous chemicals from surfacing materials. While this benefits all children, including those from low-income families, it does not directly address the economic factors of child poverty such as income, housing, or food security. The impact is indirect through improved health and reduced exposure to environmental hazards.

Title: Maryland Uniform Disposition of Abandoned Property Act – Maryland 529 Program – Exemption
Synopsis: Exempting certain accounts under the Maryland 529 Program from the provisions of the Maryland Uniform Disposition of Abandoned Property Act.
bill_summary: This bill exempts certain accounts within the Maryland 529 Program, which are college savings plans, from the provisions of the Maryland Uniform Disposition of Abandoned Property Act. This means these specific 529 accounts will not be presumed abandoned and escheated to the state.
responsible_party: Maryland 529 Program
stakeholders: Individuals, particularly families and students, who hold or are beneficiaries of accounts under the Maryland 529 Program.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory adjustment that exempts certain college savings accounts from abandoned property laws. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches; it's a modification to existing legal frameworks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill indirectly supports families with college savings by ensuring their Maryland 529 accounts are not seized as abandoned property. While preserving these assets can benefit any family, including those with limited means who are saving for college, this bill does not directly provide new financial aid or support to address child poverty.

Title: Environment – Water Pollution Control – Protecting State Waters From PFAS Pollution (Protecting State Waters From PFAS Pollution Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment to identify significant industrial users that currently and intentionally use PFAS chemicals by July 1, 2026; requiring the Department to develop certain PFAS monitoring and testing criteria for certain significant industrial users by January 1, 2025; requiring the Department by June 1, 2025, to develop PFAS action levels for addressing PFAS contamination from industrial discharge for pretreatment permits; requiring the Department to develop mitigation plans by September 1, 2025; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the "Protecting State Waters From PFAS Pollution Act," requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to identify significant industrial users of PFAS chemicals, develop monitoring and testing protocols for them, and establish PFAS action levels and mitigation plans for pretreatment permits. Significant industrial users are required to measure and report PFAS levels in their industrial wastewater, reduce PFAS chemicals in discharged water to no more than 4 parts per trillion, and safely store and dispose of captured PFAS chemicals using approved methods, prohibiting disposal at solid waste landfills or incineration. The bill also mandates an update to the Department's PFAS Action Plan by December 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Significant industrial users in Maryland, publicly owned treatment works, and the general public (benefiting from reduced PFAS pollution in State waters).
innovative_summary: The program addresses the emerging environmental challenge of PFAS pollution by establishing specific monitoring, testing, and reduction requirements for industrial discharges. Setting a discharge limit of 4 parts per trillion for PFAS chemicals and mandating approved disposal methods, while prohibiting traditional landfilling or incineration for stored PFAS, reflects a modern approach to managing these persistent contaminants.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on environmental protection by regulating industrial discharge of PFAS chemicals into State waters. While environmental health can indirectly affect communities, including those with children experiencing poverty, the bill does not directly establish programs or provide resources specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Hospitals - Opioid Overdose and Opioid-Related Emergency Medical Conditions - Treatment
Synopsis: Requiring hospitals to establish and maintain certain protocols and capacity related to the treatment of patients who are being treated for an opioid-related overdose or opioid-related emergency medical condition; requiring hospitals to make a referral for patients who are diagnosed with opioid use disorder or administered or prescribed medication for opioid use disorder to an appropriate provider to voluntarily continue treatment in the community and work with peer support professionals for a certain purpose; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires hospitals in Maryland to establish and maintain protocols and capacity for treating patients who present with opioid-related overdoses or emergency medical conditions. These protocols must include providing evidence-based interventions, possessing and prescribing medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD), and making referrals to appropriate community-based providers for ongoing treatment. Hospitals must also work with peer support professionals to help patients access these services. The Governor is required to include a $500,000 appropriation from the Opioid Restitution Fund in the Fiscal Year 2026 budget to provide training and resources to hospitals for implementing these requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Hospitals (for implementation); Maryland Department of Health (for oversight and setting requirements); Governor's Office (for budget appropriation)
stakeholders: Patients experiencing opioid-related overdoses or emergency medical conditions, individuals diagnosed with opioid use disorder, and Maryland hospitals.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates the adoption of established evidence-based interventions and medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) across hospitals, along with referrals to community-based treatment and engagement with peer support professionals. While these are crucial and effective clinical practices, the bill focuses on standardizing and mandating their implementation rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill addresses the treatment of opioid use disorder, which can indirectly impact families and children by improving the health and stability of parents struggling with substance use. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance, educational programs, or other services specifically targeted at alleviating child poverty. The impact on child poverty is secondary and indirect.

Title: Grow Your Own Educators Grant Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Grow Your Own Educators Grant Program to provide grants to local school systems for employees who pledge to fulfill a certain service obligation as a full-time teacher in the State; requiring the State Department of Education to administer the Program and to take certain actions to develop and implement the Program; establishing the eligibility for certain teacher candidates in the Program and requiring teacher candidates to be paid a certain rate and offered certain benefits under the Program; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Grow Your Own Educators Grant Program, administered by the State Department of Education. The program provides grants to local school systems to support noncertified education support professionals and provisional teachers who wish to become full-time teachers in Maryland. Eligible individuals must commit to a service obligation in high-needs schools or subject areas. The program covers tuition, books, and fees for teacher candidates, provides stipends for mentor teachers, and covers administrative costs. It emphasizes recruiting racially and linguistically diverse candidates and requires data collection and reporting on program participants and outcomes.
responsible_party: State Department of Education
stakeholders: Noncertified education support professionals, provisional teachers, local school systems, institutions of higher education, union employee organizations, mentor teachers, and ultimately students in high-needs schools.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes a 'Grow Your Own' model to address teacher shortages by upskilling existing school staff, which is a recognized strategy rather than a fundamentally new technology or government approach. Its focus on recruiting and supporting racially and linguistically diverse candidates from within school systems is a progressive aspect, but the core program design is not novel.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to place qualified teachers in high-needs schools, which often serve communities with higher rates of child poverty. By improving the quality and stability of educators in these schools, it has an indirect positive impact on educational outcomes, which can contribute to breaking cycles of poverty in the long term, though it doesn't directly address immediate financial needs or social safety nets.

Title: State Government – Attorney General – Reports
Synopsis: Altering certain reporting requirements for the Attorney General; and requiring the Attorney General to publish certain documents on the website of the Attorney General.
bill_summary: This bill alters the reporting requirements for the Maryland Attorney General. Specifically, it removes the requirement for an annual report on actions taken concerning federal government actions, eliminates the need to include an itemized statement of receipts and disbursements in the annual report, and mandates that the Attorney General publish opinions and the annual report on their official website instead of in bound volumes. It also clarifies that the annual report should be submitted to the General Assembly in addition to the Governor.
responsible_party: Attorney General of Maryland / Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: The public, the Governor, and the Maryland General Assembly.
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes the Attorney General's reporting by requiring publications to be made available on the agency's website rather than in bound volumes. While this improves accessibility and uses current technology, it is a standard practice for government transparency and not highly innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to the Attorney General's reporting requirements and publication methods. It does not establish any programs, services, or financial assistance that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: 9-1-1 Specialist Recruitment and Retention Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the 9-1-1 Specialist Recruitment and Retention Workgroup to identify and examine recruitment and retention challenges that affect 9-1-1 specialists in the State; and requiring the Workgroup to submit an interim report of its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024, and a final report on or before December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the 9–1–1 Specialist Recruitment and Retention Workgroup in Maryland. The Workgroup is tasked with identifying and examining challenges affecting the recruitment and retention of 9–1–1 specialists, including reviewing retirement rates, hiring numbers, salary ranges, benefits (like retirement, health, pension, and workers' compensation), training requirements, recruitment techniques, and promotion opportunities. It will also make recommendations on effective incentives and practices used in other states and the feasibility of incorporating 9–1–1 specialists into the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System. The Workgroup will submit an interim report by December 1, 2024, and a final report by December 1, 2025.
responsible_party: 9–1–1 Specialist Recruitment and Retention Workgroup, supported by the Department of Legislative Services and the Maryland Department of Emergency Management.
stakeholders: 9–1–1 specialists, Public Safety Answering Point Directors, various state agencies (State Police, Emergency Management, MIEMSS), county governments, members of the National Emergency Number Association, the Maryland 9–1–1 Board, the Maryland Association of Counties, the Maryland Municipal League, and the general public who rely on 9–1–1 services.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to study workforce issues and provide recommendations, which is a conventional governmental approach and does not introduce new technologies or innovative methods for service delivery or governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving the recruitment and retention of 9–1–1 specialists, which is an occupational and public safety matter. It does not directly provide financial assistance, social services, or policy changes specifically targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Department of Education - Division of Rehabilitation Services - Funding
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill a certain appropriation to the Division of Rehabilitation Services in the State Department of Education to ensure the State match amount for the Division is met as required by certain federal acts.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Governor to include an increased general fund appropriation in the annual budget bill to ensure the State meets its required matching funds for the Division of Rehabilitation Services within the State Department of Education. This action is intended to maintain compliance with federal acts and secure the benefits of federal funding for rehabilitation services.
responsible_party: State Department of Education – Division of Rehabilitation Services
stakeholders: Individuals with disabilities in Maryland who receive or could receive rehabilitation services, including vocational training, employment support, and independent living services.
innovative_summary: The bill focuses on a standard governmental funding mechanism, ensuring state matching funds for existing federal programs. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government operations or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not a direct child poverty program, this bill ensures continued funding for the Division of Rehabilitation Services, which helps individuals with disabilities gain employment and independence. Increased employment and self-sufficiency for adults with disabilities can indirectly improve household income and reduce child poverty for families benefitting from these services.

Title: Watershed, Stream, and Floodplain Restoration - Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Restoration and Stream and Floodplain Restoration Funding (Whole Watershed Act)
Synopsis: Requiring, in each fiscal year from 2026 through 2030, up to $100,000 from the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays 2010 Trust Fund to be used to fund certain operations grants at a rate of $20,000 per project sponsor each fiscal year; authorizing the use of the Waterway Improvement Fund for projects that involve the beneficial use of dredged material and for certain water quality monitoring; prohibiting the Department of the Environment from reducing certain monitoring requirements for certain projects; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Whole Watershed Restoration Partnership and the Whole Watershed Fund to accelerate the restoration of the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays and their watersheds. It redirects funding from existing state environmental funds to the new Whole Watershed Fund, sets criteria for selecting and implementing restoration projects that emphasize cost-effectiveness, rapid systemic response, and local community support. The bill requires project applicants for stream and floodplain restoration projects to provide public notice, hold public meetings, and submit comprehensive documentation. It also details the Department of Natural Resources' assessment process for these projects, focusing on degradation criteria, co-benefits, community engagement, and best management practices, while requiring at least 5 years of monitoring post-completion.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources, led by the Secretary of Natural Resources, with a State Management Team including representatives from the Department of the Environment, Department of Agriculture, Department of Planning, and the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays.
stakeholders: Communities and residents in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays watersheds, particularly overburdened and underserved communities, property owners, local governments, non-profit and for-profit organizations, community organizations, and scientists involved in environmental restoration.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes a comprehensive 'Whole Watershed' approach, coordinating multiple state agencies and funding sources for systemic environmental improvements. It prioritizes equitably focusing assistance on areas demonstrating rapid systemic response, and integrates diverse co-benefits like wildlife habitat, carbon sequestration, climate resilience, public health, and local employment. The initiative includes a public permit tracking dashboard and robust community engagement requirements, fostering innovation in restoration science and practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program can have an indirect positive impact on child poverty by improving public health and reducing environmental disparities in overburdened and underserved communities, where child poverty is often concentrated. It also notes the creation of local employment opportunities as a potential co-benefit of restoration projects, which could indirectly support families. However, it does not provide direct financial aid or specific social services aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Center for School Safety - Secure Schools Emergency Response Grant Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Secure Schools Emergency Response Grant Program to be administered by the Maryland Center for School Safety to provide funds to improve emergency notification systems and communications between public elementary and secondary school personnel, a public safety answering point, and a public safety agency during emergency events; requiring the Center to ensure that the Program is operating and available to each county board by September 1, 2026; and authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation in the annual budget bill.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Secure Schools Emergency Response Grant Program, administered by the Maryland Center for School Safety. The program provides grants to local school systems to improve emergency notification systems and communication during emergency events in public elementary and secondary schools. Key features include cellular phone application-based panic buttons that can connect to 9-1-1, facilitate text communications with public safety agencies, send notifications to authorized users, and automatically transmit school floor plans and emergency plans to first responders. It also includes the capability to generate automated emergency alerts to nearby schools for imminent threats and allows for other technologies like intercoms and public address systems. The goal is to implement this program in all public schools by September 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety
stakeholders: Local school systems, public elementary and secondary school personnel, first responders, public safety agencies, and students attending public schools in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs new technologies and approaches to school safety by integrating an emergency communication platform, including cellular phone application-based panic buttons with direct 9-1-1 calling, text communication, and automated transmission of critical information like school floor plans and emergency plans to first responders. It also enables automated emergency alerts to nearby schools, fostering a more rapid and coordinated response to school emergencies statewide.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program aims to improve safety and emergency response in schools, which can create a more stable and secure learning environment for all students. While a safer school environment can indirectly contribute to better educational outcomes, which may have long-term positive effects on a child's economic well-being, the program does not directly address the causes or symptoms of child poverty, such as providing financial assistance, food, housing, or other social services.

Title: Human Remains - Alkaline Hydrolysis and Natural Organic Reduction (Green Death Care Options Act)
Synopsis: Establishing a regulatory system for reduction operators and reduction facilities; establishing requirements and prohibitions related to the performance of alkaline hydrolysis and natural organic reduction and the disposition of hydrolyzed or soil remains by certain facilities; requiring the Director of the Office of Cemetery Oversight and the Director of the State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors to adopt regulations governing the performance of natural organic reduction; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the "Green Death Care Options Act," establishes a regulatory framework in Maryland for new methods of human remains disposition: alkaline hydrolysis and natural organic reduction (human composting). It defines these processes, outlines requirements for reduction operators and facilities, and sets prohibitions on the use and disposal of hydrolyzed or soil remains, such as preventing their use for growing food or resale. The bill mandates the Director of the Office of Cemetery Oversight and the State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors to adopt regulations, including mandatory contamination testing for soil remains, to ensure public health and safety. It also integrates these new services into existing regulations for funeral establishments and cemeteries, including provisions for unclaimed veterans' remains.
responsible_party: Director of the Office of Cemetery Oversight; State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors
stakeholders: Individuals and families seeking alternative post-mortem disposition options (alkaline hydrolysis, natural organic reduction); licensed funeral establishments, crematories, and new reduction facilities; veterans and their eligible dependents; and the general public concerned with public health and environmental safety related to death care.
innovative_summary: The bill is innovative by legalizing and establishing a comprehensive regulatory system for emerging "green" death care options like alkaline hydrolysis and natural organic reduction (human composting). This marks a significant adaptation of state government oversight to new, environmentally conscious practices in the death care industry, including detailed requirements for contamination testing and safe disposal of soil remains.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill regulates death care services and does not have a direct impact on child poverty. While providing more disposition options could indirectly affect family finances, it is not designed to directly address the root causes or consequences of child poverty.

Title: Nonprescription Drugs and Devices – Provision by Registered Nurses and Sale of Contraceptives Through Automatic Devices
Synopsis: Prohibiting the sale of natural membrane condoms, rather than all nonlatex condoms, through a vending machine or other automatic device; excluding the violation of a certain provision of the Act from certain penalties; and authorizing registered nurses to provide, without a prescription, nonprescription drugs and devices in a local health department under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill modifies regulations concerning the sale of condoms through automatic devices, specifically prohibiting the sale of natural membrane condoms via vending machines. It also authorizes registered nurses in local health departments to provide nonprescription drugs and devices, including FDA-approved nonprescription contraceptive drugs and devices, without a prescription, under certain conditions and in accordance with a formulary developed by the Committee on Registered Nurses Personally Preparing and Dispensing Drugs and Devices in Local Health Departments.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health; Committee on Registered Nurses Personally Preparing and Dispensing Drugs and Devices in Local Health Departments; Local Health Departments
stakeholders: The general public, particularly those seeking nonprescription drugs, devices, contraceptives, or family planning services; registered nurses; and local health departments.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances accessibility to nonprescription drugs and devices, including contraceptives, by expanding the scope of practice for registered nurses in local health departments. This streamlines access to essential health products by removing the requirement for a prescription for nonprescription items, representing a new approach to public health service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By expanding access to nonprescription drugs, devices, and especially contraceptives and family planning services through local health departments, the program can indirectly impact child poverty. Increased access to family planning allows individuals and families greater control over reproductive decisions, which can lead to more stable family planning and improved economic well-being, potentially reducing poverty by enabling better resource allocation within families.

Title: Video Lottery Facility Operations - Crimes of Moral Turpitude and Value of Table Game Chips - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the circumstances under which the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission is required to disqualify an applicant who committed a certain crime involving moral turpitude from holding a video lottery employee license; and altering the definition of "value" as it relates to crimes involving theft to include the face value of a chip designated for use in table games.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the conditions under which the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission must disqualify an applicant for a video lottery employee license due to certain nonviolent misdemeanor offenses, allowing for licensure if the applicant completed a problem-solving court program or if they will not be employed in gaming or security and the licensee requests the license. It also clarifies that the "value" of a chip designated for use in a table game, for the purpose of theft crimes, is its face value or a value designated by the Commission.
responsible_party: Maryland Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
stakeholders: Applicants for video lottery employee licenses, video lottery operation licensees, and individuals involved in table games within Maryland gaming facilities.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily adjusts existing regulatory definitions and licensing criteria within the established gaming industry framework. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on gaming regulations and employee licensing, specifically addressing disqualification criteria for certain misdemeanor offenses. While it might indirectly affect the employment prospects of some individuals, it does not establish programs or policies directly aimed at alleviating child poverty through economic support, educational initiatives, or social services.

Title: Child Care Providers - Anaphylactic Food Allergies - Guidelines and Indemnity (Elijah's Law)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Education and Maryland Department of Health to develop guidelines to reduce the risk of exposure to anaphylactic major food allergens in child care settings; requiring the State Department of Education to create a certain model policy; requiring certain large family child care homes and child care centers to adopt a policy to reduce the risk of exposure to anaphylactic major food allergens; and providing that certain child care providers and employees are immune from civil liability.
bill_summary: Elijah's Law requires the State Department of Education and the Maryland Department of Health to jointly develop guidelines to reduce the risk of exposure to anaphylactic major food allergens in child care settings. The State Department of Education will create a model policy based on these guidelines. Large family child care homes and child care centers with enrolled children who have food allergies must adopt and implement a policy in accordance with these guidelines. The bill also grants civil immunity to child care providers and employees for good faith actions when responding to a child's anaphylactic reaction.
responsible_party: State Department of Education and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children with major food allergies, their parents or guardians, large family child care homes, child care centers, and child care providers and employees.
innovative_summary: The program establishes joint guidelines and a model policy for managing anaphylactic food allergies in child care settings and provides immunity for good faith responses. While crucial for child safety, it primarily formalizes and standardizes safety protocols rather than introducing new technologies or significantly innovative governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on enhancing child safety in child care settings by addressing food allergies and does not directly target economic factors that contribute to child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be indirect, such as potentially reducing healthcare burdens related to allergic reactions.

Title: Baltimore City – Alcoholic Beverages – 40th Alcoholic Beverages District – Revisions
Synopsis: Establishing a Class M-F (Municipal Family Fun Center) alcoholic beverages license in the 40th alcoholic beverages district in Baltimore City; authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a certain Class B beer, wine, and liquor license to a restaurant in a certain location; and authorizing a certain Class A license issued for a certain location to remain unexpired until the end of July 1, 2025, for the purpose of renewal.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a new Class M–F (Municipal Family Fun Center) alcoholic beverages license in the 40th alcoholic beverages district of Baltimore City for a municipal bowling alley and skating rink. It authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City to issue a Class B beer, wine, and liquor license to a restaurant in a specific location (even side of the 400 block of West 29th Street) and allows for the waiver of minimum seating requirements if an applicant executes a memorandum of understanding with the Greater Remington Improvement Association. The bill also extends the unexpired period of a Class A license issued for a premises on the odd side of the unit block of West Biddle Street until July 1, 2025, for renewal purposes.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
stakeholders: Businesses seeking alcoholic beverage licenses in Baltimore City's 40th alcoholic beverages district, including municipal bowling alleys/skating rinks, restaurants, and specific Class A license holders; and community associations such as the Upton West Community Association, Penn North Community Association, and the Greater Remington Improvement Association.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a highly specific Class M-F license tailored for a 'Municipal Family Fun Center' (a bowling alley and skating rink) in a particular district, which represents a customized regulatory approach for a niche venue. While not employing new technologies or fundamentally new government approaches, it shows an adaptive regulatory framework to accommodate specific local business types and community needs through mandated memorandums of understanding.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on alcoholic beverage licensing changes and does not contain any direct provisions or mechanisms designed to address or impact child poverty. Any potential effects would be indirect through economic activity or employment, which are not explicitly targeted.

Title: Transportation - MobilityLink Paratransit Service Improvements - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Transportation Institute at the University of Maryland to conduct a study to identify methods to improve the Maryland Transit Administration's ADA MobilityLink paratransit service; requiring the Institute to submit a report on its findings and recommendations to the Governor, the General Assembly, and certain  officials by July 1, 2025; and authorizing the Governor in fiscal year 2026 to include in the annual budget bill at least $150,000 for the study.
bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Transportation Institute at the University of Maryland to conduct a study to identify methods to improve the Maryland Transit Administration’s ADA MobilityLink paratransit service. The study will compare MobilityLink to similar services nationwide, analyze service structures, fiscal costs, performance metrics (like on-time performance and customer complaints), and workforce metrics. It also requires soliciting public input and developing recommendations for service improvements, including addressing areas outside fixed routes and interjurisdictional restrictions.
responsible_party: Maryland Transportation Institute at the University of Maryland
stakeholders: Users of the Maryland Transit Administration's ADA MobilityLink paratransit service, individuals with disabilities who require accessible transportation, and residents in areas not served by fixed transportation routes.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a study to review and recommend improvements for an existing paratransit service. While the study itself involves comprehensive analysis and stakeholder input, it represents a standard governmental approach to service improvement through research and comparative analysis, rather than introducing novel technologies or innovative governmental methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on improving paratransit services for individuals with disabilities. While improved transportation access can indirectly benefit families, including those with children experiencing poverty, the bill does not directly target child poverty or provide specific interventions for it. The potential impact is very indirect.

Title: Economic Development - Strategic Infrastructure Revolving Loan Program and Tax Increment Financing
Synopsis: Establishing the Strategic Infrastructure Revolving Loan Program in the Maryland Economic Development Corporation to make loans for targeted investments in real estate and infrastructure projects located in sustainable communities, priority funding areas, and transit-oriented development areas; establishing the Strategic Infrastructure Revolving Loan Fund; authorizing the Corporation, with certain approval of a certain governing body, to pledge certain revenues generated within a certain area for certain purposes; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Strategic Infrastructure Revolving Loan Program and Fund within the Maryland Economic Development Corporation (MEDCO). The program will provide loans for targeted investments in real estate and infrastructure projects located in sustainable communities, priority funding areas, or transit-oriented development areas. The purpose is to support transformative place-making, enhance community development, and achieve inclusive economic growth, with a focus on activating underutilized assets and generating revenue. The bill also authorizes MEDCO to pledge certain revenues generated within specific development districts to support the loan fund or secure debt.
responsible_party: Maryland Economic Development Corporation (MEDCO)
stakeholders: Applicants for loans (including developers, businesses, and potentially government entities) undertaking real estate and infrastructure projects, and communities designated as sustainable communities, priority funding areas, or transit-oriented development areas, who will benefit from economic growth, job creation, and community development.
innovative_summary: The program utilizes a revolving loan fund, a traditional financial instrument, to strategically target investments in specific geographic areas (sustainable communities, priority funding areas, transit-oriented development) and project types (activating underutilized property, leveraging private investment, potential for job growth). While the strategic targeting is a focused approach, the underlying financial mechanism is not new technology or a fundamentally novel approach to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to foster economic growth, job creation, and community development through infrastructure and real estate loans. While these outcomes can indirectly improve family economic stability and potentially reduce child poverty by creating employment opportunities, the loans are not directly targeted at low-income families or specific programs designed to alleviate child poverty. The impact would be a general economic uplift rather than a direct poverty intervention.

Title: Allegany County - Alcoholic Beverages - Class BWLT Beer, Wine, and Liquor Tasting Permit
Synopsis: Authorizing a Class BWLT beer, wine, and liquor tasting permit to be issued by the Board of License Commissioners for Allegany County.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a new Class BWLT beer, wine, and liquor tasting permit in Allegany County. This permit allows holders of a standard beer, wine, and liquor license to offer on-premises tasting of these beverages. Permit holders must notify the Board of License Commissioners at least 7 days before a tasting event. The annual fee for this permit is $150, plus a one-time issuing fee of $150 for new permits. The Board of License Commissioners for Allegany County is responsible for issuing these permits and adopting regulations to implement the section.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Allegany County
stakeholders: Holders of beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Allegany County, and consumers interested in tasting events.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a new type of alcoholic beverage permit for tasting events. This is a regulatory adjustment within an existing framework, rather than an innovative approach to government or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily concerns alcoholic beverage licensing and does not have any direct provisions or mechanisms that would address child poverty. Its impact on child poverty would be negligible or indirect at best, through potential economic activity, but not as a primary goal or direct intervention.

Title: Maryland-Ireland Trade Commission - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland-Ireland Trade Commission in the Department of Commerce to study and make recommendations regarding bilateral trade relations and investment opportunities between Maryland and Ireland; and requiring the Commission by December 1 2025, to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland–Ireland Trade Commission within the Department of Commerce. The Commission's purpose is to study and promote trade, investment, and academic exchanges between Maryland and Ireland, and to make recommendations on these matters to the Governor and the General Assembly. The Commission is composed of members from the Senate, House of Delegates, Department of Commerce, Department of State, public higher education, the Maryland Chamber of Commerce, and the Irish–American community.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Maryland and Irish businesses, academic institutions, the Irish-American community in Maryland, and the economies of Maryland and Ireland.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a trade commission, which is a traditional government mechanism for fostering economic relations. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program focuses on advancing bilateral trade and investment. While successful trade initiatives can lead to general economic growth and job creation, their direct impact on reducing child poverty is indirect and not a primary, targeted outcome of this commission.

Title: Employees' and Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems - Reemployment of Retirees
Synopsis: Repealing a certain exemption from certain reemployed retiree earnings offsets for certain retirees of the Employees' and Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems; repealing certain requirements that certain participating employers pay certain offsets under certain circumstances; establishing an exemption from a reemployed retiree earnings offset for retirees of the Teachers' Pension System who are reemployed by certain employers if the retiree's salary is funded from certain sources; etc.
bill_summary: The bill repeals certain exemptions from reemployed retiree earnings offsets for retirees of the Employees' and Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems and removes requirements for employers to pay these offsets. It also establishes a new, temporary exemption for retirees of the Teachers' Pension System who are reemployed under a joint employer agreement with a local employer and the Maryland Association of Boards of Education, provided their salary is fully funded by the Association. This specific exemption is retroactive to January 1, 2021, and expires on December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees of the Employees' and Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems; State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Retirees of the Employees' and Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems who are reemployed, including teachers reemployed by local school systems or the Maryland School for the Deaf, parole and probation employees, and specifically Teachers' Pension System retirees jointly employed by a local employer and the Maryland Association of Boards of Education.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative adjustments to existing pension reemployment rules and exemptions. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily affects the reemployment earnings of retirees. While changes to retiree income could indirectly influence households with children, it does not establish programs or policies directly aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: State Retirement Agency - Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion and Governance Program
Synopsis: Establishing that the Executive Director of the State Retirement Agency shall employ a Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion of the State Retirement Agency; requiring the Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion to identify and minimize barriers to ensure access and opportunities to underrepresented groups; requiring the Executive Director to terminate the Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) position within the Maryland State Retirement Agency. This director will identify and minimize barriers to access and opportunities for underrepresented groups, engage with various entities to promote diversity, and advise the Board of Trustees on DEI topics. The bill also establishes a Governance Program within the Investment Division of the State Retirement Agency, requiring the Chief Investment Officer to employ an individual to assist in its implementation. This individual's responsibilities include developing standards for the program, monitoring and evaluating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors on investments (including DEI), integrating ESG into investment due diligence, providing recommendations, and supporting minority business enterprise policies.
responsible_party: State Retirement Agency, Executive Director of the State Retirement Agency, Chief Investment Officer
stakeholders: Underrepresented groups, staff of the State Retirement Agency, Board of Trustees, external entities, investment managers, and ultimately, participants in the State Retirement and Pension System through improved governance.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a dedicated Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion role and a Governance Program that explicitly integrates environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, including diversity, equity, and inclusion, into the investment strategy and due diligence of the State Retirement Agency. This systematic approach to considering DEI and broader ESG factors in public pension fund management is a modern and increasingly adopted practice in investment, aiming for more responsible and potentially more sustainable returns.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily focuses on internal organizational structure, governance, and investment practices of the State Retirement Agency. While it aims to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion and responsible investment, it does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or programs targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Baltimore County - Sheriff - Salary
Synopsis: Altering the annual salary of the Sheriff of Baltimore County.
bill_summary: This bill significantly increases the annual salary of the Sheriff of Baltimore County. The salary will be $90,000 for calendar years 2024 and 2025, then increase to $138,000 for 2026, $143,000 for 2027, $150,000 for 2028, and $157,500 for 2029. For subsequent calendar years, the salary will be determined by the Baltimore County Council as provided in its annual budget.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Council, Sheriff of Baltimore County
stakeholders: The Sheriff of Baltimore County
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it solely adjusts the salary of a public official.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty, as it only addresses the salary of a specific public official.

Title: Public and Nonpublic Middle and High Schools - Venue-Specific Emergency Action Plans for Athletic Facilities (The Bailey Bullock Act)
Synopsis: Requiring that each public middle school and high school alter the venue-specific emergency action plan for athletic facilities to incorporate a cardiac emergency response plan; requiring each nonpublic middle school and high school that receives State funding to develop a venue-specific emergency action plan for athletic facilities; specifying the contents of a nonpublic venue-specific emergency action plan; and requiring that the emergency action plans be reviewed and updated annually.
bill_summary: The Bailey Bullock Act requires all public middle and high schools to integrate a cardiac emergency response plan into their existing venue-specific emergency action plans for athletic facilities, starting in the 2024-2025 school year. It further mandates that nonpublic middle and high schools receiving State funding also develop comprehensive venue-specific emergency action plans that include cardiac emergency response protocols. These plans must establish cardiac emergency response teams, require specific personnel (including coaches, nurses, and team members) to be trained in CPR, AED use, and first aid, coordinate with local emergency medical services, and be publicly posted and regularly rehearsed.
responsible_party: Public middle and high schools, nonpublic middle and high schools receiving State funding, and county boards of education
stakeholders: Students attending public and nonpublic middle and high schools, particularly student athletes; school athletic coaching and training staff; school nurses; other school personnel involved in emergency response; and parents or guardians of student athletes.
innovative_summary: This bill mandates the implementation of comprehensive, evidence-based cardiac emergency response plans in schools, incorporating best practices from national organizations like the American Heart Association. While it standardizes and enforces critical safety measures such as CPR/AED training and coordinated emergency response teams, these are generally recognized as established best practices rather than groundbreaking new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses exclusively on enhancing cardiac emergency preparedness and response in middle and high school athletic facilities.
