Synopsis: Requiring a hospital to take certain actions relating to the care of infants as soon as practicable before the hospital discharges an infant after the birth of the infant, including providing oral and written educational resources to the parent or legal guardian on how to provide a safe sleep environment and providing a list of resources available for an infant's parent or legal guardian; requiring each hospital, by January 1, 2025, to establish a process for providing and confirming the receipt of the educational resources; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Safe Sleep Act of 2024, requires hospitals to provide oral and written educational resources to parents or legal guardians on how to provide a safe sleep environment for infants, as well as a list of resources to obtain necessary items, before discharging an infant. Hospitals must establish a process for providing these resources and confirming their receipt by January 1, 2025. Additionally, the Maryland Department of Health, in consultation with local health officers, must develop a county-specific list of resources for obtaining safe sleep items by January 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Hospitals and the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Infants, parents and legal guardians of infants, hospitals, and local health departments.
innovative_summary: The bill mandates standard educational practices (oral, written, and potentially video resources) and the compilation of resource lists to promote safe sleep for infants. While important for public health, it does not employ new technologies or particularly innovative governmental approaches, focusing instead on standard information dissemination and process establishment within existing healthcare frameworks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential for an indirect impact on child poverty by requiring hospitals and the Maryland Department of Health to provide a list of resources available for parents to obtain items necessary for a safe sleep environment. This could help lower-income families access essential items, potentially reducing financial strain and health risks associated with unsafe sleep, which disproportionately affect vulnerable populations. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance or items.

Title: Legally Protected Health Care - Gender-Affirming Treatment
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "legally protected health care" to include certain gender-affirming treatment, including medications and supplies, for the purposes of certain provisions of law that prohibit health occupations disciplinary actions and certain actions in criminal and civil proceedings and the use of certain resources in furtherance of certain investigations and proceedings related to legally protected health care.
bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of "legally protected health care" in Maryland to include gender-affirming treatment, encompassing various medically necessary treatments, medications, and supplies. This expansion provides legal safeguards against health occupations disciplinary actions, criminal and civil proceedings, and the use of State resources in furtherance of out-of-state investigations or proceedings related to gender-affirming care and reproductive health services that are lawful in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies, courts, and health occupations boards
stakeholders: Individuals providing or receiving gender-affirming treatment or reproductive health services in Maryland, health care practitioners, and State officials involved in legal and administrative processes.
innovative_summary: The bill represents a significant legal innovation by expanding existing protections to explicitly include gender-affirming care, thereby creating a legal sanctuary for providers and recipients of such care against out-of-state legal challenges. This reflects a proactive legal strategy to safeguard healthcare access in response to evolving interstate legal landscapes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on legal protections for access to gender-affirming treatment and reproductive healthcare, which are crucial for the health and well-being of individuals. While ensuring access to medically necessary care can contribute to overall family stability and health, and indirectly affect economic outcomes, the bill does not directly establish programs or allocate resources specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Office of the Correctional Ombudsman - Establishment and Funding
Synopsis: Establishing the Office of the Correctional Ombudsman; authorizing the Justice Reinvestment Oversight Board to make a recommendation for the distribution of money from the Performance Incentive Grant Fund to the Office for fiscal year 2025 only; requiring the Office to conduct investigations, reviews, and assessments of administrative acts taken by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, by the Department of Juvenile Services, or in relation to individuals confined by either department; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Office of the Correctional Ombudsman as an independent unit of State government, consolidating oversight of correctional and juvenile services. It transfers the existing Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit into this new office and grants the Ombudsman broad powers to investigate administrative acts, conduct reviews and assessments of services (including health, mental health, educational, and vocational programs), and monitor facility conditions within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Juvenile Services. The Office is authorized to subpoena individuals, perform unannounced site visits, and receive confidential complaints. It also creates a Correctional Ombudsman Advisory Board and prohibits reprisals against employees who provide information to the Office. The bill allocates initial funding for the transferred unit and states legislative intent for future appropriations and an initial audit of correctional programming.
responsible_party: Office of the Correctional Ombudsman (with the Ombudsman appointed by the Governor with Senate consent)
stakeholders: Individuals confined by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Juvenile Services, employees of these departments, family members of confined individuals, returning citizens, nonsupervisory correctional officers, and the general public.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes an independent Office of the Correctional Ombudsman with significant investigative powers, including the ability to subpoena individuals and conduct unannounced facility inspections. The creation of an advisory board with diverse stakeholders, including family members of confined individuals and returning citizens, reflects a modern and inclusive approach to oversight and accountability in the correctional and juvenile justice systems. This structure enhances transparency and provides a dedicated, independent channel for addressing systemic issues and individual complaints.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly targeting child poverty through economic interventions, the bill has a potential indirect impact by improving the conditions, treatment, and access to educational and vocational programs for juveniles and incarcerated individuals. Better oversight of juvenile justice facilities, ensuring children's rights are upheld, and monitoring the quality of educational and vocational training could lead to improved life trajectories, reduced recidivism, and enhanced economic stability for individuals post-release, which may indirectly mitigate cycles of poverty affecting children and families.

Title: Workgroup to Study Funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup to Study Funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility to identify and examine existing funding sources that support the Facility and study whether increased funding could enhance operations at the Facility, the funding sources of comparable facilities in the region, and available and potential federal, State, and local funding sources for the Facility; and requiring the Workgroup to report, on or before December 1, 2024, its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a Workgroup to study funding for the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility. The Workgroup will identify and analyze existing, increased, comparable, and potential federal, State, and local funding sources for the facility. It will then make recommendations on whether additional funding could improve the facility's operations and on suitable funding sources.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Residents of Westernport and Allegany County, the Westernport Wastewater Treatment Facility, State and local government entities involved in environmental management and public works.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a workgroup to study funding for a wastewater treatment facility, which is a standard governmental approach to assess infrastructure needs and funding options. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on studying funding for wastewater infrastructure. While essential infrastructure can indirectly benefit communities, there is no direct mechanism within this bill to address or impact child poverty through direct aid, services, or targeted programs for impoverished children or families.

Title: Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems - Reemployment
Synopsis: Clarifying a certain exemption from a certain reemployment offset for retirees of the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System who are reemployed by a local school system under certain conditions; and providing for the retroactive application of the Act to certain retirees who were reemployed by the Harford County Board of Education.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies and expands an exemption from reemployment offset for retirees of the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System. It allows superintendents of local school systems and the Maryland School for the Deaf to rehire a maximum of five retirees in any position within their systems (not just school-based positions) without their retirement allowance being reduced, provided they meet certain conditions. The bill also includes a specific retroactive provision for retirees of the Teachers' Pension System reemployed by the Harford County Board of Education's Payroll Department who exceeded earning limitations in 2022 or 2023, mandating that the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System refund any benefits previously offset by December 31, 2024.
responsible_party: Local school system superintendents, the superintendent of the Maryland School for the Deaf, and the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System.
stakeholders: Retirees of the Teachers' Retirement System and Teachers' Pension System, local school systems, the Maryland School for the Deaf, and specifically, certain retirees reemployed by the Harford County Board of Education.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative adjustments to existing reemployment rules for retired teachers and does not introduce any new technologies or novel approaches to government operations or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill primarily addresses reemployment rules and pension offsets for retired teachers. While it may enhance financial stability for a small number of retired educators and potentially impact staffing in schools, it does not contain direct provisions or mechanisms designed to address or alleviate child poverty.

Title: Qualifying Nonprofit Organizations - Training and Reentry Services - Funding
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor to include an appropriation of $1,000,000 in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2026 through 2028 to provide operating grants to certain qualifying nonprofit organizations for the purpose of providing training in automotive repair to incarcerated or formerly incarcerated individuals; and requiring the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services to administer the grant funds.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Governor to include an annual appropriation of $1,000,000 in the budget bill for fiscal years 2026 through 2028. This funding will provide operating grants to qualifying nonprofit organizations that offer automotive repair training and reentry assistance to incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals. The program aims to help these individuals gain employment in automotive repair, with qualifying organizations required to demonstrate a minimum 50% employment placement rate.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals seeking training and employment in automotive repair.
innovative_summary: The program is not highly innovative in its approach, as it establishes a grant system for existing nonprofit services providing job training. While beneficial, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking government methodologies. It focuses on supporting proven methods of reentry and employment assistance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has an indirect but significant potential to impact child poverty. By providing formerly incarcerated individuals with job training and employment opportunities, it can increase their income and economic stability. If these individuals are parents, this can directly improve the financial well-being of their children and lift families out of poverty.

Title: Prince George's County - Public School Employees Property Tax Credit and Office of Integrity and Compliance PG 503-24
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of Prince George's County to grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on dwellings that are owned by certain eligible employees of the Prince George's County Public School System; requiring the Prince George's County government to submit a certain report concerning the credit to certain persons on or before a certain date; providing that the Office of Integrity and Compliance is an independent unit within the school system; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes Prince George's County to establish a property tax credit for certain eligible full-time employees of the Prince George's County Public School System who own a dwelling in the county and did not reside in the county prior to purchasing that dwelling. The credit is capped at $2,500 per year or the amount of property tax imposed, whichever is less. Additionally, the bill clarifies that the Office of Integrity and Compliance is an independent unit within the Prince George's County Public School System, and its officer and staff serve as independent employees.
responsible_party: Prince George's County governing body; Prince George's County government; County Council of Prince George's County
stakeholders: Eligible employees of the Prince George's County Public School System who own property in the county, and the Prince George's County Public School System, specifically its Office of Integrity and Compliance.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a property tax credit for certain public school employees and clarifies the independence of an internal oversight office. These are standard governmental tools (tax incentives, organizational structure adjustments) and do not utilize new technologies or particularly novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill offers a property tax credit to eligible public school employees. While this could indirectly benefit the families of recipient employees by reducing their housing costs and freeing up household income, it is not specifically designed or targeted to address child poverty directly. The impact on child poverty would be secondary and dependent on the individual financial circumstances of the eligible employees.

Title: State Procurement - Preferred Provider Requirements - Waiver
Synopsis: Authorizing the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers to grant a waiver from a certain requirement to use a certain preferred provider for the procurement of supplies and services under certain circumstances; requiring the Committee to review a certain request for a certain waiver to the State or a State aided or controlled entity under certain circumstances; and requiring Maryland Correctional Enterprises to report the length of time between each order and delivery of supplies and services for each fiscal year.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers to grant waivers to State or State-aided entities from the requirement to procure supplies and services from Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE) under specific conditions. These conditions include when the MCE price is at least 10% above market rates or when MCE's delivery time does not meet the entity's needs. The bill also requires MCE to report annually on the length of time between orders and deliveries of supplies and services, in addition to existing reporting on full-time equivalents for individuals with disabilities.
responsible_party: Pricing and Selection Committee for Preferred Providers
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies and State-aided or controlled entities (buyers), Maryland Correctional Enterprises, Blind Industries and Services of Maryland, community service providers, and individual with disability owned businesses (preferred providers). Indirectly, individuals with disabilities employed by these preferred providers.
innovative_summary: This bill refines existing State procurement procedures and reporting requirements for preferred providers. It does not introduce new technologies, novel governmental approaches, or significantly alter the fundamental mechanisms of State procurement beyond adjusting waiver criteria and reporting details.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is very indirect. It supports employment opportunities for individuals with disabilities through preferred provider programs by adjusting procurement rules, which could indirectly benefit families with children if those individuals are parents in poverty. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance, services, or resources targeted at children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Department of Aging - Caregiver Expense Grant Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Caregiver Expense Grant Program in the Department of Aging to award grants to certain caregivers for up to 30% of the qualified expenses that exceed $2,000 paid or incurred by the caregiver to provide care or support to certain qualified family members; and authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of up to $5,000,000 to the Program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Caregiver Expense Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Aging. This program provides grants to eligible caregivers for qualified expenses incurred while providing care or support to qualified family members. Eligibility is based on the caregiver's federal adjusted gross income ($75,000 for individual filers, $150,000 for joint filers). Grants cover 30% of qualified expenses exceeding $2,000, up to a maximum of $5,000 per fiscal year. Qualified expenses include home modifications, assistive equipment, employing home care aides, adult day care, specialized transportation, legal/financial services, and assistive care technology. Qualified family members include elderly individuals aged 60 and older, individuals with Alzheimer's disease or a related disorder, and children or adults with developmental or functional disabilities who require assistance with daily living activities.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
stakeholders: Caregivers providing care to qualified family members, including elderly individuals (60+), individuals with Alzheimer's disease or related disorders, and children or adults with developmental or functional disabilities.
innovative_summary: The program is a straightforward grant program designed to provide financial relief to caregivers. While it includes modern "assistive care technology" as a qualified expense, the delivery mechanism (a grant program) is a traditional government approach and does not introduce new technologies or particularly innovative administrative methods for its operation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a direct potential impact on child poverty by specifically including "a child or an adult with developmental or functional disabilities" as a qualified family member. By providing financial assistance for caregiving expenses, it can alleviate significant economic burdens on families caring for children with disabilities, potentially freeing up household income and resources that can directly improve the child's well-being and reduce financial strain that contributes to poverty.

Title: University System of Maryland - Board of Regents - Membership
Synopsis: Requiring that certain appointing officials in making appointments to the Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland ensure that one member of the Board is a graduate of a historically Black college or university in the University System of Maryland; and applying the Act only after the next vacancy occurs on the Board of Regents after July 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the membership requirements for the Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland. It mandates that among the members appointed by the Governor, President of the Senate, and Speaker of the House, at least one must be a graduate of a Historically Black College or University (HBCU) within the University System of Maryland. This change will apply to vacancies occurring after the bill's effective date.
responsible_party: Governor, President of the Senate, Speaker of the House (as appointing officials for the Board of Regents)
stakeholders: Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland, graduates of Historically Black Colleges or Universities (HBCUs) in the University System of Maryland, and the University System of Maryland as a whole.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative in terms of employing new technologies or novel approaches to government. It is a structural change to the composition of a governing board, focusing on ensuring specific representation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It is concerned with the diversity of membership on a higher education governing board, which is too far removed to have an immediate or direct effect on child poverty rates.

Title: Economic Development – Maryland Economic Development Commission – Alterations
Synopsis: Altering certain requirements relating to industry representation on the Maryland Economic Development Commission and the purpose of the Commission; repealing a requirement that the Office of International Trade make a certain report to the Commission; and repealing a requirement that the Maryland Tourism Development Board submit certain plans to the Commission.
bill_summary: This bill alters the requirements for the Maryland Economic Development Commission, specifically regarding industry representation to include at least one representative from the life sciences industry and one from the manufacturing industry. It also revises the Commission's duties, removes the requirement for the Office of International Trade to report to the Commission, and eliminates the requirement for the Maryland Tourism Development Board to submit its strategic and annual marketing plans to the Commission for review.
responsible_party: Maryland Economic Development Commission, Governor, Secretary (of Commerce/Economic Development)
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland Economic Development Commission, life sciences industry, manufacturing industry, Office of International Trade, Maryland Tourism Development Board, and entities involved in Maryland's economic development.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily involves administrative and structural changes to an existing commission, such as altering industry representation and streamlining reporting requirements. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches to economic development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on the composition and administrative functions of the Maryland Economic Development Commission. While a strong economy can indirectly benefit families, this bill does not include any direct provisions, programs, or funding specifically targeted at reducing child poverty.

Title: Emergency Medical Services - Paramedics - Immunization Administration - Effective Date
Synopsis: Delaying the effective date to January 1, 2030, of certain provisions of law that repeal the authority of paramedics to administer influenza and COVID-19 immunizations under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill delays, until January 1, 2030, the effective date of provisions that would repeal the authority of paramedics to administer influenza and COVID-19 immunizations. This allows paramedics to continue providing these immunizations under specific circumstances, such as being part of a population health outreach effort conducted by local health departments or hospitals, under the direction of a medical director, and with proper agreements and documentation, for individuals at least 18 years old.
responsible_party: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems (the Institute), EMS Board, jurisdictional EMS operational program medical directors, ambulance service medical directors, county or city health departments, and hospitals or health systems in the State.
stakeholders: Paramedics, public safety and ambulance service personnel, individuals aged 18 and older receiving immunizations, local health departments, hospitals, and health systems.
innovative_summary: This bill maintains an existing authority for paramedics to administer specific immunizations, extending a healthcare delivery mechanism that was previously established. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches to service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill allows paramedics to administer immunizations, specifically for individuals at least 18 years old. While improved public health infrastructure can have broad societal benefits, this bill does not directly target or provide specific programs or resources aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Maryland Military Installation Council - Membership
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Maryland Military Installation Council to include the Maryland Secretary of Labor or a designee, the State Superintendent of Schools or a designee, and the President of the Military Alliance Council of Charles County; and increasing the number of members selected by the Governor from 5 to 6 and requiring that at least one is a spouse of a service member.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the Maryland Military Installation Council by adding the Secretary of Labor and the State Superintendent of Schools as members, updating the name of the Indian Head Defense Alliance to the Military Alliance Council of Charles County, and increasing the number of gubernatorial appointees from five to six, with a requirement that at least one of these appointees be a spouse of a service member.
responsible_party: Maryland Military Installation Council
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland Military Installation Council, Maryland State agencies (Labor, Education), military families and spouses of service members, and communities adjacent to military installations.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily alters the composition of an existing council and does not introduce new technologies or innovative governmental approaches. The inclusion of a service member's spouse among the Governor's appointees is a minor representational change.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus is on the membership of a council related to military installations and community interests. While the council's work might indirectly benefit military families, including those with children, the bill itself does not establish any direct programs or interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Workers' Compensation - Failure to Insure - Penalties
Synopsis: Increasing, from $10,000 to $25,000, the cap on penalties for an employer's failure to secure required workers' compensation insurance or comply with an order of the State Workers' Compensation Commission regarding an employer's failure to secure required workers' compensation insurance.
bill_summary: This bill alters the penalties for employers who fail to secure required workers' compensation insurance or fail to comply with orders from the State Workers' Compensation Commission regarding such insurance. Specifically, it increases the penalty from a maximum of $10,000 to a fixed $25,000 payable to the Uninsured Employers' Fund. It also establishes joint and several liability for corporate officers or members of limited liability companies who have general management responsibility and knowingly fail to secure compensation for covered employees, in cases where the employer's assets are insufficient to satisfy the penalty.
responsible_party: State Workers’ Compensation Commission
stakeholders: Employers in Maryland, particularly those who fail to secure workers' compensation insurance, corporate officers and LLC members of such employers, and the Uninsured Employers' Fund. Employees are indirectly impacted through enhanced enforcement of their right to compensation.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily modifies existing penalties and extends liability, which are traditional regulatory and enforcement mechanisms. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill enhances the enforcement of workers' compensation insurance requirements, which indirectly supports families by ensuring financial protection for employees who suffer workplace injuries. While this can prevent a family from experiencing economic hardship (and thus child poverty) due to an uncompensated injury, it does not directly establish a program to alleviate child poverty. Its impact is preventative and through regulatory compliance rather than direct aid.

Title: Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending to December 31, 2030, the termination date of the Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date of the existing Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program in Maryland from December 31, 2024, to December 31, 2030. The program provides state subsidies for prescription drug costs to eligible Maryland seniors who are Medicare Part D beneficiaries and have an annual household income at or below 300% of the federal poverty guidelines.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Low to middle-income senior residents of Maryland who are Medicare Part D beneficiaries and meet specific income and enrollment criteria.
innovative_summary: This bill extends an existing program and does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government services. The program itself is a traditional form of financial assistance for prescription drugs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program is specifically targeted at assisting seniors with their prescription drug expenses. While it may indirectly free up household income that could benefit families with children, its direct focus is not on children or families with child poverty.

Title: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists – Quorum, Examination, and Apprenticeships
Synopsis: Clarifying that a quorum of the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists consists of a majority of appointed members; altering the circumstances under which an applicant for licensure is qualified to take the examination by adding completion of an apprenticeship approved by the Board as an alternative to obtaining experience in an environmental health specialist-in-training program; and authorizing the Board to approve an examination provider to administer the examination.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies that a quorum of the State Board of Environmental Health Specialists consists of a majority of appointed members. It alters the requirements for licensure by allowing applicants to complete a Board-approved apprenticeship as an alternative to gaining experience through an environmental health specialist-in-training program. Additionally, it authorizes the Board to approve external examination providers to administer the licensing examination, rather than administering it themselves.
responsible_party: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists
stakeholders: Applicants for licensure as environmental health specialists, environmental health specialists-in-training, and individuals participating in apprenticeships related to environmental health.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces an apprenticeship pathway as a formal alternative for aspiring environmental health specialists to gain the required experience for licensure. This update modernizes the routes to professional qualification by offering increased flexibility and potentially broadening access to the profession. It also streamlines the examination process by allowing the Board to approve external examination providers.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses professional licensing standards and pathways for environmental health specialists. While it may indirectly improve career opportunities for some individuals, it does not establish any direct programs, services, or financial support specifically designed to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Cemeteries - Burial-Transit Permits - Required Information
Synopsis: Requiring a person in charge of a cemetery to write on a burial-transit permit, the date of final disposition, the name and physical address of the cemetery, the burial, inurnment or scattering section and the lot and space number, or if the body or fetus was cremated and a certain authorizing agent takes control of the cremains, the name and address of the authorizing agent and the authorizing agent's relationship to the deceased or fetus.
bill_summary: This bill alters the information required to be written on a burial-transit permit by a person in charge of a cemetery. The permit must now include the date of final disposition, the name and physical address of the cemetery, and either the specific burial/inurnment/scattering location (section, lot, space number) or, if cremated remains are taken by an authorizing agent, the agent's name, address, and relationship to the deceased or fetus. The permit must be returned to the Secretary within 10 days after final disposition.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health (Secretary)
stakeholders: Cemeteries, crematories, morticians, authorizing agents, and the families of deceased individuals or fetuses, as well as the Maryland Department of Health.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces administrative changes to the information required on burial-transit permits and does not involve new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to the information required for burial-transit permits. It does not directly address or impact child poverty.

Title: Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to June 1, 2034, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2034. This allows the Board to continue its functions related to occupational safety and health in Maryland.
responsible_party: Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board
stakeholders: Workers, employers, and the public in Maryland concerned with occupational safety and health.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it merely extends the existence of an established advisory board and its current functions rather than introducing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill extends the Occupational Safety and Health Advisory Board, which aims to ensure safer workplaces. While stable employment and workplace safety can indirectly support family income and well-being, this bill does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, educational programs, or other direct interventions.

Title: State Acupuncture Board – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Acupuncture Board in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Acupuncture Board from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring the Board's continued operation in accordance with the Maryland Program Evaluation Act.
responsible_party: State Acupuncture Board (within the Department)
stakeholders: Acupuncturists licensed or regulated by the Board, and members of the public who receive acupuncture services.
innovative_summary: This bill is an extension of an existing board and does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government. It maintains the status quo for the State Acupuncture Board.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill extends the duration of the State Acupuncture Board, which is responsible for regulating the practice of acupuncture. It does not directly provide services, financial aid, or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty, therefore its direct impact is negligible.

Title: State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring the Board's continued statutory and regulatory authority. The purpose is to maintain the certification process for professionals working in residential child care programs.
responsible_party: State Board for Certification of Residential Child Care Program Professionals
stakeholders: Residential Child Care Program Professionals and the children under their care.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it solely extends the operational period of an existing state board without introducing new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly address child poverty. It maintains the certification standards for professionals in residential child care, which indirectly supports the well-being of children in these programs, but does not provide direct financial or programmatic interventions for poverty.

Title: State Board of Dietetic Practice – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Dietetic Practice in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board of Dietetic Practice from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, allowing the Board to continue its statutory and regulatory authority in accordance with the Maryland Program Evaluation Act.
responsible_party: State Board of Dietetic Practice
stakeholders: Dietitians, nutritionists, and the public who utilize dietetic services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative extension of an existing board's authority, which is a routine governmental process under the Maryland Program Evaluation Act. It does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill extends the regulatory oversight of dietetic practice, which indirectly supports public health, including potentially improving nutrition for children. However, it does not directly implement programs, provide funding, or create services specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the sunset date of the State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030. This ensures the continued statutory and regulatory authority of the Board under the Maryland Program Evaluation Act.
responsible_party: State Board of Occupational Therapy Practice in the Department
stakeholders: Occupational therapists and the public who utilize occupational therapy services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative measure to extend the existence of an existing regulatory board. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has a very indirect potential impact on child poverty. It ensures the continued regulation of occupational therapy, which could contribute to overall public health and access to care. However, it does not directly provide financial assistance, educational programs, or other services aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: State Board of Examiners in Optometry – Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Examiners in Optometry in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the statutory and regulatory authority of the State Board of Examiners in Optometry until July 1, 2030, in accordance with the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law). Previously, the Board's authority was set to terminate on July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners in Optometry
stakeholders: Optometrists, individuals seeking optometric services, and the Department of Health (under which the Board operates).
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative extension of an existing regulatory board and does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily deals with the administrative extension of a professional licensing board. It does not contain provisions that directly address or aim to alleviate child poverty.

Title: State Board of Examiners of Psychologists - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Examiners of Psychologists in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the statutory and regulatory authority of the State Board of Examiners of Psychologists from July 1, 2025, to July 1, 2030, ensuring the Board's continued operation.
responsible_party: State Board of Examiners of Psychologists
stakeholders: Psychologists licensed in Maryland and individuals receiving psychological services.
innovative_summary: The bill is a routine administrative act to extend the sunset date of an existing state regulatory board and does not involve any new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill extends the existence of a regulatory board for psychologists. While access to mental health services can indirectly support families and children, this administrative extension has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: State Board of Social Work Examiners - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Social Work Examiners in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Board, by December 1, 2024, to report to certain committees of the General Assembly information from the preceding 6-month period on processing times for license issuance and renewal, complaint resolution times, and the rate of compliance with certain requirements.
bill_summary: This bill extends the State Board of Social Work Examiners, which regulates social workers, by continuing its statutory and regulatory authority until July 1, 2030. It also requires the Board to report certain information to the General Assembly committees by December 1, 2024, regarding the processing time for licenses, complaint resolution time, and compliance rates.
responsible_party: State Board of Social Work Examiners
stakeholders: Social workers licensed in Maryland and the public receiving social work services.
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, extending the sunset date of an existing board and adding reporting requirements. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill ensures the continued regulation of social workers, who may provide services that indirectly benefit families and children. However, the bill itself does not directly establish or fund programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists - Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee within the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2026, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Committee.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the Behavior Analyst Advisory Committee, which operates under the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists, from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2026. This action continues the committee's statutory and regulatory authority within the State of Maryland.
responsible_party: State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists
stakeholders: Behavior analysts licensed or seeking licensure in Maryland, and individuals receiving behavior analysis services.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legislative extension of an existing advisory committee's operational period and does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill extends the authority of a committee overseeing behavior analysts. While behavior analysis services might indirectly benefit children, this specific legislative act is an administrative extension and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Maryland Community Health Resources Commission – Sunset Extension and Program Evaluation
Synopsis: Adding the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission to the governmental activities and units subject to the Maryland Program Evaluation Act; and extending the termination date to June 30, 2035, for certain provisions of law related to the Commission.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission from June 30, 2028, to June 30, 2035. It also adds the Commission to the list of governmental activities and units subject to the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, meaning it will undergo periodic evaluation by the Office of Program Evaluation and Government Accountability.
responsible_party: Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, operating within the Department of Health, and the Office of Program Evaluation and Government Accountability for evaluation.
stakeholders: Maryland residents who rely on community health resources for healthcare access, particularly those served by programs funded or facilitated by the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily extends the operating period of an existing commission and subjects it to standard program evaluation, rather than introducing new technologies or approaches to government. Therefore, it is not considered innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The Maryland Community Health Resources Commission aims to increase access to health care through community health resources. While not a direct anti-poverty program, improved access to healthcare can significantly benefit low-income families and children by reducing health-related financial burdens, preventing illness that could impact school attendance or parental employment, and promoting overall well-being, thus having an indirect positive impact on child poverty.

Title: County Public Libraries - Minors, Children, and Teens - Prohibited Practices
Synopsis: Prohibiting a county public library from charging a fine for overdue library materials borrowed by a minor or intended for children or teens; prohibiting a county public library from charging a reserve fee for library materials reserved by a minor or intended for children or teens; prohibiting a county public library from prohibiting the borrowing of library materials by a minor or the borrowing of library materials intended for children or teens because of previous overdue library materials; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits county public libraries from charging fines for overdue library materials borrowed by minors or intended for children and teens. It also prohibits reserve fees for materials reserved by minors or for children/teens. Libraries cannot prohibit borrowing due to previously overdue materials for at least 21 days. The bill specifies that replacement fees for overdue materials cannot be charged to minors or for children/teen materials until 21 days after the due date, and these fees must be canceled or refunded if the materials are returned in non-damaged condition.
responsible_party: County Public Libraries, Boards of Library Trustees
stakeholders: Minors, children, teens, and their families who use county public libraries in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is a policy change that aims to remove financial barriers for minors, children, and teens to access public library materials. It simplifies library usage rules by eliminating fines and certain fees for this demographic. While beneficial, it does not introduce new technologies or a novel government approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By eliminating overdue fines and certain fees for library materials borrowed by or for children and teens, this bill directly reduces financial burdens on families, particularly those with low incomes. This ensures equitable access to educational resources without the fear of accumulating charges, thus potentially alleviating a small financial stressor that can contribute to child poverty.

Title: Public Safety - 9-1-1 Trust Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the 9-1-1 Trust Fund to authorize the use of certain allocated funds for the payment of the salary of certain personnel.
bill_summary: This bill alters the Maryland 9–1–1 Trust Fund to authorize the use of allocated funds for the payment of salaries for certain public safety answering point personnel and county personnel. Previously, the fund explicitly prohibited using money for these salaries. The bill also renumbers certain subsections related to funding use.
responsible_party: Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Public safety answering point personnel, county personnel, and the general public relying on 9-1-1 services.
innovative_summary: This bill makes an administrative change to the permissible uses of an existing trust fund. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches but rather modifies funding regulations for public safety operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill allows 9-1-1 Trust Fund money to be used for the salaries of public safety answering point personnel. While maintaining a robust 9-1-1 system benefits all residents, including those in poverty, this change does not directly establish programs or services aimed at alleviating child poverty through financial aid, specific support, or targeted interventions.

Title: Public Safety - Volunteer Company Assistance Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Transferring certain duties relating to the Volunteer Company Assistance Fund from the Military Department to the Maryland Department of Emergency Management.
bill_summary: This bill transfers the administrative duties related to the Volunteer Company Assistance Fund from the Military Department to the Maryland Department of Emergency Management. It also clarifies reporting and review responsibilities for the fund, ensuring that the new department, along with the Maryland State Firemen's Association, Legislative Auditor, and Comptroller, oversees its operations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Emergency Management
stakeholders: Volunteer ambulance, fire, and rescue companies located in Maryland or certain out-of-state companies that are members of the Maryland State Firemen’s Association and receive grants or loans from the Volunteer Company Assistance Fund.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative transfer of duties between state departments for an existing fund. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on the administrative oversight of a fund for volunteer emergency services. While these services generally benefit communities, there is no direct mechanism or specific targeting within this bill to address child poverty.

Title: State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act by extending to July 1, 2030, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: This bill extends the "sunset" date for the State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners, meaning its statutory and regulatory authority will continue until July 1, 2030, instead of terminating in 2025. This ensures the Board can continue to regulate physical therapy in Maryland.
responsible_party: State Board of Physical Therapy Examiners in the Department (of Health)
stakeholders: Physical therapists practicing in Maryland, individuals receiving physical therapy services, and the general public who rely on regulated healthcare professionals.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative extension of an existing regulatory body and does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill extends the existence of a regulatory board for physical therapy, which is an administrative function. It has no direct impact on child poverty, as it does not provide direct financial aid, services, or resources targeting low-income children or families.

Title: Department of General Services - State Buildings and Facilities - Energy Conservation and Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reductions
Synopsis: Altering the State's goals for reducing energy consumption in State buildings; requiring the Maryland Green Building Council to update the High Performance Green Building Program to ensure that the Program aligns with certain greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals; requiring the Department of General Services to identify State-owned facilities that are potential candidates for energy performance contracts; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's goals for energy conservation and greenhouse gas emissions reduction in state buildings. It increases the target for average energy consumption reduction in State buildings to 20% by 2031 (from fiscal year 2018 levels). The Maryland Green Building Council is required to update the High Performance Green Building Program by October 1, 2024, to align with the State's net-zero greenhouse gas emissions goal by 2045. The Department of General Services must identify State-owned facilities for energy performance contracts, conduct annual energy and greenhouse gas emissions audits, and enhance data collection and tracking. All units of State government are mandated to implement projects to conserve energy and reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, and leasing proposals for State space must include energy efficiency and emissions reduction goals.
responsible_party: Department of General Services
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies, units of State government, and the general public (through environmental benefits)
innovative_summary: The bill modernizes the State's approach to facility management by explicitly integrating greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets into existing energy conservation programs. It requires updated green building standards to align with a net-zero goal by 2045 and mandates comprehensive energy and emissions audits and data tracking across State-owned buildings. While building on existing frameworks, the strengthened focus on direct emissions reduction and alignment with ambitious net-zero targets represents an innovative and more holistic strategy for government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses energy conservation and greenhouse gas emissions reduction within State buildings and facilities. It does not include any direct provisions, services, or funding aimed at reducing child poverty. Any potential impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, through broader environmental improvements or long-term economic shifts.

Title: State Board of Barbers - Sunset Extension and Report
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Barbers in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2027, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025, with information regarding the Board as determined by the Committee.
bill_summary: This bill extends the statutory and regulatory authority of the State Board of Barbers by changing its termination date from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2027. It also requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee regarding the Board on or before July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Licensed barbers in Maryland and individuals seeking barbering services.
innovative_summary: This bill is a standard extension of a state board's sunset provision and a requirement for a report, which are routine legislative actions and do not involve new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty as it pertains to the regulation and extension of the State Board of Barbers, which primarily affects professionals in the barbering industry and consumers of those services.

Title: State Board of Cosmetologists - Sunset Extension and Report
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Cosmetologists in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2027, the termination provisions relating to certain statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a certain report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill extends the sunset date for the State Board of Cosmetologists, preventing its termination, from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2027. It also requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report regarding the Board to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee by July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and the State Board of Cosmetologists
stakeholders: Cosmetologists, beauty salon operators, and consumers of cosmetology services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, focusing on the continuation of an existing regulatory board and requiring a report. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill extends the regulatory authority for cosmetologists. While the profession can offer employment opportunities, the bill itself does not directly establish programs or services aimed at alleviating child poverty. Any impact would be indirect through economic stability for families.

Title: Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Program - Enforcement
Synopsis: Altering the enforcement and after-the-fact application approval procedures required as minimum elements of a local jurisdiction's Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Program to apply to all critical area violations; repealing the 30-day waiting period with which the Chair of the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays must comply before referring certain enforcement matters to the Attorney General; and expanding the authority of the Attorney General to take certain equitable actions.
bill_summary: This bill alters and strengthens the enforcement and after-the-fact application approval procedures for violations within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Program. It removes a waiting period for the Chair of the Critical Area Commission to refer enforcement matters to the Attorney General and expands the Attorney General's authority to take equitable actions for various critical area violations, including those of orders, permits, plans, local programs, or critical area law.
responsible_party: Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays; Attorney General
stakeholders: Property owners, developers, and local jurisdictions within the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily refines existing legal and administrative enforcement procedures, streamlining referrals and expanding the Attorney General's authority. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on environmental land use regulation and enforcement. It does not establish any direct programs, services, or financial assistance mechanisms that would directly impact child poverty. Any potential effect would be extremely indirect and negligible.

Title: Adult Protective Services - Review Boards - Membership and Terms
Synopsis: Altering provisions relating to the membership of, and the terms of members appointed to, adult public guardianship review boards.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership and terms of appointed members for adult public guardianship review boards in Maryland. It reduces the total number of members on each board from 11 to 8, updates the qualifications for some professional members (e.g., adding registered nurses and psychiatric nurse practitioners, and clarifying expertise in mental health medication), and revises the provisions for member terms and reappointment.
responsible_party: County commissioners, Mayor of Baltimore City, county executives, and local departments responsible for Adult Protective Services
stakeholders: Adults subject to public guardianship or protective services, and professionals and community members serving on adult public guardianship review boards.
innovative_summary: The bill makes administrative adjustments to the composition and terms of existing review boards for adult protective services. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government or service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on adult protective services and public guardianship review boards. While the well-being of adults can indirectly affect children in their care, the bill's provisions do not directly address child poverty or provide specific services or support for children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Election Law - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering the information that clerks of the circuit court for each county and administrative clerks for each District Court are required to report to the State Administrator of Elections to include the names and addresses, if available, of individuals convicted of a felony in the respective court and sentenced to imprisonment with commitment papers; requiring the State Board of Elections to adopt regulations establishing an appeals process regarding certain requests to use public buildings as early voting centers; etc.
bill_summary: This bill revises Maryland's election law by altering the information that clerks of the circuit court and District Courts report to the State Administrator of Elections regarding felony convictions, specifically limiting reports to individuals currently serving a court-ordered sentence of imprisonment. It requires public officials to make public buildings available for early voting centers when requested by a local board and mandates the State Board of Elections to adopt regulations establishing an appeals process for public officials to contest such requests. Additionally, it allows an incumbent member of a political party central committee who is a candidate for party office to act as any responsible officer for that central committee.
responsible_party: State Board of Elections, State Administrator of Elections, clerks of the circuit court, administrative clerks for each District Court, local boards of elections, public officials responsible for public buildings.
stakeholders: Maryland voters, individuals convicted of felonies, clerks of circuit and district courts, election officials, public officials responsible for public buildings, and members of political party central committees.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily updates existing election procedures and reporting requirements. It clarifies reporting details for felony convictions, streamlines the process for securing public buildings as early voting centers by introducing a mandatory appeals process, and adjusts roles for political party central committee members. While improving efficiency and clarity, it does not introduce new technologies or groundbreaking government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses entirely on election law revisions, including reporting requirements for felony convictions, the use of public buildings for early voting, and roles within political party central committees. These provisions do not directly address or impact child poverty.

Title: State and Local Correctional Facilities - Operation of Unmanned Aircraft - Image Recording and Delivery of Contraband
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from intentionally operating an unmanned aircraft over a correctional facility to record images of the facility without the authorization of the managing official of the correctional facility or the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services; prohibiting a person from using an unmanned aircraft to deliver contraband to a person detained or confined in a place of confinement; and requiring a correctional facility to post signage warning of the prohibitions in a visible area on the exterior of the property.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the unauthorized operation of unmanned aircraft (drones) over State and local correctional facilities for the purpose of recording images. It also prohibits using unmanned aircraft to deliver contraband to individuals detained or confined in a place of confinement. Violations are classified as misdemeanors, carrying potential penalties of imprisonment up to 3 years or a fine up to $1,000, or both. Correctional facilities are mandated to post exterior signage warning the public of these provisions.
responsible_party: Maryland correctional facilities and the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals operating unmanned aircraft, correctional facility staff and management, and persons detained or confined in correctional facilities.
innovative_summary: The bill addresses new challenges posed by modern technology (unmanned aircraft/drones) by establishing prohibitions and penalties for their unauthorized use over and around correctional facilities, specifically regarding image recording and contraband delivery. This updates existing law to cover a contemporary technological threat to facility security.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on security and the prevention of illegal activities involving unmanned aircraft at correctional facilities. It does not contain any provisions that would directly impact the economic well-being or poverty status of children.

Title: Notarial Acts - Protest Form Requirement - Repeal
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that a notary public use a certain protest form.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement that notaries public in Maryland use a specific protest form, which was previously prescribed by the Comptroller. It generally relates to protest forms for notarial acts.
responsible_party: Notaries Public
stakeholders: Notaries public in Maryland and entities requiring notarial acts related to protests.
innovative_summary: This bill is a regulatory repeal and does not introduce any innovative technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill relates to notarial acts and the repeal of a specific form requirement, having no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Homeowners' Property Tax Credit - Application - Attestation of Gross Income
Synopsis: Authorizing an applicant for the homeowners' property tax credit to attest to gross income on an application in lieu of providing an income tax return to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation under certain circumstances; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill amends the process for applying for the Homeowners' Property Tax Credit in Maryland. It authorizes applicants to attest to their gross income under penalty of perjury, instead of providing an income tax return, if they were not required to and did not file an income tax return. This change applies to standard applications, applications from home purchasers, and late applications from homeowners.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: Homeowners in Maryland who apply for the Homeowners' Property Tax Credit, especially those with lower incomes who are not required to file income tax returns.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces a minor administrative simplification by allowing self-attestation of income under specific circumstances for a tax credit application. It does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather streamlines an existing process.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By simplifying the application process for the Homeowners' Property Tax Credit, it may make it easier for eligible low-income families (who may include children) to access financial relief through property tax credits. This could alleviate some financial strain, contributing to a more stable household environment, but it does not directly provide services or funds aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: State Board of Individual Tax Preparers - Sunset Extension and Report
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2027, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a certain report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board of Individual Tax Preparers from July 1, 2026, to July 1, 2027, thereby continuing its statutory and regulatory authority. It also requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report on the Board to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee by July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor; State Board of Individual Tax Preparers
stakeholders: Individual tax preparers and members of the public who utilize their services in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative extension of an existing state board and an associated reporting requirement. It does not introduce any new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the regulation and oversight of individual tax preparers and has no direct mechanism or intent to impact child poverty. Any potential effects would be indirect and negligible.

Title: State Department of Assessments and Taxation - Office of the Director - Administrative Expenses
Synopsis: Increasing from 5% to 15% the percentage of the administrative expenses of the Office of the Director of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation that the Department may pay from a certain fund.
bill_summary: This bill increases the percentage of administrative expenses that the Office of the Director of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation may pay from a dedicated fund, raising the limit from 5% to 15% for fiscal year 2015 and each fiscal year thereafter. The fund is used for costs related to reviewing and processing documents, paying ground rent redemption amounts, and other administrative expenses of the Department.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: The State Department of Assessments and Taxation and, indirectly, entities and individuals who interact with the Department regarding filings and administrative processes.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative adjustment to a state department's budget flexibility and does not introduce any new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on administrative budgeting for a state department and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: Certified Local Farm and Fish Program - Annual Waiver Reports - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the annual deadline, from July 31 to October 31, for the Office for the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program to submit to the Board of Public Works a report of waivers requested and waivers granted under the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program; and altering the annual deadline, from October 1 to December 31, for the Board of Public Works to submit to certain standing committees a copy of a record of information regarding any waivers requested under the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program.
bill_summary: This bill alters the annual deadlines for reporting waivers requested and granted under Maryland's Certified Local Farm and Fish Program. The Office for the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program must now submit its report to the Board of Public Works by October 31 each year (instead of July 31), and the Board of Public Works must submit its copy of the record to certain legislative committees by December 31 each year (instead of October 1).
responsible_party: Office for the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program; Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Maryland State agencies involved in the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program, including the Office for the Certified Local Farm and Fish Program, the Board of Public Works, and relevant legislative committees. Indirectly, it relates to certified local farms and certified Chesapeake invasive species providers.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to reporting deadlines for an existing program and does not introduce new technologies or approaches to government operations. It is not innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on altering reporting deadlines for a state procurement program related to local farm and fish products. It does not directly or significantly impact child poverty. Any potential effect would be extremely indirect and minimal.

Title: State Government - Deputy Secretary of State - Title
Synopsis: Altering the title of the Assistant Secretary of State to be "Deputy Secretary of State".
bill_summary: This bill renames the "Assistant Secretary of State" position to "Deputy Secretary of State" within the Maryland State government, updating the title in various sections of the Public Safety and State Government articles of the Annotated Code of Maryland. It primarily involves a change in nomenclature for an existing role and its associated duties.
responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of State's office
stakeholders: The Assistant Secretary of State (whose title is changed to Deputy Secretary of State), the Governor, and other Maryland State government officials who interact with this role and related legal frameworks.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it only renames an existing government position and updates associated legal text, without introducing new technologies or approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty as it solely focuses on changing the title of a government position, without introducing any programs, services, or financial aid related to poverty reduction.

Title: Department of Planning - Inventory Responsibilities
Synopsis: Repealing a requirement that the Department of Planning prepare and periodically revise inventory lists of the natural resources of the State and certain public works and facilities.
bill_summary: This bill repeals a requirement for the Maryland Department of Planning to prepare and periodically revise inventory lists of the state's natural resources and major public works and private facilities important to the state's development.
responsible_party: Department of Planning
stakeholders: The Department of Planning, other Maryland State agencies, and the General Assembly (who previously requested and received these inventory lists) are the primary stakeholders affected by the change in administrative duties.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative as it repeals an existing administrative requirement rather than introducing new technologies or approaches to government.
