child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill makes an administrative change by removing a data collection responsibility from the Department of Planning. It has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: State Board for Professional Land Surveyors - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2027, the termination provisions relating to the statutory and regulatory authority of the Board; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a certain report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board for Professional Land Surveyors from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2027. It also requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025, concerning the Board.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Professional Land Surveyors in Maryland
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, focused on extending the operational period of an existing regulatory board and requiring a report. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government or public service.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill concerns the continued regulation of professional land surveyors and has no direct provisions or mechanisms that would impact child poverty.

Title: State Board for Professional Engineers - Engineer Members - Qualifications
Synopsis: Reducing from 12 to 10 the number of years that an engineer member of the State Board for Professional Engineers must have practiced engineering.
bill_summary: This bill reduces the minimum number of years of engineering practice required for an engineer member of the State Board for Professional Engineers from 12 years to 10 years. It generally relates to the qualifications for members of this Board.
responsible_party: State Board for Professional Engineers
stakeholders: Professional engineers seeking to serve as members of the State Board for Professional Engineers.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a minor administrative change to the qualification requirements for board members and does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill modifies the qualifications for members of a professional licensing board and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: State Board of Electricians - Licensing - Penalties
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Board of Electricians to impose a civil penalty of up to $5,000 instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license for certain violations; requiring the Board to consider certain factors to determine the amount of a penalty imposed under the Act; and requiring by October 1, 2024, the Board to submit to certain committees of the General Assembly a report, covering years 2018 through 2023, on the Board's practices and processes for the timely resolution of complaints against licensees.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the State Board of Electricians to impose civil monetary penalties of up to $5,000 for each violation by a licensee, either instead of or in addition to existing disciplinary actions like reprimands, suspensions, or revocations of licenses. The Board must consider factors such as the violation's seriousness, harm caused, licensee's good faith, and history of violations when determining penalty amounts. The bill also requires the Board to submit a report by October 1, 2024, to legislative committees, detailing its practices for timely complaint resolution and license approval from 2018-2023, and outlining a plan to address any backlogs.
responsible_party: State Board of Electricians
stakeholders: Licensed electricians in Maryland, applicants for electrician licenses, and indirectly, consumers of electrical services.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances the disciplinary powers of the State Board of Electricians by allowing the imposition of civil monetary penalties, which is a standard regulatory tool. It also mandates a report on the Board's complaint resolution and license approval processes, a common governmental oversight mechanism. Neither aspect employs new technologies or significantly novel approaches to government operations or public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is focused on the regulation and oversight of electricians, including licensing and disciplinary actions. It does not contain any provisions for direct financial aid, educational programs, healthcare, or other social services that would directly impact children or families experiencing poverty. Its effects are entirely within professional regulation, with no direct pathways to address child poverty.

Title: Coast Smart Council - Duties and Authority
Synopsis: Altering the duties of the Coast Smart Council to include the development of eligibility criteria, standards, and procedures for categorical exemptions from the application of the Coast Smart requirements for proposed capital projects that have been designed to include adaptation and resiliency features to prevent or mitigate damage to the maximum extent practicable; and authorizing the Council to recommend certain regulations for adoption by the Secretary of Natural Resources.
bill_summary: This bill alters the duties and authority of the Coast Smart Council. It requires the Council to develop eligibility criteria, standards, and procedures for categorical exemptions from Coast Smart requirements for capital projects that already incorporate adaptation and resiliency features. It also authorizes the Council to recommend regulations to the Secretary of Natural Resources to implement the subtitle.
responsible_party: Coast Smart Council; Secretary of Natural Resources
stakeholders: State agencies, developers, and entities involved in capital projects in coastal areas, as well as the residents and environment of Maryland's coastal regions.
innovative_summary: The bill refines existing government processes related to coastal resilience by allowing for categorical exemptions for projects already designed with adaptation features, potentially streamlining approvals. It's an incremental improvement to an existing framework rather than a novel approach or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on coastal construction practices and resilience, aiming to mitigate damage from coastal hazards. It does not directly address child poverty through financial aid, social services, or educational programs. Any impact on child poverty would be extremely indirect, through general economic stability or disaster preparedness, not a direct intervention.

Title: Natural Resources - Wildland Areas - Belt Woods Wildland
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of Natural Resources, with prior approval of the Maryland Historical Trust and after an internal departmental review, to authorize within the Belt Woods Wildland archeological inventories, studies, and research that involve surface examination or limited subsurface sampling, salvage and excavation of archeological sites, and stabilization and restoration of historic structures existing as of December 1, 1985; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to conduct specific activities within the Belt Woods Wildland in Prince George's County. These activities include archeological inventories, studies, salvage, and excavation of archeological sites, as well as stabilization and restoration of historic structures existing as of December 1, 1985. These actions require prior approval from the Maryland Historical Trust and an internal departmental review. Consultation with the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission is required for activities related to the Seton Belt Barn.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: The general public, present and future generations who benefit from preserved wildlands and historical sites; also archeologists, historians, and visitors to the Belt Woods Wildland.
innovative_summary: The bill authorizes standard archeological and historic preservation activities within a wildland area. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government operations or conservation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on land management, historical preservation, and ecological protection within a wildland area. It does not directly provide services, financial aid, or resources that would immediately or directly impact child poverty.

Title: Aquaculture - Placement of Shellfish, Bags, Nets, and Structures on Submerged Aquatic Vegetation - Extension
Synopsis: Extending to June 30, 2027, the authorization of a leaseholder of certain aquaculture leases to, with prior written approval from the Department of Natural Resources, place shellfish, bags, nets, and structures on submerged aquatic vegetation, subject to certain requirements; and requiring, on or before June 1, 2025, and each June 1 for the next 2 years thereafter, the Department to report certain information to the Aquaculture Coordinating Council, the Chesapeake Bay Program, and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: This bill extends the authorization for aquaculture leaseholders to place shellfish, bags, nets, and structures on submerged aquatic vegetation with prior written approval from the Department of Natural Resources. It changes the expiration date of this authorization from June 30, 2024, to June 30, 2027, and requires the Department of Natural Resources to report annually on the impacts of these practices on submerged aquatic vegetation and leaseholders.
responsible_party: Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Aquaculture leaseholders and the broader environmental community concerned with submerged aquatic vegetation.
innovative_summary: This bill is an extension of an existing regulatory authorization and adds reporting requirements. It does not introduce new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government beyond routine data collection and policy adjustments.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill addresses regulations for aquaculture and the protection of submerged aquatic vegetation. It has no direct provisions, funding, or mechanisms designed to impact child poverty.

Title: Aquaculture - Definition of Shellfish - Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "shellfish" as it relates to certain provisions of law governing aquaculture to include live bivalves and bivalve shells.
bill_summary: This bill alters the definition of "shellfish" within Maryland's aquaculture laws to specifically include live mollusks, molluscan bivalves, and bivalve shells. Previously, the definition listed specific items like live oysters, seed oysters, and clams. This change broadens the scope of what is considered shellfish for regulatory purposes related to aquaculture.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR)
stakeholders: Individuals and businesses involved in aquaculture in Maryland, particularly those who cultivate, import, or deal with shellfish for planting in State waters.
innovative_summary: This bill makes a definitional change in existing law, which is a standard legislative update and does not employ new technologies or approaches to government. It is not innovative.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's alteration of the definition of "shellfish" for aquaculture purposes has no direct impact on child poverty. It is a technical regulatory change for an industry.

Title: Public Safety - Board of Boiler Rules - Membership, Sunset Extension, and Report
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Board of Boiler Rules to include a representative with at least 10 years of experience in constructing, installing, and repairing boilers and pressure vessels; extending the termination date for the Board to July 1, 2029; and requiring the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a certain report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the Board of Boiler Rules by increasing the number of appointed members from nine to ten, adding a representative with at least 10 years of experience in constructing, installing, and repairing boilers and pressure vessels. It also extends the termination date for the Board of Boiler Rules from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2029. Additionally, it requires the Maryland Department of Labor to submit a report to the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee on or before July 1, 2025, providing information about the Board of Boiler Rules.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor; Board of Boiler Rules
stakeholders: Owners and users of power boilers, agricultural, model, or historical steam engine equipment, and pressure vessels; manufacturers or assemblers of boilers or pressure vessels; insurers; mechanical and stationary engineers; professional engineers with boiler or pressure vessel experience; consumers; and individuals with experience in constructing, installing, and repairing boilers and pressure vessels.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to an existing state board, including adjusting its membership, extending its sunset date, and requiring a report from a state department. These are standard legislative and governmental oversight functions and do not involve new technologies or innovative approaches to governance or public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on the administrative structure and oversight of the Board of Boiler Rules, which is responsible for boiler and pressure vessel safety standards. It does not introduce any direct mechanisms or initiatives aimed at addressing or alleviating child poverty. Any impact would be extremely indirect through general economic stability, not direct poverty reduction.

Title: Department of Planning - State Repository and Clearinghouse for Federal and State Financial and Technical Assistance
Synopsis: Repealing a requirement that the Department of Planning serve as a repository and clearinghouse for information concerning federal and State grants, loans, and other financial and technical assistance; repealing a requirement that the Department adopt certain regulations and publish certain information in the Maryland Register; and altering a requirement that the Department publish certain information concerning State financial and technical assistance offered through State assistance programs.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the requirement for the Department of Planning (DOP) to serve as a repository and clearinghouse for information regarding federal and State grants, loans, and other financial and technical assistance. It also repeals the requirement that the DOP adopt regulations for State government units to submit such information and publish grant application requirements in the Maryland Register. The bill alters the requirement for the DOP to publish information concerning State financial and technical assistance, specifying that it will now be published annually on the Maryland Infoportal for State assistance programs, rather than in catalogs.
responsible_party: Department of Planning
stakeholders: Units of State government that previously submitted information or published grant requirements, and potentially the public or entities seeking financial and technical assistance from the State, as the method of information dissemination is changing.
innovative_summary: The bill is not highly innovative as it primarily reduces administrative responsibilities and shifts a publication method to an existing digital platform (Maryland Infoportal), rather than introducing new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill deals with administrative changes to how State financial and technical assistance information is managed and published. It does not establish any direct programs, services, or funding mechanisms aimed at alleviating child poverty, so its direct impact is negligible.

Title: Property Tax - Credit for Hotel or Residential Development Projects
Synopsis: Authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is used for certain hotel or residential development projects; and altering eligibility for a certain property tax credit in Wicomico County against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is used for certain hotel or residential development projects.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of any county or municipal corporation to grant local property tax credits for new or substantially rehabilitated hotel or residential development projects. For residential projects, to qualify for the credit, at least 15% of the residential units must be affordable to households earning less than 80% of the area median income. The bill also repeals and modifies a specific property tax credit previously available in Wicomico County, incorporating it into the broader statewide authorization.
responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation
stakeholders: Developers of hotel and residential projects, residents seeking affordable housing, and local governments in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill authorizes local governments to use property tax credits as an incentive for development, including a mandate for affordable housing units. While the affordable housing component addresses a critical social need, the mechanism of property tax credits is a traditional government incentive and does not employ new technologies or particularly novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a direct impact on child poverty by requiring that for residential projects to qualify for the tax credit, at least 15% of the units must be affordable to households earning less than 80% of the area median income. This provision directly increases the supply of affordable housing, which can significantly reduce housing costs for low-income families and improve housing stability, thereby alleviating financial strain and directly impacting child poverty.

Title: Transportation - Vision Zero - Implementation
Synopsis: Establishing certain standards and requirements for implementing the Vision Zero program under the Maryland Department of Transportation.
bill_summary: The bill establishes specific standards and requirements for the implementation of the existing Vision Zero program under the Maryland Department of Transportation. It mandates that the Vision Zero Coordinator hold quarterly public meetings with key transportation officials, which must be live-streamed and archived for 5 years on the Department's website. It also clarifies annual reporting requirements for the program and the activities of the coordinator. The bill explicitly repeals provisions related to the establishment of a Vision Zero Advisory Commission.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation; Vision Zero Coordinator
stakeholders: Drivers, passengers, bicyclists, and pedestrians are directly impacted by roadway safety initiatives. The general public, state agencies, local authorities, law enforcement, and educational institutions are also stakeholders through participation in and transparency of the program's implementation.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances government transparency by mandating live-streamed and archived quarterly public meetings for the Vision Zero program and formalizing reporting requirements. While improving accessibility and accountability, these measures are standard good governance practices rather than introducing new technologies or highly innovative approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving roadway safety, which is a public health and infrastructure initiative. While a safer environment can indirectly benefit all community members, including families with children in poverty, it does not directly address the economic factors or provide financial resources to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Budget Bill (Fiscal Year 2025)
Synopsis: Making the proposed appropriations contained in the State Budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, in accordance with Article III, Section 52 of the Maryland Constitution; etc.
bill_summary: This bill enacts the State Budget for Fiscal Year 2025, appropriating funds for the operations of various Maryland State departments, agencies, commissions, and programs. It includes allocations for state aid to civil divisions, general legislative and judicial expenses, public defender services, and numerous departmental operations ranging from health and human services to education, transportation, public safety, and economic development. The bill also specifies conditions for the expenditure of certain funds, authorizes deficiency appropriations for Fiscal Year 2024, and establishes or adjusts funding for specific grants, initiatives, and capital projects.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management, Governor's Office for Children, Maryland Department of Health, Department of Human Services, Maryland State Department of Education, Department of Housing and Community Development, Maryland Department of Labor, Maryland Department of Commerce.
stakeholders: Maryland residents including children, families, students (public and non-public), low-income individuals, seniors, veterans, individuals with disabilities, victims of crime, healthcare professionals, small businesses, farmers, local governments, cultural and nonprofit organizations, and specific communities across the State.
innovative_summary: The bill funds several initiatives with innovative approaches, such as the development of a public, centralized database for children, youth, and family resources, grants for drone-based security, and support for centers focused on equitable Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Systems. It also allocates funds for a new Cybersecurity Apprenticeship Program and Zero Emission Bus Maintenance Mechanic Apprenticeship Program. Other innovative efforts include studies on commercial community land trusts, a Mesonet project, an Interactive Aging Dashboard, tax fraud detection technology, and the establishment of entertainment district security grants. Many initiatives aim to modernize government services and address societal challenges through data-driven and community-focused strategies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty through significant appropriations for Child Care Assistance Grants, At-Risk Early Childhood Grants, Head Start, and the Concentration of Poverty Grant Program. It also funds programs like the ENOUGH Act, DJS Community Investment Initiative, and grants to organizations like the Family League of Baltimore and Boys & Girls Clubs, which directly support children and families in need. Initiatives for rental assistance, low-income oral health care, and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program Supplemental Benefit for Seniors further contribute to alleviating financial burdens on families with children.

Title: Creation of a State Debt - Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loan of 2024, and the Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loans of 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023
Synopsis: Authorizing the creation of a State Debt in the amount of $1,845,046,000, the proceeds to be used for certain necessary building, construction, demolition, planning, renovation, conversion, replacement, and capital equipment purchases of the State, for acquiring certain real estate in connection therewith, and for grants to certain subdivisions and other organizations for certain development and improvement purposes, subject to certain matching fund requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the creation of a State Debt in the amount of $1,845,046,000 through the Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loan of 2024. The proceeds will be used for various State building, construction, demolition, planning, renovation, and capital equipment purchases. It also provides grants to subdivisions and other organizations for development and improvement purposes, subject to matching fund requirements and historic preservation easements. The bill adjusts prior State Debt authorizations, specifies project locations and fund uses, and outlines administrative procedures for grant approval and fund expenditure.
responsible_party: Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Maryland residents, including students, persons with disabilities, veterans, patients, low- and moderate-income households, and homeless individuals. Beneficiaries include public and non-public schools, local governments, various non-profit organizations, community centers, cultural institutions, and State agencies and facilities across all counties.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily funds traditional capital infrastructure projects such as school construction, facility renovations, and equipment purchases. While some projects may incorporate modern technology (e.g., fiber and broadband in schools, data science centers, mobile health units, robotic mowers), and a 'Housing Innovation Pilot Program' is mentioned, the overall structure and funding mechanisms of the bond loan itself do not represent a new or innovative approach to government services or interventions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has the potential for significant indirect impact on child poverty through extensive funding for public school improvements (Aging Schools Program, Healthy School Facility Fund, Public School Construction Program), public library facilities, and community centers, which enhance educational and recreational opportunities. More direct impacts arise from programs like Homeownership Programs, Partnership Rental Housing Program, Rental Housing Programs (including the Housing Innovation Pilot Program), and the Shelter and Transitional Housing Facilities Grant Program, which aim to provide stable and affordable housing for low- and moderate-income families and homeless individuals, directly benefiting children in those households. Specific grants to organizations supporting children with special needs or youth also contribute to direct impact.

Title: Budget Reconciliation and Financing Act of 2024
Synopsis: Altering or repealing certain required appropriations; authorizing the use of certain funds for certain purposes; altering, from December 1, 2024, to January 15, 2027, the date by which the Accountability and Implementation Board has to conduct and submit a certain independent evaluation; altering the sales and use tax rate on certain electronic smoking devices; repealing a certain small business relief tax credit; requiring interest earnings for certain special funds to accrue to the General Fund of the State during certain fiscal years; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Budget Reconciliation and Financing Act of 2024, makes extensive changes to Maryland's budget and financial operations. Key provisions include altering or repealing certain appropriations, modifying prekindergarten funding amounts and eligibility for 'Tier II children', and prohibiting increases in copayment levels for the Child Care Scholarship Program. It also revises funding formulas for community colleges and private nonprofit higher education institutions, reduces commissions for lottery sales agents, and repeals certain retirement system offsets. The bill changes the timeline for the Maryland Transit Administration's zero-emission bus purchases and reforms the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund, including its funding sources and disbursement methodology. A new transportation network company (TNC) impact fee is imposed on passenger trips, with revenues dedicated to transportation purposes. Furthermore, the bill increases sales and use taxes on electronic smoking devices and other tobacco products, raises annual motor vehicle registration fees and surcharges (including a new surcharge for zero-emission and plug-in electric vehicles), and increases car dealer processing fees and fines for driving while impaired. It extends the period for potential limits on per-pupil funding increases under certain circumstances, repeals the School Construction Revolving Loan Fund and a small business relief tax credit, and establishes a modified Maryland Commission on Transportation Revenue and Infrastructure Needs. Finally, it temporarily redirects net interest earnings from certain special funds to the General Fund and authorizes various fund transfers.
responsible_party: Governor's Office, Comptroller of Maryland, Maryland Department of Transportation, Maryland State Department of Education, Maryland Health Care Commission, Health Services Cost Review Commission, Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: Maryland residents and businesses, parents and children (especially those in prekindergarten and Child Care Scholarship programs), community colleges and students, private nonprofit higher education institutions, consumers, lottery sales agents, state employees and retirees, public transit users, trauma patients and healthcare providers, transportation network companies and passengers, purchasers of tobacco products and electronic smoking devices, motor vehicle owners, car dealers, local school systems, fire, rescue, and ambulance services.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new transportation network company (TNC) impact fee with an indexed annual increase, which is a modern approach to revenue generation from digital platforms, allowing the fee to adjust automatically with inflation. It also modifies the timeline for the Maryland Transit Administration's transition to zero-emission buses, encouraging the adoption of new vehicle technologies within public transit. However, most of the bill's provisions involve adjustments to existing financial mechanisms, tax rates, and administrative processes rather than fundamentally new governmental approaches or technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a direct positive impact on child poverty by prohibiting the State Department of Education from increasing copayment levels for the Child Care Scholarship Program, thereby ensuring continued affordability of childcare for eligible low-income families. Additionally, it alters prekindergarten per-pupil funding and expands eligibility for Tier II children (those with family incomes up to 600% of the federal poverty level in later fiscal years), which can improve access to early education for families who might otherwise struggle with the costs. These measures directly support parental workforce participation and child development, key factors in combating child poverty. Conversely, increases in certain taxes and fees (e.g., motor vehicle registration, tobacco taxes) could disproportionately affect lower-income families, presenting an indirect negative impact.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Military Service Credit - Eligibility
Synopsis: Repealing a limitation for members of the State Retirement and Pension System to receive certain service credit for active duty with the commissioned corps of the Public Health Service, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
bill_summary: This bill repeals existing limitations for members of the State Retirement and Pension System to receive service credit for active duty with the commissioned corps of the Public Health Service, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or the Coast and Geodetic Survey. Previously, there were specific dates and separation from employment requirements that limited this credit; these restrictions are now removed.
responsible_party: State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Members of the State Retirement and Pension System who have served in the commissioned corps of the Public Health Service, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
innovative_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to the eligibility criteria for military service credit within an existing state retirement system. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's changes to military service credit for state retirement benefits could improve the financial security of some state employees in retirement. However, it does not directly target or provide services to address child poverty.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Personal Care Aides - Wage Reports
Synopsis: Requiring residential service agencies to submit certain reports to the Maryland Department of Labor regarding wage rates for personal care aides by September 1 each year, beginning in 2025; and requiring the Maryland Department of Health to report to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Health and Government Operations Committee by the 180th day after the release of the final federal Ensuring Access to Medicaid Services rule on an overview of the final rule and plans or steps that the Department will take to operationalize the rule.
bill_summary: This bill requires residential service agencies to submit annual reports to the Maryland Department of Labor detailing wage rates for personal care aides, beginning in 2025. It also mandates the Maryland Department of Health to report to the General Assembly committees on the final federal Ensuring Access to Medicaid Services rule, including plans to operationalize it, review wage reports, and use the data to adjust Medicaid reimbursement rates. The Department of Health is also required to compare reimbursement rates with actual costs for various home- and community-based services, develop plans to close identified reimbursement gaps, and determine adjustments needed to increase personal care aide wages to at least 150% of the State minimum wage, with these reports due every two years starting in September 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor; Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Personal care aides, residential service agencies, individuals receiving personal assistance services through Medicaid home- and community-based programs, and committees of the Maryland General Assembly.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes new reporting requirements for personal care aide wages and mandates a data-driven approach by the Maryland Department of Health to review and adjust Medicaid reimbursement rates based on these wages and federal rules. While not employing new technologies, it enhances administrative oversight and aims for more equitable compensation through structured reporting and analysis.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill explicitly aims to determine adjustments needed to increase personal care aide wages to at least 150% of the State minimum wage. A significant portion of personal care aides may be low-income individuals, potentially heads of households with children. A direct increase in their wages could substantially raise household income, thereby having a direct and positive impact on reducing child poverty within these families.

Title: State Contracts - Prohibited Provisions
Synopsis: Prohibiting certain provisions from being included in State contracts; specifying that certain provisions are void if included in a State contract; specifying the applicable law and interpretation of State contracts; exempting a State contract relating to the purchase, redevelopment, or operation of a racing facility or training facility site from the prohibitions; and applying the Act prospectively to State contracts executed on or after October 1, 2024, and to the renewal or extension of a State contract on or after October 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits certain provisions from being included in State contracts in Maryland. These prohibited provisions include requirements for the State to indemnify others without an appropriation, binding arbitration clauses, venue other than Maryland courts, limitations on the State's liability for direct loss, terms unknown at signing or unilaterally changeable, appointment of non-Attorney General legal counsel, inconsistencies with general provisions, automatic renewal obligating future funding, and limitations on recovering replacement contractor costs. Any such prohibited provision found in a State contract will be considered void, and the contract will be enforced without it. The bill specifies that State contracts will be governed and construed by State law, and applies prospectively to contracts executed on or after the effective date. An exemption is provided for contracts related to racing or training facilities.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies generally, and the Department of State Finance and Procurement; the Attorney General's office is also relevant for legal counsel provisions.
stakeholders: The State of Maryland, all State agencies, and any private individuals or entities entering into contracts with the State of Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is not innovative. It establishes new legal and administrative rules for State contracts, focusing on standardizing terms and protecting the State's interests rather than employing new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. It is an administrative and legal measure focused on the terms and conditions of State contracts, which does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Higher Education - University of Maryland School of Medicine and MPowering Joint Steering Council - Funding
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to include $5,000,000 in the annual budget for the University of Maryland School of Medicine to provide clinical care at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center; and requiring the Governor to include in the budget for the the MPowering Joint Steering Council to use exclusively on the University of Maryland Institute for Health Computing appropriations of $1,500,000 in fiscal year 2026, $3,000,000 in fiscal year 2027, $4,500,000 in fiscal year 2028, and $6,000,000 in fiscal year 2029 and after.
bill_summary: This bill mandates specific annual appropriations in the State budget for two purposes: first, at least $5,000,000 for the University of Maryland School of Medicine to provide clinical care at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center, making this funding perpetual; and second, new funding starting in fiscal year 2026 for the MPowering Joint Steering Council to exclusively support the University of Maryland Institute for Health Computing.
responsible_party: MPowering Joint Steering Council, University of Maryland School of Medicine
stakeholders: Patients receiving clinical care at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center, researchers, faculty, and students involved with the University of Maryland Institute for Health Computing, and the broader public benefiting from advancements in health computing and clinical services.
innovative_summary: The bill supports the University of Maryland Institute for Health Computing, which represents an innovative approach to healthcare by leveraging data science, advanced computing, and inter-campus collaboration (MPowering Joint Steering Council) to advance health outcomes and research. This reflects a modern, technology-driven approach to public health and medical innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's potential to directly impact child poverty is low. While improved clinical care and advancements in health computing can indirectly benefit overall public health and economic well-being, the bill does not include provisions specifically targeting poverty reduction or direct financial support for children or families in poverty.

Title: Task Force to Study Crime Classification - Renaming, Membership, and Duties
Synopsis:
Extending the Task Force to Study Crime Classification and renaming it to be the Task Force to Study Crime Reclassification and Penalties; requiring the Task Force to study the penalties for crimes and civil offenses under State law, the potential need for reclassification of certain crimes, the alteration of penalties, and whether certain changes should be made to crimes lacking an explicit mens rea; and
requiring the Task Force to report to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 31, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill renames the Task Force to Study Crime Classification to the Task Force to Study Crime Reclassification and Penalties. It alters the task force's membership by adding representatives from the Maryland Sentencing Commission, Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services, Maryland Coalition Against Sexual Assault, and Maryland Crime Victims' Resource Center, Inc. The bill also changes the task force's duties from simply classifying crimes to reviewing penalties for all criminal and civil violations, recommending reclassification of crimes, altering disproportionate penalties, codifying common law offenses, and addressing criminal law provisions that lack an explicit mens rea. The reporting deadline is extended to December 31, 2025, and the act remains effective until June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: Task Force to Study Crime Reclassification and Penalties; Office of the Attorney General (staffing)
stakeholders: The legal system, including prosecutors, public defenders, victims' rights advocates, criminal law practitioners, and ultimately individuals accused of crimes and the general public affected by criminal and civil penalties.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a task force to review and recommend changes to existing crime classifications and penalties. While the task force's work could lead to updated legislation, the approach of forming a task force for legislative review is a standard governmental process and does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on the reclassification of crimes and penalties within the criminal justice system. While changes to criminal law and sentencing can have indirect impacts on families and children (e.g., through incarceration rates affecting household income), the program's direct intent and mechanisms are not aimed at alleviating or addressing child poverty.

Title: Catalytic Revitalization Project Tax Credit - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the amount of a certain credit against the State income tax that certain persons may claim for certain construction and rehabilitation costs for certain catalytic revitalization projects in the State; repealing a certain limitation on the number of initial tax credit certificates the Secretary of Housing and Community Development may award within a 2-year period; prohibiting the Secretary from revoking a tax credit certificate awarded on or before July 1, 2024, except under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the Catalytic Revitalization Project Tax Credit in Maryland. It changes the credit calculation for phased projects, allowing a 100% credit for a completed phase in the year it's issued, rather than 20% over 5 years. It repeals previous limitations on when the Secretary of Housing and Community Development could issue initial and final tax credit certificates, and removes a restriction on how many initial certificates could be awarded within a two-year period, replacing it with a prohibition on accepting new applications more than once every two years. The bill also authorizes the Secretary to revoke an initial credit certificate if the recipient is non-compliant and re-award it to another applicant, provided the amount doesn't exceed the revoked certificate. Additionally, it requires the Secretary to adopt new regulations for approving project phases for these tax credit certificates. The bill specifies that tax credit certificates awarded on or before July 1, 2024, cannot be revoked unless the recipient ceases rehabilitation of the project.
responsible_party: Secretary of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Individuals, nonprofit organizations, and business entities undertaking catalytic revitalization projects in the State; communities and residents benefiting from revitalization efforts, with an emphasis on affordable housing projects.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily refines and streamlines the administrative procedures and financial incentives of an existing tax credit program. While it introduces more flexibility in certificate management (e.g., revocation and re-award), it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government services or delivery. Its innovation lies in improving the efficiency and responsiveness of an existing mechanism.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By facilitating catalytic revitalization projects and emphasizing affordable housing within the tax credit application process, it could contribute to improved living conditions, job creation, and increased availability of affordable housing in certain communities. However, it is not a direct intervention (e.g., direct financial assistance, specific child support programs) aimed explicitly at reducing child poverty.

Title: Correctional Training Commission - Membership - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Correctional Training Commission; requiring certain members of the Commission appointed by the Governor to represent certain geographic regions; etc.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the Correctional Training Commission by increasing the number of correctional officers or officials appointed by the Governor from four to five. It also mandates that these five appointed members must represent specific geographic regions of the State: Capital, Central, Eastern Shore, Southern, and Western. The bill establishes staggered terms for these new appointments, with the changes taking effect on June 1, 2024.
responsible_party: The Governor, with advice and consent of the Senate, and the Correctional Training Commission
stakeholders: Correctional officers and officials in local correctional facilities across Maryland's Capital, Central, Eastern Shore, Southern, and Western regions, as well as the Correctional Training Commission itself.
innovative_summary: This bill makes structural changes to the membership of an existing commission by redefining appointment criteria and geographic representation. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on the composition of the Correctional Training Commission, which is responsible for correctional training standards. It does not directly provide services, resources, or policies that would directly address or alleviate child poverty.

Title: Election Administration - State Administrator, Local Boards, and Election Directors
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Elections to evaluate the performance of the State Administrator of Elections; requiring the State Administrator to provide a performance evaluation of the election director of each local board of elections to the local board; requiring each local board to confer with the State Administrator in appointing an election director, maintain a warehouse, and provide for early voting center expenses; requiring, rather than authorizing, election directors to take certain actions; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland election administration by requiring the State Board of Elections to annually evaluate the performance of the State Administrator of Elections. It also requires the State Administrator to provide annual performance evaluations of local election directors to their respective local boards, including disciplinary recommendations. Additionally, local boards are mandated to confer with the State Administrator when appointing an election director, maintain a warehouse, and cover early voting center expenses. The bill also mandates specific actions for election directors, such as managing voting system equipment and security, notifying the State Administrator of security violations or damage, ensuring cybersecurity for local board equipment, and performing delegated duties.
responsible_party: State Board of Elections, State Administrator of Elections, Local Boards of Elections, Election Directors
stakeholders: Election administrators (State Administrator, local election directors, local boards, State Board members), and the general public indirectly through improved election administration.
innovative_summary: The bill emphasizes maximizing the use of technology in election administration and mandates specific cybersecurity requirements for local board equipment, as well as new security reporting protocols. It introduces new formal performance evaluation and oversight mechanisms within election administration, which, while not employing revolutionary technology, represent an updated approach to accountability and operational efficiency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses entirely on election administration and does not directly address child poverty or provide any programs, services, or financial support that would directly impact children or families experiencing poverty.

Title: Seed Community Development Anchor Institution Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Expanding the purpose and use of the Seed Community Development Anchor Institution Fund administered by the Department of Housing and Community Development to include providing grants and loans to anchor institutions for a certain purpose in sustainable communities; and repealing a requirement that certain matching funds be from a private source.
bill_summary: This bill expands the purpose and use of the Seed Community Development Anchor Institution Fund, administered by the Department of Housing and Community Development. It now allows grants and loans to anchor institutions for community development projects not only in blighted areas but also in designated sustainable communities. Additionally, the bill repeals the requirement that matching funds for these grants and loans must come from a private source.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Anchor institutions (institutions of higher education and hospitals) in Maryland, and residents and businesses in blighted areas and designated sustainable communities that benefit from community development projects.
innovative_summary: The bill expands an existing fund's scope to include community development in "sustainable communities," aligning with smart growth principles and promoting integrated planning. However, it does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new government approaches. The removal of the private source requirement for matching funds is a procedural change.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill supports community development projects in blighted and sustainable areas. While improved community infrastructure, economic opportunities, and quality of life resulting from these projects could indirectly benefit families and potentially reduce child poverty over time, the bill does not establish direct interventions or programs specifically aimed at alleviating child poverty, such as direct financial assistance or child-focused services.

Title: Real Property - Recordation - Procedures
Synopsis: Requiring a county treasurer, tax collector, or director of finance to provide a certificate enumerating certain taxes, assessments, and charges against a property and to establish certain procedures to facilitate the issuance of a certificate; requiring a collecting agent presented with a certificate to endorse a deed on payment of transfer and recordation taxes and all charges stated in the certificate and establishing that this endorsement is sufficient authority for a transfer on the assessment books; etc.
bill_summary: This bill streamlines the process for recording real property instruments by requiring county treasurers, tax collectors, or directors of finance to provide certificates enumerating all public taxes, assessments, and charges due on a property. It establishes procedures for issuing these certificates and requires collecting agents to endorse deeds upon payment of stated charges and applicable transfer/recordation taxes. Additionally, it mandates that clerks of circuit courts and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation facilitate the electronic satisfaction of prior approvals and conditions precedent to recording documents, as well as electronic payment of associated fees or taxes.
responsible_party: County treasurers, tax collectors, directors of finance, clerks of circuit courts, and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
stakeholders: Property owners, individuals involved in real estate transactions, county and municipal governments, and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
innovative_summary: The bill promotes innovation by requiring the electronic satisfaction of prior approvals and conditions for recording documents, as well as electronic payment of fees and taxes. This shifts traditional paper-based processes to digital platforms, enhancing efficiency and accessibility for real property transactions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily addresses administrative procedures for real property recordation and tax collection, focusing on streamlining processes and facilitating electronic transactions. It does not contain any provisions that directly aim to alleviate or address child poverty.

Title: Garrett County Alcoholic Beverages Act of 2024
Synopsis: Establishing a resort beer license, a resort beer and wine license, and a beer, wine, and liquor festival license in Garrett County; altering the hours of sale for alcoholic beverages on Sundays for certain licenses; altering the residency requirements for certain applicants for an alcoholic beverages license in the county to require that at least one of the applicants be a resident of the State; prohibiting alcoholic beverages from being brought into places of adult entertainment and consumed or transferred; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Garrett County Alcoholic Beverages Act of 2024, establishes new alcoholic beverage licenses in Garrett County: a resort beer license, a resort beer and wine license, and a beer, wine, and liquor festival license. It alters the permitted hours for Sunday alcoholic beverage sales, changes residency requirements for certain license applicants, prohibits bringing alcoholic beverages into adult entertainment venues for consumption or transfer, and increases the maximum fine for violating alcoholic beverage laws in the county.
responsible_party: Garrett County Board of [Alcoholic Beverages] License Commissioners and Garrett County
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders and applicants in Garrett County, businesses operating in the county, customers of licensed establishments, attendees of the Garrett County Beer, Wine, and Liquor Festival, and adult entertainment establishments and their patrons.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily adjusts local alcoholic beverage licensing and regulations. While it creates specific 'resort' and 'festival' licenses, these are tailored applications of existing licensing frameworks rather than introducing new technologies or fundamentally novel government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses exclusively on alcoholic beverage licensing, sales regulations, and related penalties. It does not contain any provisions or mechanisms designed to directly address or impact child poverty.

Title: Corporations and Associations - Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of Washington
Synopsis: Repealing uncodified provisions of law relating to the Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of Washington, commonly known as the "Vestry Act"; and providing for the governance of religious corporations in union with the Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of Washington.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the uncodified 'Vestry Act' and establishes a new legal framework for the governance and temporal affairs of religious corporations in union with the Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of Washington. It integrates these corporations into the Corporations and Associations Article, allows them to adopt bylaws, and subjects them to the church's constitution and canons. The bill also formally recognizes the legal corporate existence of numerous specific parishes in Montgomery, Prince George's, Charles, and St. Mary's counties.
responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
stakeholders: Religious corporations, parishes, and congregations in union with the Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of Washington, specifically those located in Montgomery, Prince George's, Charles, and St. Mary's counties.
innovative_summary: This bill is primarily a legal and administrative update, clarifying governance and corporate status for specific religious organizations. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative government approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on the legal governance and corporate status of religious organizations and does not include any direct provisions, services, or funding mechanisms aimed at addressing child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect, through the pre-existing charitable activities of the religious organizations themselves.

Title: Community Health and Safety Works Grant Program and Fund - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Community Health and Safety Works Grant Program in the Department of Housing and Community Development to support certain eligible projects that improve the quality of life within and economic potential of Maryland communities by making targeted investments in crime prevention strategies to address certain concerns in certain areas; establishing the Community Health and Safety Works Grant Program Fund to provide financial assistance in the form of grants under the provisions of the Program for eligible projects; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Community Health and Safety Works Grant Program and Fund within the Department of Housing and Community Development. The program provides financial assistance in the form of grants for eligible projects designed to improve the quality of life and economic potential in Maryland communities by investing in crime prevention strategies. Eligible projects include facility and community improvements, business district and neighborhood security enhancements, and community-centered crime and violence intervention and prevention initiatives. The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund, with a mandated appropriation of $10,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2025 through 2028.
responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Maryland communities, residents, visitors, individuals at risk of becoming involved with or affected by violence and crime, tax-exempt nonprofit organizations, governmental units for political subdivisions, institutions of higher education, and local neighborhood associations.
innovative_summary: The program provides dedicated funding for a comprehensive approach to community safety, integrating environmental design (e.g., surveillance, lighting, landscaping, graffiti removal), community-based security services, and evidence-based violence intervention strategies. While the individual components are not entirely novel, the establishment of a state-level grant program specifically combining these elements for a broad range of community stakeholders represents a structured and coordinated approach to addressing crime and improving public spaces.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's primary focus is on improving community safety, reducing crime, and enhancing the economic potential and quality of life in neighborhoods. While a safer and more stable community environment can indirectly benefit children and families by fostering better living conditions and potentially improving access to opportunities, it does not directly provide financial aid, housing support, food security, or educational resources specifically targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Education - State Library Resource Center - Funding
Synopsis: Altering the calculation of certain funding for the State Library Resource Center for fiscal year 2025 and each fiscal year thereafter.
bill_summary: This bill alters the calculation of funding for the State Library Resource Center (Enoch Pratt Free Library System) for specific fiscal years, increasing the per-resident funding amount incrementally from Fiscal Year 2024 through Fiscal Year 2031 and each year thereafter.
responsible_party: State Library Resource Center (Enoch Pratt Free Library System)
stakeholders: State Library Resource Center and all Maryland State residents who utilize library services.
innovative_summary: This bill updates an existing funding formula for a traditional library service and does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill provides increased funding for the State Library Resource Center, which offers general library services to all residents. While these services can indirectly benefit children in poverty by providing access to resources, the bill does not directly target child poverty or specific interventions for it.

Title: Family Law - Victims of Domestic Violence Program - Certification and Grant Fund
Synopsis: Requiring a victims of domestic violence program to be certified by the federally recognized State domestic violence coalition as a comprehensive domestic violence program; establishing the Victims of Domestic Violence Program Grant Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund in the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services;  requiring interest earnings of the Fund to be credited to the Fund; and authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of $5,000,000 to the Fund.
bill_summary: This bill requires victims of domestic violence programs to be certified by the federally recognized State domestic violence coalition as comprehensive programs. It establishes the Victims of Domestic Violence Program Grant Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund within the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services, with annual appropriations of $5,000,000, to provide grants to certified public or private nonprofit comprehensive domestic violence programs for operations, including establishing additional shelters.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Victims of domestic violence and their children, as well as public or private nonprofit comprehensive domestic violence programs in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a dedicated grant fund and formalizes a certification requirement for domestic violence programs to receive grants, ensuring that funded programs meet comprehensive standards. While this improves program quality and funding mechanisms, it is more of a refinement of existing governmental support structures rather than introducing new technologies or radically different governance approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: By providing a dedicated, recurring grant fund for comprehensive domestic violence programs, the bill directly supports services like temporary shelter, counseling, and rehabilitation for victims and their children. These services are crucial for stabilizing families fleeing abusive situations, preventing homelessness, ensuring safety, and providing resources that can alleviate the immediate and long-term impacts of child poverty associated with domestic violence. This direct support helps create safer, more stable environments, which are foundational to reducing child poverty.

Title: Commission to Study African American Civil War Soldiers in Maryland
Synopsis: Establishing the Commission to Study African American Civil War Soldiers in Maryland to study the history of the African American soldiers who fought for the Union Army in Maryland and to make findings and recommendations regarding the funding, design, construction, and location of an appropriate memorial dedicated to the African American Civil War soldiers; and requiring the Commission to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Commission to Study African American Civil War Soldiers in Maryland. The Commission is tasked with studying the history of African American soldiers who fought for the Union Army, including their service details and honors. It will also make recommendations regarding the funding, design, construction, and location of a memorial dedicated to these soldiers. The Commission must report its findings and recommendations by December 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Commission to Study African American Civil War Soldiers in Maryland, with staff provided by the State Archives
stakeholders: Historians, descendants of African American Civil War soldiers, the general public interested in Maryland history and memorials, and Maryland's African American community.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a commission to conduct a historical study and recommend a memorial. While important for cultural preservation, it does not employ new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government functions. It is a traditional government commission and study.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on historical research and the establishment of a memorial for African American Civil War soldiers. It does not directly provide services, financial aid, or policy changes that would immediately or directly impact child poverty.

Title: Courts - Prohibited Liability Agreements - Recreational Facilities
Synopsis: Establishing that a provision in a contract or agreement relating to the use of a recreational facility that purports to limit the recreational facility's liability, or release the recreational facility from or indemnify or hold harmless the recreational facility against liability, for injury caused by or resulting from the negligence or other wrongful acts of the recreational facility or its agents or on-duty employees is void and unenforceable under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill establishes that any provision in a contract or agreement related to the use of a recreational facility that attempts to limit the facility's liability, release it from liability, or indemnify it against liability for injuries caused by its negligence or other wrongful acts, is void and unenforceable. This applies to commercial recreational and athletic facilities, including gymnasiums and swimming pools, but generally excludes lodging establishments unless they operate a recreational facility available to the general public, and units of state or local government leasing facilities. It also does not apply to health club services agreements for adults.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and legal system (Courts and Judicial Proceedings)
stakeholders: Users of commercial recreational facilities, commercial athletic facilities, and amusement attractions, as well as the owners and operators of these facilities.
innovative_summary: This bill is a legal reform aimed at enhancing consumer protection by voiding certain liability waivers in recreational facility contracts. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new governmental approaches, but rather adjusts existing legal frameworks related to contract enforceability and tort liability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill enhances consumer protection by making recreational facilities more accountable for negligence. While this could indirectly benefit families, including those with children experiencing poverty, by ensuring potential compensation for injuries or reducing medical burdens, it does not directly address the core drivers of child poverty such as income, housing, food security, or educational access. Its impact on child poverty would be minimal and indirect.

Title: Criminal Law - Private Home Detention Monitoring - Notification
Synopsis: Requiring a private home detention monitoring agency to notify the court within 24 hours after a defendant subject to home monitoring as a condition of pretrial release has violated a condition of home detention monitoring; requiring a private home detention monitoring agency to notify the Division of Parole and Probation within 1 hour after an individual subject to home monitoring as a condition of probation violated a condition of home detention monitoring; etc.
bill_summary: This bill amends existing law to require private home detention monitoring agencies to notify the court or the Division of Parole and Probation within specific timeframes (immediately, within 1 hour, or within 24 hours) when a defendant or individual on probation violates a condition of home detention monitoring. Previously, notification was primarily for individuals missing for 24 hours. The bill also clarifies that a person is 'released' to a private home detention monitoring agency and authorizes the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services to impose civil penalties for failure to give timely notice.
responsible_party: Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services; Division of Parole and Probation; Maryland Courts
stakeholders: Private home detention monitoring agencies, defendants subject to pretrial release with home detention, individuals on probation with home detention, and law enforcement agencies.
innovative_summary: This bill refines existing regulatory and notification processes for home detention monitoring. It does not introduce new technologies or fundamentally new approaches to government, but rather enhances the timeliness and specificity of incident reporting for current monitoring practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on criminal law, specifically the operational aspects and accountability of private home detention monitoring. It does not include provisions for economic support, educational programs, or direct services aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity and Related Approvals - Definition of Generating Station (Critical Infrastructure Streamlining Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Altering and establishing the definition of "generating station" for the purpose of exempting the construction of certain generating facilities used to produce electricity for the purpose of on-site emergency backup and certain test and maintenance operations from the requirement to obtain a certificate of public convenience and necessity or certain other related approvals under certain circumstances; and altering the distribution of income tax revenue from corporations that is attributable to certain data centers.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the Critical Infrastructure Streamlining Act of 2024, alters the definition of "generating station" to exempt certain generating facilities used for onsite emergency backup at critical infrastructure sites (like hospitals and data centers) from requiring a certificate of public convenience and necessity and other related approvals. It also mandates reporting requirements for these exempted facilities to the Department of the Environment and for the Maryland Energy Administration to report on backup generation technologies. Furthermore, it reallocates 15% of corporate income tax revenue from qualified data centers to the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment, Maryland Energy Administration, Department of Commerce, Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: Owners and operators of critical infrastructure facilities (including hospitals and data centers) in Maryland, the general public who rely on critical infrastructure, and the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund.
innovative_summary: The bill is not highly innovative, as it primarily modifies regulatory definitions and processes for existing energy infrastructure and reallocates tax revenue. While it supports the reliable operation of critical infrastructure, it doesn't introduce new technologies or groundbreaking governmental approaches. It mandates reporting on "advancements in backup generation technologies," but this is an information-gathering role, not an innovative program itself.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill has no direct impact on child poverty. Its focus is on energy infrastructure, regulatory streamlining, and corporate tax revenue allocation, with no provisions for direct assistance, services, or economic opportunities targeting low-income families or children.

Title: Families Serve Act of 2024
Synopsis: Authorizing employers to grant a preference in hiring and promotion to spouses of eligible service members; and requiring the appointing authorities in the Executive Branch of State government to apply a credit of 10 points on any selection test for eligible spouses and veterans of certain uniformed services.
bill_summary: The Families Serve Act of 2024 authorizes private employers to grant hiring and promotion preferences to spouses of active duty service members, eligible veterans, spouses of eligible veterans with service-connected disabilities, and surviving spouses of deceased eligible veterans. It also requires appointing authorities in the Executive Branch of State government to apply a 10-point credit on selection tests for eligible military spouses, eligible veterans, spouses of eligible veterans with service-connected disabilities, and surviving spouses of deceased eligible veterans, with an additional 2 points for former prisoners of war. These preferences do not violate equal employment opportunity laws.
responsible_party: Appointing authorities in the Executive Branch of State government; private employers
stakeholders: Spouses of eligible service members, eligible military spouses, eligible veterans, spouses of eligible veterans with service-connected disabilities, surviving spouses of deceased eligible veterans, and former prisoners of war.
innovative_summary: This bill modifies existing hiring and promotion preference laws by expanding eligibility to include spouses of active duty military service members. While it aims to support military families, it does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches, but rather adjusts existing policy frameworks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential impact on child poverty is indirect. By improving employment and promotion opportunities for military spouses and veterans, it may increase household income for some families, which could, in turn, alleviate financial hardship for children in those households. However, it is not a direct child poverty reduction program.

Title: Governor's Office for Children - Engaging Neighborhoods, Organizations, Unions, Governments, and Households (ENOUGH) Grant Program (ENOUGH Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Establishing the Governor's Office for Children and the Special Secretary of the Governor's Office for Children as the head of the Office; requiring the Special Secretary to chair the Children's Cabinet; requiring the Office to staff the Children's Cabinet; requiring the Children's Cabinet to meet not less than four times each year; requiring the Accountability and Implementation Board, in consultation with certain departments, to submit a certain recommendation to the General Assembly by December 1, 2025; etc.
bill_summary: This bill, known as the ENOUGH Act of 2024, establishes the Engaging Neighborhoods, Organizations, Unions, Governments, and Households (ENOUGH) Grant Program within the Governor's Office for Children. The program is designed to advance place-based strategies targeting child poverty in eligible neighborhoods by providing grants for technical assistance, planning, and implementation. It requires the Children's Cabinet to meet regularly and submit reports, and mandates the Governor's Office for Children to develop a public centralized database of resources. The bill also establishes the ENOUGH Grant Fund and specifies an initial appropriation of $15 million for fiscal year 2026.
responsible_party: Governor’s Office for Children, Special Secretary of the Governor’s Office for Children, Children's Cabinet
stakeholders: Children, youth, and families living in eligible neighborhoods with high concentrations of child poverty; local community organizations, unions, anchor institutions, small business owners, local law enforcement agencies, faith-based organizations, local governmental entities, public schools, and local management boards involved as partners.
innovative_summary: The program employs an innovative 'place-based' and 'community-driven' approach to addressing child poverty, requiring partnerships between various local entities. It also features dedicated staff assigned to grant recipients to serve as liaisons to State government and help navigate funding streams, alongside the creation of a public centralized database of resources.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill directly targets child poverty by establishing a grant program specifically designed to advance place-based strategies aimed at reducing it. Its purposes include increasing community health and safety, providing access to high-quality education and care, connecting residents to quality jobs, enabling family-sustaining income, and improving access to essential services like housing, childcare, and healthcare for families in eligible neighborhoods.

Title: Education - Child Care Career and Professional Development Fund - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the qualifications for an award from the Child Care Career and Professional Development Fund to include a service obligation to work in an approved child care setting for at least 20 hours per week; requiring the Office of Child Care to prioritize grant awards to certain applicants; requiring award recipients who do not perform the service obligation to repay certain award funding except under certain circumstances; and applying the Act prospectively.
bill_summary: This bill alters the Child Care Career and Professional Development Fund by adding a service obligation requirement for award recipients. Individuals receiving funds must commit to working in an approved child care setting for at least 20 hours per week for a period determined by the Office of Child Care after completing their course of study. The bill also prioritizes grant awards to applicants who have not completed any college courses and those attending institutions offering native language or bilingual coursework in early childhood education. Furthermore, it establishes a repayment requirement for recipients who do not fulfill their service obligation, with provisions for waiver or deferral under extenuating circumstances.
