innovative_summary: The bill introduces and specifies requirements for 'newborn safety devices,' which are climate-controlled, equipped with 9-1-1 alert systems, video surveillance, and automated locks. This utilizes new technology to facilitate safe surrender. The public information program also includes the maintenance of an interactive website, which is a modern approach to public outreach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program provides a safe alternative for parents unable or unwilling to care for a newborn, preventing abandonment and ensuring the child's immediate safety and entry into the welfare system. While it does not directly address financial poverty, it provides a critical safety net that can prevent a child from facing extreme hardship or neglect, indirectly supporting their welfare. By ensuring a safe start, it lays a foundation for future well-being, but it does not offer direct financial or material support to alleviate child poverty.

Title: Public Health – Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program – Recovery of Funding
Synopsis: Altering the number of years after completion of a project funded in part by a grant of the Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program after which the State may recover funding under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Federally Qualified Health Centers Grant Program by altering the period during which the State may recover grant funding. Previously, the State could recover funds within 30 years after project completion if the property was sold, transferred, or ceased to be a federally qualified health center. The new law differentiates, allowing recovery within 15 years for leased properties and within 30 years for owned properties.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Counties, municipal corporations, and nonprofit organizations that receive grants to operate or intend to operate Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) in Maryland, as well as the FQHCs themselves.
innovative_summary: This bill is administrative in nature, clarifying existing rules for funding recovery. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's changes to funding recovery periods for Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) have a very indirect potential impact on child poverty. While FQHCs often serve low-income populations, including children, this specific administrative amendment does not directly provide services, financial aid, or other direct support that would alleviate child poverty. Its effect is limited to the financial and operational stability of the centers, which could, in turn, indirectly affect service availability.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Licensing Fees
Synopsis: Altering certain licensing fees for alcoholic beverages in Baltimore City.
bill_summary: This bill alters various alcoholic beverage licensing fees in Baltimore City. It increases annual license fees for different classes of beer, beer and light wine, and beer, wine, and liquor licenses. It also raises supplementary fees for Sunday sales and renewal application fees. Additionally, for certain festival and tasting licenses, the Board is now granted the authority to set the license fees rather than having them fixed in the law.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Board of Liquor License Commissioners
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders in Baltimore City, including breweries, restaurants, package goods stores, arenas, racetracks, municipal golf courses, zoos, and special event organizers.
innovative_summary: This bill focuses on administrative adjustments to existing alcoholic beverage licensing fees in Baltimore City. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government operations or public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill solely deals with altering alcoholic beverage licensing fees and does not contain any provisions that directly establish services, funding, or policies aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority Task Force
Synopsis: Establishing the Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority Task Force to study and make recommendations concerning the membership, purpose, and function of an entity or strategy to govern the renovation, revitalization, financing, and ongoing maintenance and management of the Baltimore Convention site and certain surrounding areas; and requiring the Task Force to report its findings and recommendations to the Mayor of Baltimore City, the Governor, and the General Assembly on or before December 1, 2024.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority Task Force. The Task Force is charged with studying and making recommendations on the membership, purpose, and function of an entity or strategy to govern the renovation, revitalization, financing, maintenance, and management of the Baltimore Convention site and its immediate surrounding areas. It aims to foster economic development, tourism, and job creation in Baltimore City and the State.
responsible_party: Department of Commerce
stakeholders: The Task Force members represent various state and local government entities, business and tourism organizations, labor unions, and community groups, including the Mayor of Baltimore City, State legislators, Secretaries of State agencies, executives of tourism and development corporations, representatives from the restaurant and hotel industries, and residents and businesses near the Baltimore Convention site. The ultimate stakeholders are the residents of Baltimore City and Maryland who benefit from economic development and tourism.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a temporary task force to study governance and redevelopment strategies for the Baltimore Convention Center and surrounding areas. While the formation of a task force is a common governmental approach, the mandate to consider various operating models, evaluate underutilized assets, and make recommendations that specifically exclude the status quo and at least one option that does not include a public-private partnership, could lead to innovative policy proposals for urban revitalization and economic development.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill establishes a task force focused on economic development, tourism, and the revitalization of the Baltimore Convention site. While successful economic development can lead to job creation and increased prosperity, which may indirectly alleviate child poverty, the task force's direct mandate does not include specific programs or interventions directly aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Public Safety – Extreme Risk Protective Orders – Review of Court Records
Synopsis: Authorizing researchers affiliated with institutions of higher education who are conducting research to review a court record related to a petition for an extreme risk protective order; requiring the Maryland Judiciary to require an institution of higher education that has researchers reviewing court records to enter into an agreement providing for the storage and handling of the records; authorizing the Judiciary to institute an injunction or other remedy for a violation of the agreement and to prevent disclosure of certain records; etc.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes researchers affiliated with institutions of higher education to review confidential court records related to extreme risk protective orders (ERPOs) for academic or policy research. The Maryland Judiciary is required to enter into agreements with these institutions to ensure the secure storage, handling, and confidentiality of the records, stipulating that the information may only be used for the stated research and cannot be disclosed to unauthorized persons. The bill takes effect on October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
stakeholders: Researchers affiliated with institutions of higher education conducting academic or policy research, and individuals whose confidential court records related to extreme risk protective orders may be reviewed for such research.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a structured framework for academic and policy researchers to access confidential court records related to extreme risk protective orders. This approach fosters data-driven policy evaluation and research by enabling external academic review of sensitive government data, under strict confidentiality agreements, which is a modern method for informing public safety policy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary focus is on public safety through extreme risk protective orders and facilitating research on these orders. It does not directly address child poverty through economic support, services, or policy changes aimed at poverty reduction. Any impact on child poverty would be highly indirect, stemming from potential long-term public safety improvements.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Bus Lane Obstruction - Monitoring Systems Expansion and Workgroup (Better Bus Service Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Prohibiting a person from parking or standing certain vehicles in a dedicated bus lane; making statewide the authority of a local jurisdiction to use, in accordance with certain standards and procedures, a bus lane monitoring system to enforce the prohibition against driving, standing, or parking a motor vehicle in a designated bus lane; and establishing the Workgroup on Curb Space Management.
bill_summary: The "Better Bus Service Act of 2024" expands statewide the authority for local jurisdictions and transit agencies to use automated bus lane obstruction monitoring systems. It prohibits vehicles from driving, standing, or parking in dedicated bus lanes, bus stop zones, and bike lanes, and authorizes the use of these monitoring systems to enforce these prohibitions. The bill also establishes a temporary Workgroup on Curb Space Management to analyze curb space regulations, recommend strategies for managing roadways with frequent bus service, examine obstruction enforcement at bus stops, and provide recommendations for a public education campaign and addressing privacy concerns related to the monitoring systems.
responsible_party: Law enforcement agencies, parking enforcement agencies, local, regional, or statewide transit agencies or authorities (including the Maryland Transit Administration and the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority), the Chief Judge of the District Court, the Governor, and the Department of Transportation.
stakeholders: Motorists who violate bus lane, bus stop, or certain parking rules; public transit riders who benefit from more efficient bus service; local jurisdictions; the Maryland Transit Administration; the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority; local departments of transportation; school bus operators; emergency vehicle operators; and members of the Workgroup on Curb Space Management.
innovative_summary: The bill expands the use of automated bus lane obstruction monitoring systems statewide, applying this technology to enforce a wider range of vehicle prohibitions in dedicated bus lanes, bus stops, and bike lanes. While the core technology of automated enforcement systems is not entirely new, its broader application, explicit inclusion of transit stops and bike lanes, and the requirement to consider privacy concerns (e.g., prohibition of biometric identification), represent a moderately innovative approach to traffic management and improving public transit efficiency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's potential to directly impact child poverty is minimal. It focuses on improving bus service efficiency through traffic enforcement, which could indirectly benefit low-income families by making transit more reliable for accessing jobs, education, and services. However, it does not provide direct financial assistance, educational programs, housing support, or other direct interventions against child poverty.

Title: Assisted Living Programs - Assisted Living Referrers - Requirements and Prohibitions
Synopsis: Establishing certain requirements for assisted living referrers, including requirements related to the maintenance of general liability insurance, criminal history records checks, and the provision of certain agreements and descriptions of services; prohibiting an assisted living referrer from requesting payment for a referral more than 2 years after the referral was made; requiring the Office of Health Care Quality to maintain a certain database of approved assisted living programs; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes new requirements and prohibitions for assisted living referrers in Maryland. It mandates that referrers maintain general liability insurance, conduct criminal history checks for employees, and enter into written agreements with clients outlining services. The bill prohibits referrers from requesting referral fees more than two years after the referral and from selling client data. It also requires the Office of Health Care Quality to maintain a user-friendly database of licensed assisted living programs and enforces strict data privacy provisions for referrers, requiring informed consent for sharing medical records and prohibiting the sale of personal data.
responsible_party: Office of Health Care Quality; Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Assisted living referrers, assisted living programs, and individuals seeking assisted living services (clients/potential clients and their representatives).
innovative_summary: The bill introduces specific data privacy regulations for assisted living referrers, requiring informed consent for sharing medical information and prohibiting the sale of personal data, with a clear timeline for compliance with broader data privacy laws. It also mandates the Office of Health Care Quality to maintain a user-friendly database of licensed assisted living programs, enhancing transparency and consumer access to information. These measures represent a modern approach to consumer protection and regulatory oversight in the elder care referral industry.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses on regulating assisted living referral services, which primarily serve adults, typically seniors, seeking long-term care. It does not contain provisions or programs that directly address issues of child poverty, such as financial assistance, educational support, or healthcare for children.

Title: Maryland Clean Energy Center - Climate Technology Founder's Fund
Synopsis: Establishing the Climate Technology Founder's Fund in the Maryland Clean Energy Center; requiring the Maryland Energy Administration to use the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund to provide at least $1,200,000 in each fiscal year for fiscal years 2025 through 2028 to the Climate Technology Founder's Fund; authorizing the Governor, on or before June 30, 2024, to transfer up to $2,200,000 of funds in the the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account to the Climate Technology Founder's Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Climate Technology Founder's Fund within the Maryland Clean Energy Center. The purpose of the fund is to provide early-stage funding for start-up companies focused on climate technologies, including solar, wind, energy storage, grid modernization, and carbon capture. The fund will be administered by the Maryland Clean Energy Center, with an oversight committee. Funding will come from the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund (at least $1.2 million annually from FY2025-FY2028) and a one-time transfer of up to $2.2 million from the Small, Minority, and Women-Owned Businesses Account. The bill prioritizes funding for small, minority, women-owned, and veteran-owned businesses, and allocates 40% of seed grants for start-up companies from Minority Serving Institutions. Recipients must provide matching funds.
responsible_party: Maryland Clean Energy Center
stakeholders: Start-up companies focused on climate technologies, particularly small, minority, women-owned, and veteran-owned businesses in the clean energy industry, and start-up companies from Minority Serving Institutions.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a dedicated fund to provide early-stage funding for start-up companies developing new climate technologies, such as advanced energy solutions and carbon capture. This approach supports innovation by de-risking early investments in emerging green technologies and focuses on supporting diverse entrepreneurs in this critical sector.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program aims to foster economic growth and job creation within the climate technology sector by funding start-up companies. While successful companies may create jobs that could indirectly benefit families and potentially reduce poverty, the program does not directly provide services, financial assistance, or interventions aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Carroll County – Alcoholic Beverages Licenses – Alcohol Awareness Training
Synopsis: Requiring the holder of a Class B or Class D alcoholic beverages license in Carroll County or an individual designated by the license holder who has completed training in an approved alcohol awareness program to be present on the licensed premises at certain times when alcoholic beverages may be sold; providing for certain penalties; and requiring at least one license holder to maintain alcohol awareness program certification while listed on the license.
bill_summary: This bill requires the holder of a Class B or Class D alcoholic beverages license in Carroll County, or a designated individual, to be certified in an approved alcohol awareness program and to be present on the licensed premises during hours when alcoholic beverages may be sold. It also mandates that at least one license holder listed on the license maintains a current alcohol awareness program certification. The bill establishes penalties for violations, including fines and potential suspension or revocation of the license.
responsible_party: Carroll County local alcoholic beverages licensing authority
stakeholders: Class B and Class D alcoholic beverages license holders, their designated supervisory employees, and patrons of establishments with such licenses in Carroll County.
innovative_summary: This bill introduces standard regulatory updates regarding alcohol awareness training and presence requirements for license holders. It does not employ new technologies or innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on alcohol awareness training and regulatory compliance for alcoholic beverages licenses has no direct impact on child poverty. Its effects are primarily on local businesses and alcohol sales practices.

Title: Prior Authorizations of State Debt - Alterations
Synopsis: Amending certain prior authorizations of State Debt to change the names of certain grantees, alter the authorized uses of certain grants, and extend the termination date of certain grants.
bill_summary: This bill amends prior authorizations of State Debt in Maryland by changing the names of certain grantees, altering the authorized uses of existing grants, extending the termination dates for some grants, and adding new grant authorizations. The grants fund a variety of capital projects including community centers, recreational facilities, medical centers, infrastructure improvements, parks, cultural centers, and low-income housing across various counties and Baltimore City.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources (for specific grants); Maryland Board of Public Works (for general grant oversight and disbursement of state debt); various local government entities and nonprofit organizations are direct grantees.
stakeholders: The general public across Maryland, specifically residents of Baltimore City, Prince George's, Anne Arundel, Carroll, Howard, Montgomery, Charles, Washington, Caroline, St. Mary's, and Calvert Counties. Stakeholders include children and youth (through Boys & Girls Clubs, playgrounds), families seeking low-income housing, individuals in recovery, and communities benefiting from improved infrastructure, recreational amenities, and cultural facilities.
innovative_summary: This bill is primarily administrative, re-allocating and re-directing existing state debt authorizations and adding new grants for capital projects. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches. The programs funded are traditional capital improvement projects for community, recreational, and housing needs.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill includes grants for projects with direct potential to impact child poverty, such as funding for low-income housing properties (IHOMES), community resource centers (C.A.R.E. Community Resource Center), and facilities for the Boys & Girls Clubs of Southern Maryland. Additionally, investments in local parks and playgrounds can provide safe, accessible recreational opportunities for children in underserved communities.

Title: Hospitals - Private Hospital Grant Program - Funding
Synopsis: Codifying a private hospital grant program for the purpose of making recommendations to the Governor for funding for capital projects at private hospitals in the State; requiring the Maryland Hospital Association to establish a certain review committee to develop a certain process for hospitals in the State to submit requests for funding; authorizing the Governor to include in the capital or operating budget bill in certain fiscal years an appropriation of $20,000,000 for the Private Hospital Grant Program; etc.
bill_summary: This bill codifies the Private Hospital Grant Program, establishing a mechanism for recommending state funding for capital projects at private hospitals. The Maryland Hospital Association is required to establish a review committee to develop processes, eligibility and project criteria, and deadlines for funding requests, and to make final recommendations to the Governor. The Governor may include an annual appropriation of $20,000,000 in the state budget for this program, starting in fiscal year 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Hospital Association (in consultation with the Department of Budget and Management and the Department of Legislative Services)
stakeholders: Private hospitals in Maryland, and indirectly, patients served by these hospitals.
innovative_summary: The program establishes a formal grant process for capital funding to private hospitals, managed by a review committee. While it codifies and formalizes a funding mechanism, the approach itself is a standard governmental grant program and does not employ new technologies or significantly novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill provides funding for capital improvements at private hospitals. While improved hospital infrastructure can generally benefit all community members, including children from low-income families, there is no direct provision or mechanism in the bill specifically designed to address or alleviate child poverty. Any impact would be indirect through general healthcare access and quality.

Title: Maryland Department of Health - Reproductive Health Care Clinic Security Grant Program - Establishment (Supporting Reproductive Health Care Clinics Act)
Synopsis: Establishing the Reproductive Health Care Clinic Security Grant Program in the Maryland Department of Health to assist reproductive health care clinics in the State with costs associated with security improvements and safety operational expenses; prohibiting the Department from disclosing certain personal information of an individual associated with the Program; and authorizing the Governor to include in the annual budget bill for fiscal year 2026 an appropriation of $500,000 to the Program.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Reproductive Health Care Clinic Security Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health. The program aims to provide financial assistance to reproductive health care clinics across the State for security improvements, such as facility hardening, lighting, fencing, access control systems, cameras, and alarms, as well as operational safety expenses. The Governor may appropriate $500,000 for fiscal year 2026 for this program, with up to 5% allowed for administrative costs. The Department of Health is responsible for administering the program and protecting the personal information of applicants and grant recipients.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Reproductive health care clinics in Maryland and individuals who utilize their services, including those seeking legally protected health care.
innovative_summary: The program focuses on providing grants for standard security improvements and operational safety expenses for health care clinics. While crucial for safety, these measures do not employ new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's primary goal is to enhance the security of reproductive health care clinics. While access to healthcare services, including reproductive health, can indirectly impact family stability and economic well-being, the program does not directly provide financial assistance, education, or other services specifically aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Information Technology - Modernization of Information Technology Projects
Synopsis: Altering the duties of the Secretary of Information Technology related to modernization of information technology systems; renaming the Major Information Technology Development Fund; requiring 20% of the amount appropriated to the Fund to be set aside for expedited projects each fiscal year; requiring the Board of Public Works to expedite the placement on an agenda and approval of certain contracts; altering the name, duties, and membership of the Modernize Maryland Oversight Commission; and providing for the terms of certain Commission members.
bill_summary: This bill updates the State's approach to modernizing information technology (IT) systems. It renames the Major Information Technology Development Fund to the Information Technology Investment Fund and requires at least 20% of its annual appropriation to be set aside for "expedited projects." The bill also streamlines the approval process for certain IT modernization contracts by the Board of Public Works. It redefines "major information technology development projects" to increase the cost threshold to $5,000,000 and establishes a process for funding expedited projects. The duties and membership of the Modernize Maryland Oversight Commission are altered, renaming it the Modernize Maryland Commission and tasking it with identifying best practices and providing recommendations for IT modernization and legacy system replacement. The Department of Information Technology is mandated to develop a State Modernization Plan by December 1, 2025, and to hire new staff to administer expedited projects and seek grant funding. The overall intent is to prioritize IT projects that address public health, education, safety, or financial well-being.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Information Technology (DoIT), Secretary of Information Technology, Board of Public Works, Modernize Maryland Commission
stakeholders: Maryland state government agencies and units, Maryland residents (through improved public services and cybersecurity), IT vendors, state employees involved in IT operations.
innovative_summary: The program emphasizes modernizing existing government IT infrastructure by identifying and replacing "legacy systems" and adopting a structured "information technology investment maturity model" for decision-making. It introduces a process for "expedited projects" to allow for nimble and rapid modernization, streamlining procurement and approval processes. This represents an updated and more strategic approach to internal government IT management rather than a groundbreaking new public service or technology.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on improving the efficiency, security, and modernization of state government information technology systems and procurement processes. While more efficient government services could indirectly benefit families and potentially those experiencing poverty, the bill does not establish any direct programs, services, or interventions specifically aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Behavioral Health - Language Assistance Services Pilot Program
Synopsis: Establishing the Language Assistance Services Pilot Program in the Behavioral Health Administration to provide grants to local behavioral health authorities to reimburse behavioral health providers for language assistance services for children with limited English proficiency accessing and receiving behavioral health services and for parents and legal guardians coordinating the provision of behavioral health services and making health care decisions regarding the services on behalf of a child; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Language Assistance Services Pilot Program within the Behavioral Health Administration. The program provides competitive grants to local behavioral health authorities, which then reimburse behavioral health providers for interpretation and translation services. These services are for children with limited English proficiency who are accessing behavioral health care, and for their parents or legal guardians who are coordinating these services.
responsible_party: Behavioral Health Administration
stakeholders: Children with limited English proficiency, their parents and legal guardians, local behavioral health authorities, and behavioral health providers.
innovative_summary: The program addresses a critical need for equitable access to behavioral health services for individuals with limited English proficiency by providing reimbursement for language assistance. However, the mechanism of grants for reimbursement through existing authorities is a standard government approach and does not introduce new technologies or highly novel governmental processes.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program improves access to essential behavioral health care for children with limited English proficiency. While better health outcomes can indirectly contribute to family stability and well-being, potentially easing financial burdens associated with unaddressed health issues, the program does not directly provide financial assistance or resources targeted at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Government - Executive Appointments
Synopsis: Authorizing the Governor to appoint individuals to the State Board of Elections and the Accountability and Implementation Board during the recess of the Senate under certain circumstances; requiring the Governor to submit a certain nomination to the Senate if the term of office will end during the next upcoming recess of the Senate; authorizing the Governor to submit a certain nomination to the Senate more than 40 days after the commencement of the regular legislative session and before Sine Die only if the Senate consents; etc.
bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland law regarding executive appointments, outlining conditions for recess appointments to specific boards (State Board of Elections and Accountability and Implementation Board), setting timelines for the Governor to submit nominations to the Senate, and establishing rules for the continuation of service for officers after their terms expire, including a maximum of 4 years. It also details the consequences for individuals whose nominations are withdrawn or not confirmed.
responsible_party: Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Individuals appointed or nominated to executive offices and public bodies in Maryland, including members of the State Board of Elections and the Accountability and Implementation Board.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily introduces procedural and administrative changes to existing executive appointment processes, defining clearer timelines and conditions for nominations and service. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to governance.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's provisions focus entirely on the administrative processes of executive appointments and have no direct connection or mechanism to impact child poverty.

Title: Baltimore County - Alcoholic Beverages - Individual Storage Permits
Synopsis: Requiring an alcoholic beverages retailer in Baltimore County to have written approval from the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County before applying to the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission for an individual storage permit for alcoholic beverages.
bill_summary: This bill amends the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article to require alcoholic beverages retailers in Baltimore County to obtain written approval from the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County before applying for an individual storage permit from the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission. This requirement already existed for Anne Arundel County and is now extended to Baltimore County.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County; Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverages retailers in Baltimore County
innovative_summary: This bill makes a regulatory change by extending an existing approval requirement for alcoholic beverage storage permits to Baltimore County, mirroring a process already in place in Anne Arundel County. It does not introduce new technologies or novel governmental approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill regulates the process for alcoholic beverage retailers to obtain storage permits. It has no direct connection to programs or policies aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: State Procurement - Procurement Forecast and Outreach
Synopsis: Requiring the Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to consult with each primary procurement unit to identify potential contracting opportunities for and increase outreach efforts to small businesses; requiring each unit, on or before June 30 each year, to submit to the Office a procurement forecast for all procurement contracts over $100,000; requiring each unit, on or before August 15 each year, to submit its reconciliation of the prior fiscal year's procurement forecast in accordance with certain requirements; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires each State procurement unit to submit annual procurement forecasts for contracts over $100,000 to the Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs. The Office will then consult with these units to identify potential contracting opportunities and increase outreach to small businesses. It also mandates the Office to develop a program to identify and raise awareness of procurement opportunities for small businesses and assist them with bidding procedures. The Office will publish the compiled procurement information on its website and track the status of forecasted procurements. A new compliance officer position will be created within the Office to implement these requirements.
responsible_party: Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs
stakeholders: Small businesses (including minority and women-owned businesses), and State government procurement units.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency and accessibility for small businesses by centralizing and publishing State procurement forecasts online. It improves existing government processes by creating a more proactive outreach and assistance program for small businesses, rather than introducing fundamentally new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's primary goal is to increase small business participation in State procurement. While this could indirectly lead to job creation and economic growth, potentially benefiting families, it does not directly address child poverty through aid, services, or financial support to children or families living in poverty.

Title: Frederick County - Juveniles - Truancy Reduction Pilot Program
Synopsis: Authorizing the Circuit Administrative Judge of the Sixth Circuit to establish a Truancy Reduction Pilot Program in the juvenile court in Frederick County.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Circuit Administrative Judge of the Sixth Circuit to establish a Truancy Reduction Pilot Program in the juvenile court in Frederick County. It expands existing provisions for similar pilot programs to include Frederick County and clarifies that these programs operate to the extent that funds are provided in the annual State budget or through gifts or grants.
responsible_party: Circuit Administrative Judge of the Sixth Circuit (Frederick County Juvenile Court) and Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Maryland
stakeholders: Juveniles and their families in Frederick County who are experiencing truancy issues.
innovative_summary: The bill establishes a new pilot program for truancy reduction in Frederick County, but it is an expansion of an existing program model in other counties. It does not introduce new technologies or novel government approaches, focusing instead on judicial intervention for truancy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This program aims to reduce truancy among juveniles. While not directly addressing child poverty, keeping children in school and engaged in education can have a positive indirect impact on their future educational attainment and economic stability, which can help mitigate long-term poverty risks. The direct impact on immediate child poverty is limited, as the program focuses on school attendance.

Title: Alcoholic Beverages - Breweries, Wineries, and Distilleries - Direct Delivery
Synopsis: Establishing direct-to-consumer alcoholic beverages delivery permits authorizing the direct delivery of beer, wine, or liquor to a consumer in the State; establishing the requirements an individual must meet to qualify for a direct-to-consumer alcoholic beverages delivery permit; establishing a maximum amount that a recipient of an alcoholic beverages delivery may receive annually; and repealing a maximum amount that a consumer may purchase when visiting certain alcoholic beverage manufacturers.
bill_summary: This bill establishes new permits for the direct delivery and shipping of alcoholic beverages (wine, beer, and liquor) from licensed manufacturers to consumers in Maryland. It outlines the qualifications, application process, and responsibilities for these direct delivery and shipping permits, including age verification requirements for recipients, annual quantity limits per address, and reporting obligations. The bill also amends existing provisions related to the maximum amounts consumers can purchase when visiting alcoholic beverage manufacturers and tasks the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission with evaluating a standard digital age verification system for direct deliveries.
responsible_party: Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission
stakeholders: Licensed Maryland breweries, wineries, and distilleries; consumers in Maryland; common carriers involved in alcohol delivery; and the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission and the Comptroller of Maryland as regulatory bodies.
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the evaluation of a standard digital age verification system for alcoholic beverage direct deliveries. This initiative aims to leverage technology to enhance compliance with age restrictions, which represents a moderately innovative approach to government regulation in the alcohol industry.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill primarily regulates the direct sale and delivery of alcoholic beverages from manufacturers to consumers. It does not contain any provisions related to income support, education, healthcare, or other services that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: Cigarettes, Other Tobacco Products, and Electronic Smoking Devices - Revisions (Tobacco Retail Modernization Act of 2024)
Synopsis: Prohibiting licensees that sell cigarettes, other tobacco products, or electronic smoking devices at retail from displaying cigarettes, other tobacco products, or electronic smoking devices for sale unless located behind a counter; requiring certain licensed retailers to verify an individual's date of birth before selling cigarettes, other tobacco products, or electronic smoking devices in a certain manner; altering the application fee for a county license to sell cigarettes or tobacco products at retail; etc.
bill_summary: The "Tobacco Retail Modernization Act of 2024" significantly revises laws governing the sale of cigarettes, other tobacco products, and electronic smoking devices in Maryland. Key changes include: prohibiting the display of these products for sale unless located behind a counter; requiring all retailers to verify a buyer's age (at least 21 years old) using a government-issued photo ID in a face-to-face exchange for all sales, eliminating the previous exemption for active duty military members aged 18-20; increasing application fees for county retail licenses and allocating a portion of these fees to the Maryland Department of Health for enhanced enforcement; mandating the Maryland Department of Health to conduct at least one unannounced inspection of licensed retailers annually, with an additional inspection required after a violation; removing the general "electronic smoking devices retailer" license type and redefining "vape shop vendor" to exclusively sell electronic smoking devices, which effectively means general tobacco retailers can no longer sell electronic smoking devices unless they become an exclusive vape shop; increasing penalties for distributing tobacco or electronic smoking devices to underage individuals, including potential license suspension or revocation; and requiring a comprehensive report by October 1, 2025, on retailer licensing, geographic density, potential license limits, and the public health and economic impacts of underage tobacco and electronic smoking device use.
responsible_party: Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission; Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Licensed retailers of cigarettes, other tobacco products, and electronic smoking devices (especially those currently selling both tobacco and electronic smoking devices); individuals under 21 years old; active duty military members under 21 years old; and the general public, particularly youth.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily strengthens existing regulations and enforcement mechanisms related to tobacco and electronic smoking device sales. It does not introduce novel technologies or particularly innovative governance approaches, focusing instead on tightening existing controls and penalties.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to reduce youth access to tobacco and electronic smoking devices, which may lead to long-term public health benefits. However, it does not include provisions that directly address financial assistance, educational programs, healthcare access, or other social determinants that would directly impact child poverty.

Title: Department of Information Technology - Evaluation and Development of a 3-1-1 Portal Using Artificial Intelligence
Synopsis: Stating the intent of the General Assembly that the Department of Information Technology evaluate the feasibility of creating a 3-1-1 portal utilizing artificial intelligence and that the Department prioritize the creation of the portal if feasible.
bill_summary: This bill states the General Assembly's intent that the Department of Information Technology (DoIT) evaluate the feasibility of creating a statewide virtual 3-1-1 portal using artificial intelligence. If the Department finds it feasible, it is instructed to prioritize the creation of this portal to provide Maryland residents with nonemergency government information and services.
responsible_party: Department of Information Technology
stakeholders: Maryland residents who seek nonemergency government information and services
innovative_summary: The bill is innovative in its directive for the Department of Information Technology to evaluate and potentially prioritize the use of artificial intelligence in creating a virtual 3-1-1 portal, aiming to modernize access to nonemergency government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill's direct impact on child poverty is low as it focuses solely on the evaluation and prioritization of a technology portal. While an operational 3-1-1 system could indirectly connect individuals to services that alleviate poverty, this bill does not establish or fund such services, nor does it guarantee the portal's creation or functionality.

Title: Public Schools - School Security Employees - Appropriations
Synopsis: Authorizing local school systems to use certain funds for school security employees.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes local school systems to use existing school safety funds for school security employees. It revises annual appropriations for these grants, increasing them to $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2026 and $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2027 and each fiscal year thereafter. The allocation of these grants will now be based on student enrollment rather than the number of schools. Additionally, the Maryland Center for School Safety, the State Department of Education, and the Interagency Commission on School Construction, with input from the Maryland Coordination and Analysis Center’s MVIEW program, are jointly required to review the state of physical security in schools and existing safety guidelines every two years, starting July 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Center for School Safety
stakeholders: Local school systems, public schools, students, school security employees, and local law enforcement agencies.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily refines existing school safety funding mechanisms and formalizes a joint review process for physical security guidelines. It does not introduce novel technologies or approaches to government, but rather adjusts how established programs operate.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on enhancing school security through funding and employee deployment. While a safer school environment benefits all students, including those from low-income backgrounds, it does not directly address financial, social, or health-related aspects of child poverty. The impact on child poverty is indirect, by creating a more conducive learning environment.

Title: Emergency Services - Funding
Synopsis: Increasing the motor vehicle registration emergency medical system surcharge to $40.00 per year for certain motor vehicles; altering certain provisions of law related to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund, including provisions related to the contents and sources of the funding and the determination of eligibility for disbursements; requiring the Governor, beginning in fiscal year 2026, to include an annual appropriation of at least $16,500,000 to the Senator William H. Amoss Fire, Rescue, and Ambulance Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill significantly increases funding for emergency services in Maryland. It raises the motor vehicle registration emergency medical system surcharge from $17 to $40 per year, with specific allocations to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund ($6.50), the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center (at least $9.00), and the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund. The bill also increases fines for various driving while impaired offenses, with at least 20% of these fines directed to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund. Key changes to the Maryland Trauma Physician Services Fund include expanding eligibility for reimbursement to "trauma health care practitioners," increasing reimbursement rates for on-call services to 60%, and allowing the Commission to adjust these rates and hours. It also establishes an annual grant of up to $1,800,000 for Level I pediatric trauma centers. Furthermore, the bill mandates the Governor to include an annual appropriation of at least $16,500,000 to the Senator William H. Amoss Fire, Rescue, and Ambulance Fund beginning in fiscal year 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission, Health Services Cost Review Commission, Comptroller of Maryland, and the Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Motor vehicle owners (due to increased surcharges), individuals convicted of driving while impaired (due to increased fines), trauma physicians, trauma health care practitioners, trauma centers (including Level I, II, III, and pediatric centers), rehabilitation hospitals, and various emergency services entities (e.g., Department of State Police Aviation Division, Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems, R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, Maryland Fire and Rescue Institute, Senator William H. Amoss Fire, Rescue, and Ambulance Fund, and Volunteer Company Assistance Fund). The general public benefits from improved emergency medical services.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily modifies existing funding mechanisms, increases fees and fines, and reallocates resources within established emergency medical services and trauma care systems. It defines new eligibility for reimbursement and adjusts rates, but does not introduce new technologies or significantly innovative approaches to government services or healthcare delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on funding emergency medical services and trauma care, which can indirectly benefit all families, including those experiencing poverty, by ensuring access to critical healthcare. However, it does not directly address the root causes of child poverty or provide direct financial or programmatic support aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to study and make recommendations regarding the costs and availability of both publicly and privately provided pretrial home detention monitoring systems; and requiring the Workgroup to submit a report of its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly on or before December 31 each year.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring. The Workgroup is tasked with studying and making recommendations regarding the costs and availability of both publicly and privately provided pretrial home detention monitoring systems. It comprises representatives from the legislature, executive agencies, the judiciary, advocacy groups, law enforcement, detention centers, and private monitoring agencies. The Workgroup is required to submit annual reports of its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly. The Workgroup is effective from July 1, 2024, until its abrogation on June 30, 2027.
responsible_party: Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring, with staff support from the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services. Reports are submitted to the General Assembly.
stakeholders: The Workgroup members include legislators, the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Public Defender, the President of the Maryland State's Attorneys' Association, the Judiciary, the Executive Director of the Maryland Network Against Domestic Violence, a representative of the Job Opportunities Task Force, representatives of police and sheriffs' associations, local detention centers, county pretrial release programs, and private home detention monitoring agencies. The study's findings may indirectly impact individuals subject to home detention and the broader criminal justice system.
innovative_summary: This bill establishes a workgroup to study existing home detention monitoring systems. This is a conventional governmental approach to policy review and does not introduce new technologies or innovative methods of public service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on establishing a workgroup to study home detention monitoring systems within the criminal justice context. While criminal justice involvement can have indirect impacts on families and child poverty, this bill does not directly establish programs or allocate resources aimed at alleviating child poverty through financial assistance, educational support, or other direct interventions.

Title: Correctional Services - Diminution Credits - Sexual Offenses
Synopsis: Prohibiting the earning of diminution credits to reduce the term of confinement of an incarcerated individual who is serving a sentence for rape in the first degree in a State or local correctional facility.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits individuals serving a sentence for rape in the first degree (specifically violations of § 3–303 of the Criminal Law Article) for offenses occurring on or after October 1, 2024, from earning diminution credits (good time credit) to reduce their term of confinement in State or local correctional facilities.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services; local correctional facilities
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals serving sentences for first-degree rape (specifically violations of § 3–303 of the Criminal Law Article).
innovative_summary: This bill is a legislative amendment to existing criminal sentencing and correctional policies, specifically regarding diminution credits. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or novel approaches to government operations.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill amends laws concerning diminution credits for certain incarcerated individuals. It does not establish programs, services, or financial support directly aimed at reducing child poverty.

Title: Emergency Services - Automated External Defibrillator and Naloxone Co-Location Initiative - Requirements for Public Buildings
Synopsis: Requiring the State Emergency Medical Services Board, in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health, to develop and implement an initiative under the Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program to require that naloxone be co-located with each automated external defibrillator placed in a public building; establishing a certain immunity from liability for individuals who administer naloxone made available under the initiative in response to a known or suspected drug overdose; etc.
bill_summary: This bill requires the State Emergency Medical Services Board, in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Health, to develop and implement an initiative to co-locate naloxone, a medication for reversing opioid overdoses, with automated external defibrillators (AEDs) in public buildings. The initiative specifies that up to two doses of naloxone should be visible and in close proximity to each AED, with clear labeling. The bill also establishes civil immunity for owners and operators of public buildings who provide and maintain naloxone under the initiative, and for individuals who administer it in response to a suspected overdose. Funding for the initiative will come from the Opioid Restitution Fund. The goal is to achieve co-location in all eligible public buildings by October 1, 2027.
responsible_party: State Emergency Medical Services Board and Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Owners and operators of public buildings (public mass transportation accommodations, public parks/recreation centers, and facilities for secondary/higher education), individuals who may administer naloxone, and members of the public who may experience or witness an opioid overdose in these public buildings.
innovative_summary: This program innovates by leveraging existing public health infrastructure (AED locations) to strategically distribute naloxone, a critical overdose reversal medication, in high-traffic public spaces. This approach provides a systematic and readily accessible method for immediate intervention during opioid overdoses, representing a novel application of co-location for public health response.
child_poverty_direct_summary: While not directly an anti-poverty program, this initiative can indirectly impact child poverty by potentially saving the lives of parents or guardians who experience an opioid overdose. Preventing a fatality from overdose can prevent the severe financial and emotional destabilization of a family, thereby mitigating a significant factor that can lead to or deepen child poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Maryland Police Officers and Probation Agents Scholarship Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering the definition of an eligible institution for the Maryland Police Officers and Probation Agents Scholarship Program to include a community college in the State.
bill_summary: This bill alters the definition of an eligible institution for the existing Maryland Police Officers and Probation Agents Scholarship Program to include community colleges in the State. This expands the educational institutions where prospective and current police officers and probation agents can use this scholarship.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Students intending to become police officers or probation agents, current police officers and probation agents, and community colleges in Maryland.
innovative_summary: This bill is an administrative change that expands eligibility for an existing scholarship program by including community colleges. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill expands access to higher education for individuals pursuing careers as police officers or probation agents. While increased access to education can indirectly support families, it is not a direct program designed to alleviate child poverty through financial assistance, services, or specific interventions for low-income children or families.

Title: Hospitals and Related Institutions – Outpatient Facility Fees
Synopsis: Altering the required contents of the written notice regarding outpatient facility fees; requiring the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission, in consultation with certain entities, to study and make recommendations regarding hospital outpatient facility fees; requiring the Commission to convene a workgroup on outpatient facility fees notices; and requiring the Commission to submit, on or before December 1, 2024, a report to certain committees of the General Assembly on certain recommendations.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the required content and delivery methods for written notices about hospital outpatient facility fees, including applying these requirements to out-of-state hospitals that provide outpatient services in Maryland. It also mandates the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission to conduct a comprehensive study on hospital outpatient facility fees and convene a workgroup to advise on expanding notice requirements to cover all outpatient services.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission
stakeholders: Patients receiving outpatient services, hospitals (including out-of-state hospitals with in-state facilities), physician practices, health care payers, consumer advocacy groups, and employer groups in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill enhances transparency for hospital outpatient facility fees through updated notice requirements, including electronic delivery options. It also establishes a framework for studies and workgroups to analyze the impact of these fees and explore potential reforms. While it incorporates electronic communication, the overall approach is regulatory and analytical, rather than introducing entirely new government technologies or services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill aims to increase transparency regarding hospital outpatient facility fees, which could indirectly benefit low-income families by enabling more informed healthcare decisions and access to financial assistance information. The mandated studies will also specifically consider the impact on Medicaid recipients and consumer out-of-pocket costs, potentially informing future policies that could more directly address financial burdens on families, but the bill itself does not directly provide financial aid or poverty-reduction services.

Title: Annual Corrective Bill
Synopsis: Correcting certain errors or omissions in certain articles of the Annotated Code; clarifying language; correcting certain obsolete references; reorganizing certain sections of the Annotated Code; providing that this Act is not intended to affect any law other than to correct technical errors; and providing for the correction of certain errors and obsolete provisions by the publishers of the Annotated Code.
bill_summary: This bill is an annual corrective measure designed to fix technical errors, omissions, obsolete references, and clarify language across various articles of the Annotated Code of Maryland. It reorganizes certain sections and explicitly states that it is not intended to affect any law other than to correct these technical errors. The publishers of the Annotated Code, in consultation with the Department of Legislative Services, are authorized to make the necessary corrections.
responsible_party: Publishers of the Annotated Code of Maryland, in consultation with the Department of Legislative Services, and implicitly, all Maryland State agencies and departments whose code sections are affected.
stakeholders: All individuals and entities subject to Maryland law, including legal professionals, state agencies, and the general public, as the bill corrects errors across numerous articles of the Annotated Code.
innovative_summary: This bill is a routine legislative measure for correcting technical errors in existing statutes. It does not introduce any new technologies, services, or innovative approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses entirely on technical corrections to existing laws and does not establish any new programs, allocate funds, or directly implement policies aimed at addressing child poverty. Any impact on child poverty would be indirect and negligible, arising only from the clarity of the legal text.

Title: Natural Resources - Fish and Fisheries - Reporting Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring certain persons licensed or regulated with respect to fish and fisheries by the Department of Natural Resources to submit reports in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.
bill_summary: This bill requires individuals and businesses licensed or regulated by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources for fish and fisheries (including those dealing in fish resources, licensed nontidal anglers, and Chesapeake Bay/coastal sport anglers) to submit reports in accordance with regulations adopted by the Department.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Individuals and businesses licensed or regulated by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources for fishing and dealing in fish resources, including nontidal anglers and Chesapeake Bay/coastal sport fishers.
innovative_summary: The bill updates the method by which reporting requirements are established, moving from specific forms to regulations adopted by the Department. This is an administrative change and does not introduce new technologies or significantly novel approaches to government.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill focuses solely on reporting requirements for fishing licenses and fish resource businesses and has no direct impact on child poverty.

Title: University System of Maryland – Academic Facilities Bonding Authority
Synopsis: Approving certain projects for the acquisition, development, and improvement of certain academic facilities for the University System of Maryland; authorizing the issuance of bonds by the University System of Maryland for financing the projects; and providing that the bonds are not a debt or obligation of the State or any of its subdivisions.
bill_summary: This bill approves specific academic facility projects for the University System of Maryland, including campuswide building systems and infrastructure improvements at the University of Maryland, College Park, and systemwide capital renewal projects for existing academic facilities. It authorizes the University System of Maryland to issue bonds totaling $30,000,000 to finance these projects, clarifying that these bonds are obligations of the USM and not the State of Maryland.
responsible_party: University System of Maryland
stakeholders: Students, faculty, and staff of the University System of Maryland institutions will be impacted by improved academic facilities and infrastructure.
innovative_summary: This bill authorizes funding for standard capital improvements and facility renewals within the University System of Maryland. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government services or educational delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill focuses on funding academic facility improvements at universities. While a better educational environment can indirectly contribute to long-term economic well-being, this bill does not include any direct provisions or programs aimed at alleviating child poverty.

Title: Tax Assistance for Low-Income Marylanders - Funding
Synopsis: Requiring the Comptroller, for fiscal year 2025 and each fiscal year thereafter, to distribute $500,000 from the remaining net abandoned property funds after certain distributions to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund; requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget, for fiscal year 2026 and each year thereafter, an appropriation of $800,000 for the CASH Campaign of Maryland to award grants for providing certain tax assistance through certain on-demand and mobile tax clinics; etc.
bill_summary: This bill increases funding for tax assistance for low-income Marylanders. It requires the Comptroller, starting in fiscal year 2025, to distribute $500,000 annually from abandoned property funds to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund. Additionally, beginning in fiscal year 2026, it mandates the Governor to include an $800,000 annual appropriation in the State budget for the CASH Campaign of Maryland. Of this appropriation, $150,000 is specifically designated for grants to external entities providing income tax assistance through on-demand or mobile tax clinics that serve senior populations, rural communities, or under-resourced communities, including new American populations. The bill also requires established tax clinics to interact annually with the CASH Campaign to ensure sufficient access to tax preparation services.
responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland, Governor of Maryland, CASH Campaign of Maryland
stakeholders: Low-income Marylanders, including senior populations, residents of rural and under-resourced communities, new American populations, and organizations providing tax assistance such as the University of Maryland School of Law, the University of Baltimore School of Law, and the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service.
innovative_summary: The program promotes and funds the use of on-demand and mobile tax clinics, which is an innovative approach to extending the reach and accessibility of tax assistance services. This method aims to serve underserved and hard-to-reach populations more effectively than traditional fixed-location services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential for direct impact on child poverty by providing free tax preparation services. This assistance helps low-income families correctly file tax returns, avoid predatory fees, and successfully claim federal and state earned income tax credits (EITC). EITC and other tax credits directly boost the disposable income of qualifying families, many of whom have children, thereby directly alleviating financial hardship and child poverty.

Title: Higher Education - Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship - Repeal of Service Terminal Date
Synopsis: Repealing the service terminal date required to be eligible for the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship.
bill_summary: This bill repeals the service terminal date requirement for eligibility for the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship. This change means that veterans, active duty members, reserve components, or Maryland National Guard members who served in these conflicts, and their eligible family members, will no longer be excluded from the scholarship based on when their service ended.
responsible_party: The Office
stakeholders: Veterans, active duty military personnel, members of reserve components of the armed forces, Maryland National Guard members who served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflicts, and their sons, daughters, stepsons, stepdaughters, or spouses who are Maryland residents pursuing higher education.
innovative_summary: This bill is an amendment to an existing scholarship program, primarily focused on modifying eligibility criteria by removing a service terminal date. It does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches to government service or program delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program provides scholarships for higher education to veterans and their families. While increased access to higher education can improve economic opportunities and indirectly alleviate poverty over time, the bill does not directly address or provide services for child poverty alleviation.

Title: Prince George's County - Alcoholic Beverages - College Athletic Event Venue Concessionaire Beer, Wine, and Liquor License
Synopsis: Establishing a Class B-CAEVC (College Athletic Event Venue Concessionaire) beer, wine, and liquor license in Prince George's County; authorizing the Board of License Commissioners of Prince George's County to issue the license to a certain concessionaire; authorizing beer, wine, and liquor purchased under the license to be consumed in certain areas; and providing for the hours and days of sale and an annual license fee of $3,500 to be paid to the Board on or before May 1.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a new Class B–CAEVC (College Athletic Event Venue Concessionaire) beer, wine, and liquor license in Prince George’s County, Maryland. This license authorizes concessionaires operating at college athletic event venues on the University of Maryland, College Park, or Bowie State University campuses to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption in designated areas. It sets the hours of sale, consumption areas, and an annual license fee of $3,500.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County
stakeholders: Concessionaires operating at college athletic event venues at the University of Maryland, College Park, and Bowie State University campuses, as well as attendees of these college athletic events in Prince George's County.
innovative_summary: This bill primarily introduces a new category of alcoholic beverage license for a specific type of venue and operator. It is a regulatory adjustment rather than an innovative program employing new technologies or novel approaches to government services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This bill is focused on regulating alcoholic beverage sales at college athletic venues and does not have a direct mechanism to address or impact child poverty. There is no direct link to poverty reduction, aid, or support for children.

Title: Affirming the Federal Equal Rights Amendment
Synopsis: Urging the Administration of President Joseph R. Biden to publish, without delay, the federal Equal Rights Amendment as the 28th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and for the U.S. Congress to pass a joint resolution affirming the Equal Rights Amendment as the 28th Amendment.
bill_summary: The Maryland General Assembly passed a joint resolution urging President Joseph R. Biden's Administration to publish the federal Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) as the Twenty-eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution without delay. It also urges the U.S. Congress to pass a joint resolution affirming the ERA as the Twenty-eighth Amendment. The resolution details legal arguments asserting that the ERA has met constitutional requirements for ratification, arguing that the original time limit for ratification was not legally binding as it was not part of the amendment's text ratified by the states.
responsible_party: Maryland General Assembly, Department of Legislative Services
stakeholders: All Marylanders and the public generally, especially those affected by sex-based discrimination; federal officials (President, Vice President, Archivist of the United States, Congress); and other state legislatures.
innovative_summary: This joint resolution employs a standard legislative method for a state to express its opinion and urge federal action. It does not introduce new technologies or novel approaches to government functions or services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: This resolution advocates for the federal Equal Rights Amendment, which aims to ensure equality of rights regardless of sex. While gender equality can indirectly contribute to economic equity and improved household financial stability, which may, in turn, impact child poverty, the resolution itself does not establish any direct programs or allocate funds specifically to address child poverty.
